description:
Open late night. The food is good and serviceable especially for late night. I'm a big fan of the bulgogi beef and pork. The fried rice is decent too.

Wish they had more small soup options.
author: Joshua F.

description:
I still can't believe how many times I've been here this month. Majority of circle of friends rave about this place. Yes, it's good, yes I'd come back again but it's not my go-to spot. 

The staff here, I feel like is a hit or miss. I had pretty good experience here in the past, until recently for a friends birthday dinner. There's these 2 waitresses, waitress one was being overly rude! she literally wouldn't let us take another table behind us for the rest of our party, their was 12 of us. Mind you, my friend made a reservation a day or two prior letting them know how many people are coming. We were literally ready to leave after the second time we asked if we really couldn't take that table and there weren't even customers behind us! I'm pretty sure everyone who's been here, we all know how small the inside of this resto is. You can't make 12 heads fit in a table that sits 7. After that, waitress two comes to take our orders and for some reason she too wanted to give us an attitude and kept rushing us. Seems like some of their staffs, don't like accommodating a big group like us into their business.

I don't get why their kimchi fried rice is so greasy, i like it and i usually get this with their kimchi pancake and soup (which makes it less heavy). I also enjoy their buckwheat noodle, soo good where i'd rather have it to myself. but i guess sharing is caring! Their flavored soju is exceptional, depending which one you get though. (I'm just not a fan of overly sweet alcoholic beverages, ok) I do recommend getting the mango or peach soju if you're into the lighter and not heavy (like the yogurt one) dranks. The lemon and aloe soju is good too but i wouldn't order it again. Now, what I like best is somaek (soju w/ beer) and pairs best with their chicken and kimchi rice!
author: Deneb T.

description:
Oh my gosh!!! I took my family here because my grandma loves Korean food.. and my grandma said she experienced the worst service she has ever seen in all 76 years of her entire life! 

I don't want to drop any names but Jun, the server ruined our families dining experience with her attitude and lack of professionalism. 


Great food but unfortunately, out of respect for my grandmother, who would probably whoop ass if she knew I came here again, I won't be coming here again.
author: Kevin P.

description:
This is probably one of my top late night eats spots. I am a fan of their fried chicken and kimchi fried rice. You can substitute the beef in their fried rice for spam instead if you want, which is a nice option. 

Pros: 
+open late 
+affordable food 
+decent-sized portions for the price 
+good fried chicken 

Cons: 
- service isn't always the quickest 
- staff isn't always the friendliest (at least when I'm there at 9:30 PM) 
- no banchan (Korean appetizers) 

Overall I would come back here for some late night eats.
author: Lynn T.

description:
If you want basic Korean food that opens late this is the place. I been like maybe twice? Food is mediocre, nothing special to brag about. 

Chicken wings is bland, I got the spicy chicken wings but it actually comes dry, no sauce on it.

The spicy calamari is meh, not that great but portion is big. 

They accept cards, and have a call button on the tables which is nice.
author: Debbie D.

description: Yo this place is fire and it's a shame I found out about it after I moved out of the area. I watched a little too much of Hot Ones and was craving wings. It says they're spicy chicken wings, but they weren't spicy at all. They were crispy and good af tho! The beef kimchi fried rice was spicier, but also barely felt a sting on my tongue. The fried rice was still really yummy though. The pork cutlet was so crispy and delicious. The salad dressing is the spiciest thing I had there lol. The staff were all very friendly. I think everything was like $42.16 with tip.
author: Caitlyn S.

description: After the museum of natural history on Thursday we hit this place.  It was sooooo good!!!  I'm welcome.  Service was fast and helpful!
author: Alphonse M N.

description:
Went here tonight with a group of 8. We made a reservation ahead of time, which was a good move because there were a good amount of people waiting when we arrived at 8! The restaurant is small, but the decor is made to look like it's inside a garage, which we all thought was really cool. 

The service wasn't anything spectacular, but the food came very quickly when ordered, and they were good at accommodating dietary requests like excluding pork from dishes.

We ordered the kimchi pancake, chicken wings, beef bulgogi, japchae, kimchi fried rice, and a kimchi tofu curry. All of it was amazing, such that I can't even say what was my favorite! We all left the meal completely satisfied and would definitely return again
author: Sonia S.

description:
You can't go wrong with Korean junk food!!! The stew with ramen, chicken wings, seafood pancake, and kimchee fried rice is the sooooo good that it makes me salivate just thinking about it.

Just a warning: this is considered 'fun food' so it's not for eating all the time. This type of food is for when you want to have some flavored fruity soju and be unhealthy after a week of eating salads. It's a good cheat meal.
author: Andrea T.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in the neighborhood for late night eats. They are open til 2am!! Firstly be aware that this place looks like a house and even though it is happening inside the doors look like they may be closed. Make sure you pull on the doors before walking away because I have def done that thinking they were closed when in fact they were open.

We were here on Sat at 5pm when they opened and were seated right away. I have been here other time in the week and weekend and they get very busy so plan accordingly. My only other pet peeve is that on many evening occasions there is always a group of people smoking outside and it takes away from the experience of going in to enjoy my food. 

We always get the spicy pork dish which is one of my favorites here. It has a ton of flavor and mild spice. You have to order the rice separately. 

This time we also tried the chicken wings which were nicely seasoned, crunchy on the outside and tender meat on the inside. Yum!
author: Shristi R.

description: This is the best Korean house. Exceptional sides and amazing mains. Service was so professional. I love the taste of the calamari with bulgogi. The time and money you spend here are worth it. Definitely be back soon.
author: Natasha R.

description:
Would give this place negative stars if possible. 

Someone in our party accidentally wrote the name in the wrong place, lady b*tched us out and talked down to us. 

We apologized and asked to stay and she insisted no and kept talking down to us. 

I've never seen this kind of customer service

Edit: the employee was Joon. For some more clarity - she accused us of trying to cut the line and when we tried to explain it was a mistake and we were more than willing to wait the full time she continued to accuse us and continuing escalating the situation. Someone had also crossed out a name (presumably because they had been called already or left) and she assumed it was us - came outside to announce to all the customers that SOMEONE had been going around crossing off other people's names to cut. 

I never write negative reviews
author: Jeremy L.

description: Love love their kimchi fried rice, kimchi pancake and all their soju flavors.  Best tasting and crispy kimchi pancake I've ever had.  Their kimchi fried rice is flavorful and the egg is great mixed up with everything.  I loved trying the different flavors of soju but the ridiculously long wait makes it less appealing.  Still my favorite Korean place in SF.
author: Amy T.

description:
Toyose! This place transports me back to the days of going to school and hanging out in LA's Koreatown! I've missed the LA Korean drinking spots with the endless soju and lots of good spicy food. We made reservations for 5 on a Friday at 9 pm. This place although far out in the sunset area is very popular so definitely make a reservation or you'll be waiting for quite a while.

The 5 of us squeezed into a booth and right away pressed the buzzer to order our feast. We ordered:
+ Soju: can't go wrong with original but if you prefer flavored soju, the lychee one is great. The watermelon soju tastes good but was a bit too 'pulpy'.. so you'll be chewing your drink.
+ Kimchee pancake: good but wished it came on a sizzling skillet that made it more crispy rather than doughy
+ Shrimp fried rice: pretty good but I kinda forgot about the fried rice since it's a Korean restaurant after all
+ Spam soup (aka military or hangover soup): I love Korean soups! I've had better but it was pretty good. 
+ Fried whole chicken: super crispy chicken.. it was probably double fried. However the large pieces of white meat were way overcooked since it was really dry.

Don't expect the staff to be smiley & friendly.. it is an asian restaurant after all so you're there for the food. The place is pretty rowdy so it's great to come with a group of friends and have fun. The booth has this bamboo thing you can roll down for a bit more privacy but it doesn't do much. Toyose is great for hanging out and having good food & drinks. I'm sure we'll be back for some more fun times soon!
author: Ruby C.

description:
Whaaat, dinner? In someone's garage?? This Korean restaurant serves a lot more traditional dishes compared to other Korean places in the area. Definitely a family style type of restaurant, the portions are pretty big. 
Seafood pancake is always a good choice. Kimchi fried rice, chicken wings, and beef stew is also good. I really like the food here, and it's super good for late night cravingsss.
The wait here can be soooo long because the place is super small. (lowkey got claustrophobic lol). But if you come late enough on a weekday night it's a lot better.
author: Patricia T.

description: Great dinner / late night spot! Exceptional Korean food. Full of flavor and tame spice. They do not take reservations and do not have a host. There is a whiteboard when you walk in, to the right of the hallway. We went on a Saturday night with a rather large group (8) and was seated about an hour after arriving. They do not take phone numbers, so guests must stay nearby to be seated. There's a bar across the street as well as a casual Mexican spot to pass time. When you walk in Toyose  the smell is undeniably intoxicating, and you will be willing to wait. The waitress was rather short but answered all our questions. I will say that the "spicy" chicken wings were not spicy at all. Perhaps they forgot to add the chili because they were so busy that night. Overall amazing and unforgettable experience.
author: Navila H.

description:
TL;DR hole in the wall (literally)

Toyose has a solid menu of classic Korean dishes like kimchi fried fried, stews, and fried chicken. I shared the fishcake stew and kimchi fried rice, both were really good. The flavor, texture, everything was exactly what good Korean food should taste like. My favorite part about the restaurant is how homey it feels, it's a nice and cozy, but very small space. If you come during peak hours, I think the wait time is probably 30-60min, so get there early. Toyose literally looks like a garage outside, so don't miss it!
author: Sophia L.

description:
The spam stew and corn cheese at Toyose are tops. But am I crazy or has the service been abysmal lately? Attitude while waiting, not enough utensils/water/napkins/place settings. 

I know I know--don't judge a restaurant by its snooty employees. But the service has been INFILTRATING the thick cloud of spam-induced high during my meals lately.

What to order:
-spam stew (feeds at least 3)
-corn cheese
-spicy fried chicken (it's not actually spicy)
-kimchi-fried rice (wished they'd be more generous with that fried egg on top)

I'm very impressed with the stews in general here. Both in terms of flavor and portion size! Eating in a converted garage is also cool. Parking around here is pretty good too.

Damn, if only the service and wait during normal hours wasn't so bad.
author: Cindy T.

description:
I had a really hard time deciding between 3 and 4 stars on this one. I'm going with 4 just because of the "ah-ha" factor when you realize that this really is not a garage, but in fact a pretty nice Korean Restaurant. (It really looks like a garage from the outside - dive bar at best).

Inside is really quite nice. Mood lighting with Christmas lights, lots of wood, good feel.

We got there at like 6:15 on a Tuesday (they open at 6) and although it wasn't full, it was easy to get a table. when we left an hours later though there was a line waiting. 

My husband and I got four things - which was probably two things too many, but we wanted to try different stuff - so take home it is.  

My favorite of the night was the tempura calamari. Nice big pieces of squid, and well fried - but be warned, it was VERY greasy. 

Second favorite was the Kimchi and beef fried rice. Not too spicy, not too sour. Came with a fried egg on top which is always a winner. 

Third, although not so impressed where the deep fried pot stickers. They tasted like deep fried Pot Stickers. Again, very oily.

Fourth, and really I didn't like it all, was the seafood and kimchi pancake. Honestly it just mostly tasted like oil to me. Yes, very greasy. But my husband really liked it and I recognize that asian pancakes aren't my thing, so there is that.

They also have hot pot, which would looked like a popular thing to get (many types on the menu too). They also had some kind of beverage in vinegar looking containers? We didn't get that, but I think that must be a thing they do particularly well because most tables did...

I'd say the food here is really a 3, but I'll bump it up for it's novelty and ambiance.
author: Sarah C.

description:
The atmosphere here is unique. This place is really a garage that's been converted into a dining area that sits less than 50 people. It's pretty cramped and if you're over 6 feet tall, watch your head. 

We were lucky to get a table for ten at 6:30PM as others were waiting afterwards. Some of the favorites are the chicken wings, Kimchi fried rice with a sunny side up egg on top was perfectly prepared and their big casserole (some of the casserole you can ask them for some ramen) was enough to feed four adults. The casserole can be on the spicier side, so as it boils down, ask the staff to add more soup stock to mellow it out.  They have two salads (family portion) that will make excellent starters to warm up your taste buds. Their Soju was fairly inexpensive for a large bottle. It was more on the light side and I think it went perfect with the meal. The chicken gizzard was a bit over cooked and chewy and the iron platter it came on wasn't sizzling.

Parking here was not as difficult as we thought and you can easily find a space about a block away.
author: Eric T.

description:
No wait on a Monday night at 7pm!! Definitely be aware that lines can get very long on the weekends though. I have waited for at least 1.5 hours on a Friday night before getting seated. 

Love the ambiance of the place, especially for a Korean restaurant. Gives off a very cozy homey feel that you are literally like in a Korean grandmother's garage and waiting on their amazing food. 

We ordered the kimchi fried rice, corn cheese, and spicy chicken wings. The combination of kimchi fried rice and corn cheese is to die for. I love the extra sweetness of the corn to balance out the good funkiness and kick of heat of the kimchi fried rice. The kimchi fried rice also comes with a perfectly sunny side up egg that produced the iconic runny yolk pop. 

The spicy chicken wings had just the right amount of kick to them. It also came with a small side of pickled radish and coleslaw. I am very glad that they included the pickled radish since it definitely cleanses your palette for the next delicious bite of kimchi fried rice with corn cheese. 

Since it was such a small space, you can easily eavesdrop on your neighbor's conversations or what they are going to order. 

One of my top korean places in the city whenever I crave it and back at home.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Flew in from east coast and learned of this late night joint. There was a wait and it's tight quarters in the small lobby and dining room, but well worth it. If you wanted a drink at the bar while you wait you will be waiting a long time because there is no bar (just to make you aware). 

It was refreshing  to reacquaint myself with some of my favorite Korean comfort dishes aside from BBQ and Yaki Mandu. The seafood and Kimchee pajun (savory pancake), japchae (hot noodles), along with perfectly simmered bulgogi beef with calamari and vegetables were all over the top delicious. 

If you've got some time and are hungry late nite..or early nite, go tuck  in to some superb Korean grub washed down by a variety of sojus and a Hite beer. Mmmmm
author: Chris R.

description:
Solid Korean late night food spot! If you time your visit right there's actually not too long of a wait either! :).

I recommend coming in earlier rather than later because I can see this being a very popular drunchie spot.

My two top favorites from here are definitely the korean fried rice and the seafood pancake. A lot of people also opt for the fried chicken, but I personally felt like there wasn't much flavor to them without any seasoning/sauces
author: Andrew T.

description: Decent late dinner spot in the city. Small restaurant with small tables. You'll be seated comfortably if you're a party of 2 or 4. Odd number parties will have you seated at the end of the table in the way of other customers and wait staff. Three things worth trying here are the chicken wings, japchae noodles and grape soju.
author: Mai N.

description:
I've used this account on yelp for over 3 years now. 
Prior to this account, I've been continuously using yelp since 2006. NEVER have I EVER left a 1 star review for yelp in my entire life. I worked in the restaurant industry for almost 10 years as a dish washer, server and sushi chef since I was a young teenager until I graduated from college. I'm very experienced with the service industry, I know how tough it is. That's why I'm extremely forgiving of mistakes and always tip well even if the people I'm eating with disagree convincingly. This is why I'm so disappointed and disgusted with Toyose tonight. This was our entire group's first time eating at this place. We walked in and the girl in our group wrote her name immediately on the board and subsequently the 3 of us went to the bathroom while we were excitedly trying to figure out how Toyose is run. After coming out of the bathroom, "JOON" accused us of DELIBERATELY trying to cut in line. She wouldn't listen to us and aggressively kicked us out. I politely let her know that it was our first time and that we did not deliberately intend on cutting anybody. I even called in before our meal and was notified that the wait was approximately 20 minutes. I then informed "JOON" that we were just confused because it was our first time eating here and would be more than happy to wait in line. Instead of acknowledging or considering anything I have to say, with an extremely hostile facial expression, she repeatedly responded bluntly by saying " I can't handle this". She then continuously rebuked me and laughed at me as if I was lying to her, as if that warrants a considerable difference. Despite her repulsive tone and disrespect, I let her know that i totally understand how extremely busy she is and that we are simply newcomers who just wanted to be new customers. Honestly, I always tip fat because I know how hectic the service industry can be. She seemed furious on such a unnecessary level that it seems incomprehensible to fight over wanting to be served for dinner at a restaurant. Although she initially told us it would be two hours, she didn't like our response and instead of relieving tensions/misunderstandings, to my absolute surprise she unexpectedly escalated the situation with her grotesque animosity by smiling and saying it's gonna be "3 hours". For the first time in my LIFE, I lost my cool and couldn't be so forgiving as I typically am and could not be so tolerant of her disrespect to my integrity as a customer. I'm okay if the line was too long and thus couldn't get seated. That's no big deal, we'll come back next time. I'm not okay with my SERVER aggressively intimidating me and making me feel unwelcome, especially during my first time. Typically restaurants will sometimes give appetizers or drinks to newcomers, but not here at Toyose, definitely not with "JOON". I've had to apologize to customers even when it wasn't my fault while working in the restaurant industry. I had to put a smile on my face and do my job as a server or chef and serve my customers. I would have been more than happy with even "bad" service, hair in my food, wrong order, wrong bill, even getting sick from spoiled food(this actually happened this year and still I tipped and didn't leave a bad review at all), etc. I just won't stand such ridicule to an extent as if it's a reality tv show targeted for teenagers esp in front of the entire restaurant. Public humiliation/shaming for simply wanting to try Toyose. Your poor handling of the situation, or shall I say toxic behavior, caused other tables/customers to rally, cheer and shout despicable things to us based on your false assumptions. One table was belligerently slamming their table as they shouted degrading things to us as we left with our heads down for NO reason, maybe it's because they were drunk. I saw many bottles of soju on their table as we were rebuked and decided not to argue with drunk people. I have more rights than that as a customer of their business. This is a business, it should be professional. I refuse to succumb to such unnecessary conflict. Disgraceful. Absolutely embarrassing. I didn't even get to try their food. This post is NOT about the food. If "JOON" apologize to us then I'll take this post down and replace it with an excellent 5 star review. Until then, you reap what you sow. Don't piss off and scream at your customers, without us (your customers), you are nothing. Show some respect, if you don't like your job then quit or complain to management if you are struggling with external factors such as understaffing. Until then, good bye.
author: Kevin Y.

description: My go to Korean spot in SF!!! I don't know why I have such an unhealthy obsession with this place but something about it makes me always go back lol. My go-tos are the tteokbokki with ramen, kimchi fried rice, cheese corn. My friends always say the tteokbokki is super spicy, but I can handle spice and I think it's the perfect amount. The rice cakes are always cooked perfectly, not too chewy and not too soft. I love getting the cheese corn and putting it on EVERYthing, cheese makes everything taste so much better!! I always love how this place is open late night too because you don't find a lot of places with these type of hours in SF. This place is really a hole in the wall, it's in a garage lmao so it definitely gets packed. I find that the most busiest hours are actually when it gets later in the night around like 10 pm. There are booths in the front for bigger groups and then more tables in the back. This is def a more family style type restaurant and has a very homey ambiance, so I love going to this place with friends!
author: Erica L.

description:
3.5 stars. Finally came back here with a small group of friends to grab some dinner and soju. We got there around 6:30pm and got seated a little past 7pm. Place is kind of small and if you have never been to it before you might miss it. It is literally a garage that opens up to a restaurant. I like the nice, comfy vibe, but sometimes the wait can take a while and there isn't much space inside to do that.
Food wise, they have some really tasty dishes and some not so great ones. Heads up, no bonchon but they do send out bowls of popcorn to keep you satisfied while waiting for your dishes to come out. We usually go for the basic stuff. Love their pancakes! Recommend getting either the kimchee or the seafood. We tried the combo kimchee seafood pancake and enjoyed it less then when they are separated. The bulgolgi with calamari was a miss in my opinion. Not bad, but barely any meat and mostly veggies & squid. They do have some really good corn cheese. I think their corn cheese is actually my favorite out of all the places I've tried. The cheese is a little burnt on the top to give it that little crisp but still has that stringy effect when you grab a chunk of the corn! I also enjoy the casseroles, which come out in a big pan and burner to keep it hot. The spam  and kimchee one is my favorite cause it has some heat to it. Plus you can never really go wrong with spam!!
There soju is also really good! Lots of flavors to choose from and all really delicious. I've been to some places where the soju is to watered down or the flavoring tastes off but Toyose seems to have got it down. They offer a variety of all the flavors like strawberry, kiwi, mango, lychee, peach, pineapple, watermelon, yogurt, & aloe! If you haven't tried aloe before, I recommend it! Taste like muscat, or white grapes. Surprisingly refreshing! Just be careful because their soju will definitely creep up on you!
Definitely would go back, just not regularly. Great kick it spot especially if you are craving some soju. Food is good if you order the right things. Expect to wait for a table, anywhere from 30mins to over an hour depending on what time you go. Recommend only for smaller groups do to the limited seating/space.
author: Christian N.

description:
Toyose is a small, yet really well-known, Korean restaurant that is located in a garage in the Sunset district. I'm not sure if this place is popular because of the quality of the food or because they are open until 2am. Nevertheless, their food is good, definitely spicy, and satisfies late night cravings. 

The seafood pancake ($12.95) is one of my favorite orders. It's crispy, flavorful, and has a good amount of seafood in it. It's definitely a great appetizer to share. 

The beef stew ($28.95) has a good variety of different types of food, all in one pot - beef, noodles, baby octopus, tofu, mushroom, and other veggies. It's sure to satisfy a variety of appetites, but even at mild, it can be a little too spicy. 

The calamari with bulgogi ($13.95) is great for kids and those that do not like spicy foods. It comes out on a hot skillet w/ mushrooms and small vegetables. It was pretty good. 

The kimchi fried rice with egg ($10.95) plus spam ($2) is another tasty, yet spicy, dish. I do wish they added a bit more spam as I didn't find much in the dish (and they charge extra for it). Compared to other restaurants that serve this dish, the spam content was a bit minimal. 

One thing I like about this restaurant is that at each table, they have a little button that will summon the waitress to your table. One thing I don't like about this restaurant is that there are table that are right infront of the entire waiting area so not much privacy as your are dining while hungry people are hoping you will hurry, finish, and leave. 

Toyose provides great late-night eats in the outer sunset and even at midnight or 1am (on weekends), there is a wait for a table. The crowd that dines here is definitely young, hip, and (usually) Asian. It's best to order a variety of food and soju to share with a small group. Just make sure to bring something to entertain you during the wait.
author: Jean S.

description:
Who would've known opening a random garage door somewhere in SF on the west side would open up such a nice, quaint and delicious late-night Korean joint?

You walk inside, and the decor is what's left of what appeared to be an old-school German pub that a Korean restaurant took over. So yeah, lots of wood, red beams left and right, covered by Chum Churum soju posters and hot plates of kim chee fried rice zooming past you.

We ordered the budae jigae, spicy fried chicken wings and corn cheese. 

The budae jigae was delicious, albeit pricey. They've thrown every piece of processed meat you can find at a grocery store. They also threw in some of the pork meat that comes in spicy pork, or daeji bulgogi. The broth was delicious and I have to say this is probably the best budae jigae I've had in a restaurant thus far out.

The spicy chicken wings are something I can get behind. They say they're spicy, but they're not. No way. A small zing at best, nice and crunchy and could eat them all day.

The corn cheese was meh. It's literally corn and mozzarella. Some of the better Korean cheese I've had mix in mayo. You have to have mayo in the corn cheese, otherwise the mozzarella becomes its own separate layer, kind of like how it is on pizza. There is nothing there to bind the cheese and the corn together. The mayo is extremely important. Also, for flavor.

The fact that they're open until 2am provides me with an easy place to keep in mind for a late night munchie if I'm ever in the city. The restaurant is in a really interesting location and going in and out of it, I feel like I'm warping to two different worlds.
author: Tom S.

description:
How have I missed something this delicious on my block all these years? I'll never know but I'm glad I've walked in, sat down and ordered away.


Been coming to Toyose since my friend took me for my birthday a few months ago. We got the gal pals together last night and tried even more dishes like the seafood stew and beef kimshe fried rice.


This is very much a Korran American spot. My favorite dishes remain to be the shrimp fried rice and shrimp tempura. The seafood stew was spicy for my liking but I'd try there other stews and hot pots for sure.


Service can use some improvements and a few more smiles. However, they are on top of their game considering they are almost always at capacity every night. Kudos to the chefs back there, whatever magic they are using on these dishes is addictive. I'll be back for more!!
author: Hala A.

description:
If you're looking for some good food and soju to wash it down with, Toyose is a pretty solid spot for that. The wait was just a short of 15 minutes on a Friday night which isn't too bad but the place is indeed a smaller restaurant. It is decorated as a garage door entrance and parking can be found on the street around the restaurant. I recommend ordering the Kim Chi fried rice and fried chicken wings. For Soju, I highly recommend Kiwi and Lychee. I've seen the mac and cheese corn to also be a popular dish. 

Overall I recommend it for smaller groups of around 4-6 people as it is a smaller restaurant. I'd probably expect some longer waits on weekends as well. 

Oh, it also opens till 2am. Perfect for the drunkchies
author: Auden W.

description:
I reserved a seating for 7 on a Sunday. I will definitely recommend reserving a seat if you have a big group, otherwise there is a wait. The food was delicious. We got GOYZA, CHICKEN WINGS, KIMCHEE AND SEAFOOD PANCAKES, TEMPAURA, KIMCHEE FRIED RICE, SHRIMP FRIED RICE, AND BACON SAUSAGE. 

The atmosphere was unique, its in side or a garage. their is also a buzzer if you need assistance. we also tried almost all the flavors of soju. We tried (watermelon,pineapple, mango, kiwi, regular).
author: Bonnie C.

description:
I like its atmosphere, it was very unique from other Korean restaurants. I felt like i was sitting in a Korean traditional house and they also have a bamboo blind to make more privacy. 
 They do not provide any side dishes as others, just only bland pop-corn. 
 I ordered a Kimchi&seafood pancake, it was good but a pancake in" Dae jung gum tofu house" still the best one to me and my friends also agree wt me. 

KFC was ok , just a normal fried chicken didnt mixed wt any special sauce. 

Kimchi tofu soup was ok. If you like soft tofu in soup. This might not meet ur need and the soup was a bit too sour to me.
author: Tiratiwan L.

description: Bommb to the max esp when you have a had drinks. kimchi fri2d rice, bulgogi with squid and the spam ramen. Holy cow ...
author: G. B.

description:
I don't know how I haven't reviewed this place yet! I've come here multiple times with my friends for the yummy Korean food and soju cocktails. 

I like that they take reservations over the phone, so as long as you call in advance and let them know, they're pretty good about holding your table. They typically won't seat you until everyone in your group is there, so watch out for that.

On my most recent visit here, my friends and I shared two budaejjigae (Korean army stew, $25.95 each) and a seafood pancake ($12.95) along with some soju cocktails. I have very low spice tolerance, so I just picked at random things in the budaejjigae, but my friends really enjoyed it. Each budaejjigae is good for probably 2.5 people (we shared 2 among primarily 4 people and we ended up with a lot of leftovers).

The seafood pancake was decent...a little bit too oily and I didn't like how they put jalapenos on it as that's not a topping I typically see, but it was good and the portions of seafood toppings were generous.

We also ordered the yogurt and kiwi soju ($11 each) and both were bomb. I prefer my drinks fruity and really liked the fact that the soju flavor was not overpowering in either flavor. More so than the food, I love coming here for their amazing selection of soju cocktails! They offer a wide variety of flavors as well: aloe, kiwi, lemon, lychee, mango, peach, pineapple, strawberry, watermelon, and yogurt, so there is something for everyone! Each carafe is enough for probably ~14 shots.

They have a service button, so it was always easy to get our server's attention for additional orders, the check, etc.

We all left this place stuffed and our wallets only $22 lighter. Not a bad deal at all, especially for SF!

Parking in this area is all street. We found a spot along a residential street a block away pretty easily.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Toyose is probably one of my favorite group spots to bring out-of-towners to because it captures this true SF vibe (not the bougie/techy/ new SF vibe). I love the fact that the restaurant is in someone's garage. True immigrant grit and hard work. 

I order something different every time depending on whom I'm with but the seafood pancake, spicy rice cakes, and chicken wings are always a must. If I'm with a group big enough, I really like to get the beef pot because it has a medley of goodies including noodles, meat, and veggies. 

It definitely gets crowded and feels a little cramped but when you're laughing with friends and a couple of sojus in, you're fine. I think they take reservations but honestly don't try to bring a group bigger than six.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Keep an eye out for the sign as you walk up because if you're looking for the door, you can walk right past it. The exterior is painted just like an old 50's garage door. 

Once you walk in,Walk towards the middle of the restaurant and across from the cash register, put your name on the board to the right of you. You can either wait in the tiny waiting area, sitting or standing, or wait outside. If you choose to stand inside, you'll be next to some other patrons sitting at their table and awkwardly pointing your butt towards their table. Because it was cold, and limited seating in the waiting area, I chose to point my butt towards a table that was dining nearby. 

I unfortunately got seated at one of those tables next to the waiting area. But it was just my friend and I, so we sat against the wall, and with a half bamboo curtain, it wasn't TOO TOO awkward for us, and the line for waiting was smaller by the time we were sat. It probably would have been more awkward if there were four of us, and the waiting area was really packed. What's really handy at these tables is that there's a button on the wall next to you that you can push to call your waitress over. No need to wait for them to come by! But they come by anyhow without calling called. 

Look at my pictures. they should say 1000 words for how delicious it was. A pescaterian shouldn't have a problem eating here, a vegetarian might. I would definitely get the seafood pancake and the soup again. The fried chicken was still delicious the next day. The rice in the kim chi fried rice was a little too soggy for my tastes, but it was delicious when heated up the next day!
author: Vicky L.

description: Best Korean food in a garage ever.  Spam stew on point, kim chi fried rice . Seafood pancake and gyoza . I went early and they were packed already.  Worth the wait
author: Tim C.

description:
I love this place, drunk or sober, the Korean food here is comforting. The restaurant is literally located in a garage, and if you've had one too many drinks, you'd probably walk right past it. It is definitely cozy inside but I think that's part of the appeal and charm. Located in the Outer Sunset, parking can be a hit or miss. If you arrive right when they open, you shouldn't have a problem getting seated. However, any time after that, be prepared to wait at least 30 mins to an hour for a seat, depending on the size of your group. If you plan on going with a large group, call and make reservations to save yourself from waiting. Service here has always been fine for me especially since there is a button at each table to catch the attention of the waiters. 

I only had the weekend in SF so I had to choose the places I wanted to eat wisely, and of course I picked this place! I used to come here in college all the time and for good reason. The food is deeeelicious! They do not serve banchan, but don't let that deter you. The food they serve is more than enough. We ordered my favorites:
spicy seafood pancake, spicy chicken wings, kim chi fried rice, steamed egg, grilled mussels and lychee soju - to all that I give a 5/5. Especially the soju! It had real lychee in it and it was refreshing to drink with all the spicy food we ate. 

I makes me sad knowing that I'll be back in Seattle and will have to wait another year or two before I can visit this place again. So if you live here, go check it out.
author: Marian D.

description: Awesome restaurant! Good drinks and food. It's a local favorite which is what I love to find. There is usually a line but we lucked out.
author: Michelle E.

description:
My friends brought us here and it was a pretty decent experience.

Let's start this off good... the food wasn't a disappointment at all, I enjoyed it for what it was. I ordered calamari and tried my friends' gyozas, corn cheese, fries, & fried rice. We ordered soju as well. Our stomachs left satisfied for sure.

But to be honest..the service wasn't that great. The waitress wasn't very friendly... 

Don't have much to say, if it wasn't for the good company I was with, this place wouldn't be as great of a time
author: Deanne L.

description:
MAYBE TIME TO HIRE NEW STAFF?! 
2.5 hrs wait ?!? Wtf ?? Food is great, service exact opposite
author: Ling L.

description: You gota love this spot for what it is. Where else can you find kimchi fried rice, baked mussels and a bunch of delicious soju inside a garage in a residential neighborhood. I like taking friends from out of town to this spot because it always blows their mind once they step inside. Delicious food and waitresses always on top of everything. Popcorn for finger food, I will be back.
author: Manny R.

description: Came here at 1:15 AM when business hours advertised 2:00 AM; they refused service to me. Never have I met such rude people, either they change their service or attitude. Don't come here past 12:30 AM to make sure you're serviced.
author: Joscelynne R.

description:
The short: solid Korean spot in the Sunset

Without the restaurant sign up top, I would not have known to open the door to head inside. 

Since it was only my friend and I at 6:30 pm on a Saturday night, we put our name on a waiting list and waited 5 min. If you missed the beginning seating, time to get comfortable on the benches.

We decided on:
- tteokbokki with ramen add on: ramen was such a lovely touch and made the dish so much more interesting. Overall, we thought it was really spicy. Nevertheless, the rice cakes were chewy and yummy
- fried chicken: likely fried for too long. Exterior was too crispy, but meat was still delicious.
- seafood pancake: my favorite dish, plenty of seafood, crispy and flavorful

(No pics because I forgot my phone)

The bell ringer was really handy as the waiters are constantly handy. Service was prompt and friendly. Though on the dim side, the atmosphere was lively, I could still hold a conversation, and it felt somewhat private

Verdict: would be interested in coming back to try other things on the menu
author: Catherine W.

description:
If you're looking for some decent Korean food, then I would say come here. 

I ordered a bulgogi dish which came with some other items that I didn't really care for. I'm a pretty picky eater, so most things on the menu doesn't really fit my taste. However their rice cakes are good.

If you're of drinking age, then get the Soju. Their soju is pretty delicious and that's saying something coming from me since I cannot handle liquor.
author: Allyson L.

description:
This place is always busy. Even when we come at later times it seems like I always have to wait. 
Been here a few times and my faves are probably the stew and the soju. The stew definitely fills you up and maybe too much for a party of two (especially when you were snacking on popcorn chicken just and hour ago). 
This time I opted for a seafood udon while my bf had a seafood soybean paste and of course can't forget the soju (we had kiwi). The udon was not bad. I'd say the shrimp was a little too tiny compared to what I'm used to and there was WAY TOO MUCH octopus. After awhile I began to get tired of eating octopus so I ended up taking it out into a small bowl and it filled up like ¾. That's a little too much octopus. Aside from that it was pretty standard udon. Nothing special nothing horrible. 
The tofu on the other hand was to my bf's liking. It came out boiling and it was definitely filling for him with the bowl of rice. 
Last but not least, the soju. I like how it's a purée of real fruit + soju. It doesn't taste bad and goes down easily. Personally I think a bottle may be good enough for those who can handle their alc and if you can't it's always good to share. It comes out to a little less than 10 shots but worth the price.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Went here for a company dinner.

The decor is super cute. At the 4 seated tables, there are little bamboo drop curtains you can use for more privacy. How awesome is that? It definitely doesn't feel like you're in a garage.  There is also a ton of posters and cuts outs of Korean celebrities everywhere. 

I'm not entirely sure what the names of the dishes were. I let the pros take care of the ordering. I provided pictures though. 

Corn cheese: never tried it before but it was buttery and cheesy. Loved it

Seafood pancake; they put nice big chucks of seafood in it. It was super good

Udon soup? It was just okay.

Kimchi tofu: not overly spicy

Rice with fried egg: a little too mushy for me

Soju:
Lemon: okay
Strawberry: okay
Peach: my fav
Definitely got me buzzed

We were a loud group and I'm sure the patrons around us were getting peeved. But service was good, food was good, drinks were good. Loved it!
author: Lynn C.

description: A classic in the sunset if you drive to fast you my miss it, Toyose is a great spot to drink and have some tasty Korean food...if your in a rush you need to get here when they open,otherwise be prepared to wait...the stews are nice and spicy and filled with all the goodies lol, the fried chicken is crispy and juicy the classic cheese corn is good too but could use a little more corn... definitely and good spot to try out if you never been
author: jonathan h.

description:
Every time I come here I always line up before 6PM (the opening time). So I never had to wait for a long time :) This place seems to always be busy. However, the service here is good because you can just press the button and someone will come to you.

I've tried the stews, soups, fried chicken, kimchi fried rice, and rice cake. I think my favorite is the fried chicken and kimchi fried rice because they are just so simple and delicious. But.... im not sure if I would wait over an hour for those two dishes. 

Overall, I think it's a good place especially if you come early and be the first ones in! The decor is also really cute and the room feels intimate.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Having traveled to South Korea 3 times now I'd have to say that Toyose is the closest that I've had to authentic Korean food! The set-up inside is super homey and warm; a little hole in the wall like how a majority of restaurants are in Korea. 

Every time that I go to Toyose I always get the Seafood pancake and fried chicken. These are a MUST get whenever I eat here. The pancake is thick and super good! + the sauce it comes with to dip in is really good too. The fried chicken is almost identical to what they serve in Korea so that's why I always come back.... to be honest I really just come back for the fried chicken. lol, I do wish they had all the side dishes and side sauces like other Korean restaurants do too, but I can manage since the fried chicken is super good by itself already.

Some other things I've ordered here is the Cold buckwheat noodles which is more like a salad? There are lots of other vegetables in it which was different than what I'm used to. The taste is pretty refreshing but it wasn't what I expected from Spicy cold buckwheat noodles. 
I also had the tteokbokki which isn't bad... but there are other places that are a little better too. 
The kimchi pancake is good but not as good as the seafood pancake. The only difference is that you can taste the spice and the spiciness from the kimchi in the pancake. 
SOJU!!! The fruit soju mixes are amazing. I don't think there's much soju in it but it's super good.. lol, we ended up getting mango and peach and then a regular FRESH soju... + 2 bottles of beer for soju bomb. 

Overall, I eat here about once every week. The restaurant is small in size and is usually busy so I've been ordering take out recently.. When I'm up to it I'll wait for a table or reserve ahead of time.
author: Emily T.

description:
I love little spots that don't seem to impress you until you walk half way in to sign your name on the board and your senses are overwhelmed with the wonderful smells of what the place has to offer. 

Food was pretty damn good for a tiny little spot, not to mention definitely worth the half hour wait on a Sunday night. 

I would make it a point to come here if I ever find myself in the sunset district!
author: Erin M.

description:
Cool factor: It's in a converted garage and you feel like you're somewhere far away, even though you kind of are unless you live in the outer Sunset. 

Nice factor: Lovely, swift service. You can be in and out, or you can sit for a long while. Either way, they are very kind.

Sugar factor: Too much sugar in almost every dish. I wanted more salty. I feel like the food would be better if it was less sweet. Perhaps I need to keep trying more dishes to find the ones that aren't sweet. 

Line factor: If you don't have a reservation, be there at 6 on-the-nose to get seated right away. If you show up any time after, you'll be waiting (and potentially sorry).
author: Meredith R.

description: Only place to get kimchi and seafood pancake - not just one!  The spam stew is rich and hearty and there will be leftovers!
author: Veronica C.

description:
TL;DR Novelty restaurant w/ great party food and drinks, average everything else. 

When I first came here a few years ago, this place was so magical. The place looks like a garage from the outside but is super cozy inside. They have curtains for each table that you can use for privacy, which are a godsend when people are innocently waiting in line but also awkwardly watching you eat. 

Now, on to the food. Having explored many Korean restaurants over the years, this place is only slightly better than average. Whole fried chicken and kimchi fried rice are really good but they're a hit or miss for many other dishes. Kimchi pancake was bomb, but the dubu kimchi was over salted and not flavorful enough. It was served up in a pool of grease. Their budae jjigae is very watery (Cooked it for an extremely long time and it still wasn't the correct consistency). Tteokbokki sauce tasted pasty, most likely due to the rice cakes themselves being undercooked. Flavored sojus are really good! The lychee soju has lychee chunks in it. 

They charge $2 for refills on banchan. When I came here a few years ago, they didn't charge. I personally have never heard of a Korean restaurant charging extra for refills, it was always complimentary. 

If you're planning to eat here during the weekends, arrive before 6. There's a long wait!
author: Naomi T.

description: Why only 3.5 stars? This place is good. We had yogurt infused soju, the seafood stew, beef fried rice, and spicy pork. It all rocked so hard. I'd 10/10 eat here again. Cheers.
author: Charles N.

description: Their kimchi fried rice is SOO BOMB. if you're like me and can't eat spicy food but still likes to eat them, you'll love their kimchi fried rice. The hotpot was too spicy for me but it was really tasty. I wish they gave us more noodles tho. Their sojus don't have much alcoholic taste to it.
author: Lauren C.

description:
For fast service....push the Red BUTTON.

Came here on a Monday at 1am with some friends, the place was mostly packed for a Monday night. We ordered: the whole fried chicken, chicken wings, mussels, 2 - kimchi fried rice, and some fries . 

3 stars alone for the kimchi Fried rice, will definitely be back.
author: Erika K.

description:
Decent food, but 2 stars for the horrible service. 

My friends and I came here on a whim, luckily with no wait. Toyose is tiny so there was a wait once we left, even on a weekday night. 

We shared their rice cakes with ramen and their seafood pancake. I enjoyed the doughiness of the rice cakes and the crispness of the seafood pancake. Aside from that, the food wasn't too memorable.  

Don't come here expecting a leisurely or pleasant meal - our entire meal was rushed. I didn't expect top notch service but I also didn't expect our female waitress to be so unprofessional. A friend asked her for suggestions and she simply said she didn't know. Once the bill came, she came back for the bill a few times before we were ready. She finally asked us to leave because our table was "reserved." I get it - people are waiting for a table and it can be hectic serving a full house. But would it be so hard to show a little decency and hospitality for paying customers?

Toyose is not worth the drive, time or effort to return.
author: Charlene E.

description: It's good and delicious especially its fruit cocktails. I tried lychee which was really good.
author: Tingying C.

description: So sad. I love Korean food but the kimchi pancake was OILY and bland. How is that possible with anything kimchi? It was. The seafood udon was even more bland. We had to ask for salt! And chilli. And it still didn't help. Most people around us had the wings and fried rice so I guess that's what's to be had here. No big flavors.
author: Claire N.

description: This place is always a go-to when me and my friends are up for some soju and killer Kim chi fried rice. It's such a hole in the wall spot, but that's what makes it so cool! Don't you think? The experience of feeling like you're literally eating in someone's garage is for sure like something you haven't experienced so often lol. The wait could be crazy long, but trust me when I say it's worth it. The staff does try their best to be as fast as possible and make you feel comfortable. Definitely recommend giving this place a try!
author: Monica-Leah A.

description:
Will definitely go back. Great food. Great ambiance. Nice staff.
Try the fried rice with beef & kimchi and the specialty sweet potatoes vermicelli with veggies. yummm. The toasted rice tea is very good too.
author: Meryl H.

description:
A hole in a GARAGE! Literally. That's the fascinating part is that this restaurant is located inside a house garage. How unoriginal and unique! From the outside, it looks like any sunset house but once you enter, the place consists of these tables with pull down bamboo curtains and further in are more tables. The vibe can be intimate and also cozy and fun for bigger crowds. 

On this occasion, the bf and I took my grandma here cause she's never ate Korean food before. In the beginning, I tried to order things that I thought were more enjoyable for her like the japchae and chicken wings. BUT to my surprise, she liked everything else we ordered !

FOOD:
- JAPCHAE: came in a white boat shaped dish that is pretty good portioned. Consists of clear noodles that are sweet but NOT too sweet cause it's made of sweet potatoes!! and assorted veggies. Has a very good chewy texture. The grandma loved this dish! (4 stars)

- GRILLED MUSSELS: comes in 6 individual half shelled mussels that are cooked and topped with this spicy mayo sauce I think? Very creamy and rich (3 stars)

- BEEF KIMCHI FRIED RICE: theeee very fish dish I ever tried at Toyose years ago. I use to think it was HELLA good when I was younger but over the years, i realized it was just a hype and it wasn't as great as I thought it was. Just spicy kimchi fried rice mixed with beef, an egg on top, and shredded seaweed. (3 stars)

- CORN CHEESE: one of my favorite dishes cause I love cheese and I love corn! So bam! Put together is yumm in every bite !! Really cheesy from the butt loads of melted buttery mozzarella they put and stringy!!! Only down side is when it gets cold and the cheese gets hard. So don't let this one sit for too long! (4 stars) 

- SPICY CHICKEN WINGS: must try!! The bf, grandma, and I all loved this dish. The wings were fried perfectly and crunchy and delicious! Comes with a side of salad and pickled radish. The bf isn't a spicy eater but he loved it (4.5 stars)

- SPAM STEW: this dish is huge !! Came out in a big hot pot looking ... Pot. Sits on top of a portable stove so you can adjust the flame. This dish can be shared between 2-3 people. It includes spam, sausages, vegetables, slices of beef, rice cake, and ramen! The broth is spicy and steamy!! Perfect pick for a cold day. The dish itself consists of very basic and cheap ingredients  but what made us love getting it was the fun and warm feeling we get. Literally comfort food. :) (4.5 stars) 

DRINKS:
- FRESH SOJU: initially got this for the bf and I while my grandma drinks hot tea but she insisted on trying and after that she kept saying in Chinese "hao jiu" which means good alcohol. Lol! She took a good two and half shots and a cup of beer. O.o
The soju wasn't too strong tasting with that rubbing alcohol taste which is good cause I HATE how some drinks have that smell and taste. Yuck. This pure soju was light and very easy to down (3.5 stars) 

- KLOUD: Toyose ran out of the OB beer that the bf likes so the waitress suggested he try another beer called Kloud. I'm not a beer drinker but the bf said it was good and paired well with the food. Grandma liked it also so I guess it's good ! 

Service wise, both waitresses were really nice and friendly. Even joked around saying we sure know how to feast for ordering so much for just three people!! Heh heh. Little did we know that they were right and we end up packing half the food. All cause i ordered with my eyes again :| 

Strict on checking IDs also. Got our IDs checked twice by the two waitresses cause we asked for another shot glass for my grandma and they thought one of us was underage so had to check us both again. But props to them for being careful about underage drinking.!
author: Anissa D.

description: Too bad service I have never seen, very rude and very arrogant , we had no service at all, and when we check out ,that is very rude to ordered us finish the drinks in ten minute. OMG, what kind of service they are.
author: Genyuan L.

description:
If you give this place less than 5 stars, something is wrong with you. Please list a better Korean joint for me to go to. Service is always great here. Lines can be VERY long though.

Here is what I order every time! Beef Kimchi, Chicken Wings, Cheese Corn & Veggie noodle thing I can't remember what it's called but it's got glass noodles.

SOJU is dank. Get Kiwi or Watermelon.
author: Harley M.

description:
I love this place! The wait is always long even on the weekday but it's totally worth it. They have the most amazing corn cheese I've ever tried in my whole life. Also, their soju is the best!

My favorite hang-out spot in the city
author: Mara O.

description:
Not just a place for us to go drinking anymore!

Sure, those days were good, but this has become a regular staple for us and our friends and the kids recently.

As we have begun to explore the menu beyond just the late nite drinking food, we have found that all the food is really tasty.

Chicken gizzard is a must for us, and combined w a little salt and pepper and lime, it is pretty amazing.

As with any good Korean place the Kal Bi must be top notch...if the Kal Bi isn't great, it cannot be a good Korean place...this place delivers!

We always order one of the giant hot pot style dishes to share between everyone.  I haven't seen this anywhere else and the spicy soup along w the noodles (order an extra dry ramen packet to go w the order), veggies, spam, and bulgogi really hits the spot.

We also order other random dishes on the side that I recommend, including Jap Jae, chicken wings, and of course the meal comes w pan chan.

Can't beat this place on a cold winter nite (or a cold summer nite in sf too)!
author: Bradley H.

description:
It was my first time here with my sister-in-law and I must say that the food is delicious! Great portions at a great price. The only down side is that the wait can be pretty long if you don't get there right when they open (or even a little before). They don't give you an estimated time on how long you could be waiting, but honestly how are they supposed to know?

Great service, great food and a great atmosphere!
author: Betty C.

description:
I was able to walk here from my house and grab a table. WARNING: Everyone in your group has to be present in order to get a table. People actually arrive when they open on time.

-My friends and I ordered chicken wings, octopus with spicy udon, kimchi fried rice, & their seafood pancake. Everything tasted delicious and they didn't take too long to bring the food out. Their kimchi fried rice and chicken wings are pretty average tasting. The chicken wings come with a small side of diced radish. I saw a lot of pictures on social media sites about how good Toyose and their food was, but the in-person experience is even better.

-There's zero ventilation. Let's be real, this is a restaurant in a garage. The only source of wind/air is if the door is being opened and the small window of the backyard. I'd totally recommend dressing light and thinking twice about the layers. Some people eat, then go outside to chat or smoke, then come back inside to eat again. It is a weird concept, but my friends and I basically did that, and actually felt much better when sitting back down to finish eating our food.

It can get pretty hectic/noisy, so if you can't stand that type of environment, you should order takeout. Regardless, the environment at Toyose is group/date friendly. I've ordered takeout plenty of times here and it sometimes feels like the portions are bigger than eating in. They're very considerate about takeout orders because they wrap the food in foil, which is then inside the plastic box.
author: Erica K.

description:
After trying the food here, I thought... I'm totally going to become a regular here. This place is solid. My new roommates took me here on one of our first outings together, and it's awesome to now live within walking distance of good Korean food. We celebrated with lychee yogurt soju which was amazing!! That stuff is so dangerous.

We ordered a few things to share at the table, including the seafood pancake, kimchi fried rice, and chicken wings. They were all tasty and came in large, shareable portions. The seafood pancake and fried rice were favorites, and apparently that's what my roommates usually order. This restaurant is super cozy in terms of space and is optimal for four people. No more than that. And though we didn't have to wait for a table on a weeknight, I can imagine this must get busy on the weekends. Fortunately they take reservations.

I'll be coming back here again to feast on that seafood pancake and fried rice, along with a few other menu items and of course more yogurt soju.
author: Stefanie C.

description: How long did we wait? One hour and five minutes. I think it's worth it because that was our first time. Don't have the courage to wait second time.
author: Waiwa S.

description: My late night food spot! My boyfriend knows I crave the kimchi fried rice. I've been in here a few times with my brothers. Most of the time I order for pick up. Their hours are so convenient for when I'm hungry. I really like the chicken and the gyoza. It's as if someone in the family that owns that house just said screw it I'll just turn our garage into a restaurant. And it's been successful ever since lol
author: Sasha M.

description:
Been here off and on over the yrs. While it is the original Korean soju spot in the sunset area, it's really lost its major appeal over the past few yrs. 

The decor hasn't been updated in yrs, so it's still super tiny and pretty outdated. Some of the furniture is basically falling apart. 

Also, while there is a button to get the wait staffs attn (which is widely prevalent in LA, but not SF), it still doesn't REALLY get their attn here. They're always too busy running around to pay attn to you...and the set up really doesn't allow for them to see you in all the seated locations (which is why the button should work to get their attn, but it doesn't..)

Honestly, the food is only okay, and as other Korean soju spots have opened up, the soju drinks (which is what made them special here) no longer have that special feel. Places like Tonight Soju (also in sunset) have watermelon soju in a watermelon!

I've always hated that they don't have soondubu here...whyyyy??? The have another firm tofu soup here, but it's just not the same. Instead, I've opted for the rice cake/fish cake + ramen combo...superrrr spicy. Be warned! And I hear their kimchi rice is pretty ridiculously good (haven't tried it myself, but my meat-eating friends have told me). 

3 stars (for the nostalgia)
author: Jennifer L.

description: Love this little hole in a wall place located inside someone's garage (literally). Its open until 2am everyday which is a plus. The downside it can get really busy I mean really busy where the wait can get extremely long, like hours long. On the bright side the food is quite good. They tend to serve korean street food such as fried chicken, pot stickers, etc. Its definitely worth a try if you are ever in the outer sunset around 11 pm and graving some korean food
author: Paul C.

description: Servers are so rude. They are keep telling you another 15 min and it never comes. Waiting over an hour and half to finally sit. They short in staff. If you plan to ruin your Saturday on this place plan to wait for a log time. And their food is so so.
author: Nickan J.

description:
It's been awhile since I came here, but it's definitely not as good as I remember.  Last time I was here I would give is a solid 4 star.  I really wanna give it a 4 again, but I'm struggling with it.  

We had the seafood kimchi pancake, cheese corn, and spicy chicken.  The pancake was by far the best thing we ordered last night.  

The chicken wasn't that good.  It really reminded me of KFC hot wings.  Again this was better a year or two ago.

The wait was long to get seated, it that was expected cause it's a small place.  They were seating a lot of parties of 2 with big tables, the table I sat at could fill 6-7 people...  we only had 2 people sitting.  If they prioritize their seating arrangements it would have been better for everyone instead of seating on a first come first serve.  There was a party of 6 behind us that could have used it.  They might be able to get people in and out more quickly that way.

Pros: fair prices, large selection of food, and service is fast.

Recommendations: Try to get the food quality bad up to how it was 2 years ago and seat parties more efficiently.
author: Nathan S.

description:
I love that this restaurant is hidden away in an old garage. Both times I've been there was a pretty long line, so go in, put your name down, then go take a stroll along Ocean Beach which is within walking distance. After being chilled by the SF fog, come back for some steaming and spicy Korean hot pot!

The pancakes are delicious - buttery with a slightly crisped outside and soft battered inside. Great for sharing. 

The hot pot is hearty and filling with lots of flavor. Definitely enough food for two. 

Service is a little lacking - waitresses are brisk and impatient, but I guess it's necessary with such a long line.
author: Hali M.

description: Ok this place is definitely a hidden gem and very small so come early! They don't take reservations and people wait here for them to open. I've been here a few times now and if you come with a group of people you HAVE to get the spam stew if you like spam of course. They say it's for 2 people to share, but I'm telling you this stew is enough for 4 people and then just get a couple appetizers. I LOVE japchae and here it's pretty damn delicious. I've also tried their kimchi fried rice, kimchi soup, Korean pancake, and cheese corn. Everything is soooo delicious and filling! You'll definitely be satisfied and its hard to see from the street since the restaurant is a converted garage so there's no windows, but just look for the people waiting outside and you're there.
author: Dianne E.

description: One of my top places for Korean food in the city! Everything is good and this place is always crowded. I always make a reservation when the girls and I come here. Our go to dishes to order is the corn cheese, japjae, bulgogi, seafood pancake, kimchi and seafood pancake, kimchi pancakes, and more. Everything is so good and my mouth is watering just thinking about the food lol. Their soju is good as well!
author: Foodie Sushi Q.

description: Cozy spot! Favorite menu items were the seafood pancake and the lychee soju. Delicious! Next time I'll skip the sea bass soup and just stick to the pancake.
author: Nena K.

description: Love the ambience. The price is a little on the high side but the taste is just average. Would come here again just to drink with friends though!
author: Boba O.

description:
Toyose is a perfect place for friends to get together eat, drink and talk! They recently changed the seating times so you only get 2 hours max. I rarely come to this place because it gets jammed PACKED! Its literally a restaurant in a home garage. I suggest to plan ahead and make reservations. 

What my friends and I usually order are as the following: 

Casserole (Assorted meats): Its so good, basically in a pot full of different things, theres spam, hot dogs, tofu, mushrooms, rice cakes, kimchi, veggies, beans, and many more! It usually comes with ramen, and you can order more if you want. We usually order more ramen because it goes really great with the soup base. It's not too spicy for all you non-spicy eaters, its pretty bearable, and I dont eat spicy much but if its not spicy enough you are able to ask for more chilies powder / flakes if needed. 

Chicken wings: They are friend really well and I like that the meat is not dry. I always ask for the extra salad sauce to dip with the chicken even tho it on the salad that comes with the dish. 

Chicken Gizzards: Its a hit or miss, some days it is over cooked so its a but hard to eat. I usually order the extra scallions and garlic to eat with. They do provide a seasae sauce and hot sauace but I dont usally use it since there is enough flavor in the gizzards when they cook it. 

Spicy Seafood Udon : I've only had it twice ever going there is its very good! The sauce and the udon go great together, along with teh seafood. it is very saucey , so the udon is not dry at all. Again def not spicy, but to your liking you can ask for more chili flakes. 

Kimichi pancake or seafood: I always get it as an appetizer , it goes great with drinking soju and snaking on something light and not something super heavy. 

Cheese corn: Its a must, to order as appetizer along with all the other small dishes such as wings, and pancake !

They have a variety of soju, usually we order so man I cannot keep track. 

All in all this place is great, it just gets very busy and sometimes the wait can be up to 2 hours. They are good with reservations so I would high suggest to dot hat and NOT be late, parking is ok, depending on the week and day.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
One of the main reasons I love coming here is for their kimchi fried rice. Ugh. So yummy and so addicting. Definitely one of the best places to get kimchi fried rice around the SF area. Another reason is for their soju; I'm not a huge fan of soju in general, but Toyose's is pretty good! 

If you plan on coming here, be prepared to wait (15+ mins) because there is almost always people waiting outside. It's definitely worth it if you want your Korean food fix!! 

Must order: kimchi fried rice, cheesy corn, and soju (pineapple and lychee is the best)!
author: Kelly C.

description: This place is always pack and the lines are long, but worth the wait.   They accommodate big party, too.   Cheap food that warms up the tommy is perfect for raining days.   Service is not too bad and food is actually good.   Love the chicken wings, seafood pancake is really good and the casserole is like mom's home made  noodle.
author: Tiffany Q.

description: If the restaurant owner had the chance to see the review, all I want to say is that I hope your waitress knows what is the service fee or tips. We asked a table for 4, the waitress gave a corner table to us which there just one side of the table can seat. So, we asked her for switch to a normal table. After we transferred to other table, she refused provide water to us because our "touched" water is on the corner table. While we transferring table, we bring all the menus and dishes by ourselves and we just ask her "could you grab the cups for us?". She is using the contemptuous look to us says that " Your water is on that table, if you need it, you have to bring it by yourself..."
author: Shuaitian Z.

description:
If you want to support a business that thinks it's anyway acceptable to flip off a customer, be my guest. I have never seen such a disrespectful, unprofessional conduct in my life. I went to Toyose with a couple of friends last night. After our meal, when we received our check, we noticed an automatic 18% gratuity for a party of 3. We asked the servers that there must be a mistake and she very hesitantly agreed to waive it but tells us that since the kitchen was "forced" to stay open, we were charged with that fee. 

What in the world? 
1) mind you, my party arrived well before the business was scheduled to close for the night and the restaurant was packed and still sitting new customers.
2) standard tip of 15%-18% is no big deal, but it is about the principle. Shouldn't you notify your customers of such charge? No one asked the kitchen to stay open to accommodate us in anyway. 


But to top it all off, the server and her "male friend" had the audacity to flip off my friend from another table. I was in complete shock and disbelief. There are plenty of quality restaurants in the area similar to that of Toyose with quality food and professional service. You can bet that we are never returning to this place again.
author: Ye K.

description:
Probably my favorite Korean place to eat when I'm not eating my mom's food. Sometimes the service is great, sometimes you get the rudest servers. I had a server cuss in Korean when I asked for a bad for the take out (to take her time because we weren't in a rush). I'm assuming she thought that I didn't understand what she would say; so she went ahead and shit talked me while walking away. 
It was a quite upsetting because I go there at least once a week, and now I don't go at all.
author: Dank M.

description: This is one of the better Asian restaurants in the Sunset. Great all around for a with my favorite being the kimchi fried rice
author: T K.

description: I am here for dinner the first time with my friend . It's a very cute restaurant in the garage. The interior is very nice and warmed and the food is fresh . I can say the best Korean food I have never had. We ordered the kimchi fried rice is really standard and delicious. We also ordered the soju yogurt favorite is sweet and tasty. Love this place a lot !
author: Ying Ying Y.

description: Saturday night, my friends and I showed up at around 1:10. We asked for a table but got rejected because apparently they're "closed". They said their kitchen closes at 1 AM. This one star goes to them stating their store hours end at 2 am but actually "closes" at 1. If their kitchen closes at 1, they should just close down the shop at 1 AM also. Super annoyed. Probably won't come again.
author: Tammy T.

description: I've been dying to try Toyose!! The wait was pretty long so I would recommend getting there right when they open. I got the cheese corn, kimchi fried rice, japchae, and the army kimchi budae jigae. Overall, the food was tasty but nothing mind blowing. Their kimchi fried rice was a little bit on the bland side. The japchae was by far the best dish... super flavorful and yummy. My friends and I were actually looking forward to the cheese corn the most... only to be disappointed. The corn did not really stick to the cheese and ended up falling off... it would have been better if they put cheese on the bottom instead of just topping it. The budae jigae was good. They did add a generous amount of sausage and rice cakes... however there was A LOT of cabbage and kimchi. Love that they add ramen to it. PSA this restaurant only accepts card.
author: Sam L.

description: Bad service，food is ok. We went to here just because it opens late. We only have two people，but the worst part is that the bill has added tips.
author: Xu J.

description: what the fucking service... No matter how good the food was in a restaurant, we were disappointed that the service was too poor. We were here to consume, not to see their faces. We were very happy to have dinner with our friends, but in the end we were too disappointed and sad.They ' re very kind of discriminating against . I promise I won ' t go again . It ' s insulting and stupid
author: Yan X.

description:
One of the few places in the city that's open past 10pm and is actually delicious. This place is literally in someone's garage so is very tight on space. Make sure you are bundled up because you may have to wait outside in the cold since there is limited seating.

The thing to get here is definitely the seafood pancake: thin, crispy, and sprinkled with jalapeños. Tastes even better when you dip it in the spicy dipping sauce. My other go-to items here are fried chicken and kimchi fried rice. 

Definitely order the kimchi fried rice if you're on a budget and are starving. It's a huge portion and it's cheap!

The soups that they list on their menu in the section that states "serves 2 people" is definitely an underestimation. My party of 6 ordered this with 3 other items and we still had half the soup left! Definitely more like 8 servings. Order these if you have a big group.

Overall this place is a tried and true favorite that I will always come back to when I'm out late at night and want something good to eat. 

Pro Tip: If you're in a big group, make a reservation and you can avoid the long wait and be seated immediately once your entire party is there.
author: Jane C.

description:
A unique Korean restaurant that's in a garage? You don't see that everyday. It's tuck in a neighborhood so if your not paying attention, you might think your going into someone's house. 

I liked the setting inside. It's nice, if you were inside and I told you that this is a garage, you wouldn't believe me.

As for the food I tried 
*Spicy Edamame - needs soy sauce.

*Calamari and Beef - 'Twas actually good, but the portion size isn't the business. While I did get a good amount of calamari, the beef was no where to be found. The plate was swarming with veggies :(  

Although I liked the decor inside, from what I seen in previous reviews and from my experience. It's always loud in here, sometimes the people are too obnoxious. And when your sober this might not be the place to eat. But if your coming with a group of friends then I can see why it can get poppin in here. The food here is alright though, more options on the menu than Soju tonight, but still looking for the meat.
author: Arron E.

description: The most delicious Korean in SFO. We ordered the fried chicken, fried rice and kimchi soup. All were amazing. I will come to here again.
author: Maggie H.

description:
I finally got to try Toyose!  The Korean restaurant in a garage.  Sounds like a novelty, but the nightly packed resto shows that people love coming here!

Luckily I came with some friends that made a reservation beforehand.  One thing to note though is that their tables are really packed tightly.  I wouldn't recommend coming here with more than a party of 4 otherwise seating will be kind of a tight squeeze.

On to the food.  The menu pretty much consisted of the usual Korean restaurant staples.  We definitely ordered their Kimchee Fried Rice since the yelp gallery is flooded with pics of it.

Kimchee Fried Rice --  http://bit.ly/1z7MpGi

Kimchee & Seafood Pancake --  http://bit.ly/1FAGf9h

Japchae --  http://bit.ly/1z7Mfi7

Calamari & Bulgogi --  http://bit.ly/1FAFT2t

Fried Chicken Wings --  http://bit.ly/1FAFNrq

The food was good for the most part. The Kimchee Fried Rice and Chicken Wings were my favorites as they really should be when you're eating at a Korean restaurant.   A little disappointed with the pancake though.  It was good and had a nice amount of seafood in it, but it was just average.  Everything on the menu was reasonably priced, affordable, and great for sharing when dining with a group.  Though what I do remember most was that we definitely ordered a lot of soju.   Toyose is definitely a great spot for soju drinking, which I believe is their bread and butter.

Overall, although it's a little bit out of my way for some Korean food, I wouldn't mind coming back to Toyose again and try different things off their menu.   It's a very interesting spot to dine with a nice group of folks.
author: Rodney H.

description:
