The food here is great , some of my favorite spam stew in the city , the outside of this restaurant looks like a garage from the outside but is so cool on the inside! Love the decor ! I really want to give this place 5 star reviews, and most of the food is worth 4.5 to 5 stars it is very good. The only reason I took away a star is due to two things . Firstly they charge 3$ extra on your bill to get a second serving of ban Chan or " side dishes" which r small portion and any other Korean restaurant you go to they will fill up your side dishes as much as you like for free, kind of weird you have to pay 3$ for your first refill , maybe after 2nd or third I would understand. Secondly, and most importantly the service is very cold, distant and make you feel a little unwelcome. Usually if I go somewhere new I give the waitresses benefit of the doubt if he or she is not friendly ( maybe they are having a bad day I get it)... I have been a waitress for over 5 years so I get it !! But Iv been here 5+ times and I always tip 20% I never complain I always say hi and smile bye and smile etc , I'm a waitress so I always try to be as easy as possible and nice to other waitresses . But the waitresses that work here never smile, won't answer your questions , give off the " I don't give a hell" attitude and quite frankly make you feel as if you should just shut up eat pay and go and not feel comfortable . 
Service : 1 Star
Food: 4 1/2 stars
Wait: long at night, it's pretty popular
author: Lara C.

description: kitsch lil spot.. corn & cheese.. simple af, but damn does it just hit the spot. seafood pancake is a must as well... hot pot is decent..
author: Est L.

description:
All good things start in a garage. Toyose is no different. The next Google/Amazon/Apple in Korean food, Toyose offers a variety of delicious Korean fusion dishes, along with soju cocktails. Imo one of the best late-night dining and drinking spots in the city. 

*** Atmosphere: 10/10 ***
It's small yet cozy, it's loud, there's Korean posters everywhere and kpop music in the background. Just like a real South Korean restaurant. 

*** Service: 10/10 ***
Service is commendable: warm, friendly and attentive. Constantly come over and checks on you to make sure you have everything and that you're good. If they do get busy, just press the button near your table to summon them. We pressed it once, and all 3 waitresses came to us at the same time.

*** Food: 100/10 ***
It is 'the' place to get your Korean comfort food fix. Get the fried chicken wings. Get the casserole or the hearty stews. Get the seafood pancake. Get the fried rice. Actually, just get everything. It's what we locals do ... cram your table full of food. Throw in a pitcher of a beer and some soju cocktails in there too (I recommend the Mango or the Yogurt). Can't finish them? It's ok, send them to me. I'll eat the leftovers.

Wait can be quite long, especially on weekends or later on at nights. The smell of the delicious food won't make the wait any better. But trust me, it is worth every single second of the wait.
author: Xin W.

description:
Fun Korean restaurant to go to with friends. Each table has a little screen you can lower for some privacy. We came on a Friday night around 7:30pm and waited for about 45 minutes for our table without a reservation. You can, however, order drinks while you wait to pass the time more quickly. 

The duppoki was quite good, as was the kimchi fried rice. Corn cheese here is also pretty solid.
author: Jackie Y.

description:
It was my first time here, but I ended up getting the:

1) chicken wings:4/5 pretty good with the side salad and radish, would get again

2) octopus with spicy udon:5/5 the highlight of the meal, super tasty and spicy, but not crazy spicy

3) kimchi fried rice 3/5: typical fried rice with egg on top

4) seafood pancake 4/5: was really good and loaded with seafood and veggies

5) kimchi stew with veggies and pork: 3/5, was too sour and as spicy as expected

Overall,it was good and I would come back for certain items only.
author: Wesley K.

description: My friend took me here to celebrate my birthday belatedly. We had shrimp fried rice and seafood pancake. Shrimp fried rice you can find lots of places, but seafood pancake is harder to come by, and it's really good at Toyose. Service was not very good last night. I had to flag them down all the time and it wasn't very friendly. I am sure they are busy, but they can try harder to make us feel welcome.
author: Denise C.

description: Great for some late night ramen. Make sure to get the spicy miso on the side if you want it more spicy. And the fried egg....*drools. Ramen was amazing and very fulfilling - soup was hot and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The ambience is very Lowkey and great for all purposes. We ordered the tonkatsu ramen as an entree and grilled pepper / pickled veggies as apps. Both apps were fresh and mouth watering.
author: Darius R.

description:
atmosphere is nice

you're getting consistent korean food, but there are other places that are better alternatives 

if you're looking to eat in someone's garage, go to toyose
author: Stephen C.

description:
After like IDK how many centuries, I finally was able to try Toyose! Came around 10pm on a Thursday and there wasn't a wait but there was still a lot of people. Waitress was nice but seemed a bit rushy.

Got the Chicken Wings, Kimchi & Seafood Pancake, Kiwi Soju, and a Jap Chae. They say their soju is made with real fruit. We tried the Kiwi soju and it was tasty! There wasn't a heavy taste of alcohol but there were a LOT of kiwi seeds. The chicken wings were good too. They were big, crispy and tasty. The Jap Chae was a big portion. It was satisfying but it could use a bit more flavor. It was hard to pick up because it was a big portion and stuck together. The pancake came last surprisingly. It was delicious but too spicy for me.

All in all, I'm glad I finally got to try Toyose. Pleasant experience. Portions are somewhat big to match the price paid. Will definitely be back!
author: Benita M.

description:
Had dinner with the besties here last night. They arrived before I did, and lucked out with getting the last available table before the wait line started forming. Based on the high traffic of people that were there throughout our visit, I'd recommend going as early as possible right when they open especially if you have places to go afterwards. This is definitely a spot best for sharing a meal family style. Our order consisted of fried wings, seafood pancake, beef bulgogi with calamari, kimchee fried rice, cheese corn, and spam stew (spicy broth with pieces of spam, tofu, kimchee, and topped with uncooked ramen noodles) - the stew we could have skipped - in the end we were left with nearly a huge pot of it - and two bottles of soju in strawberry and yogurt flavors. Total bill with a 20% tip totaled to a bit over $150. Pretty good considering all that we ordered. Servers only came by if we pressed the call button on the wall.

Come with people you love to talk to/hang out with, come hungry, and dress in layers. The place gets uncomfortably warm quickly. We were all sweating halfway into our meal. At one point we asked to have the front door opened to let in some cool air. Also, bring cash or Venmo if you have more than two people per table and plan to split the tab. They only take up to two cards per tab.
author: Elaine W.

description: Unique location, kept losing the door. Overall nice experience, too busy eating to document menu as son did the ordering. No itemized receipt so no recollection. Fried chicken was a bit bland, but very crispy.
author: Michael A.

description:
Gah..it's been several years since I was here. I thought it was an interesting place as it was somebody's garage basically. Lol.. 

I remembered that the soju was delish. Food was okay, but I wasn't familiar with Korean food at the time so I ordered some intestine dish which I didn't like at all. 

You would push a button to get the servers.
author: Amy C.

description:
Came here to drink with some friends and it was really good!

Pros
Good atmosphere- feels very cozy in there
Soju is really good!
Good if you're craving Korean food
Can hang out and it's not too loud 

Cons
The food isn't to die for, but is good
author: Ori N.

description:
This was back in March 2016. My first time at Toyose was with a 7 ppl group. We got the pot filled with spicy kimchi and spam and some flavored soju.

The soju there was ok, the mango one was the best. The other ones tasted like medicine. If you don't mind the taste you'll get a pretty light buzz from it depending on your tolerance.

The lighting there is a little dim but not too dark. Everything went really well and we were there for our friend's birthday. Apparently they don't do anything for birthdays but that's ok, we had a pretty good time.

The food overall was pretty good but I wished the chicken wings weren't so hard you can barely bite into it. I didn't rate it a 5 star because it is most definitely NOT the best Korean spot, but it is one that allow for late night meals (past 9:30/ 10pm). I would go again but my next experience wasn't so good.
author: Kimberly W.

description:
We came here on a Friday night at around 7:30pm. Luckily we found parking in front and there aren't anyone waiting outside. Just a few couples inside. My sister in law told me about this hip place to try that's close by where she lives.

It's built literally in a garage. But it's pretty well decorated with bistro lights and ton of shiny wood tables and pillars and fake plants. Very cool.

Food: 4
I think they may have better stuff I haven't tried. We got Kimchee fried rice, Soybean miso soup, fried chicken wings, and seafood pancake.

My favorite is by far the seafood pancake. They're not cheap on ingredients and it's crispy. I also really like their fried chicken wings because the oil isn't old and it's crispy and not too much batter. Kimchee fried rice is good, but we are not exactly big fans of Kimchee - still I know when it's good. The soup I'm not a fan. But I think that's Korean make it? Flavor is waaay too strong.

Other things I'd try next time would be the cheese corn and maybe order some meat.

Man, all this Korean food makes me wanna visit LA again.

Would come back and recommend this to others.
author: Kevin L.

description: Went here after going to Zoo Lights after dark with some friends. We had just beat the dinner rush and did not have to wait for seating. I enjoyed the kimchi fried rich as well as the spice rice cakes. Feel free to put down the veil for some privacy.
author: David N.

description:
If you don't want to wait an hour or more for a table, COME EARLY! This place opens at 6pm. My friends and I came here on a Friday night around 6:15ish? We had to wait... We came with empty stomachs and were so hungry! 

NOTE: This place will not have an estimate time on when you will get seated. Put your name down on the blackboard and wait patiently until your name is called. Parking can be tricky - Street parking. I am not from San Francisco and always hated parking in San Francisco. Toyose is pretty small. It is a garage turned into a restaurant. Lighting in the restaurant is very dim.

I think it was about an hour or so after that we got seated. We ordered lychee soju, kimchi fried rice, chicken wings, japchae and the seafood pancake. All dishes were good! 

Lychee soju: Had lychee bits and was yummy! 
Kimchi fried rice: Flavorful and was topped with a runny-sunny side up egg.
Chicken wings: Very crispy!
Japchae: Warm, but good! I am used to eating this dish cold.
Seafood pancake: One of my favorite Korean dishes. Was nicely fried and the sauce on the side was sweet with a hint of spice.
author: Kathleen L.

description:
I wish I came up with the great idea of converting my garage into a Korean restaurant (uh, wish I had a garage in the first place!) especially one that stays open into the wee hours of the night. 

Then I'd have a constant crowd of people (mostly Asians really!) who'd patiently wait for hot off the fryer KFC. Or a plate of kimchi fried rice. Or an expertly prepared seafood pancake. Add a tasty bowl of japchae or sautéed beef and calamari. I'm telling you, endless plates of NOM! 

I'd definitely trek to the far ends of the earth (aka: outer sunset) for Toyose's food and their bomb ass kiwi soju. So fresh, it's plucked straight out of the tree.
author: Janice C.

description:
Excellent mango soju! but unfortunately I can't handle spicy food so I was forced to order the fish ball stew. needless to say it was literally a giant pot of 40 or so variations of fish balls. There were probably a few strands of A choy here and there but I can't stress how tired I was of fish balls. My bf and I still had over 20 pieces left over after our meal.

Next time I will probably come just for the soju cocktails and order an appetizer to come along with it. 

This place literally looks like the garage of someone's home so don't be fooled when you are circling around the neighborhood if you are lost.
author: Danae L.

description:
I won't rate any star for this place if there is option. 

The Korean waitress wasn't polite at all to returned customer.  She tried to charge me 18% tips even we were only party of 2. She did not respect me and slander me that did not leave tip last time. In fact I am sure that I left tip of 15%  last time. I told her to check the camera and see I really left tip. Her action of adding 18% of tips to my check made me so angry. I told her to check camera, but she still did not trust me that I left tips for the service last time. what a bad place and service, I won't recommend this place now. Pls don't go to this bad place, you may get in to the situation of slander.
author: Ray L.

description: Terrible service from very rude waiters. The food here is subpar and definitely not worth the wait.
author: Aiden H.

description:
Decent food, terrible service, average/poor value. 

Service: The host refused to sit our party of 5 in a larger table after multiple requests, assigning our party to sit in a cramped and dimly lit 4 person table "in case" a party of 6 or more comes in (not a reservation). Before making the decision, he asks us how much we would order. The larger table remained unseated throughout the duration of our dinner. This place is only 2 blocks away from my house but I will not be returning. 

Value: items are not particularly cheap, expect to spend a upwards of 11 dollars on each plate. Expect to spend  20+ per person.
author: Edwin M.

description:
This place used to be my favorite neighborhood restaurant.  But after today's visit(10/04/2017),  I probably will never come back. 
    We walked in around 12:45 today,  sat down and start placing orders at 12:55. 
We first wanted the beef stew,  server answered in a haughty tone,  said they don't serve that after 1 am. I looked at my phone again,  it's still 12:55, I'm pretty sure that he noticed the time too.  But we were hungry so we don't want to bother and ordered the kimchi stew instead. 
    Then our dishes came around 1:10, he informed us that this was last call,  so we placed another order of fried rice.  Then as we we're eating our food,  we realized there was something missing.  The side dishes. We came here a lot,  so we kinda know that they are like many other Korean restaurants that once you placed your order they will bring you side dishes. So when we asked for the side dishes,  the server said "ya kitchen is closed", he didn't make any apology of any sort...It's around 1:15, and they were still in the process of preparing our fried rice. 
This is the tipping point, 
-he should have informed us that they don't serve side dishes at the time of our order
-he should at least apologized for not serving them
-the restaurant should have a last call notice posted

oh almost forgot to mention, after he gave us the check, he constantly asked us to sign it, at least 3 times, I still don't get his intention for doing so, but it's extremely unpleasant and rude. 

    We walked out at 1:29 am - still 30minutes before their closing time, they almost immediately started mopping,  we figured that they just want to end the day by chasing us off.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Somehow I never plan ahead when coming here and call in a reservation, so I've been stuck waiting an average of 2 hours every time I come (weekend evenings... figures.) 

Yet, for whatever reason (it's the wings) I always stick around, staring enviously at the people chowing down in the front booths. For this reason, definitely go with a table in the back if you have a choice - the diners in the front get stared down HARD by hungry waiting people in the constant line that only gets longer.

Must haves: THE WINGS, the seafood pancake, and the kimchi fried rice. I love wings that are seasoned without sauce, so these are one of my favorites. Don't get me wrong, San Tung will always have its place, but these are great in a different way. 

I always feel like things are a bit too expensive here for the amount you get, but the flavors and textures are always spot on so I forgive them. And based on the wait, the demand is clearly there... Well, what can you do. I've had the same dishes at comparable places like The Crew, but the food here just hits the spot!
author: Delia Z.

description:
This is now the second time where someone cut the line in front of us by writing their names in the waiting board to the top. 

Why isn't their staff able to keep an eye on this? 

If you don't mind the long wait, the food is actually decent
author: Daniel C.

description:
I have been here quite a few times now.  During my latest visit, I came here around 8pm on a weekday.  Parking was relatively easy to find, as there were empty metered spots all around.  We waited approximately twenty to thirty minutes before getting seated.  We looked through the menu and decided on the beef kimchee fried rice, kimchee pancake, japchae, and the corn cheese.   

Food made its way to our table in a timely manner.  The beef kimchee fried rice was great.  The egg was super runny and it oozed all over the rice like how egg porn should.    The kimchee pancake was very flavorful.  It was probably my favorite dish, just because it was also the easiest to eat!  The japchae was exactly what you would expect-- nothing more, and nothing less.  The corn cheese was different from what I have ordered at other places.  It was really cheesy, maybe even too cheesy for my liking. O_O! I wish there was a higher ratio of corn to cheese.  

In conclusion, I will be back.  They do have a lot of tasty items on the menu.  Service was okay.  They did not really pay any attention after we got our food.  The fact that Toyose is essentially located inside a garage is rather creepy, but at the same time unique and surprising that the city would actually allow this to exist.
author: Victor L.

description:
UM HI. I cannot say enough good things about this place. If you're walking by it you might miss it since it's literally in someone's garage, but once you walk in you completely forget that fact. It looks like a typical Korean restaurant inside, maybe a little darker than most. It is a little small and the seats fill up quickly so I recommend getting here right at opening for dinner! This will help with parking too since parking tends to be a bit difficult in this area. 

The food is all incredible so there's really no need to rate them separately. The kimchi fried rice is bombdigs - its the perfect balance of spicy and sour and the portion sizes are pretty generous. The chicken katsu is crispy but incredibly juicy and not at all overdone. But the absolute star of this place is the spam stew aka army stew aka budae jigae. Guys this is amazing. It's literally a spicy soup base, full of rice cakes, hot dogs, spam, tofu, ramen noodles, beef, and some veggies. For anyone who is super against this cause of the processed meat, get over yourself and give it a try, it might surprise you! Cause let's be real, hot dogs and spam make everything better, sorry not sorry.  The portion size says for 2 but you could definitely split this between 3 or 4 people. I'm not big on spice and this was a little rough for me at the beginning but guys it's so worth it. This warms you up from the inside out and is perfect on a cold San Francisco evening.  Ugh I'm drooling just thinking about eating here - I will definitely be back soon!
author: Sam L.

description:
Came here around 10:45 and waited for about 10-15 for a seat. It was pretty loud as usual. My friend and I ordered two plates of beef kimchi friend rice and corn cheese.

I have to admit that the kimchi fried rice from Toyose is the BEST I've had compared to other restaurants. It is so flavorful and they don't add too much oil in it. Some places add so much oil it makes the rice soggy and disgusting.

The corn cheese- in my opinion, it was so bad. At the beginning, when the top layer (cheese) was still hot, it was ok. When it got dry, it got hard and it was difficult to chew. The corn was a little bit dry. I don't think I'll get that particular dish again.

Overall, I still love this place with a burning passion. So far I've brought my boyfriend and all my friends and they like it a lot. Customer service is getting a lot better too! :)
author: Kathy D.

description: Horrible! Came here to eat in peace wanted to enjoy my off time and this happens. Twice were we asked to pay even though we were not done. The service went down rapidly. They closed off early at 1:47am and couldn't wait the 13mins. Rushed us out... upsetting! And now I'm smelling the clean up crew and bleach! Health and safety violation!
author: Mimi Y.

description:
We have been waiting for 2 hours and they called someone who was on the list after us. 

The waitresses are really rude. There shouldn't be a reason for them to be treating their customers the way they do. They should hire more competent people. Won't be coming here anymore.
author: Momoe K.

description:
Fun, quirky, romantic, late night, good eats. Toyose serves well for date night or a large party. Usually large group dinners leave a diner paying 3x the amount you normally would pay, but with Toyose, the more people you bring to your party, the more reasonable you share of the bill.
Favorite food so far is the seafood pancake and the kimchee fried rice. The soju (Korean vodka made from distilled rice or sweet potato) is tasty because they blend it with frozen fruit puree.
author: Carrie H.

description:
The Korean waitress was unkind. My friend wanted to have hot water, she said :"we have hot tea but not hot water. " 
Does it make sense? You use hot water to make tea! Lies!
author: Sabrina C.

description: Located in outer sunset district, Toyose is a little nook in the wall that offers a variety of traditional Korean "street food" that would normally be found in Korea. We came around 7 PM on a Wednesday, and waited about 20 minutes which is average here, since seating is very limited The menu has about 40 items to choose from. I tried the beef kimchi fried rice, spicy chicken, and pork tonkatsu. They were all equally good. I wouldn't recommend this place to children during the night time. The mango soju was especially delicious, 10/10 would recommend. Overall I'd give this place a 4.5, but I gave them a 5 stars in the end because the customer service was pleasant.
author: Angel K.

description:
Toyose getting 1 star? Trust me, it's not because of the food. It's how incredibly inflexible that staff is. I also need this review to stand out.

Big customer tip: Come at 12:30, they're going to hate you if you come at 1.

I'm a reasonable guy, and when I come to a restaurant that closes in an hour, I think getting a seat and food is a totally reasonable expectation. But that wasn't the case. 

My group of 4 came in at 1 AM to the dot, an hour before closing. There was no line, and there was definitely space for us. I signal a "4", the lady sees it, and disappears to some corner. She comes back and says "sorry we're take out only at this time." I was dumbstruck, there was no sign in the front (and if there was, I was too hungry and it was too dark to see it), and I know we would have honestly been out quickly considering how hungry we were and how quick they are. At any rate, we were too hungry to go anywhere else so we just decided we'll eat in my car and I figured we were being flexible for their sake (kind of the reverse considering how I was the customer). They gave us the menu and we started looking through it. End of story right? No. 

A couple minutes after my group arrived, another group came by. They were told the exact same thing, and the girl asked if they could just order take out and eat inside. The response just made me angry. The lady basically said "No, do you want to eat here? Because we're closing our kitchens in like 5 minutes so you have to order in like 30 seconds." (That's not verbatim, but that's the jist) That's such a terrible answer to give a customer. She gave no reason WHY they couldn't eat inside. Anyway, we got our food and we ate in the car without drinks (we actually asked for drinks but I guess they were so much in a rush they neglected to give us any). While we ate, I was going to buy some soda from them, so I came back in at 1:40, I didn't even get to say a word before she yells across the room "We're closed now!" I told her I just wanted to buy some drinks (AKA give your business some easy money) and she still said no. Apparently it's just IMPOSSIBLE for a small business to give a customer 4 sodas out of their fridge 20 minutes before closing. 

Look, I've worked at a small business, I know it can be a pain to deal with customers, especially the ones that make unreasonable demands. I think I was being reasonable. We finished our food well before closing, and I still saw people trickling out as they finished their food past 2AM. We could have easily eaten our fill and gotten out of their hair by 1:45. It was incredibly inflexible. 

Personally, I think just giving a 1 star is unhelpful for a review. So here are a few suggestions to foster growth: 

Put a sign that says "take out only after x time"

Close your restaurant at 1:30 if you don't want to serve people that come it at 1:00.

Listen to your customers and be flexible. 

I've got a good feeling the business isn't going to read this review, so I don't know if writing this review was a waste of time or not.
author: Carlo L.

description: I've been to this location twice and during those two times I've had such a great time with my friends. Every time we come here we order the army stew which is perfect and one of the best army stew I've ever had in the bay area. We also order the fried chicken which I'm not a big fan of because I feel like the chicken is too dry. I like my chicken saucy and one of the best locations I found is called bowl'd. The soju was a hit and miss sometimes they make it sweet but other times it taste pretty good. This place gives your popcorn to snack around as you order and as you wait for your food. Overall the service of mediocre I wouldn't say it's one of the best services nor one of the worst I've received. They usually just can't take your order then walk off and then later on they bring you your food. There's nothing that they do that I feel like is extraordinary. Parking is also a hit or miss, sometimes you can find parking right outside while others times you would have to park somewhere a block or two away. This place is hard to find it almost looks like a garage door on the street so if you want to try this for the first time make sure you give it a double take to make sure you're entering the right place.
author: Amy Y.

description:
I absolutely love the concept of eating inside a garage turned restaurant. 

I live just a few blocks away from Toyose, so it's been a monthly spot for me since I moved to the Outer Sunset. Fun Fact: my parents lived in this exact building when they first immigrated to America so many years ago. It blew my mind when I found that out. I always feel like I should mention it to the Toyose staff for fun, but never do.

Since I've been coming here for about a year now (12+ times), I've always enjoyed my experiences. I've had my fair share of not so fantastic service, but this place is an absolute mad show after 7pm on most days, so I don't blame them for not being able to keep up with 50+ people all night. The food is always consistent, and while it's not anything revolutionary, it's comfort food at its finest. You can always stop by after a bar run and grab some chicken or kimchi or you name it. The soju is tasty here as well, and a very reasonably priced for what seems like a good 10 shots per bottle. When it comes down to it, if you have never been here, it's definitely an experience, as there aren't many places with the type of ambiance Toyose has. 

Final verdict: It's a family run restaurant inside a garage. Right away, you either love the idea or hate the idea. If you are curious at all, I can tell you right now that it's well worth a try. They serve up yummy Korean food in a unique location. Prices aren't exactly cheap, and service is not always perfect, but they provide for a fun night out.
author: Alex B.

description: They take reservations, which is great but they do not seat until your whole party has arrived which can be a hassle if you have a large party. But putting that aside, this place is so cool! This restaurant is located inside a garage and may even be hard to locate from the outside. The soju here is so good and so is the food. The flavored sojus can be a bit sweet and weak so if you want it stronger, buy a bottle of the regular soju and mix it together :) They have really good food and all dishes are decently priced. Some of my favorites were the chicken wings and kimchi fried rice. The corn cheese was a bit bland, will pass on next time. Our server was not very attentive and seemed rather irritated but I'm not sure if that was just because it was busy. Overall great experience and can't wait to be back :)
author: Lushi Z.

description:
This place is literally a garage...but an awesome one filled with food and drinks! It's a small restaurant so try to make reservations if you can since the wait can be pretty long. The service isn't that great - I've been here a few times and they're usually rude or ignore you unless you have someone who speaks Korean. (And I only say this because my Korean friend confirms that it's true.) We were a party of 6 (4 guys, 2 ladies) and I was annoyed that they squeezed us into a table meant for 4 people. It was so hard to eat without bumping into one another. 

Anyway...onto the food. We ordered a lot but I couldn't take pictures because we were starving and dug right in. 

-Kimchi fried rice: Always a good choice! Just the right amount of spice and the kimchi wasn't overpowering at all. Delicious! 

-Seafood pancake: This is one of the better seafood pancakes I've had compared to other restaurants. There is a good variety of seafood - shrimp, squid, oyster, etc - and the pieces are nicely chopped up. I would recommend ordering this for sure. 

-Spam stew with ramen: This dish can be spicy so if you have a low tolerance, you should make sure you let your waiter know. There was plenty of meat - spam, hot dogs, beef galore. This is a good one to order for a group to share. 

-Calamari tempura: Meh. Pass. The calamari was over breaded and there were vegetables we could not identify. 

-Fried chicken: It's fried chicken. Nothing special. 

-Lychee soju was yummy! Especially if you get the last of the bottle with all of the lychee bits. Mmmm. We also ordered the kiwi soju but I didn't think it was that great. It had a weird aftertaste to it.
author: Xue Vee Y.

description:
Food: overall, mediocre. The beef kimchi fried rice was really good. The chicken wings were too fried for my taste. The calamari and bulgogi was meh.

Service: really needs to be improved. My boyfriend and I were done eating and waiting for the check. Turns out. Both servers were just gossiping with a friend. You could at least turn your fucking head now and then to check on your patrons ugh.

Not coming back.
author: Christina T.

description: Do not order their chicken wings, because they are all rotten. When we got our to go order, all the chicken wings were rotten, which means the wings were turning bad/smelly. You don't smell it because they deep fried those wings. I threw them all. You can still eat it if you don't want to get sick.
author: Mary Y.

description:
Popcorn, spam stew, bacon sausages, cheese corn, fried chicken wings and soju so cold it like a lychee slush.... What is there not to like!?

If by any chance you are impatient there is a helpful "I need attention" button to annoy your server if you wish...

Service is great and so is the food....Give it a try and enjoy!
author: Joanna Z.

description:
I'll start off by saying my girlfriend and I were kicked out of Toyose on Valentines Day. (mentally)

I've been going here for 5-6 years, eating and drinking soju with friends, co-workers, family etc.  Up until last night I've always had a nice experience here, at a point got to know some of the waitresses/waiters, Annie, June, and my favorite but doesn't work there anymore, Jin.  Shoutouts to Jin, thanks for your great customer service here when you did work at Toyose.

It was a very busy night on Valentines Day, we waited and caused no disturbance.  Getting straight to the point my girlfriend and I had plans for another restaurant but sadly it was closed so we both decided to go to Toyose.  We ate and decided to drink after eating.  Before drinking we decided to get some fresh air for 5 minutes outside so Will our waiter took my ID so I don't run out not paying the bill.

After coming back I had to use the restroom just to wash up.  I was in and out in literally less than 20-30 seconds.  Coming back we were just about to order some soju until Will our waiter came up behind me and told us with a very bold confident tone "oh can you stop tagging our restroom?".  Confused I looked at my girlfriend to see what she knows about this "tagging" we both looked confused at Will.  With a confident tone he constantly nagged "yeah it's okay we know so please stop tagging okay?".  I was SHOCKED, I literally thought this was one of those YouTube prank videos.

I asked Will to show me the graffiti, he opened a cabinet inside the bathroom and pointed out some crayon like tagging inside the cabinet door.  He smirked like he was confident that he caught me doing this.  What was worse I looked at June who I remember being served by for over almost 5 years accuse me too.  After coming out of the bathroom with the waiter Will she added "when you went into the restroom it wasn't there and when you came out it was there so we know so please stop tagging" as I walked back.  

I paid and left.  It killed the entire night for my girlfriend and I on Valentines Day.  I didn't tip, why bother tipping a place that's going to accuse me of doing something I didn't even do.  The worst part is that their "evidence" is based off what I wrote on the wait list which looks "similar" according to waitress and waiter to the tagging and it looks like it says "Eros" which is my name.  Keep in mind when I wrote my name on the wait list it was written in regular print and looked nothing like cursive/graffiti tagging.

TL;DR  Went out to Toyose for Valentines Day dinner date, been going here for 5-6 years, was kicked out for being accused of tagging their bathroom.  Killed our day and mood for the rest of the night.

They're literally confident that I tagged their bathroom with no solid evidence at all.  I can now see why everyone likes this place but if anything the customer service is terrible.  So next time if you ever do decide to come back to Toyose think about if maybe they'll just point the finger at you and blame you for tagging their bathroom or something crazy and silly.

Toyose and especially Will you take the biggest fattest L.
author: Eros M.

description: Wow I used to like this place and be a fan but tonight changed all that. Literally watched about 6 parties who came after us get seated before us, some who were not on the board (and since you can't ask how long the wait is, this is really unfair)! The food is tasty for Korean bar food but considering the trek to get out there and then the unknowable waiting time, you need to give yourself potentially a lot of time to finally sit down and eat.
author: Heidi D.

description:
One of my favorite spots in the city, but it's still super crazy getting a table even though it's almost at Ocean Beach! My favorites are the spam stew and the kimchi fried rice. The chicken wings are pretty good too, and they lack the caramelized sauce that Santung's wings are famous for, which is good or bad depending on what you like. I really liked how crispy the skin on the wings were!

Overall, this place serves amazing Korean food and at reasonable prices. Hands down one of my go to restaurants, and I wish I could eat here more often!
author: Grace C.

description:
Their menu seemed authentic and not Americanized. Nice. 
The whole chicken (not the wings or drums set) was mf dry. Comes with some radish cubes, no sauce, no flavor, and overall plain dry with old fryer oil. We couldn't get thru past 2 pieces. Kind of sad since the fried chicken was supposed to be the best thing on the table.
author: Gloria L.

description:
I have come here several times and I thought it's due for a review. 

Service it's so-so. They have a button on the wall for every table they have and you have to push the button when you are ready to order and checkout. You can also ring the button for necessities that you might need with your meal. 

I order the following every time I come to toyose:

Chicken wings- I recommend asking them for a side of the sauce they put on the side salad and complement it to the wings. It adds more flavor to it. Their wings are not bad but sometimes they fried them too dry. 

Rice Cake (tteokbokki): it is good but the sauce it's a little too sweet for my personal taste. But it is spicy. Sometimes when I order Kimchi fried rice I pour the rice cake sauce on my rice to make it more spicier and more flavorful. I recommend anyone to do this once and tell me if they liked it or not. 

Beef kimchi fried rice- regular kimchi fried rice. Like it when they chop the kimchi into bite pieces. 

I haven't had a chance to try their stew because I'm not a fan of packed ramen. But it is on my list to try next time.
author: Jenny L.

description:
NOTE: TOYOSE REMOVED MY INITIAL REVIEW. What a great way to deal with negative feedback by trying to silence your customers. 
-----------------------------------------------------------
People usually skip over service related reviews (I know I do), but this isn't meant to sway the general public, as I know on a place with 1300 reviews and 3.5 stars my opinion isn't likely to mean much. And maybe that's why the staff at places like these may feel immune to poor customer experiences, but it's the few 1 or 2 star reviews that will unnecessarily bring your score down over time if the service is consistently terrible.

This is a letter to the owner of Toyose, urging you to hire better servers (maybe ones that don't antagonize your customers like June did to us) and a note for my ~900 Yelp friends, who will see this as one of the top reviews when they search for a Korean spot to eat in this area. Please take your business elsewhere.

Came here last night with a couple friends under a reservation. As we were waiting for a table, one of my friends was unknowingly leaning on the door of the bathroom which the waitress June was in. When she opened the door he fell in as his weight was on it and she said something like "Can I get out first?" to which he replied "You let me in!" in a lighthearted joking manner (because he pretty much fell into the bathroom). It was such a non-issue we thought nothing of it until when he came out she came up to us and said "I took your names off the reservation list because I didn't appreciate the way you talked to me" and we all were super confused like wait ... did this really just happen? My friend tried to apologize and explain his side of what happened, which she refused to acknowledge and dismissed as insincere. Minutes after our reservation time comes and passes I come up and ask if we are going be seated. In the rudest manner she tells us to feel free to put our names back on the waitlist as she won't honor our reservation and kept aggressively gesturing to the "we reserve the right to refuse service to any customer" sign. As individuals who have held jobs in the restaurant/service industry ourselves, we all agreed that we would never dream of treating any customer the way we were just treated - so we left.

There are always two sides to every story. I've explained the facts of what transpired as objectively as possible, you can decide whether or not the actions were justified.

We'll never come back because extremely rude service far outweighs the novelty of eating in a garage. Especially when there are other delicious Korean spots right around the corner where you won't be treated like shit. See:

- Shin Toe Bul Yi
- The Spot Lounge

And I feel like this is common sense, but maybe if you hate people so much and are going to be a raging bitch to your customers, maybe DON'T WORK IN CUSTOMER SERVICE? Life is too short to live such a hateful existence as a demonic waitress at a mediocre Korean restaurant.
author: Michelle N.

description: Yummy, over-priced Korean food.  Prepare to wait a long while.  Write your name and party size on the board just past the first few tables on the right side of the wall.
author: Roger E.

description:
T wrote "I have our next food excursion locale picked out." "Next food excursion" turned out to be a Wednesday evening. Late Wednesday evening for that matter. The excursion was to outer sunset, where I had spent my significant youth but since not returned, coming up 20 years. His friend used to live near it, and I was told that the restaurant had been around for some time, with the claim of fame being that it was an old garage.

He wanted seafood pancake, and I wanted the fish roe soup. It was my go to standard in evaluating the authenticity of Korean restaurant. How good is the fish roe soup? 

This turned out to ben an outstanding roe soup, rivals with LA Korean town.

I found memories of the teens and early twenties pouring in. So across the steamy bowl of soup, I told T some of the stories I had never shared with anyone else. Not because they were secrets, but no one had seemed to cared to know until now.

The outer sunset seemed very deserted and sleepy, but it was significantly more crowded than twenty some years ago. 

For years I had wanted to venture out and try ethnic food in the Avenues but I had never met anyone who was as obsessed with ethnic food until now.

I made a mental note to return here but the real challenge is the location. It's a bit out there, any closer to the ocean it'll be swallowed up by the waves. 

Over the years I've been slowly conquering food scene in varies parts of the city: Mission, SoMa, Financial District, Hayes Valley, North Beach and Potrero Hill. My New Year resolution includes getting to know the food scene in the Avenues. If you see a petite Asian woman in a petite car, driving from Inner Richmond to the outer Avenues week after week, you know it's me. And I plan to park that petite car in front of this restaurant, again, sometime soon.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Teeny tiny place that's semi- hidden. Only way I knew about this place was through friends who found out by other friends. Although their food is a bit on the pricer side, their soju is only $11. Although I've seen bugger bottles before, for their price and quality it's spot on. Tried the kiwi (HIGHLY RECOMMEND), the mango, and the strawberry. All were very good. If I'm looking for a soju place, this is the place I'd choose. They also give popcorn with your soju order! 

Overall, food wise I thought it was just ok. I'd come back for the soju but not so much on the food. Had the corn and cheese, kimchi and seafood pancake, bacon wrapped sausage, and the spicy chicken wings. Found none of them to be so amazing that I'd have to come back for it. But will come back to try one of those soup pot things they have. Those look good. And you can't forget about the button at the end of your table to use to call for service! Service was pretty good here, due to the buttons help.

5 stars for the soju, 3 stars for the food. Overall 4 stars.
author: Mariel Ashley S.

description:
Korean "comfort" food in a garage that has soup, soju, and other specialties. It's similar to the "porn" bar in Oakland except in the residential area of SF.

I had some of the everything soup, and mango soju. The soup we had included ramen, sausage, spam and had good flavor, just a little expensive for the portion and the "cheap" ingredients. The soju wasn't that strong, but was at least refreshing. This place was an interested experience but in the end wasn't super authentic and skimped out- thus lacking somewhat in quality and quantity.
author: Steven V.

description: Aweful service and hosting system. We waited for 1.5 hours for a party of two but they seated a lot of parties who came after us first. The food is ok and not worth the wait
author: Golnaz A.

description:
Let's start of by saying, I wouldn't have came to this restaurant in my own volition. The front door does not look welcoming whatsoever. We went here with my fiancé's cousins who recommended the place.

The servings are huge! I love the spam stew and the kimchi fried rice. Everything was seasoned with the right amount of spiciness as well, just enough heat to keep you eating more and more. I would definitely come back
author: Julian T.

description:
Toyose is well known as the little garage in the Outer Sunset, perfect for late night munchies and bomb soju. Before I went here, I initially envisioned a dingy garage with cramped tables, but the interior is quite the opposite. The entire front section of the restaurant has individual tables that line the wall for added privacy and the atmosphere is cozy and welcoming. 

Indulge in comfort food favorites like corn cheese and garlic cheese fries, and if you're in the mood for a full-fledged dinner, they offer hot pot and a variety of stews. Some of the most popular items include their seafood pancake and kimchee fried rice, which is moist, flavorful, and greasy in all the right ways. And their fried chicken wings are just what you'd expect,  but they get a tangy kick from the crisp bites of daikon on the side. 

They have dangerous soju as you can barely taste the alcohol and the kiwi one is riddled with a seedy puree that adds great texture. Pop the top off the bottle to get all that good stuff off the bottom!

Toyose can get crazy busy, so your wait time to get a table and then your food might be a bit lengthy sometimes. When it's not as busy though, Toyose has great service and if your servers do disappear on you, they have service buttons at each table. Not the cheapest spot for Korean fare, but for decent quality food available 'til 2am EVERY night of the week, Toyose has my vote!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Great place for a dinner night out with friends! Love the spam stew, Kimchi fried rice and kimchi pancake. The downsides are this place doesn't serve with banchan and the line is always long in the weekend!
author: Ivory Y.

description: This place is my favorite Korean restaurant. There are few dishes I order most of the time are kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, beef pot and fried chicken wings. I also love to order their yogurt soju because it has right amount of the alcohol and yogurt. The service is OK so I give 4 stars instead of 5 stars.
author: angel w.

description:
I've been on a chicken wing kick lately. Last Tuesday, I was craving wings again, so the roommate and I decided to get pick up from Toyose for dinner. I've been meaning to try them for their wings and kimchee beef fried rice.

*Spicy fried chicken wings: Nice and crunchy. A little spice but not much else. I wanted this to have something else to contrast the salt and hint of spice. The chicken was moist and fried well.

*Kimchee beef fried rice: Bland. Not much flavor or beef. I wanted this to be spicy, salty, sour, etc, but it didn't  have much of any flavor. Also, the rice was a little mushy.

I get why this would be good food when you're drunk. Carby & fried food to soak up all the alcohol. I first came here years ago and had their flavored soju and some food. I remember it being better. Maybe I just needed some alcohol in order to elevate the taste of the food. I might come back for their soju and cheesy corn. I've been craving cheesy corn lately!
author: Elena N.

description: The wait is really long. The host is very rude and sometimes yells at people who are waiting. Food is only ok. Not really worth it..
author: Cam M.

description: Pics do not do justice. Fried chicken wings and seafood pancake are absolutely delicious. The buzzer makes it so easy to ask for additional sides and refills of drinks.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
*update 

Returned here and ordered their kiwi soju. It was delicious! Tart, sweet, and refreshing (w out masking the soju).

Bumped them up a star just for this soju
author: Liz N.

description:
There are some major big points with Toyose that you've got to keep an open mind with; the biggest being that you're eating in a converted garage, but the interior is super cute and actually reminds me of actual restaurants in Korea with the decor, so you're in for an interesting experience!

Nakjee Bok-Um (spicy octopus stir fry): 4/5, the octopus was prepared well and wasn't as chewy as some other places, and they threw it in with udon noodles which were a nice surprise! the only thing is it wasn't as spicy as I was expecting, but delicious nonetheless

Chicken wings: 5/5, it comes with some julienned cabbage and a nice slightly spicy dipping sauce; the wings are moist, hot and crispy. Yum, one of my favorite dishes

Seafood pancake: 4/5, this was good. Crispy and moist, packed with lots of veggies and some nice assorted seafood. It won't blow you away, but it's a nice side dish to share among friends!

This place has some awesome late night food; they open around 5pm and stay open late, so if you're in the mood for 1am cravings, this place will do you nicely.
author: Jay P.

description:
Loooovee Toyose! It might be a weird idea to eat inside someone's garage, but when you walk inside you don't feel like you're in a garage at all! 

With 1,200 reviews, it's hard to say something that hasn't been said already... But the items that my friends and I always order are the japchae, kimchee fried rice, spicy chicken wings, seafood pancake, and cheese corn! My favorites of these are the japchae, cheese corn, and the seafood pancake. The japchae comes in a huge boat shaped dish with cabbage, green onions, and bellpeppers. The sweet potato noodles (still don't understand how they make noodles out of sweet potato... lol!!) are soft and chewy, and they taste slightly sweet. The japchae is also warm and not cold like other places. The cheese corn is basically buttered yellow corn with mozzarella cheese melted on top... So basic, but delicious! The seafood pancake is a flat, crispy pan-fried pancake with a hefty amount of seafood mixed in.. I like the octopus and the squid! In my opinion, the kimchee fried rice is only okay.. The presentation is pretty with the egg and the nori, but it just kinda tastes like spicy rice to me!

All of the entrees are shareable, so you should definitely try to come with 3 or more people so you can try different things. It's also very affordable! With the 5 dishes that my friends and I order, we usually pay around $16 per person, with a group of 4. We always have leftovers too. Not bad!

The only thing that sucks about Toyose is the wait. The place is pretty small, so make sure to get there when it opens at 6, or make a reservation!
author: Tara A.

description: Change your hours to 1. I spent $35 on a Uber just to come eat here and was treated by your hostess like shit, they didn't explain that the kitchen closes at 1 and just told us that they were closed.
author: Nick H.

description: Food is delicious. I love how they open until 2 a.m. so you can pop in for a late night snack or drink. The place is a little small and wait is usually long unless you get there right when they open. Great place for friend get togethers.
author: Wanda L.

description:
"There's so many soju flavors!"
"Which ones should we get?"
"Dude, let's get all of them."
"Rainbowwww!"

And that is how a memorable (or the opposite for the lightweights) night starts. My friends and I made reservations made for 8 pm. They have a very strict policy where everyone has to be present at the reserved time or they will give your table away. Not only that, but we had to be done in 2 hours. 

Flavored soju: 11 different flavors. We ended up ordering 4 more afterwards. The general consensus was that peach was the best flavor. Other honorable mentions include kiwi, lychee, and aloe.

Kimchi fried rice: Yes.

Cheese Corn: Meh.

Seafood Pancake: Yes.

Chicken Gizzards: Yes

Beef Bulgogi: Meh.

Fried Chicken Wings: Yes.

Spam Stew: Double Yes.

Calamari w/ Noodles: Triple Yes.

The place is cramped which is expected, because after all, it is a garage. It will get stuffy in their. The servers are a little snooty. That being said, my friends have already made plans to come back, and I'm okay with that.
author: Jenny Y.

description: Food is okay but communication with the hostess and staff need to be worked on. I came with a carseat for my infant and a toddler with a reservation and I had felt they were shooing me off. As a Mom I never felt so frustrated and disappointed dining out with my family. I know this place is not a good place for kids but the fact that they did not make us feel welcome to dine is frustrating. Pls work on your customer service skills.
author: J B.

description:
Note to self, never come here again!

I thought it was a fluke the first 2 times, but this is the third time I came here and I had the worst stomach ache ever!! You know those contraction pains that makes you sweat, that's what happens to me after eating here.
author: Karen T.

description: Of course I had to have Korean food while I'm out here in San Fransisco. Surprisingly there's no Korean town or many options for Korean food in San Fransisco but toyose is on point. We had many many bottles of soju and bottle of hite so I forgot to take pictures of the food and decor. The wait is was almost an hour but it feels like to be a good restaurant in San Fran the wait is a must. The seafood pancakes, whole fried chicken, chicken wings with radish, and spicy tofu/pork ramen soup and as tasty tasty tasty!! The inside feels like an actual Resturaunt in Korea. The space is very small but very comfortable. Service  as actually very very good. Our waitress was super nice and constantly checking on us. If you want some tasty Korean barstraunt food I recommend toyose all day/
author: Chadwick G.

description:
Eating food in someone's garage/basement? Weird, huh.

+ Food & Soju
Their Kimchi Fried Rice plates are delicious. The sizzling meat and the flavorful Kimchi are mouthwatering. And the Kimchi Spam Stew with Ramen and Corn Cheese (Cheese Corn?) looks amazing! I gotta try that next time! Other food I tried and enjoyed: Fried Chicken Wings, Chap Chae, Dukbokki, and the Spicy Pork plate.
Get some Soju to add some excitement to your meal. I enjoyed their Peach & Kiwi Soju the most.

+ Service & Ambiance
I can see why they are always busy since Toyose is a little too small to accommodate everyone. My group of friends and I usually wait for 45-60 minutes every time we come here (group of 4-6). I would recommend planning in advance who's going and who's not before showing up at the door and writing your name down. Staff is friendly, but getting their attention could prove to be difficult: the place is always overcrowded and I bet it's difficult for them to attend to everyone. Thank you (the staff) for still being accommodating and hospitable.
The place is surprisingly located in a garage in a "typical" San Francisco house in the Sunset area. The entrance is pretty small and not as flashy as any other restaurant around the block, which makes it stand out a little. The place itself is tiny thus creating an intimate, cozy, warm, and welcoming atmosphere when dining here.

+ Overall & other notes
Parking is really hard to find on some days and getting a table might take a while (a long time). Be prepared to wait. However, the food and the atmosphere are great for late night munchies or simply for a dinner. Definitely a place to try out!
author: Alex L.

description:
This restaurant is inside a garage, the front entrance is a bit odd but the inside is really cozy and cute. I love how this spot is open late and has a nice variety of sojus. We ordered the Kimchi Fried Rice, french fries with garlic & cheese and the Spicy Rice Cake Soup with udon. I am a fan of their rice cake soup, the broth has lots of flavor nor is it spicy at all.  

For drinks we ordered the watermelon soju, which I wouldn't recommend. I don't think these two mix well together - the soju had a strong aftertaste. I want to come back and try their Kiwi Soju. 

I've found it hard to find a nice Korean restaurant in SF, but Toyose overall exceeded my expectations. They have good food/drinks and ambiance, I would recommend this over Tonight Soju Bar. The only downside is this spot is really small, so the wait does get pretty long so I recommend calling ahead of time and trying to make a reservation.
author: Karen C.

description:
The last time I was in town we spontaneously came here and had such fond memories. I had to come back! Let me start by saying I love Korean and I come from humble Ohio. 

This is a small location, a handful of tables on the inside, there is a homey nautical charm when you first step in and usually a wait. When we arrived on a Tuesday night about 8, we didn't have to wait too long. I can see how there could be a long wait but it's all about timing! The food was amazing, great for sharing, they had a lot of great offerings and filled us up! Well priced soju if you wanna get your drank on, we had the mango flavor. Definitely recommend:
**kimchi soup - for those cold days
**spicy wings - extra crunchy & delicious
**kimchi fried rice - can't go wrong!

Can't wait to come back!
author: Daniel P.

description: It was 1:30am and my cousins and I were hungry. We were right around the corner from this diamond in the rough! More like the garage of a house in the Sunset district, by the beach. Lychee soju was THE BEST lychee soju I've ever had. It has real lychee in it, it's cold and it's enough for 4 people to take 4 healthy shots! Go!!! It's opened til 2am!!
author: Ryan A.

description:
yummy Korean comfort food ! really recommend the JAPCHAE and the lychee SOJU !!

don't judge a book by it's cover, cause the store definitely looks closed/ deceiving from the outside (yes, it's built in a garage :O). but the inside is pretty cozy and there's quite a good amount of tables! cute ambiance w/ some christmas lights

came here w/ a party of 12 for a bday dinner & we ordered family style~ other recommendations: 
- kimchi fried rice
- dukbokki/ spicy rice cake (really good, but a bit tooo spicy for me)
- chicken wings (crispy, &not that spicy at all!)
- seafood pancake

We also got cheese & corn (pretty good), kimchi soup was ok, but however I didn't really like the spicy calamari salad. Also gave small bowls of popcorn before our meal :OO

SOJU !!! really really good, especially the lychee. We also ordered strawberry & watermelon, each one had small bits of fruit, yums! In the end, price was very good for all the food we ordered + drinks !!

service was nice & accommodating, they also have those buttons to press. +++ stars cause our server came out with plastic plates & forks when she saw we brought a birthday cake, aww thanks :)
author: Christine T.

description: Joined a friend who lived in the neighborhood for dinner. Loved this spot. Kimchi fried rice, chicken wings and Kimchi/Seafood pancake plus a big bottle of beer. And they're open late-night! Looking forward to returning soon :)
author: Mike J.

description:
Whenever I am craving Korean food I always go to Toyose. The only problem is that I am always out of money after I go! This is a pretty pricey Korean restaurant but the food is delicious! I recommend getting one of their hot pots so that you can share with friends and the bill will be a little cheaper. Their fried chicken is also a very delicious dish to share as well as their kimchi fried rice and pancake. Toyose's portions are a good size so I wouldn't recommend getting their appetizers unless you are extremely hungry and/or willing to spend. 

Sometimes the wait can get long and especially how the place is like a hole in the wall. Space is very limited! So I would try to call ahead and set up reservations (I'm not sure if they do that). I do know, however, that they do do to-go orders! So whenever you're in the Bay Area and crave some Korean food give Toyose a try!
author: Kaitlyn K.

description:
Boo Dae Jun Gol was pretty good. Good amount of spam and meat, just what I needed when I was feeling sick! I would come here again. We went early and we got a table pretty easily but the place can fill up quickly! 
Hefty prices compared to other korean spots I been to.
author: Andrew S.

description:
This review isn't for the food, but for the waitress who took my friends whiskey bottle OUT OF HER BACKPACK and "confiscated" it from us like we were 5 year olds. We were not drinking it in your restaurant and we ordered 3 big bottles of soju from your establishment. The whiskey was for activities after the restaurant (chugging in the uber lol). 

You basically stole something out of our backpack and accused us of drinking it in the restaurant. She picks up our beer cup and smells it. HEY GUESS WHAT?! DID IT SMELL LIKE BEER?! cause that's all that was in it. 

I want my 16% gratuity back, you rent-a-cop.
author: Katie M.

description:
Due to the expected Saturday-Night-Long-Wait, I've decided to call for pick up instead. 
Kimchi Fried Rice - a must.
Spicy Chicken Wings - a must.
If you are a big fan of calamari like me, definitely try the calamari with rice cake! (Well, I do order it every time except today)
Too bad they don't sell soju to-go :( I love Kiwi, Yogurt, Pineapple.....soju except Strawberry)
author: Elaine Y.

description:
The food here is prrrretty good, and I'm generally unimpressed by Korean bar food. But the service was disappointing to me, and I didn't even expect awesome service since it was a Saturday night and pretty packed. We came here for a belated birthday celebration, and there were six of us. The waitress checked on us maybe once, never smiled, and forgot about the birthday cake we'd given her earlier before bringing the check. Also, I didn't realize this until later, but we didn't get any side dishes at all. For the pretty pennies this place charges for mediocre portions, the service was lacking.

The inside is crowded and stuffy, with spindly chairs and tables. We made a reservation since this place is tiny (yes, it's actually a garage), and it took a short time to get seated. 

Strawberry and kiwi soju:
The strawberry and kiwi soju (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=blBLAko7I1qcUK0bUsGfHA#sJoUwcRP_WQEpdGm5eqZMg) were tasty, and my friend did this nifty thing where he made rainbow shots (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=blBLAko7I1qcUK0bUsGfHA#WJpl9T_tj189pLmRYPqnGg) by layering the two. I don't know if they were super strong, but I didn't really taste the soju at all.. I think they used real fruit though, which I was a fan of. The bottles that these come in have small openings, so sometimes you need to pop the top and reinsert it before the liquid starts flowing. The price wasn't too bad for the amount.

Spicy fried chicken wings:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=blBLAko7I1qcUK0bUsGfHA#ZzKKqvqHLXLqlzqZSFRyoQ)
This was okay, nothing special. I felt like the temperature was the best part: piping, piping hot. The flavor was unmemorable, and I don't think I would get this again.

Beef kimchi fried rice:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=blBLAko7I1qcUK0bUsGfHA#79EVJ-9sz_Jcsl7p_UiGwQ)
So every time I go to a new Korean place, there always seem to be reviews claiming that the kimchi fried rice there is "the best." I was really surprised when I tasted the kimchi fried rice here, and I think it really is the best I've ever had. I don't know what it is, but maybe it's the fact that they use ground beef, which distributes the beefy flavor more evenly and potently throughout the rice. The rice itself was maybe a tiny bit on the sticky side, but it was very well mixed and the flavor is unparalleled. The portion was mediocre, but I would definitely get this again.

Kimchi seafood pancake:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=blBLAko7I1qcUK0bUsGfHA#6o2Pj1wOxSKvsf33lsUrlQ)
I've never seen kimchi seafood pancake before (usually it's just seafood pancake), so I was excited to try this. It tastes like seafood pancake.. with a bit of sour distributed throughout. It was slightly undercooked in the middle so that the batter was a little soggy, and I do remember thinking that it was a little thinner than ones I've had at other places.

Seafood stew:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=blBLAko7I1qcUK0bUsGfHA#bn8LmUdbAqutq86jLxOzjQ)
I was actually really impressed with this stew. For almost $30, I was skeptical about how worth it this would be, but it came in a huge pot with a personal stove and frozen udon (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=blBLAko7I1qcUK0bUsGfHA#GgSea5QhWyFIAlRsit3sPg) on the side. There was a generous portion of all kinds of seafood inside, including blue crab, octopus, head-on shrimp, fish (bone-in pieces), tofu, and vegetables. The ingredients all tasted pretty fresh, and this was more than enough to share. The soup flavoring was maybe a little one-dimensional since it was just spicy, but the seafood was delicious. 

When the waitress did finally bring out the birthday cake (after I reminded her twice), it was still in the box it came in.. I was a little dismayed at that, but maybe that was a miscommunication since I didn't specify that she should take it out of the box. That's never happened before at other restaurants though.

The food was good, but maybe next time I'll get takeout..? Actually I'm not even sure they offer takeout..
author: Maggie X.

description:
Toyose is definitely the spot to go when wanting to drink and eat good drinking food with your friends. The place is a bit small, given that it was originally a garage. Not good for my 6'3 friend, but he managed haha. 

We ordered the lychee soju, along with several plates to share. Sharing is a must! We ordered the kimchi fried rice, chicken wings, seafood pancake, and japchae. Freakin good. Every dish really embodied that Korean flavorful that I know and love. The japchae was warm, which I'm used to having cold, but I scarfed it down anyway! I actually prefer it warm now. The seafood pancake was out of this world! They don't skimp on the seafood because every piece had good chunks of squid or shrimp. Definitely order this! 

Ooooooh. Toyose. Why so good?! Will be coming back!
author: Veda T.

description:
Came here twice with my girlfriend to see what the hype was all about. The first time I completely forgot what happened so I figured it is only right that I truthfully taste the food again to give it a fair review.

We ordered the kimchi fried rice, chicken wings, seafood pancake, bulgogi with calamari, kimchi tofu soup. The kimchi fried rice was the highlight of the meal, only dish worth coming back. 

After a more clear tasting of everything else, the bulgogi with calamari was subpar. Something thrown together in a hurry. The seafood pancake lacked ingredients and the batter was too soft (Fell apart). Wings were fried good but nothing special. I liked the kimchi tofu soup as it wasn't just spicy, but had a good sour flavor to it. But, I think it's overpriced as you only get a couple pieces of tofu and soup.

I can swear I thought the food tasted better the first time! Sadly, this place is more hype than anything. With the long waits per night, I don't think I am going to return anytime soon unless I am craving for some kimchi fried rice.
author: Ronny Y.

description:
Toyose is my go to place for soju cocktails ($11 per pitcher). Our group of 5 ordered the following flavors: yogurt, peach, mango, watermelon, and lychee (has pulp). My personal favorite is the mango and watermelon is a close runner up. I find these flavors refreshing. A great thing about these cocktails is that you can mix the flavors; a little bit of yogurt here, some watermelon....yum! There are so many fruity combinations you can make so definitely experiment with it. 

My friends and I waited for around an hour or less for a table. Since the restaurant was busy, only parties with everyone present were seated.
author: Katie C.

description:
Didn't know what to expect from this place that looks like a plain garage from the outside. Surprisingly the place fits a a good amount of booths, tables, and seats for the waiting area. It's really spacious for what seems like a really small garage.

Me and my girl friend ordered the military soup, a mixture of kimchi soup, spam, sausages, ramen noodles, and a whole bunch of other goodness. SO GOOD!! The bulgogi and calamari wasn't too shabby either. 

Now my favorite part.....soju :) They have a good selection of fresh cold fruit soju to choose from, including pineapple, aloe, peach, strawberry, watermelon, etc. as well as plain soju. I had the pineapple soju and it was really fresh. It served as a chase to the plain soju......great times :) 

Overall this is a small cozy place with good comfort Korean food. Definitely a great place to come eat and hangout and have a few (or a lot) of soju too!! :)
author: Amanda R.

description:
i didn't have a good experience the first time coming here, so i never wanted to come back until my friends convinced me to. i decided to give it a 2nd try and i definitely had a better experience haha. i recommend getting their hot pot dishes. i forgot which one my friends and i got but it was on a mini fire stove and the ingredients in the hot pot consisted of ramen, rice cakes, beef/pork?, carrots, and the soup was pretty darn spicy. but it was so goooood! i also recommend the seafood pancake, the corn cheese, and the kimchi fried rice! :D i do not recommend getting the fried chicken because you can barely taste the meat (it's so deep fried to the point where there is no meat left). oh yeah, you can't forget to order the flavored soju. it's a must if you're at a korean restaurant and soju bar! :P

tips: it's usually super busy around dinner time, so be prepared for the long waits. sometimes the waiters will try to rush you to pay the bill if they have a lot of customers. lots of meter parking but parking can be unpredictable sometimes. noise level is really loud, so you might have to talk louder. the food doesn't take that long to come out, plus they give you a bowl of popcorn while you're waiting haha.
author: Sylvia H.

description: Easily the best non-BBQ Korean food on the east side of SF. If you don't want long waits I recommend getting there by 630, but if you do have a long wait the bar across the street is a good time filler.
author: Jared T.

description:
I've been here twice and both times I had to wait at least 25-30 minutes. That isn't too bad for dinner, but I would recommend coming here on a weekday or when it is least packed because the wait is not fun especially when there is absolutely no room to wait inside, and being forced to stand in the cold outside is a bummer and absolute mood killer. ): 

I'm not a huge critic of Korean food but I would say their food is pretty standard. The atmosphere of the restaurant really helps create a comforting feeling. If you're craving korean comfort food that isn't too expensive, this is the go to spot! 

ALSO! I would highly recommend asking to be seated inside and not at the tables by the door. Not only will a long wait drive you mad, but having people stare at you eat while THEY wait and having the door constantly open (letting in the breeze) will drive you insane!!
author: Mary L.

description:
When someone tells you that this restaurant is actually the garage of a house, you can't help but think "I'm sorry, what did you just say?" but it's true. Toyose is the garage of a house and the atmosphere just works with this place. Parking is all on the streets in San Francisco. 

The inside of this place is cramped. Very cramped. Don't expect to just flow through the restaurant. Chances are... there's gonna be some "excuse me's" and sucking in your tummy in order to walk through. There's a decent amount of tables in here seeing as how it is like a garage so no complaints there. 

Came here with 9 other people so seating was a bit cramped, but you make do with what you got. We ordered their seafood pancake, chicken wings, and japchae and I can honestly say... delicious. Those chicken wings are worth bragging about. 

Since the main purpose of coming here was the drinks... the group got a ton of drinks. If I recall correctly, we got mango, lychee, aloe, pineapple, and yogurt soju and beer. The lychee soju was definitely my favorite. Tasted just like juice, lol. 

Overall, yeah. I definitely want to go here again when I can. I want more chicken wings gosh darn it! And soju... mostly the chicken, though. 

And I would like to dedicate this review to my cousin, Erica, who reads my reviews when she's bored at work. =)
author: Venus L.

description: Toyose is nice when you don't have to wait upwards of an hour for a table, which apparently happens a lot of the time. Most recently I found that coming in late (10 or 11) on a weekday means no wait at all, but the inside is still sufficiently active and noisy. Other than the waiting, most other aspects are on the positive side. It is definitely a small space and quite loud, while having the buttons at the tables makes getting attention easier. Kimchee fried rice and other greasy items are food staples, while the flavored sojus are popular drinks. I found that the samsachun is a new favorite of mine, with the fruit flavoring being subtle but very tasty.
author: Tony D.

description: This place has no instructions or servers announcement on how to get into the wait list. When everyone is waiting in the front door. The wait list sheet is actually hiding inside the restaurants. Also their food is pretty average, no as good as expected. As well as it's quite expensive. Not worth waiting in line.
author: Justin Z.

description:
Highly recommend the yogurt soju and then mix it with any other of the flavored sojus. Guaranteed good night!

The food was all solid but nothing stood out either. 

The restaurants in a dank little garage and there's usually a decent line/wait during normal dinner hours
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Gem of a place in Sunset. Full of character and good food. Soju drinks are unique and wonderful to experiment. Service hustles, while always being extremely busy.
author: TC C.

description:
I love going here when it's with a fairly bigger group - we can order more and share several dishes! It's always more fun like that right?? My go-tos, and also the seemingly popular dishes, (in no particular order) are

- kimchee fried rice; can't go wrong with this! 
- cheese corn; sounds so simple and boring yet tastes so0o0oo good!
- jap chae; love the texture of sweet potato/yam noodles... has a wonderful sesame/sweet taste!
- "spicy" chicken wings; not spicy at all! crispy and flavorful without being too salty!
-  seafood pancake; crispy yet chewy.. packed with seafood! love the dipping sauce that comes with it! 
-  kimchee spam casserole w/ramen; love a great kimchee soup with a kick.. plus ramen noodles and spam?? yes pleaseeeeee

Parking can be a bitch, but hey it's SF... there's definitely areas with shittier parking. Service has never been a problem; it's not all smiles and ass-kissing.. but waitresses/waiters are fast and they get the job done. I don't know how authentic this place is for you ~authentic gurus~, but it's authentic enough for me! The wait can be horrendous, but apparently they accept reservations!

Go with a big group! Order a lot! Share! Stuff your faces! Drink some soju if you like!
author: Kris C.

description:
Let's eat in somebody's garage? Okay!

Toyose is a very close-knit and authentic feeling Korean establishment. Despite the visible tightness of the restaurant, the tables are actually spacious and feels as if you have a secluded section to yourself due to the decor.

I visited for dinner with some friends on a weekday for dinner. We waited about an hour despite the place just opening. There is limited space for waiting inside, so hopefully you won't mind being outside in the cold. Parking is usually easy this deep in the Sunset/Noriega and free if you park off the main street. My friends ordered the Jap Chae, spicy fried chicken wings, seafood pancake, and kimchee fried rice and topped it off with a bottle of lychee soju. 

Jap Chae: It was nice to get a break from the usual cold Jap Chae and having it warm instead. 
Fried Chicken: Crispy and not spicy, but still flavorful. 
Seafood Pancake: What's not to love about these types of pancakes. It had a variety of seafood including squid and shrimp. The dipping sauce brought it all together.
Kimchee Fried Rice: That runny egg doe.
Lychee Soju: The lychee really thickens the soju, almost like a shot of yogurt. It had the perfect taste combination of fruitiness and alcohol.

It's nice to take a break from AYCE, and this is definitely a good place to do so.
author: Micki H.

description:
Eating in a garage was very interesting, the place is a little small though. 

My friend and I went there at 6PM on a Wednesday night right when it opened and when we opened the door, there were already 4 parties in front of us waiting! We immediately sat down and told the waitress that we're ready to order. The service was ok, the waiters and waitresses didn't seem too friendly or smiled much. I like how there's a call button for the waiters/waitresses in case we needed something. 

Besides the service, the food was delicious! We ordered kimchi fried rice, spicy chicken wings, and kimchi seafood pancake. For two people, trust me, that's a lot of food. The flavor was very flavorful for all three things, and the quantity was just right. I did feel that the chicken wings were kinda dry, but it might just be me. The sauce that comes with the pancake makes the pancake taste better for every bite. 

Everything was good and he price was affordable, typically just your average korean restaurant place.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
