This place is in a garage! Yes, a garage. There's even a call button you use to get a server's attention.

Walk to the middle of the restaurant and put your name down. My friends and I got a table just before the rush.

That said, we ordered a ton of food. 

Spicy pork
Chicken 
Udon
Calamari and bulgogi
Fried chicken wings

Overall, we enjoyed everything except for the calamari and bulgogi. It lacked flavour. The spicy pork was spicy enough but not overly spicy. I enjoyed the tempura udon immensely.

Parking was pretty easy in this neighborhood but it was a holiday weekend so that might be why. 

For all five items and a beer the bill was about $90 including tip. Next time we'll try the beef stew which is a favourite and maybe hotpot.
author: Amy J.

description:
Came here on a last minute vdate dinner and guurrll that shit too bombbb ( i hope someone gets this reference LOLOLOl) 

Apparentlyyy this used to be someones garage and daMN, they really renovated the shit outta the place. It's pretty nice and cute, they have about 4 booths once you step in and then an open space filled with tables and chairs after. The ambience that day was pretty romantic and date like. But i heard that the soju and drinks here are really good, so im sure that on some days, people are gettin drunk and it'll be a place to get turnttt up 

Anyways, this place is pretty popular, so it took us about 45 minutes to get a table. It was packedd. There is a bench to the side that people can sit and wait to be called. I could see the waitresses and hosts rushing around trying to make sure everyone was okay. Once we got seated, we were given free appetizer popcorn while we looked over the menus. We ordered --
-spicy rice cake (Ddukbokki/Tteokbokki): We had the ramen add-in which made it more filling. I cant take a lot of heat, but this was a good of spicyness for me. For those who can take more spicy, you would def feel a bit of a kick in the dish. REALLY GOOD. the rice cake and fish cake pieces are soft and chewy and the cabbage gives it a nice crunch.
-fried chicken wings: i heard these were really good, so i had to order them! they also come with a side of daikon. These worked well with me because when the spicyness would be too much for me, i would eat a piece of chicken and daikon to cool my mouth. The fried chicken was crunchy on the outside and meat was done really well. They had sliced cabbage on the side with some kinda sauce. The day we went, it was kinda dry.
-KIWI SOJU!: its realllyyy good. Theres def kiwi in there bc you can taste the pureed parts, but you can barelyy taste the alcohol. There are little kiwi seeds in them too. really refreshing and comes in a bigger version of the plentea bottlle lol. One soju bottle is good to share with two people. .....unless you wanna get drunk, you should def just order one to yourself hahahahaha

Parking is .....basically like anywhere in SF, SHITTY. LOL. but we found parking about 2 blocks away. not bad. Service could be a little better though, kinda spotty, but its okay. The food and ambience and decor really make up for it. Definately want to come back to try more food items though
author: Vivian H.

description: This place is amazing if you're hungry at midnight (they're open until 2am)!The portion size is great for the money you pay. Service is always amazing... there's a button you can press if you need help at your table for immediate service.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Great food!  Cute restaurant in a converted garage.  We waited approximately 30 minutes for a table for 3 on a recent Thursday night.  My 6'8" husband had to duck several places within restaurant to avoid hitting his head, but there are warning signs posted.  The server who seated us was very concerned that he was careful.

This was one of my favorite meals from our week in San Francisco.  Good service, very tasty food, large portions, and reasonable prices.  What more could one ask for?
author: Ruth C.

description: I came here twice so far so I thought I should write a review. I like it how once you get a table and order, they have a button that you can press to get the waiter/waitress to come and get whatever you need. As for the food, both times when I came with a group of friends, we both ordered spicy rice cake, soup (forgot the name of the one that I ordered), more appetizers, and wings. I thought the food tasted pretty good. What I also liked about this place was the way they treated us. The last time I was here, there was an incident that occurred and they helped us with it right away. I will definitely be coming back!
author: Amy H.

description:
Is it just me, or is it Tyose or is it Korean food in general??? But I found the food to be bland and lacking flavor.  We had  the calamari & beef dish- don't remember what it was called , the fried rice with an egg on top, the seafood pancake and the wings split between my friend and I.  

First of all... I let my friend order, and that's ok, but I didn't realize it would All be fried except for the calamari - beef dish ( was my favorite ).  

The wings were crispy and pretty good but nothing to write home about.  

The Seafood pancake didn't have any flavor at all except the oil it was fried in ( the oil was fresh, but I certainly didn't come here to  taste oil.  Also, all the seafood seemed like it came straight out of a bag from Costco and was not seasoned at all.  In fact the texture was like rubber and the flavor was totally lacking the robust flavors I like in food.

The fried rice also didn't taste like anything.  Sorry to say to all the other Yelpers trying to make this sound like the best rice in the world.  - if it had any flavor at all I would have been a little more satisfied.  

As for the wait staff, we received  2 napkins on our table for all this food and I ended up waiting about  10 minutes to catch the servers attention in order to request an additional napkin.   I mean- they were busy, so I'm not hating on them by any means, but it would of been real nice if they checked on us a little more often.  

We waited about 45 minutes for out table and I don't believe it was worth it. This is my humble opinion.    
on a positive note- I liked the ambiance.
author: Justin G.

description:
Hands down the best kimchi fried rice I've had yet! 

This tiny-garage-revamped-into-a-restaurant-space can cook up quite a delicious meal. Knowing the long waits it's infamous for, we arrived when it opened at 6pm and were seated promptly. It's cramped inside but the atmosphere and vibe felt very intimate and comfortable. 

We went ahead and ordered some of their popular items on the menu: kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, and spicy chicken wings. The spicy chicken wings came out first and they were very crispy! We enjoyed the light batter and were able to taste the semi-spicy flavor of the chicken as well, although the chicken itself was a bit dry. The seafood pancake was pan-fried nicely and generously filled with seafood. The star of the night though, the kimchi fried rice, took my expectations for this dish to a whole new level! It's well praised amongst Yelpers because the rice wasn't clumped together, kimchi wasn't spicy but contained the flavor (as it should be), and there was a good portion of meat, which many Korean restaurants tend to skimp out on. 

Definitely recommend trying this place if you're in the area...and of course, I'll be returning ;)!
author: Vivian L.

description:
When Yelpers wrote that this place was someone's garage, I thought they were just comparing it to someone's garage.. but when we got there, it really was a garage! It's pretty small, so if you don't like waiting, make sure you call and make a reservation. Your whole party has to be there at the time of your reservation otherwise they won't save your table! Over the phone, they told me they could seat a table for 7-8, and anything bigger would be harder. When we got there, my party of 8 was squeezed into one of the booths. (A REALLY tight squeeze - we joked that we had to finish all the food when it was served because we only had room on the table for the alcohol. We did end up trying to finish all the food so we had more space.)

- Dubboki with Fish Cakes: perfect amount of spiciness, but I wish there were more rice cakes! It seemed as if the whole dish was filled with fish cakes.
- Cheese Corn: lots of ooey-gooey cheese.. can't really mess up cheese corn, right? ;)
- Seafood Stew: at ~$26 a pot, I expected more from this dish especially since people raved about it and the pictures look awesome. We'd definitely skipping this dish next time for something else.
- Seafood Pancake: nothing *too* special.
- Kimchi Fried Rice: this dish did live up to its hype on Yelp. How did they make it so addicting!?

Soju ($12) Flavors: strawberry, mango (MUST GET!), peach, pineapple, yogurt, aloe (I LOVE aloe,  but this you can skip..), and kiwi (has kiwi seeds!). We tried to order the lemon and cranberry flavors, but those never came out. Not sure how those would've tasted though..

Beer pitchers are actually just those big bottles you see in the Korean supermarkets. They have Hite and OB!

The decor of this place isn't as modern as Tonight Soju Bar, but it's still kind of cute with the wooden dividers and benches. There is one unisex bathroom smack on the right hand side. The service was pretty good - our server seemed happy to fulfill all of our requests and the food/drinks came out fairly fast. I did wish they had better ventilation though - our party was pretty happy whenever the door opened because there would be a nice breeze!
author: Christine S.

description:
Hit or miss.

Some things here hit the nail on the head: kimchi pancake, spicy pork, beef bulgogi. Those things are amazing.

Other things on the menu are so-so. And some things coming out of the kitchen are outright garbage. The latter is referring to my experience from last night where the 10 dollars I though was funding an order of chicken katsu instead rendered two microwaved Banquet chicken patties served with a warm, unappetizing lettuce salad. 

  I thought maybe they ran out and thought it was better to sell something than nothing (it's not, btw), but then I saw that it's a mainstay here. There is a review on here praising the chicken katsu, which is laughable at best (look at the picture in Sam L's review, you can clearly see it's a processed frozen chicken patty). I don't usually get this bitter or petty on Yelp, but when you pay over 10 dollars for a dish, you expect it to not be from the freezer section at Costco. So I repeat, DO NOT ORDER THE CHICKEN KATSU, unless you like wasting money on something you could get for a fraction of the cost at 7Eleven.

  Also, the bulgogi and calamari sounds like a great idea, but it's disappointing. It's very watery and bland, with the flavor having been drawn out of the beef into the water and the calamari rubbery and flavorless as well. Just get the regular bulgogi. 

  Overall, I'd recommend this place, because their good items are very good, but you should go in prepared to learn expensive lessons via trial and error on what you shouldn't order.
author: J R.

description:
Tofu Kimchee (Kimchee & Spicy Pork & Vegetable served with Tofu)
^super good, loved the pork, very tender. It's just firm soft tofu. [:I don't think people really eat the veggies?

Rice Cake ((TTEOKBOKKI) Sauteed Rice Cake & Fishcake in hot Chili Paste)
^we added ramen to this: it was super delicious, I'd recommend. There were veggies, lots of fishcake, I didn't see any rice cake I think.. and some jalapenos that might be pickled, not sure since I didn't eat the pepper.

Seafood Pancake (Home style seafood and green onion pancake)
^octopus? or squid legs for seafood = yummy! comes with a dipping sauce, loved it.

Spicy Chicken Wings
^good, crispy, and come with pickled daikon cubes and also a little yummy salad on side (tiny)

French Fries
^didn't eat this too much, but we added garlic and cheese, it was bomb!

Kimchee Fried Rice
^bomb even though I didn't get to try it hot since me and my cousins got way to much food..

Strawberry Soju
^first experience with Soju, it was good. A little bitter for me? But, like I said first soju so I'm not sure what to expect, but everyone at the table said it was the best strawberry soju they ever had, so I'd recommend that. 

*Didn't get it, but my cousin and his girlfriend recommend the corn cheese!

***** I LOVED IT, I WOULD DEFINITELY GO HERE AGAIN. SUPER GREAT FOOD, NICE SERVICE (WHEN YOU PUSH THE BUTTON TO RING THEM UP), CUTE PLACE.. just amazing. [:
author: Lilian L.

description: I read some of the bad reviews below; no joke, I had not yet encountered any of these situations. They are very on top on their job. I eat there once or twice every month and never once been disappointed at their dishes. PS kimchi fried rice, must orders!!
author: Simon L.

description:
I actually come here to satisfy my korean food cravings vs my soju cravings. Occasionally we would order soju to accompany our meal. Not saying their soju is bad, it's decent and ~$11/bottle, but there's better soju cocktails out there.

First time I came here, I couldn't even find the place. Toyose means garage and it literally is a garage door outside. And after I found it, a table for 2 was like a 1.5 hr wait...say whattt? But it was a Friday night I guess. I recommend having a reservation. But there were occasions were I was seated with no wait! (miracle?)

You walk in and it's a long hallway of tables with bright lighting. Not your typical korean club/lounge scene, it actually looks like a sit down restaurant.

I always get their seafood pancake, chicken wings, and kimchi fried rice. You definitely won't be disappointed. I like it because it's crispy versus your wet glazed wings. Their seafood pancake is cooked to perfection with a good amount of seafood and flavorful. Their kimchi fried rice is sooo good. I have no idea why, but I like it more than other korean spots. Maybe they put MSG in it, jking...but maybe....? It could be because I find the beef more flavorful than spam, don't get me wrong I do like spam. But I guess the beef makes it different and stand out from your typical kimchi fried rice. Or maybe it's just that perfectly cooked fried egg that wins me over and the yellow river that flows over my rice that makes my mouth water.

Price isn't bad at all. I always leave stuffed and there's still leftovers! And I didn't break my bank either. I would definitely recommend eating family style.

Their service is quick and they have the service button since they're always running around and it's convenient. 

To sum it up, FOOD OVER SOJU.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
A small but cozy Korean spot - highly recommended by the locals. It was good but didn't blow me away by any means. I found most things to be rather heavy and oily. Their stuff was legit spicy. And the free side dishes were rather limited.

THE WAIT: 40 minutes (to the dot) at 7:30pm on a Sunday:

THE SERVICE: They're busy, but our server got things done fairly quickly and did her job.

* Peach soju - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=mx23XC8p4gyTSkU6-nHcyw#LwTmQzO5TVdPAL5KLE5lmg
You get a pretty big bottle (worth at least 7-8 shots), it comes out quick, and is tasty.

* Chicken wings - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=mx23XC8p4gyTSkU6-nHcyw#SElTLNyxk21o8QiX0De9qw
Crunchy breading, spicy, and tender meat. Good!

* Kimchi & Seafood pancake ($13.95) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=mx23XC8p4gyTSkU6-nHcyw#6cl_sRWvibMGYlNvn5_aEQ
Good - the pancake part was soft & chewy, and it was flavorful. There wasn't quite enough of the sauce for the amount of pancake. I found it a little heavy and oily though, and not quite as thick as other seafood pancakes I've had. I didn't really taste the kimchi either.

* Beef stew - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=mx23XC8p4gyTSkU6-nHcyw#HQtr0XQCtTsDhIDgkbVR9A
Very spicy. It seemed like the beef was more cartilage/fat than actual meat, and there was just way more onion and cabbage than even the better veggies like daikon radish & bean sprouts. There were very, very few vermicelli noodles which disappointed me. You do get a lot and it's fun having this on a portable stove on your table.

Sauteed items menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=mx23XC8p4gyTSkU6-nHcyw#mx23XC8p4gyTSkU6-nHcyw
House favorites menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=mx23XC8p4gyTSkU6-nHcyw#J295o7XpuMCYSdtDEHr2iQ
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Let me start by saying I was excited to come here after looking through the pictures on yelp. The food looked delicious, so I convinced my boyfriend to take me. This review, however, will not be about the food but about the service because the quality of service outweighed the quality of the food. 
My boyfriend and I decided to take my dad here for father's day. Things were going okay, until we paid for our food. After we paid for the food, my boyfriend went to the bathroom. While my boyfriend was in the bathroom, my dad and I stayed at the table talking and  packing our leftovers to go. That's when one of waitresses (who wasn't even our server) rudely interrupted us asking if we were paying tip. I've never encountered a server asking for tip before, and especially not as rudely as she did. Due to her rudeness, we decided not to leave tip. As we were leaving, that same waitress actually chased us down (mind you we were sitting at the back of the restaurant), yelling as we were passing customers, and all the way to the exit. She was adament about us paying tip, so my father responded by asking if it was mandatory. She then goes on to argue with my dad ON FATHER'S DAY! That's when my boyfriend steps in and tells her "we are not legally obligated by law to tip you."  She then has the nerve to respond "don't ever come back again." U serious? U weren't our waitress and you're not the owner. But to be honest, you didn't need to tell us that because we definitely won't be back after how you treated us. To the owner, please talk to your employees or hire better workers. Our experience was THAT bad that it caused me to take the time to write this. I've never taken the time before to write a review on yelp.
author: Arlene C.

description:
The waitress here has the worst attitude! My table of 5 had waited over an hour and a half to be seated and ordered multiple rounds of soju and food so you'd think they'd be a little bit nicer! We also saw our table empty for a good ten minutes before one of my friends pressed the call button so the waitress could come clean it for us so we could finally sit down wtf. 

Ordered five bottles of flavored soju. Plain soju is the same price so we just ordered the flavored ones. Strawberry and pineapple were the favorites. Waitress had a serious problem with my friend and didn't even bring her a shot glass until we asked her for one. 

We were also charged 18% gratuity even though we only had 5 people wtf. Fraudulent business practices!!! I'm sure she did it on purpose because she knew she wouldn't have been getting a tip otherwise. Be careful if you have five to a group too because they crammed us into a table only big enough for four and I barely had room to move my arm to eat. Kimchi fried rice is good but a small portion. Love the seafood pancake we ordered a second one! I wish they had bibimbap here. I wonder if its a regional thing.
author: Tiffany V.

description: Very noisy, small place but food are great. They don't take restoration for 2 or 3 people however they do take a big group hmmmm ????? The wait forever long...... allow extra time waiting to be seated 2 hours or more ):-----
author: Lili L.

description: I love that the place is in a garage because from the inside, I would never guess. They decorate very well and the lighting is very cute and dimly lit. However, this is not a romantic spot because it is a pretty frequent spot for rowdy drinkers. The food is pretty standard for casual Korean food and drunk food, but it is a bit on the pricier side in my opinion. The corn cheese is super gooey and tasty, but may be a bit pricey for what you are getting.
author: Edmund L.

description:
Great place for KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) and soju. Other than that, Toyose is not the first place I'd go to if you're craving Korean food although the classic comfort food favorites are solid: Kimchi / seafood pancake, kimchi fried rice and ddukbokki. I personally feel they can enhance if they simply their menu a bit and add beef/BBQ to their menu but appears they are quite popular regardless. 

Like everyone has mentioned the exterior is truly deceiving. The interior is dark and cozy and the front dining section almost had an Asian slash tiki bar feel. Each booth had a partition you can roll down if you want your area to be more private and cozy. So yeah a complete 180 from whatever you've conjured up about this restaurant based on the aesthetics from the other side of that door.  

The place gets packed after 7-7:30pm so try to arrive early if you don't want to wait.
author: Esther A.

description:
Yea. So this is probably the first time I have ever eaten at Toyose 100% completely sober.  

This is just one of those places that tastes better when you're inebriated. I've also learned how to make my own kimchi fried rice. It's so easy that I don't bother going out for it. I also make my own kimchi. 

Portions are larger than what I remember. However they only give you 4 banchans and are skimp about it. They'll refill it though. 

The worst thing I had here was the cheese corn. It is way too darn overcooked. The cheese is supposed to be gooey!! Yea, the cheese corn at Toyose has a hard brown crust. I even looked at all the other tables who ordered it. Same golden brown crusty top. Know what else? They use the bags of frozen mixed veggies. You know what I'm taking about, corn / carrot / PEAS. I've never freaking had carrots LET ALONE PEAS in korean cheese corn. So disgusting. We barely touched it and my friend actually picked around the carrots and peas. 

Still, I guess it's okay to come to and drink. I'm over it, the crowd annoys me here. LOUD. LOUD. LOUD. Even when the booze hasn't started flowing yet! I know we are in garage but GEEZUS there's no need to SHOUT to the person SITTING RIGHT NEXT TO YOU. And if you're on a diet, STFU ABOUT IT. DON'T GO OUT TO EAT!! Ugh. Children.
author: Susy C.

description: This hole in the wall delivers great food. Service was average. The wait around dinner time is about an hour, but since its pretty close to Ocean Beach, the wait didnt seem that long. I do like how they dont hover to wait to take your order, instead there's a call button thats super convenient. My friend and I ordered the fish liver hot pot along with the seafood pancake. Both were delicious.
author: Teresa C.

description:
Must try: Beef Kim chee fried rice. Seafood pancake. Strawberry soju.

OK items/I wouldn't miss them: Spicy pork. Buckwheat noodles. Spicy stew with tofu, spam, hotdog.  

Smell like the food when you leave.

Waited about 40 minutes for table of 6.
author: Jenn D.

description:
Toyose must be the Korean version of a speakeasy.

Hiding behind the garage doors is a variety of flavored soju and some good, spicy Korean bar food. Everybody has their favorite flavored soju, but you can't go wrong with Yogurt! If you're feeling hardcore, you can order the non-flavored ones. It's a little nasty to me, but different strokes for different folks.

For food, I like the Kimchee Fried Rice and the Spam Casserole. The casserole comes in a hot boiling bowl of soup with some ramen dumped inside. But they put so little ramen in the bowl so it's actually not as filling as it looks. I've always wondered if I could bring my own pack of Shin Ramen to go with the Casserole, but maybe it's frowned upon. The casserole looks super spicy because of the color, but it's just a front. Even my granny can eat this no problem.

Seeing as how this is kind of a Korean speakeasy, you may not have a lot of luck trying to flag down the waitresses. Instead, there's a little bell on the wall for you to buzz discreetly when you want to order a second round of soju : )
author: Ringo M.

description:
Don't judge a book by it's cover!  The outside of this place looks like a house.  I'm pretty sure the owners converted a house into the restaurant.  There isn't much around this restaurant, just houses and maybe a convenience store around the corner.  When my friends and I walked into toyose it was packed!  The whole place is small, so it gets filled up quick!  There was a lot of people in the waiting area.  My friend made reservations, but they won't set you until your whole party has arrived.  Half of our party was running late, so we had to give up out reservation.  When our whole party finally arrived they were very  accommodating.  We didn't have to wait too much longer till we got a table.  The place is very small that your table could be right next to people waiting to be seated.  Definitely try to get a reservation if you don't want to be waiting for a long time.  

Okay onto the good stuff!  My group got the seafood pancake, kimchi fried rice, and spam stew.  When the pancake and fried rice came, I was wondering if we would have enough food for the group.  Then came the spam stew, it's huge!  Let me break down the meal: 

Kimchi fried rice- ohhhh soo soo good!  I wish it was a bigger plate!  It had good kimchi flavor and the fried egg on top was perfectly cooked.  

Seafood pancake- the pancake is pretty big!   I didn't expect it to have so many pieces.  Lots of seafood bits in it.  Some of seafood did tasted a little over cooked, but over all good flavors! 

Spam stew- huge pot! Definitely need a group to devour this!  The stew had a good amount of spicy flavor.  There was a square piece of those dry ramen that you can buy at super market placed in the stew.  The stew pot came on a portable stove so you can cook the ramen in the stew.  In the stew were pieces of spam, hot dog, tofu, fish cake, rice cake, veggies, and ramen.  There was definitely a lot of meat, but I wish there was more ramen.  The flavors were flavorful.  

Yogurt soju- came in a pretty decent size bottle.  This was my first time having soju and it wasn't bad.  Didn't know what to expect from it.  I could definitely taste the alcohol with a little yogurty flavor.  My group of four got 4-5 rounds of shot glass size servings from the bottle.  

This place is pretty busy, so you'll probably won't get too much attention from your waitress, but they do try to check up on you if you need water or more food once in a while.  

Toyose is really good and filling! Will definitely be coming back!!!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Sleeper alert... well, maybe not since there are so many reviews on this Outer Sunset restaurant/bar.
In what looks to be a converted home, this sleepy dining establishment is home to, what I would describe, Korean fusion food.  Arriving just after 6 pm on a Wednesday evening, parking was a breeze and there was no wait for a booth table near the entrance.  Being my first visit here, I left the menu to my friends who both have dined here before.
Dining family style, here's what we ordered:

1) Seafood pancake (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=eU3zYVkPdzj9OdpYjlD8nw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Nicely cook and served hot with a tangy dipping sauce.

2) Fried chicken (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Tmbx1dzbfDGT8sFeSM_KCw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My hosting friend insisted on this since the restaurant always ran out before he could order it. Lightly crusted, crispy fried chicken worked very well with the pepper salt dip.

3) Kim Chee fried rice - Nothing spectacular, but glad the rice was not mushy.

4) Spam stew (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=U5llt2l7q5uFZeOSUATcAA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Yes, look at the picture and marvel at the ingredients.  As the broth boiled and the ingredients literally disintegrated into the soup, this became a interesting mix of both flavors and textures.  The ingredient mix (Spam, Vienna sausage slices, chives, Napa cabbage, rice cake, and, yes, ramen noodles... probably missed something here).  If you like Spam and sausages, this dish will warm you  on those cold winter Sunset nights.

The portions being targeted for family style were generous and the prices reflected it (Spam stew was $23.50).  They also provided a variety of banchan that included Kim Chee cabbage, marinated bean sprouts, pickled cucumbers, and bow tie pasta salad.  
Midway through the meal, we noticed people coming in and seating themselves on a bench across the walkway from our table so definitely recommend coming early or probably late for dinner.  As the number of waiting customers increased, our waitress kindly pulled down some wooden blinds to project some impression of privacy.  There is a service buzzer at each table in case you need the waitress' help.  
I wouldn't look at this as a destination dining spot, but more of one of those "if-you're-in-the-neighborhood" places, especially for late night dining judging by their hours of operation.
author: Mike C.

description:
I wasn't too happy this time around because we came pretty early but were pretty much seated last after groups that arrived after us... 

The hostess kept changing up the order that we were going to be served and seemed very confused even though our name was clearly at the top of the board. She told us we were next, then fifth, then second...? Not too impressed. 

Prices went up and portion sizes got smaller. Definitely not worth the hype it used to be. Tonight soju bar down 19th would be a better time.
author: Cece C.

description:
I won't be back, due to the unprofessional and rude service. We got to our table at around 1:10am and were told that last call is in a few minutes... fine. It's late. I get it. But literally less than a minute later, the waitress swiftly asked us for our order. I didn't really have time to look at the menu,  although I did try my best to skim and look for the kimchi fried rice, to no avail. I asked if they served kimchi fried rice. She said yes and I remember saying in a low voice, "We'll do that." We ended up not receiving the kimchi fried rice... we kindly asked where that was, and she got extremely defensive and almost argued with me. Apparently, I specifically only asked her if their restaurant served kimchi fried rice-- I didn't actually order it. I found it ridiculously comical, because if you as a server came to a table to take an order, and someone asks you whether a dish was available, wouldn't you assume that they were at least interested in ordering it and confirm? Moreover, why would we eat two plates of meat with no rice? We got the check, promptly gave our cards, and even then, we were rushed and asked to sign the checks right away. Mind you, this is well before 2am and there were still people in the restaurant. I get that their customers are mostly groups of rowdy and drunk people, but we were a completely sober table of two that simply wanted a late night meal. 

The food wasn't anything to write home about. I hope they can improve their customer service, because feeling like livestock being pushed out with electric prods in a restaurant is a turn off.
author: Pia D.

description:
Im really picky with korean food especially since my mom always cooked korean food for me growing up but really enjoyed the food here .
Maybe it was also the 1am cravings but the nakgee bok-um (spicy octopus?) was so yummy ! Never had it before with udon noodles but it was really interesting with udon noodles and tasty!
I love how the restaurant is a garage also and the interior is adorable which is always a plus!
author: Julia K.

description: The small server is extremely aggressive. Beware this lady is ready to be rude to you if she can't go home early. (Why is she working there?!) NOT PROFESSIONAL AT ALL.  and i clearly heard her saying 'fuck you bitch' in Korean. The owner needs to fire her otherwise all your customers are gonna leave.
author: Hyunha K.

description:
The food is good and I love their beef casserole. It's really flavorful and packs with lots meat. Also, they have the best kiwi soju in town. 

The reason I give the restaurant a 1 star,because of their service.  We came here for a friend's for birthday dinner, of course we would order drinks. One of waitress was super rude. When i was ordering some drinks, she suddenly turned around and served another table. For me to get her attention back, I repeated what I wanted to order. She turned around and SHOUT " CALM DOWN" at me that she hear my requested and she said yes. Her back was facing me. Sorry, I don't have the ability to read lip from your back. I understand that you might be busy but no need to be super rude to your customers. If she is so rude to the customers, I don't think she is suitable for food industry.  We, customers come to the restaurant want to enjoy our meal and have a good time not come to get SHOUT by a waitress.
author: Stacy L.

description:
2nd time here, the soupbase for seafood hot pot was not very strong or spicy..
drafted the review above sometime ago and I don't remember it at all, I guessed that's why I gave a 3 stars lol
author: Jane D.

description:
4-Stars if your purpose was to come here to drink and snack
3-Stars if your purpose was to have an actual dinner

Yes, I've been here in both occasions and I can understand the high ratings due to the Soju and kimchi fried rice what not. BUT, coming here for dinner isn't really all that great. Food is mediocre and the price is DEFINITELY not cheap. 

Yes, kimchi fried rice and the seafood pancake were probably the best two things on their menu. Still though, the rice could have had a bit more flavor of some sort. Seafood pancake is doughy, but, I like it like that. Oooooh, and who could forget the soju? Hard to taste the alcohol = the dangerous kinds 

The biggest disappointment was their fried chicken wings. Where's the meat? Pretty disappointing. Flavor was okay, though. Their tofu and hot pot items were also a total let down. It didn't feel authentic as the broth tasted like hot water, with the ingredients just tossed in. 

It's different. Dining with friends and dining with parents. Friends, you care more about the drinks and food is more the bonus. Dining with parents, you actually experience the food. I felt bad bringing my parents here because it was totally OVERHYPED and not worth. I know there's a wait, but I never understand the why people would wait.
author: Fiona L.

description:
Toyose is a quirky little Korean Restaurant out by the beach that's perfect for late-night eats & soju cocktails or a remedy for the next morning's hangover. Upon arrival you realize it's hidden in a repurposed garage and can smell the delicious food as soon as you open the door. The location, along with the interesting decorations and cozy ambience, make it a fun place to have some flavorful Korean specialties. 

When you get inside make sure to sign-in on their list towards the back of the restaurant so the waitress can seat you sooner. Its a small restaurant and is usually crowded so expect a moderate wait. We had a party of two on a Friday night and only waited 15 minutes or so. 

My girlfriend and I ordered the Toyose spicy fried chicken wings, Seafood stew casserole, shrimp fried rice, and a bottle of OB beer. 

The chicken wings weren't very spicy, but still decent, and paired well with the OB. The Seafood stew casserole came out on a burner and was full of squid, octopus, fish, shrimp, tofu, an assortment of vegetables and some ramen. It had a rich, spicy broth that's great for warming up on a cold night or winding down after a night of drinking. The shrimp fried rice was okay, but I'd probably go with the kimchee fried rice next time. 

Overall Toyose was an enjoyable experience and would be a great choice to have a fun night of food and drinks with friends.
author: Phi P.

description: Has the best soju in town. Has fresh fruit mixed on soju. How about that, right. Unmatched. Open late.
author: Faustino R.

description: Overrated and overpriced. Came here cause of the hype, but I left disappointed. We ordered seafood soybean paste soup, fried chicken, and japchae. First, the fried chicken was dry and flavorless. Second, no Korean side dishes, no white rice with the soup and no free tofu soup or steamed egg. For similar prices, much better food at a nearby location, I would choose Shin Toe on Taraval.
author: Tracy Q.

description:
If you find yourself hungry in the Outer Sunset at 11pm... not all hope is lost. There's Toyose!

When you get here don't let the line discourage you, it generally goes by pretty fast. Just be patient... I promise you the kimchi beef fried rice and those crispy chicken wings will be worth the wait. 

(if you don't like waiting, call and make a reservation beforehand)

This place is super comfy (it's a converted garage), has some tasty Korean dishes, and numerous flavors of Soju (you really can't go wrong with any of the flavors).

One of my favorite spots to visit whether for dinner or for a late-night snack.
author: Reina B.

description:
This is a converted garage and you might miss the entrance if you're not looking closely.  They have limited seating and it was packed on a Tuesday night.  Parking is easy to find.

The seafood pancake was burnt but had less dough so it was good.  The spam/sausage stew was very generous and came with ramen.  The portions here are ridiculously generous and you can share with 4 people.  

This is a good place if you are willing to take a hike to the outskirts of SF.  Bring another jacket.  And there is limited air circulation so your clothes will smell - wear something that is easy to wash.
author: Chris L.

description: This place is in a basement of a house in Sunset district of San Francisco. However, don't underestimate the greatness of this restaurant. The fried chicken (whole or wing) are authentic yet creative. The fish intestine soup is second to none, in taste as well as in specialty, found in any other Korean restaurants in town. The staffs are very friendly. Especially to kids, with popcorn and biofeel (a kind of nutritional drink for kids), they can easily capture favor of children.
author: Liming Y.

description: shit place. Waiters are mean. When I ask how many people in front of me. They said I don't know. What means by u don't know?? And fuking noisy.
author: Christina C.

description:
Best Korean food I've had in a while & no surprise it's located in SF...but a garage?! After getting over the initial shock & walking into the garage it turns out to be a decent restaurant.

Luckily, I came in right when it opened so my party was seated right away. Service was slow but it seemed busy after we got seated.

Seafood pancake - made just right. You can actually taste the seafood not like other places where the flour buries the seafood.

Kimchi soup - hot & spicy, just how I like it!

Beef with calamari platter - sizzling & flavorful.

Mango soju - you cannot taste the soju AT ALL. One of those drinks you can drink forever & next thing you know you're on the floor. Jk. Actually no, that might happen. Lol, drink with caution!

Kimchi fried rice - topped with a fried egg on top. Amazing! I love everything about this dish. If I was to have my last meal on earth, this dish might actually make it to that list. This is a must try!
author: Anne P.

description: Food is mediocre but really hits the spot when you're drinking. If you want specifically Korean food there are better spots in the city. What's nice is that this is essentially a garage turned restaurant tucked away in a residential district by the beach. They serve soju and if you come early enough on the weekends the wait is the minimal.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Been wanting to try this place for a while now and finally had the chance to do so this past weekend. My friends and I arrived a little before they opened, and there were already several small parties before us! We all waited until the workers were ready to seat us. Overall, I think this is a good spot to chill over some decent Korean comfort food. Very chill atmosphere with Korean music playing :)

We ordered croquettes, calamari and noodles (spicy), seafood soy bean paste soup, and the seafood pancake. Everything was really good -- potatoes deep-fried into goodness; noodles tossed with hot pepper paste, calamari pieces, and veggies; a subtle spiciness that came from the chili peppers that snuck into our soup; and lots more calamari pieces in the seafood pancake. We had a lot of calamari that night. Service was pretty good for a busy place (maybe we got lucky); the lady came to check on us every time we pressed the service button on the wall.

Will definitely come back to try their chicken wings (especially after the smell wafted over from the table behind us before our food came...  made me regret immediately for not getting those wings). I also heard their kimchi fried rice is worth a try!

Yup, a fan.
author: Sara T.

description:
First off, my party of 5 was charged 18% gratuity fee when the menu clearly states that gratuity fee is added on for parties of 6+.

The food is a bit more pricey than other Korean restaurants I've been to, but the portions are large. Had kimchi fried rice and BBQ spicy pork. The kimchi fried rice tasted ordinary to me and didn't meet expectation. The BBQ spicy pork was very disappointing. They put it on a charcoal plates like most korean restaurants. The spicy pork was very burned and made the whole dish taste bitter.

Service was average. Waitresses didn't go above and beyond nor did they ignore us.

Overall, not worth the hour wait and money when you want good Korean food.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Hands down the best Kimchi fried rice I've had!
Probably my favorite Korean restaurant in SF, even though it's in a garage! Kimchi fried rice is a must have, and I usually switch it up between the stew or fried chicken wings+another dish for party of 2. The portions are really big(eps the stew), so we often end up with plenty of leftovers. The service is great, parking is convenient and free since it's located in a residential area. One of my to-go places!
author: Sharie H.

description:
My first experience coming here (sometime in 2016) was great. It was a long wait for a big group, but we didn't mind. It was a trendy interior, but small space. Took a while for the waitress to take our order, but we were quickly served afterwards. The seafood stew was little too salty for me, but the whole chicken and beef fried rice was absolutely delicious! I was a little disappointed that kimchi seafood pancake wasn't as delicious as the reviews said. Also, no water refills and napkins were given.
I went back in March 2017 for dinner and ordered the cheesy corn and the shrimp fried rice. I thought the shrimp fried rice was delicious, but the cheesy corn was not as amazing as I remembered. It was surprisingly filling for 2 people. A week later, I came back with a small group and I got the beef fried rice. My partner ordered the calamari with rice cake and it was delicious, but no napkins and no water refills again! 

-2 stars for service. Since my first visit I haven't seen an improvement in accommodating the customers. No napkins and no water refills, we weren't even checked on. We were sitting right next to where the waiters and waitresses were too. Did I really need to reach over the table to press the button to talk to them from my seat or get their attention? Also, it took forever to get our bill and even longer to get it back. (Still seated with the register in plain view and still no check after 10-15 minutes)
Food is a bit pricy, but you really pay for the atmosphere and ambiance.
author: Sabrina H.

description:
The concept of eating in a garage maybe cool but the fact that every table orders the hotpot makes the place stuffy and uncomfortable quite quickly. There were 2 people serving the entire restaurant so not only we stood beside an empty table for 20mins, we were told by the waitress that she was too busy so she couldn't take our order - this was a first. 
We got the fried chicken wings which are not as legendary as some has described, the kimchi fried rice is only okay, the kimchi stew was extremely salty. I have never been to a Korean restaurant where a soup stew was not served with plain rice - this was another first. 
The restaurant is almost completely sealed so it tends to get quite loud, not a pleasant experience. 

There were many firsts at Toyose but none of them are good. There are way better places than Toyose, if you're into fried chicken Shin Toe Bul Yi is MUCH better.
author: Da D.

description:
What's your first impression of Korean food? Side dishes? A lot of side dishes? Side dishes served right after you put your order?
Well, for this place, only "side dishes" fits. 
It's actually our second time here, though for some reason I don't have that much memory left from the first visit except that the food we ordered last time was not bad. Plus this place is literally a garage---fun fact, no? 
We ordered a kimchi fried rice, fried chicken wings, kimchi beef hot pot(yes, HOT POT).
After a while the fried rice was served, but no sign of side dishes. We had to ask for them. Then they gave us four dishes. Only four, and not even that tasty. Later my husband reminded me that they didn't serve side dishes at all last time. Hmm...
While we were waiting, we saw this fancy soup hot pot and we really wanted to try that so we ordered kimchi hot pot. Then they gave us kimchi soup and said, ya, it's hot pot. The fancy hot pot like thing we saw was something else. Seriously??? Challenging common sense???
Anyways, food is okay. 
Oh and people work here all have this "I hate my job and I hate the world" look on their faces. No one taught them how to smile??? 
Too bad the last time I didn't quite pay attention to a lot of things, which led to today's experience. What I do know is, this will be my last visit here. And I'll tell my friends to never come. 
They are lucky this place is a garage---SF people are really into this kind of "pretentious" stuff, myself included. Otherwise with all the great Korean restaurants with awesome service around, why would any one come here?
author: Lina M.

description:
After having it bookmarked for years I finally dragged some friends out to Toyose. 

Went with the most talked about Yelp items: beef Kim Chee fried rice, spicy fried chicken wings, corn cheese, and soju: pineapple and strawberry. 

Nothing disappointed. Everything was delicious. 

Best Kim Chee fried rice I've ever eaten. The chicken wings were just okay but still better than BonChon. The corn cheese was an interesting concept. So simple yet so good. Would have preferred more corn but still delicious. The soju flavors will delicious. Can't wait to try more.
author: Dina V.

description: Toyose was a good place to be for a late night snack. At 11:30pm on Saturday night, the place was well packed. We ordered some of their fried chicken, seafood pancake, and bulgogi for our group.  They tasted good but it's nothing I'd rave about coming here.  We had several servings of soju and beer as part of our order.  Overall the experience was good but it's not a place that had me craving for food.
author: Nick A.

description:
Came here with my cousin for dinner. We arrived right as it was about to open, so there was no wait.

For food, we ordered the spicy pork, seafood pancake, and chicken wings. All were really good and came in big portions. 

We also ordered the lychee soju, which was awesome. 

Overall, I was really happy with the quality of food/drink and I thought the prices were really fair.
author: Caroline C.

description:
My roommate and I were craving some late night korean food and a couple friends suggested we try Toyose. From the outside, this restaurant looks just like any other garage on it's foggy block. However, upon entering it's a whole another story. The restaurant is cozy without being overly congested. There's a couple four tops in the front and the back opens up to a seating area that holds probably 20 maximum. We were seated promptly in the back. The decor was pretty basic, but I found it to be just the right touch of led strung lights, bamboo shades, and authentic korean decorations. It felt very homely. 

Looking at the menu the first thing I noticed was that there wasn't enough variety. You've got your hot pot/hot soups, appetizers, and a couple rice dishes. But, where was the meat dishes, like the ever popular bulgogi, kalbi, etc...?  There was nothing on the menu that screamed for my attention and made me want to buy. The appetizers were the usual fare ranging from mandu to baby octopus (not alive). My roommate and I ended up ordering the japchae and the kimchi bokkeumbap. The food arrived quickly and was hot. 

The japchae noodle was cooked well, but that's where the goodness ends. The onion, bell pepper, and cabbage were cut to a huge size and weren't complimenting of the noodles at all. The seasoning was pretty off too, as the japchae tasted like pepper. There was no depth and umami flavors. 

I figured that the kimchi bokkeumbap would be the hero and save the night, but I was wrong. The rice was over cooked and the whole entree, just like the japchae, lacked flavor. How could something so pretty with a fried egg on top and so red be so bland?! The dish needed more of a salty, pungent, and tangy element. 

The upside though was the attentive and happy service from the waitresses. Not to mention the huge Hite beers that they sell!  Overall, a cute and comfortable place that is cool for hanging with friends and grabbing some drinks (and perhaps just some appetizers).
author: Josh S.

description:
Updating my review because we came here yesterday just to eat, but of course ended up drinking a bit haha.. Anyways we ordered an order of kimchee fried rice, seafood pancake, chicken wings and the spam casserole. Everything came out hot and fresh, took a bit but seemed like they like to bring everything out around the same time. The fried rice is good here, not too salty like I've had at other places and not wet and gravy like.. Chicken wings are okay.. Kind of bland. Casserole was good, lots of meat, might have to order an extra ramen pack inside next time and wish they had more rice cakes inside like at Arang. The seafood pancake is filled with seafood and has a nice crisp to it. Dipping sauce is good too.

Prices are about right for a Korean place.. About 20$ a person... 

We drank a little afterwards, had a green bottle of Soju and a strawberry Soju. Pretty good, tasted strong cause we mixed both in the shot glasses. Best way to drink Soju! We also ordered an order of garlic cheese fries and they were okay. Eat them quick or the cheese gets hard and it's hard to eat. They also give you complimentary popcorn which is a nice snack to eat while drinking and chilling.
author: Tiff C.

description:
I've heard great things about this restaurant, and I can definitely vouch for Toyose that this is a delicious Korean restaurant to dine at! I'd recommend making reservations as I heard and have seen that this place is quite crowded.

My party of 4 and I made a reservation at 7:30PM and was seated immediately. We ordered a bottle of Kiwi Soju, a bottle of Peach Soju, spicy chicken wings (appetizer), kimchi fried rice, and one of the kimchi soups. The spicy chicken wings came out almost immediately, and they were crispy and delicious! The four of us devoured them instantly. Also, I knew I wasn't a fan of kimchi fried rice because I didn't like it the one time I ate it at a Korean food court, but the kimchi fried rice here is bomb! It was also devoured within five minutes of being served. The kimchi soup with beef had so many fresh ingredients in it and is definitely family-sized. Some ingredients include octopus, beef, the thin white mushrooms, etc. I also heard the kimchi soup with spam was good as well, but had more of a salty taste to it.

I cannot even begin to explain how tasty the soju is here. It's the best and freshest tasting soju I've ever had, especially because the fruity sojus are served with real fruit. For example, the kiwi soju contained kiwi seeds inside of it, which makes the drink have a really nice texture as it smoothly slides down your throat. The peach soju was deliciously sweet and I knew I could drink the whole bottle if I tried. The waitress said that the sojus were strong and that they could sneak up on you if you drank fast enough...boy was she right, haha.

I'd definitely want to come again, and the next time, I hope to try all of the flavored sojus! They mentioned more flavors that they served, such as watermelon and lychee.
author: Michelle S.

description:
i cam here sunday night and there was a really long line and it was really cold. We still waited inside because we didn't want to check out other restaurants in the cold. I love the udon broth here, but it may be a bit too salty for others. For the most part, everything else we tried was somewhat decent, but a bit pricey.

Btw, there is a pokestop that you can reach from inside the restaurant. It is very likely that someone will drop a lure module during your time there. I happened to see someone drop 3 on this one alone.
author: Marco C.

description: There's a sign up black board at the end of the entrance hall by the bathroom. The service was quick and efficient - I don't see why people complain. It's a busy hole-in-the-wall restaurant with a constant line of people waiting outside for a table to free up. It reminded me of Korea and the food was definitely nostalgic of college town.
author: Carol P.

description:
This place is my go to spot when I'm craving Korean food. 

I get the kimchi fried rice, fried chicken, and the spicy pork. (Sometimes, I order soju.) 

The atmosphere will make you feel at home. 

Depending on the day this place can get extremely busy, and you have to wait off to the side while people are eating. 

(The only thing is because this place is located in the garage area with an extension on the bottom floor of a home, you'll probably wait on a bench that's directly (pretty close) to someone's table.)

This place should open up another location. 

Other than the small waiting area I'm pretty satisfied with the service and food. 

I'm going to continue to eat here.
author: M N.

description:
I am pretty happy I got to try this place out, but I didn't think it was epic. I came here with a group of friends a little while back and I got to try out a variety of different dishes here as well as their soju drinks.

Overall, the dishes were plenty big and share-able, the flavors were pretty good but again nothing that I was like OMG over.

I think mostly this place is popular via word of mouth and hype. We didn't wait for very long, which was nice, but I don't know if I would wait like 45 minutes for this place. The soju was ok, it wasn't life changing either. I do think it's a great place for Korean food but not worth all the hype.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
This Korean restaurant is so exotic!  Half the garage is used as the kitchen/storage area and the other half is the dining/restroom area.  


L A Y O U T - The place is already so small and they have to add the restroom because lots of people come here during the later evening hours to dine in, eat and order rounds of soju drinks!  They have to put a restroom so people can do their thing in the restroom from the shots of soju they drink!!!  Repeat cycle for the night and they surely make bank.  

I love the decor to this place!  Even though it is small, it makes the place quite cozy to be in.  The first time I was here, I got caught off guard by the interior.  The interior is decorated from top to bottom!  They painted the ceilings, have this dim lighting going on and you can draw down these blinds if you are seated next to the aisle.  I think that is very cool because the blinds not only adds to the ambiance, it also makes it convenient if you don't want waiting customers watching you eat!  

S E R V I C E - Considering that it is a very small place, the wait to get a seat may take up to an hour and half - depending on when you go!  They can't help it!  It is understandable!  It is the hot spot to be at during the late night hours with friends! 

F O O D and S O J U - Their food is very tasty compared to other soju lounges I have been to in San Francisco!  I love the variety on their soju flavors!  They give you free, unlimited rounds of popcorn if you order soju!

DO ORDER
+ SEAFOOD PANCAKE
+ KIMCHI FRIED RICE
+ CHICKEN WINGS
+ ...and if your eyes are bigger than your stomach, or you are with a hungry, big group, get the Spam Casserole!  It is delish!  Spicy soy bean based soup filled with spam, slices of hot dog and ramen goodness!

- The mango soju is the classic favorite.  
- Strawberry, pineapple and peach are the originals.  
- Kiwi was special!  I like how it had seeds in the soju drink still. 
- For the aloe and yogurt soju, you can taste the soju more than the flavor.  Only order those two if you have never tried it before!


One soju drink is 9 bucks!  WARNING - With a group of alcoholic, foodie friends, this dining experience can be quite costly!  

Overall, I love this place!  From the exotic presentation, ambiance, food and to the soju drinks, this Korean garage restaurant is a crowd pleaser indeed!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
This place is a hidden gem in SF and is located in a garage which makes it even cooler.  The wait staff are adorable and super helpful!! 
You may have to wait a bit to get seated, but you can just go across the street and have a drink at the bar.

Best place is the Bay Area to get some late night grub...
author: Evan E.

description: One of the most authentic Korean foods in town! Great for friends gathering and small party. My grind ordered the fried whole chicken (hidden menu?) and it was delicious. The seafood pancakes, kimchi soups, and seafood tofu soups were all very flavorful. The 5 of us cleaned the table almost immediately. The only down side was the place is not too big, and the place is always packed, so do expect a line for waiting! Great place, would love to come back again!
author: Wendy C.

description: Got here on a Friday night and parking was fairly easy to find. We got seated immediately and beat the rush. We ordered five items which is kimchee soup, calamari w/ rice cake, kimchee fried rice (since everyone raved about it), corn cheese, and spicy chicken wings. Most of the items we ordered were okay but not the best nor the worst. Kimchee soup tasted like tomato soup with a little spice we were really disappointed by that and also don't order the calamari with rice cake because 3/4 of that dish is vegetables. There were literally 8 pieces of rice cake considering that we paid 14$ for it. Corn cheese was mediocre and the spicy chicken wings weren't even spicy. It tasted like Chinatown salt n pepper chicken wings. Kimchee fried rice was okay as well. Service was okay, the waitress didn't check on us or anything. They just left the dish on the table and that's it. Overall I wouldn't return.
author: Tina C.

description:
Toyose offers a really great range of Korean dishes covering KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) to Kimchi Fried Rice and Seafood Pancake.

The aforementioned dishes are my go to whenever I visit this restaurant and is on par with your average Korean restaurant. Kimchi Fried Rice was a little bit on the oily and damp side. KFC was well fried and not overly seasoned. The restaurant is also generous with the seafood in their Seafood Pancake.

My order has been messed up before, due in part to miscommunication and staff being on a rush. Would recommend asking the staff to repeat the order.

Parking and seating can be tough depending on the time you visit. The few times I did go, I aimed for opening (6pm) or 9pm, and didn't have too much trouble getting seats on a Thursday and Friday night. Would definitely come back, but probably not go out of my way for unless friends were interested in eating here.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Dear Toyose, 

I've been paying you a visit for almost about 4 years now. But...for the past year, I'm so tired of trying to be a loyal fan of your Korean goodness. Nowadays, for Christ's sake, just trying to get a seat inside you is practically impossible, unless I wait outside your humble abode for over an hour and a half every single time. 

I get it. Your food's surprisingly good. It's not the greatest Korean food ever (check out Los Angeles), and it's a bit pricey too, but something about that chef you have working like a slave really drives home the flavor in your chicken wings and spam kimchi fried rice. 

And my god, has anyone given the recommendation for your watermelon soju? If not, then people, TRY IT. IT'S THE BEST. Yes I get drunk to this tiny restaurant's soju, but so what, that shit's delicious! And the liquor's a real after-30minute creeper. 

But Toyose, I really would have given you your solid, well-deserved 4 stars if ONLY I DIDN'T HAVE TO WAIT FOR 1.5 HOURS ON A TUESDAY EARLY NIGHT! 

People, this is what Yelp does to anyone's favorite small businesses. In my quest to obtain Elite, I'm simultaneously causing the harm to my beloved go-to spots. Why, why!!!!!
author: Thankie S.

description: Favorite korean place by far as well as open late I come here after work often to eat and drink with friends I really like the atmosphere as well. Food is super good and I really enjoy the kimchi and seafood pancake.
author: Wren X.

description: Came here because I didn't want korean fried bbq, but rather just some other korean food that wasn't tofu either. I really missed the giant pots that had ramen, rice cakes, and other goods inside it. We came here and ordered the seafood pancake, fried chicken, and the said pot (spam one). Let's start with the giant pot, it was very disappointing tbh. The rice cakes weren't that great in it, and it was mainly filled with kimchi and really hard to finish all of that. Wish there was more soup actually. Usually not a big proponent of seafood pancake, but man this was actually really good, glad we got it. And it was quite large. The fried chicken was also really good. So basically came here for 1 thing, best thing was the 2 other dishes.
author: Victor D.

description:
Looking to get out of our SoMa comfort zone to grab a dinner on a weeknight, no less, Jamie W. and I ventured way, way out to the Outer Sunset and decided to take a chance on this little Korean place which I found most favorably reviewed on the Yelp app. I saw the awning but thought it was closed since the doors were shut and there were no windows. I didn't realize it was a converted residential garage until we entered and saw how tiny it is in there. Our timing was good because we were seated right away at a table meant for four people but unfortunately in clear view of everyone who followed us and ended up waiting on the bench staring at us as we ate. Welcome to Toyose.

We were pretty much starving by the time we got there since it is a schlep from SoMa, so we were a mite disappointed that the banchan consisted of only four little dishes instead of the usual 10 to 12 (see photo). Jamie quickly zeroed in on the $10.95 Beef Kimchi Fried Rice which looked lovely with a fried egg and strips of nori on top (see photo). It was hearty and flavorful, but I have to admit the kimchi didn't have quite the kick we were both hoping for. That problem was not as apparent with my pick, the $13.95 Tofu Kimchi, quite an extravaganza of tofu slices with a torrent of spicy pork and vegetables and kimchi running through the middle of it (see photo). That was the best dish of the night.

Marginally disappointing were the $12.95 Spicy Chicken Wings, rather overpriced for the portion and not that spicy either. I quite liked the shredded cabbage salad on the side which was covered in a thousand-island-like miso dressing (see photo). However, I have to admit the totally dispensable dish of the night was the $5.95 Corn Cheese, which didn't strike us as Korean but more like something Stouffer's would sell as a frozen side dish for the busy suburban housewife. It was absurdly gooey with melted cheese mixed with a few kernels of corn and chopped green beans and then obviously put under a broiler for the crusty topping (see photo).

Both the wings and the corn cheese struck us more as bar food for the seriously hung over. Speaking of which, we noticed a high hipster quotient in here as well as a strong dosage of Asian family parties. It's probably too far-flung a location for the tourist trade, and frankly, who would come cross-town to a converted garage anyway? Service was attentive, and they even have a buzzer which you can press as it clings precariously against the wall. I guess it's sorta like honking your horn at a drive-in diner so that the waitress on roller skates can come pick up the tray off your car window. I think Toyose serves its purpose in serving Korean comfort food and satisfying a case of the post-barhopping munchies.

FOOD - 3 stars...good portions, some good flavors but needs a bit more kick and a little more panache
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...it's a garage with no windows for Pete's sake
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...the waitresses respond to the buzzer almost as good as the flight attendants on Southwest
TOTAL - 3 stars...popular Korean outpost in the Outer Sunset isn't lacking for hungry & possibly hungover customers
author: Ed U.

description: Uh, who doesn't like Korean fried chicken, kimchi fried rice, and seafood pancake?? Yum, yum, and YUM.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Food (4/5): My friend and I shared the spicy fried chicken, kimchi fried rice, and spam stew. Everything was really good!! Definitely recommend the chicken and fried rice. The spam stew was pretty spicy for me, but I have low spice tolerance haha. It was packed with kimchi, hot dogs, spam, ramen noodles, rice cakes, and beef. So much food :o Portions are huge, so be prepared to share!

Service (4/5): A lot of the reviews complain about bad service, but I actually thought it was really good! We were seated pretty promptly, food came out quickly, and the servers were really nice and helpful.

Value (5/5): The bill came out to a little over $60 including tax and tip, which seems like a lot for two people, but we only ate like 20% of the food and took the rest home as leftovers. Half of the leftovers lasted me three more meals, so it was super worth.
author: Abby S.

description:
The food was not bad, me and friends always order spam Budae jjigae, kimchi fried rice, chicken wings, and some other dishes. We can satisfied about food, but service, no!

The one star rate for the service attitude. Been there several times, and every time go there would like expect they can improve service attitude, but , no, not at all... I know you guys are busy, but which is not means you can being rude to your customers.

Will consider not going anymore.
author: Carrie T.

description: Used to come here a lot but the quality of food and service has gone downhill. Apparently they now charge $3 for 1 refill on 4 tiny side dishes (beansprouts cost pennies to make...). The small waitress had attitude and DID NOT inform us of this charge. She scoffed when we asked for a refill and asked if we were done when the plates were full of food. Im very disappointed and won't be back.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
I love this place, it's the cutest little gem known for being situated inside a garage in Sunset. I've been coming here since 2010 and it's always a recommendation for friends visiting from out of town. 

There's a wait sometimes, could be up to an hour or more if you're unlucky on a busy night. It's best to arrive right when they open at night. They have the best kimchee fried rice ever, I say that because I honestly have yet to find a better place for it. It goes so good with their cheese corn. That's usually all I get here but their soups and chicken wings aren't bad either.

I never had a problem with the service, the servers do always seem very rushed, busy, and tired but it's not bad service.
author: Cammi Z.

description:
I am in love with this place. I would drive to SF just to wait an hour just to eat here! 

I love their seafood pancakes, Kim-chi fried rice, chicken wings, and soju! The Kim chi fried rice is off the charts. I sometimes order two between three people because it is so good. I cannot understand how mouth watering it is. I highly recommend trying the items I have listed. I wish I could bring more people to try all the other foods that they offer. 

Neat place, parking is sometimes hard to find. There is street parking but if you get lucky you find a spot. Be prepared to wait since it's a small location (inside someone's garage) but it is nicely decorated! 

The only downside food item that I disapprove of is their cream corn. Taste like a can of corn that they took out and put cheese over it and put it in the oven. You can literally taste the block of cheese and corn together. It was hard, I do not recommend this at all!
author: Stephy L.

description:
I'm seriously amazed and a little alarmed by how many seats, tables, and people can be fit in such a small garage space. These people literally utilized all of the space in their restaurant. They even had decor! Also, I give them points for having the roll-down blinds for the tables near the entrance. Everyone is always crowded around the entrance waiting to be seated and it is extremely awkward when you're trying to eat and 5-10 people are salivating in front of your table with their twitchy eyes. At this place, you can just roll down the blinds and all is good.

My friend and I waited 40 minutes for a table. We went back and forth about leaving because the wait was ridiculously long, but if so many people wanted to eat here, it had to be good, right? 

We ordered a kimchee fried rice, kimchee pancake, and lychee soju. It made my taste buds happy and I thought the food was pretty authentic. I even started to question if the lychee soju had alcohol because it just tasted that damn good, but then my friend started turning pink and began to mumble her words, so I knew they didn't skimp out on the alcohol hahaha! 

I gave this place a 4-star because I feel like their menu could have been better. I wish they had seating for people outside or at least moved away the stacked chairs so that people could sit while they waited. Overall, good place!
author: Emily F.

description:
Really delicious crispy fried chicken! The kimchi pancake was also really good. 

There were only 2 beer selections, neither of which I had ever heard of, but they had an extensive selection of soju. I had never tried soju before so we shared the mango version. It was too sweet for my personal taste but I'm glad I tried it. However, both of the shot glasses we were given for our drinks had very large cracks in them. We asked for new glasses and received two new glasses, both of which were also cracked.

I will definitely be back because the food was so good (and they are opened late).
author: Rachel C.

description:
I came here on a Saturday night at around 10PM, after having dinner in the SoMa district.  My friends and I were just down to drink, and I guess eat, more...

The restaurant is pretty small, and seating is very limited.  Saturday night was quite packed, and it was very difficult to sit comfortably.  

My friend ordered the Lychee Soju shot, along with the OB pitcher of beer.  We also ordered the kimchi fried rice.  The fried rice was pretty good, and portions were perfect for four of us.  

The lychee shots were a bit too sweet for my likings, but I found it to be a good mix along with the beer.  

The service is not bad--but their staff are always so busy, so it's hard to get their attention when you need something.  

The entire restaurant, in my opinion, seems quite dingy, and quite noisy.  I guess it's expected in any sort of Korean restaurant though--can't really complain about that.

Overall grade: A
author: Bobby K.

description:
Bueno. Woohoo! As good as it gets!

Came here from FiDi last night to chow down with a few friends from out of town. Groaning that it was already 9:30 (past my bedtime) before I headed out, I was definitely not cheery when I got there. On top of the late time, a few other "bad" factors weighed in #1 it was hella far for me #2 it was hella cold out there #3 I thought this place was closed from the outside.

But that all transformed and turned my frown upside down when the food came. The wait was supposedly "40 mins" but we got sat down in 10. The waitress wasn't super personable but I forgave her as the guy waiter was super nice. Still groaning, we decided to order one of each of the "popular" items. We got the beef kimchi fried rice, seafood casserole, seafood pancake, and the spicy chicken wings.

My favorites in the following order:
1) Seafood casserole
2) Kimchi Fried Rice
3) Seafood Pancake
4) Chicken Wings

- Lychee soju which doesn't count so it gets its own category! Delish, didn't taste like alcohol and at $11 a bottle, it can add up but we were glad we ordered it.

The reason why the chicken wings were ranked the lowest was probably because I was expecting Bon-Chon-esque (for those NE'ers out there, you know what I mean) and would be sauce-y and not super dry. The wings didn't taste bad by any means but I just had a different expectation of what it should taste like. They were kinda small and a little dry to my liking. 

For the seafood casserole though - DELISH. We ordered it as mild and the flavor wasn't water'ed down and had a tinge of sweetness to it. We literally slurped up the whole thing and had to ask the waitress for additional broth for free (which she happily got for us +5 stars!) I think this was my favorite casserole place in all of SF.

Kimchi fried rice was delish - as it's hard to mess this up but the little chunks of beef went very well with the dish. She said it was medium spicy and it wasn't spicy at all which was perfect for me since I am not a spicy-fan.

The seafood pancake was also pretty good and not too many onions/scallions and fried very well with a delish dipping sauce. I approve!

I usually don't go back to the same restaurant twice but think I'll need to come back in case I ever need to satisfy my Korean-drinking food cravings!
author: Vanessa K.

description: This review is for their service (the worst service I ever had). So I've been coming to Toyose for many years and I come here for the yummy food. Our normal waitresses are the 2 sisters, but we haven't seen them in awhile. It was my brothers birthday and we made a reservation for 4 people. We got to the restaurant and one person got sick and couldn't come. I told this "new waitress" that we are here for our 7 o'clock reservation and she walked us to the table. I proceeded to tell her that it's only 3 people now since one person cancelled. She said no, we only take reservations for parties of 4. I explained what happened and she pointed to the board and rudely told us to put our names on the board to wait for a seat. I was surprised at her rude and dismissive response and said "are you kidding"? She mocked me and responded "are YOU kidding" , laughed and pointed to the board once again. She gave us a poop face and totally snubbed us and walked away. I eat out more than the average person and had numerous experiences at Asian restaurants and never expect great service, but I also never expect to be treated so poorly. It was my brother's choice to come here for his 18th birthday and needless to say it ruined his and our night. For now, I have to say goodbye to Toyose.
author: Ping L.

description:
Took us a bit to find this place! First impression of the restaurant was that it seem like we were dining inside someone's house. We arrived on a weekday, so the wait was relatively short compared to the weekends. We only had to wait about 15 minutes before being seated by the hostess. 

For food, we got the beef and octopus casserole, seafood pancake, and a pineapple soju for the two of us. Our total came out to be around $50, but we had so much left overs! For the casserole, there were an assortment of other things inside that includes, sliced fish balls, squid, shrimp, mushrooms and glass noodles. The seafood pancake was similar to a size of a medium pizza and it definitely got us by surprise. There is also a button on the side of the wall that you can press anytime you want to alert the waiter. Due to the size of the restaurant, the waiters were relatively busy since there weren't that many waiters in the first place.

Price: For two dishes and a bottle of soju, it came out to be around $50, so it wasn't too bad. We definitely had way more left overs than ecpected

Food:The pancakes were definitely a MUST try. I actually believe that they are the best seafood pancakes I had in the bay area. The beef and octopus casserole was absolutely huge! We were barely able to finish half of the casserole before give up.

The food was great though! I would definitely come back again! It may be a little pricey though compared to others Korean restaurants, but it is well worth it!
author: Michael W.

description: So bad service!!we r the first come here , and when we were just come here and see the menu ,the waitress always ask ' are u ready?' , j want to come here ,eat and relax but they gave me the feeling like always hungry up me , when we were not finish the food , they took off my friend's plate and gave the check, what do they mean?? I will never come back here
author: 永

description: Super old school (as in a renovated garage) kind of speakeasy. Almost like you need to know someone to go. We had a blast after an event earlier in the evening. Food was delish. We will surely be back. Can have a long wait so be prepared.
author: Lorenzo R.

description:
At the suggestion of Big Poppa Eats (food critic and friend), I visited TOYOSE-Korean restaurant in SF. I have to say I will give them another try another time as I know there are off days and I KNOW my friend has some pretty good tastebuds. 

Unfortunately the overall review from this first trip: long wait, hurried order-taking (after waiting for a seat for almost an hour, the wait staff gave me about two minutes to look through the menu and ask me what I wanted, and then came back to me twice more within another two minutes when I asked for more time). I felt a bit rushed for someone who had to wait a while for a seat.

There was not enough variation of banchan (side dishes) that balanced out each other. The banchan offered were undercooked cubed syrupy potatoes, mushy overboiled kelp, bland kimchee and three sprigs of broccoli with julienned carrots. They lacked acids...too alkaline. 

I had overcooked eel that was not fileted properly and was doused in heavy, syrupy and salty sauce (too much sea salt), and my kimchi pancakes were also too salty and tasted more burnt than pan-fried. The dipping sauce was right, though.

Edges were crisp and center was soggy and the underside was dark with a bit too many burn marks. The kimchi used for the pancakes were also bland--it had the heat but the ginger and garlic did not stand out.
