How do I gauge the food? I'm part Korean. I've had Korean food all my life and some fantastic dishes in NY where I grew up and lived most of my life.

Another note: It was very hot and humid in there too. They needed better ventilation that day. Despite the tight quarters, and camouflaged entrance (retrofitted garage space) it was very friendly and warm and I look forward to giving it another go as I saw some other dishes on other tables that looked good. We all have off-days. I certainly do in my own kitchen.
author: S Y.

description:
Toyose is a dimly-lit, Korean dive restaurant that's hidden inside a residential garage. My sister says it translate into garage in Korean, but I'm not sure how true that really is. I think it's closer to meaning "hole-in-the-wall." It's seemingly always packed with young Asians who come for the soju and stay for the comfort food. The wait can be a bit long, but it's worth it for the atmosphere if that's what you like.

The food comes relatively fast and comes in either soup/stew form or fried. My favorite dish of the night was the beef kimchi fried rice with an egg. The seafood pancake was just okay as the batter mostly stuck to the wax paper. The spicy chicken wings were nicely fried, but didn't have much flavor. The different kinds of seafood stews were good, but are mostly similar from one to the next. I didn't like the texture of the very rubbery and possibly undercooked octopus in the soup. The four dish banchan also wasn't that impressive. Perhaps a few bottles of the yogurt soju would've made me forget some of the underachievements of this place.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
2 words - MANGO SOJU!!

I'm not a big drinker so I love girly drinks.... Baileys, Moscato, Champagne, and MANGO SOJU... okay you get it.

We ordered the mixed casserole (feeds 4-5 people) and it was pretty good. You can add ramen to it if you're super hungry or like ramen. We also ordered the seafood Pajun (korean pancake) That was really good and one of the better ones i've had.

The decor was very cozy. They divided each section with wooden beams and each table is good for 4-5 people. They added a new sign up in front and I think that it made it a little tacky cause it was much cooler when it had just a garage door in front.

TIPS: 
1. GET MANGO SOJU

2. There's usually a wait especially on the weekend so make reservations! Everyone  has to get to the reservation on time so don't be late (even 5 min!!) you may lose your spot. (even if you have a 20 person group everyone has to be there to get seated)

3. Get the chicken wings. They are soooo good. Not as good as www.bonchonchicken.com but equally satisfying.

4. Parking. If you're looking to drive there are some parking spots up in front and down the next block. 

5. GET MANGO SOJU
author: Jennie C.

description: Love the corn cheese. It was well grilled and not too oily. The Korean hotpot was amazing. The level of spicy was on point and I loved the rice cake in it the most. They have different  taste of soju also.
author: Alice T.

description:
Well-prepared food and tasty soju concoctions is the name of the game. Followed by the parenthetical, "bring a lot of money." I'm used to K-town cheapness; sue me. 

The service was good, also. It can get a bit cramped inside and the wait can be off-putting, but fried chicken may change all of that for you. 

My only complaint is that the portions don't really reflect the prices. I'm a very light eater and I feel like I would have to lay down 50 shells just to feel sated. 

Next time, I'll just bring some cereal in my pocket. 

Corn pops anyone?
author: Aren A.

description:
I've heard about this place and its true when they said that its a garage converted into a restaurant.  This place is pretty cramped and for Saturday night, there was a wait.  It was a pretty friendly environment with pretty dim lighting.  I pretty much stood in front of the restaurant and wondered if it was really there.

Based on previous reviews, we ordered the beef kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, spicy fried chicken wings, and lychee soju.  First off, I really liked the soju.  I do recommend it but of course as long as no driving is involved.  Safety first!  I'm pretty sensitive to the taste of alcohol so the amount of it in this soju waa the best amount for me.  Plus I love the taste of lychee.  The spicy fried chicken wings came first.  I was expecting it to be amazing but it somewhat reminds me of chicken wings you'd find in some other restaurant.  It has a nice crunchy texture though.  The next that came was the seafood pancake.  One of the best dishes here that I've had.  Plenty of seafood with a very nice crunchy texture.  Lastly came the kimchi fried rice which I enjoyed.  I loved the fried egg in top and it had good flavor.  

Overall, I didn't think it was too bad.  Recommend trying it at least once if you haven't yet.
author: Teresa W.

description:
2 stars? But it's in a garage!

Yeah, that's the main attraction here. I've been to Toyose a few times, and for the most part, service is quick, but in the "let's get you out the door so we can seat others" sort of way. For context, most soju-centric spots emphasize a longer experience where you drink and catch up with friends, and order anju (drinking food) with each round or two. Given the quick turnaround for tables, Toyose would be better categorized primarily as a restaurant instead of a soju bar.
author: Andrew L.

description:
So good if you want amazing Korean food late night!  This place is only open at night! Come early if you do not want to be stuck in the freezing cold while waiting for a seat (which usually happens if you want to come here after 9pm).  

The different flavored yogurt sojus are SO GOOD!! The food is good too!  I love the casseroles here!! Also the kimchi fried rice!! Pretty sure I don't remember every single item that my group got but then again, we were about 6 yogurt soju bottles deep.
author: Esther A.

description:
This was stop #2 in my garage eating tour. Lol. 

Their chicken wings are overrated.  I did like how they were crispy and not too salty. I don't know if they're supposed to be spicy because they're not. Although I did see some pepper flakes on them.  Think of them as fried chicken with a slight Korean twist and not the other way around.

Cozy inside.
Service is pretty good.
It is crowded so expect to wait. We waited about 10 mins on a Monday night.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Toyose is somewhere I like to visit for fun/late night grubbing and drinking. The first time I went to Toyose, I tried it out for dinner and it was underwhelming. Not that the food is bad here, it's just not great. Hubby makes better Korean food on the fly for the most part. 

However, coming here late at night for some socializing or late night food and drinks, it's the perfect spot! My recent trip back to Toyose was one of the nights after Outside Lands - my bestie and I were hungry and it was late. We went to Toyose for Kimchi Fried Rice, Spam Casserole, and Pineapple Soju. The food is decent, but not great as I mentioned before. But after a day of walking and dancing and along with soju, it's a great late night cap.

The one thing that this place has above others is the restaurant itself. As another Yelper mentioned, themed restaurants around here are hard to find. Toyose definitely makes you feel like you might be in Seoul. Fun atmosphere!
author: Tiffany K.

description:
The spicy pork is yum, the chicken wings are great, the seafood pancake and kimchi fried rice are definitely on my favorites list, and the spicy kimchi soup is comforting. 

As stated in a few reviews, the service isn't always great. But hey, go with your friends and enjoy their company while eating, and try not to pay attention to the service issues. My stars are reserved only for the food. 

Make a reservation to avoid the wait.
author: Sarah B.

description:
First, can I just point out this place opens until 2am!! It's so hard to find places that open late in the Bay Area besides Mexican joints and fast food restaurants (even those close). Now here's a place that can satisfy all those late night asian food munchies/drunchies/food cravings of all sorts. The place is incredibly spacious inside, so no need to worry about squeezing in like some other small SF places. 

Second, can I just praise their different types of sojus. They have kiwi soju - how many places have you been to that have this option AND have the soju actually taste remarkably good. Their peach soju also hits the spot. Perfect for those get together with friends when you just want to chill and have fun without having to scream at each other in a bar. 

Third, the food. I got the seafood pancake, their appetizer plate, wings. Incredibly delicious and flavorful food that really captures that Korean taste if you know what I mean.

I need to go back and try more food options to add more depth to this review, but for now I still highly recommend this place! There's also parking spaces outside, like what? Since when does that ever happen
author: Alice Y.

description:
This place is awesome! Definitely what looks like a hole in the wall. It's a restaurant, built inside a garage! Though looks are seriously deceiving. It's actually quite roomy inside. This place is definitely for smaller groups (the tables are pretty crammed together), but it makes for a great cosy atmosphere for a intimate group of friends. Their soju is really tasty (lots of different flavors and options). 

We had the chicken wings (yum!), the chap chae (um probably some of the best chap chae i've ever had at any Korean restaurant), the seafood pancake, kimchi friend rice, and a bunch of other random dishes. I know the bay area isn't exactly known for it's Korean food... this place is pretty good though in comparison.

The waiters are super nice and accommodating (even after some of our friends got a little rowdy) and it was a pretty good price for everything in the end (split amongst 8 people). Service is pretty quick and responsive too (they have the little service buttons which makes a difference), which is kind of rare I think in Asian restaurants, so props to that.

It does get a little loud, but we didn't mind (we were probably the loudest there -_- haha). Definitely on my list for cool chill bar/restaurants to go to in the city (for us old people who can't stand the clubs anymore).
author: Denise C.

description: Don't post the closing hours on your door as 2 a.m. and then refuse service to patrons that walk in at 1 a.m. If the "restaurant closes at 2 a.m. but the kitchen closes at 1 a.m.," as you say, then indicate that on your door and correct your hours on yelp.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
When it's cold and misty outside, Toyose is the perfect place to go for some delicious Korean food. I've had their kimchi friend rice to-go before but only recently came in to the restaurant itself. Phew! It was quite a drive out here from the Inner Richmond, but it was definitely worth it. 

Toyose is a cozy little restaurant built in a garage.  You definitely don't expect it to look as it does from the outside. The interior is warmly lit, with a number of booths, though not many, so it does get crowded. My friend and I waited about 15 minutes while the party of 2 behind us had to wait 30-40 minutes at around 8pm.  Get there early!

Many of them menu items looked so delicious but we couldn't possibly order and eat them all, so we settled on 2 items. Kimchi Fried Rice, of course, can't go wrong with that: moist and not too spicy.  Their Seafood and Kimchi Pancake was splendidly delicious; I wish it was a bit crispier, but that's just me being picky. We also had the Calamari and Bulgogi; I honestly did not expect it to be so yummy, but to my surprise it was! The marinade was perfect. 

For drinks, we channeled Beyonce and decided on the Watermelon Soju (...surfbort).  Unlike soju cocktails from other places, Toyose's was super refreshing, not overly sugary and can actually taste the alcohol, and tastes like watermelon should, not that fake generic flavor. I don't even like watermelon but I would recommend it.

Service was really on point.  Sometimes when you ask servers for another minute to decide, they come back way too soon or don't come back for too long of a while, but our server came back at an appropriate time so we got our order, food, check, and card back in a timely fashion. As expected of such a crowded restaurant. 

I don't often give 5 stars, but I really have no complaints about Toyose. Will be back to try many more menu items!
author: Monica V.

description:
I've been here a few times and I've never written a review. Well, today I am. 

It's a literally a garage with a bird as it's mascot... Upon reading the Korean sign, it roughly translates to the Swallow Room. Birds. 

Speaking of birds, fried chicken is served here. You can get it whole or you can just have wings. But be warned, it's not spicy as it is advertised. I like the crunchiness of it and that's why we order it each time we visit. And as long I'm on the bird thing, I had the opportunity to try to gizzards today and it was amazing. I enjoyed it as much as the wings. 

The kimchi fried rice is something we always order as well, my favorite part is the over easy egg as I feel the rice is lacking kimchi flavor. Another dish I don't enjoy as much is the beef bulgogi. With or without the calamari, I feel they could use a bit more soy sauce in the marinade and leave it to sit for a longer time. This is saying a lot since I don't care for salty food.

As for stews, you've got to try it. We like adding ramen to our selection. 

The seafood pancake is doughy and chock full of seafood. You will not be disappointed so long as you use the sauce that accompanies it. We were given kimchi pancake by mistake and if it wasn't for that mistake, I would have never tried it. It's crispy and awesome. 

Finally the soju. The cocktail sojus are what this place is known for. I've tried most of the flavors and my least favorite so far is the aloe. I don't care for peach and kiwi alone, but I mixed the two together and enjoyed it more. 

I would give a full 5 if the wait wasn't so ridic. But it does take reservations so be sure to do that and save an hour of wait time.
author: Serinda O.

description:
Not the best korean place I've been to, honestly..
Though, We did get free yakult!
I ordered Bibimbap...
And my friends got tofu bowls.
The Bibimbap was okay, not bad, not that good either. The taste was rather bland... I wish they had more meat in it.. for their price. Honestly, I couldn't find the meat.
The tofu bowls, were okay, but again, the seafood tofu bowl, their seafood pieces were pretty small! 
But their taste, eh, it wasn't something to complain about! 
Their service was pretty slow...
Like I asked for a spoon, they wouldn't bring it till like 5mins later...
Cleaness, it was alright.. It was preeeeetyy smokey though.
Sorry about the complaints, but its not that bad, worth a try!
author: Aya H.

description:
CHICKEN WINGS. That's a must if you're coming here. Otherwise, you're wasting your time.

The four of us came here on a late Thursday night. Even then, it was still pretty poppin' and we still had to wait 10 mins. I guess Toyose is very popular even on a week night.

The service was straightforward-- fast and efficient, with their service button on the wall. 

What we got:

Chicken Wings: Crispy, hot, amazing-- all of the reviews here rave about it. I don't think I need to say more.

Clam Soup: My favorite soup. It was so light, slightly gingery, and clean-- perfect before a meal. It really washed everything down, since everything else you order is super salty.

Kimchi Soup: Ugh I got this thinking it was Kimchi Chige, and that it wouldn't be as salty as it was. I think I used the clam soup to wash this down. It was gooey and was full of sodium.
 
Kimchi Fried Rice: Pretty good, pretty good. It was like your standard Kimchi fried  with an egg on it.

I think the chicken wings and clam soup wins here :) I know that this place gets way packed during the weekend nights, so if you need to tend to your drunk munchies with their bomb chicken wings, order to-go before you get there. To avoid all that, week nights are probably a good time to come.
author: Grace H.

description: It is not good for a big group. Came in a group of 6 and made reservations and upon arrival they gave up our seat to another group. The food is only ok, it is nothing to rave about. Service was terrible, it was only good when we ask for the check, otherwise we are invisible. We ordered a fried rice but never showed up.The only good thing about this restaurant is that it has a clean bathroom and the soju drinks were amazing.
author: Julie H.

description: My  wife and I just got married. She just moved into the neighborhood with me, and we really like to find good eats around the neighborhood. Toyose, is a place we've really wanted to come, based on what we've read and seen. Those lines of people waiting to get in, are usually pretty long! What I can say, is that the food was worth the wait. The spicy fried chicken was cooked just right, the seafood pancakes had a really nice texture, and the kimchee rice dish rounded out our little meal with a kick.  The peach soju added to the dining experience as well. Thanks Toyose, to our dining experience being a great one, and one worth re-creating.
author: Paul M.

description:
One of the hidden gems of San Francisco. Want to share a teapot full of hot sake with some friends at late night and hangout, come here. This garage is nice, warm and cozy for cold San Francisco nights. The kimchi pancake is very good (contains fish sauce/extracts ...). Steamed egg is amazing. It was great surprize for me. I had never thought of cooking an egg by steaming it. The steamed egg is soft, fluffy and moist.

I come here for hot sake, good snacks, and hang out with friends. I will be back again in a month!
author: Sid P.

description:
If the line here weren't always an hour wait, I'd be coming here a lot more often. And of course they don't take reservations unless you have a large party (I'm guessing greater than 6). It's also a small restaurant, so I usually come with small groups of 2-4. The dishes are perfect for sharing though.

It's a hole in the wall -- or should I say hole beside a garage, but it seems like everyone and their mom knows about it. You get here anytime during meal hours, and there's a bunch of people waiting already. It's great for late night eats though as they open late, and there's no wait after the dinner rush. 

Everything here is delicious, but I'd definitely recommend the fried chicken and one of the hot pots. Other than food, the ambience is probably the biggest differentiator. It feels kinda special to walk into a garage side entrance into an oasis of korean hot pot, fried chicken, and kimchee fried rice. A very different korean meal experience than most anything in the Bay Area or even Los Angeles (yes, even LA)!
author: Audrey L.

description:
Do not go here, I tipped them 2.00 Dollar for their rude behavior and they somehow managed to add an extra 0 on the tip line and make it 20.00 Dollars on the tip line. 2 disrespectful waitresses with a horrible attitude, overcharging on food, extra charges in tips, all in one night.

Make sure you dont tip for bad behavior and if so make sure you take a picture.
author: Gunny K.

description: Regardless of waiting an hour just to get seated, the food made up for it. Also lost stars because the server forgot to write down our order of chicken wangs. Had the beef kimchi fried rice and shrimp fried rice. Both were delicious but I enjoyed the shrimp fried rice a lot more. The chicken wings were not all that, so avoid if necessary. Should have gotten hotpot instead. The soju was also good, wish they provided a bigger portion.
author: Raymond M.

description:
Hands down my fav Korean soju spot in the area. Been coming to "the garage" for over 10 years. Didn't even know it was actually called Toyose til years later haha The only reason I would refrain from coming here would be the expected wait time. During weekends and prime time hours, it's almost always at least a 45min wait. 

Must order:
- Kimchi fried rice-it's seriously the best here! 
- Seafood pancake
- Kimchi stew with ramen (feeds 4+) 
- Chicken wings are a hit or miss. Sometimes it's dry and bland. But the side cabbage slaw that it comes with is always good
- Soju - they have tons of flavors but I always get the yogurt or strawberry
author: Cathy M.

description: Bitch gave me an attitude. I asked how long for our table and she was like "I just called ----" like umm that was not my question at all and there's 2 tables available and they ain't doing shit. Waitresses be drinking on duty????? FYI this is my first time hear so honestly I wouldn't recommend.
author: AyeC. M.

description:
Came here on a monday and the line was moderate. It literally took me a minute to figure where the door was as the restaurant was converted from a garage. 

Food: We got their usual fare, seafood pancake, kimichi fried chicken and watermelon soju. They also recommend their fried chicken, but what we got was more than enough for 2 ppl so we passed on the fried chicken.

Seafood pancake was really thick compared to other seafood pancake that I had before. Came with a dipping sauce. Kimchi fried rice was very decent with the right amount of kimchi and beef. I think they also have a seafood version.

Watermelon soju: The best I have ever had. Came in a olive oil bottle. It was pretty light as it tasted like watermelon juice for the most part. Very tasty and highly highly recommend. However, the soju definitely gave me a kick afterwards
author: Ruxin H.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, because I love Korean food. My husband and I are arrived the restaurant it was full,and wait time was 40 minutes. So I decided to order to go. We waited about 20 minutes and got back home.My seafood soybean paste soup tastes like fish soup and all ingredients don't look so fresh! It's pretty expensive too; I paid about $13.99+tax. Furthermore, spicy chicken wings are so dry and portion is soooo small!! And they even didn't give us side dishes- white radish, or any side dishes for my food!! 
I'm very disappointed and will never go back again!!
author: Christine H.

description: Not exactly a place to go to if you are looking for a lot of varieties of Korean food. This is more of an eat and drink type of a place. Food is good though. Make sure you call before because they are usually super packed.
author: Elaine C.

description:
I just wanted to ask, "Do you have an idea about the wait time for 2 people?"

I approached one of the waitstaff with a smile. I was only able to get to "Do you have..."  and she cuts me off and says "Write your name on the board!" I then continue to TRY to complete my sentence. I got to "do you have an idea about the wai..." and she cuts me off and hit me with "The board is right there!"

How is she going to cut me off twice before I finish my sentence? I didn't even finish it and she walks away. Alright. I'll give her the benefit of the doubt. It was a hot day and they were busy. But be nice, ok? I could've easily snapped back and knocked over your bowl of peppermints. I walk out and fought myself over stealing something in retaliation.

Like I say with all of my bad experiences with rude people, clock out and go home. No one is forcing you to be there. Don't like people? Be a killer whale trainer at Sea World. Plus, your chicken wings and seafood pancake isn't that great. It's good though. And don't be so far up your ass that you don't need customers. Yeah, Toyose is popular BECAUSE OF US! 

I do love the ringer button at each table, though.
author: Ro R.

description: It used to be better. Got there a little after 6pm,was seated right away. Service pretty prompt and there is the usual bell on the table to ring if needed. Food took a while to come out. The seafood pancake was good but overall, had too many pieces of tiny squid in it. Wished it had a more variety.  The seafood stew was not good at all. It was bland, really no flavors just a lot of red powder floating around. Haven't been in awhile but I remember it was so much better before. Chicken gizzards are Dry! The filefish appetizers are my favorite, chewy hard pieces of dried fish that probably may give me cancer overtime, I don't care..... Kim chee fried rice is pretty good.  May need to come back soon to  reacquaint my taste buds.
author: Alicia A.

description:
Finally got to try a legit meal here! (by that I mean not just drinking and snacking)

Got the beef stew with an added ramen, gizzards, and seafood pancake for the night. OH, and some kiwi and strawberry soju to go along.

Beef Stew - Pretty darn amazing! When we asked for a ramen, the waitress said there's enough glass noodle in the stew, but after 2 people jabbed in their chopsticks for it, it was already gone. So the ramen was definitely needed and made it much better.

Gizzards - It was alright. Not quite amazing as other places iced tried so ill skip that next time.

Seafood pancake - OH MY GOD. this was so good! Very flavorful, crispy and a lot of squid. The dipping sauce made it more amazing. A definite must have here, and I'm even currently craving it as of right now. 

Kiwi soju - babe and his friends said it was really good here, but I only thought it was okay, nothing tooooo special.

Strawberry soju - ugh. Cough syrup. Anybody sick want some? Lol you can definitely skip this.

Overall, quite satisfied with the food here :)
author: Harriet W.

description:
Korean fried chicken + kimchi fried rice +soju and a whole lot of loving.

This place is one of my favorite Korean joints in the Bay Area. You can't go wrong with the fried rice or fried chicken. The soju and sake just make it better. 

The only problem with this place is that if you go later on in the night, GOOD LUCK trying to find a table. People drink a lot here and they stay for a very long time. I love how the restaurant is in a house/garage setting. 

The food is excellent and the price ranges from $5-$17. Go here for a good time with your friends. This place hits the spot!
author: Adam J.

description:
What a Gem! 
I literally had dinner tonight in a garage! 
It was awesome! 
Food was great!
We had the.....
Wings
Seafood And Kimchi pancake
Calamari udon noodles (the bomb and highly suggested!)

Omg the Kiwi Soju is to die for! It's a must try!
I will definitely visit this place again!
Wish they open in SD, but a girl can only dream! :)
author: Kimberly M.

description:
I love korean food, especially on cold days and when it's in sf, it is always cold. 

First off, let me comment on the parking... What parking? We had to circle almost 4X and park up the hill and walk over. I guess when it's in sf, you'd have to assume the worst with parking, traffic, wait. The entrance of the restaurant is very grungy since they wooden doors. The seating is extremely small. 

The food takes the cake. We ordered the spicy fried chicken wings. I cannot eat spicy very well, however the wings aren't spicy at all. Mind you that this is not the spicy glazed with the hot pepper sauce. This is deep fried dry chicken wings. the little side dishes were a little disappointing. I was hoping for some potato or fish cake... it was mostly pickled items. 

The casserole, hot/pot like dish was my favorite since I love soup. My friend chose the spam one with ramen. There were so many items in this. Spam, hotdog, beef, veggies, ramen, rice cake and plenty of broth. The broth was perfect, not too spicy and it was on a flame so our food remained hot throughout the meal. I hear they are quite busy on the weekends, we went on a weeknight so we were seated promptly. I would definitely come back for their soup.
author: Phuong V.

description:
Loved this place! Good representation of random SF places with amazing food! This was one of my first times going to a Korean restaurant, but my roommate is Korean so I have tried the food before. The Kimchi Beef Fried Rice is so bomb! You must get it! Also, the kimchi pancakes and chicken wings are very good. The assortment of salty dishes added perfectly to the meat dishes. Also, the Soju! Get the strawberry soju! It doesn't even taste like alcohol...

Lastly, 5 stars to the service! I wouldn't expect awesome service like this but I left my iPhone charger there (and I was there for busiest time: dinner) and came back an hour later and the waitress saved it for me!!! Thank you so much!!! Love this place, will be back very soon.
author: Nikita K.

description: The waitress had  a poor attitude and seemed so impatient,the service was aweful.Honestly it's not a professional Korean food restaurant though.The price is just soso,no small dishes for free like commmon Korean's service, so crowded，so noisy, not worthy with what you have paid for.
author: Ivy M.

description:
Chicken wings, kimchi fried rice and alcohol in the Outer Sunset is all you need for a solid Friday night. Invite friends to join you on the fun, and it's a real party :)

If you are even craving some spicy Asian flavors in the garage of a house, look no further to Toyose. With solid food, good soju, and the typical "must be summoned with a button or else they will pass by you in the dark of night" service, you got a good thing going for you. 

I've gone here with a party of two and a party of 7, and no matter what, if you don't make a reservation or get there at the crack of dawn you will wait. Just like anyone under the influence, you will sit and drink, eat food, then get the drunchies and sit and drink and eat more. The service is fast and efficient, it's just that the customers will milk their time there to take advantages of the fruits of Toyose's labor.  Be prepared!

Favorites include:
-KimchI fried rice, with the egg as its crowning glory. Good for a party of two, maybe three. But, it is really good. 
- Spicy chicken wings. Again, good for a party of two or three, but also really good
-Cheesy corn, Literally corn on a skillet with cheese melted on top. Put this on the fried rice, you got your mind on your money and your money on your mind. AKA it's bomb, do it. 
-soju. nuff said, am I right?!

NOTE: if you do not want to wait, order to go. 10 minutes can get you fried rice and chicken wings, and since that's all i usually want for the most part, it's nice to have the option of not waiting and enjoying the goodness in my home.

Bomb food and room to enjoy this bomb food with bomb company. It's da bomb. (yes, let's bring thing phrase back into our venacular) 

**the door looks like a garage door. yes, go inside. it's okay.
author: Kristine T.

description:
It's late at night and you're near the beach, and you think to yourself "man, I could really go for some Korean food and soju in a house/garage-turned-restaurant." 

OK, the above scenario would likely never happen, but you should make it happen. Why? Soju cocktails, hot pots and fried pot stickers. Tasty, authentic and reasonably priced. The ambiance is flexibly fun, with tables at the back and booths with blinds at the front. It's small enough that I don't really get their table buzzers for service in the open area at the back, but they're still cute.

PEPPER POSSIBILITIES: Guys. You could have a bonfire on the beach and then get midnight korean fried chicken. Make it so.
author: Evelyn A.

description:
Who has two thumbs and lives close enough to walk to the best KFC in town?  This guy!  I didn't even know this place had a name at first, I kept hearing about a garage with fantastic Korean food.

Well "they" weren't lying, the food hasn't disappointed yet.  The chicken wings are crispy and well seasoned...but not spicy.  The Kimchi fried rice and seafood pancake are also super tasty!  Oh, the cheesy corn was another table-pleaser, definitely give it a try.  They're open late...you don't have any excuses not to stop by!
author: Josh M.

description:
Update. 

Holy crap.

1) the mussel soup? Delicious. I can literally drink this all day, but I'm sure the sodium level is through the roof.

35 minutes to come out. 

2) Kimchi fried rice? Average. I can't believe I waited 40 minutes for this plate. The egg was already cold, but the rice was still pretty flavorful. I wasn't angry; I had great company, but if I was really hungry, I would've left. 

40 minutes.

3) Service? Let's not kid ourselves here. It's pretty much nonexistent. When I asked a question, I got a grunt. Ok, I guess we're hiring neanderthals in mini skirts now. 

My previous review stands.
author: Tiffaney L.

description:
I wouldn't really refer to this place as a hidden gem because with over 600 reviews it's pretty translucent; and I wouldn't want to call someone's house in the Sunset a hole-in-the-wall either. Affectionately known to locals simply as "The Garage", this place is hot and not because of the kimche dishes this Korean bar food restaurant serves up... 

When we walked inside, it instantly reminded me of when I grew up and we used to hang out inside of friends garages where we once used to host dance parties spinning LP's under subdued lighting a long time ago... 

My wife's nephew and his wife were still acting as our fixers while we were visiting up in the city. They had already hooked us up at Bi-Rite and Tartine, now it was time for some dinner in someone's remodeled garage somewhere in outer Noriega St. (???). Fortunately they had called ahead and made arrangements, otherwise we would have had to wait along with the dozen or so other customers waiting just inside the barn-like double doors at the entrance. On that night, we rolled in like rockers 'scuse me, pardon us,..." 

The ambiance is Korean ghetto chic if there really is such a thing -- I might have just made that up. There was sectional wood paneling with posters of cute girls with flowing Farrah-Fawcett like hair holding bottles of beer adorning the walls, bamboo mat partitions were suspended from the ceiling, dividing the dining area in the otherwise long narrow space. The waitresses that remind me somewhat of bar maids were these cutsy diminutive little Asian girls that were busy running around filling orders, bringing food and drinks, and clearing off tables. Our waitress was orderly and attentive, even if a bit subdued and silent... 

We let our hosts do all the ordering, especially since I wouldn't know what to order aside from the really ordinary stuff like bulgogi. The soju here is suppose to be super popular but I'm not much of a drinker to begin with and nobody else in our party of 6 seemed interested in trying it. One thing I noticed right away was the lack of very many sides or ban-chan as I had encountered at Korean BBQ places in the past, perhaps it wasn't customary to serve it in this case, I didn't know. We had: 

- Spicy Fried Chicken Wings;  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=vtB8-qdrQiRF9YHNwy5DtA 
- Kimche Fried Rice;  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=5cEyQZ9nOVEHbCGODkHZ2g
- Seafood Pancake;  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=vF7sqlHZbO_JvlSfp5fNhA
- Bulgogi and Calamari;  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=7w2kbsN5dLUiafPdKIM3qg

The first two items I understand are their most popular dishes.  All in all I was happy with the taste of each dish, but I didn't feel full, even though we doubled up on most everything for the 6 of us...

Thinking about it, this is a great place to come to warm up with some spicy food, especially during those typically foggy SF evenings.  I even heard that it's open til 2am, now that's some serious eats...
author: Lawrence L.

description:
If SpongeBob SquarePants had Korean parents and a Japanese aunt or uncle, I could see this as being his restaurant. The interior nautical hints of boat ropes and wood posts almost make you forget you're in a converted garage, and the fact that you're in a garage might make you not notice the slightly maritime decor. I include Japanese in the background due to the presence of Japanese writing on at least one wall decoration.

Seems to me like the menu might be a little different now than in months or years past, but the army stew, bibim naengmyeon, and selection of beverages to pass around and try to thump the metal twig off the cap are still there. My friend liked the fact that there's popcorn, and spicy edamame is always good to me. There are also fish sticks, bacon sausage, and fried whole chicken. So any Blues Brothers fans out there can literally order four fried chickens and a Coke.

This place keeps an interesting mix of dishes, but to me it doesn't quite warrant a crosstown trip for dinner. Still, for meeting friends or as the afterparty to whatever, I'd go here any night, though I might wear an eyepatch and bring some Hemingway to read on the way over.

FYI: The signage outside does say both "Toyose" and "Chamse", but rest assured you are at the right place. People speak of this restaurant using the names interchangeably, so keep that in mind too.
author: Dan B.

description:
Dined June 18, 2015, with my son and his significant other. We arrived about 8 p.m. there looked to be room for about 40, maybe 50.The hostess would not say how long the wait was, nor say how many people were waiting;  apparently this is their policy. Had I known it would be over 2 hours, I would have asked to dine elsewhere. 

That said,  the food was delicious. We tried and greatly enjoyed chicken wings,  a kimchee pancake and a beef stew with greens, tofu, mushrooms, octopus and glass noodles. I  had only had Korean beef and fish stew when I visited Korea while on a port visit  (Navy daze).

I don't think it was worth the wait  (nothing is at this point), but the food is awesome. Hopefully there's an app or something that could help them predict seating vs. wait time.
author: Varrick N.

description: The food was great but service was HORRIBLE. Seriously those waiters needs to go back to kindergarden and learn their manners. I would come back for the food but cos of the service, nah.
author: Valerie H.

description:
Food: 3.5/5
Customer Service: 0/5
Noise Level: 4/5
Speed: 3/5

The ONLY reason I'm even giving this place two stars is cause the food is here is pretty decent. I've been to Toyose twice, the first experience better (only because it was nearly empty when I went) than the latter. 

First of all, the customer service here sucks. The waitresses here need hearing aids. My friend called at 6 to make a reservation for 630. The waitress then told her the reservation had been set for 630. When we arrived at 620 the SAME waitress said our reservation was at 730 and gave us dirty looks when we tried to explain to her that it was definitely 630 not 730. Her bad and ignorant attitude instantly gave me bad vibes and frustrated me.

If you can deal with shitty customer service in exchange for decent korean food then go for it. But if you wanted to be treated like a decent human being then you should go somewhere else. There are plenty other korean hotspots in SF. 


On a final note, the beef kimchi fried rice here is good but the rude customer service and crowded ambiance ain't worth it.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Toyose is all hype and is awful. I ordered the kimchi fried rice and the assorted seafood udon. First off the fried rice was extremely bland and tasted but only a little kimchi. It had a minuscule amount of beef and was definitely not worth the price. The udon was falsely advertised. The label said assorted seafood but all there was was a loads worth of octopus (~20 pieces) and 2 tiny shrimp, 1 muscle. I personally like octopus but this octopus was tasteless and exceedingly chewy. Couldn't and didn't bother finishing the bowl. 

I don't usually write bad reviews but this restaurant had me feel that I wasted my money big time. 11 dollars for tasteless fried rice that had nothing but barely any meat is ridiculous. And the assorted udon was nothing but octopus which was a huge disappointment.

And to finish it all off, the server was rude, impatient, and unhelpful. She talked to us as she walked away and did not have any mannerisms.
author: Lewis T.

description: Super authentic great food. Great service. Open till 2 am. What more could a neighbor ask for?
author: Jonah K.

description:
The first time I heard about this place was some time in high school. A couple of nights ago I finally got the chance to come here with some friends for late night food and drinks. 

We ordered: 
Kim Chee Fried Rice - pretty good, definitely hits that late night food craving, Cheese Corn - this was on their house favorites list, it's literally cheese... and corn... it wasn't very exciting if you ask me, Fries + Garlic and Cheese - savory and filling, the typical snack food people would order after you've had a few drinks. 

Kiwi and Pineapple Soju - This was my first time having soju and it was pretty good. The pineapple flavor was probably my fave because it wasn't too sweet. The kiwi on the other hand is more syrupy and tasted a lot like a jolly rancher. 

Overall our experience was okay, the decor was interesting.. I mean it is the infamous Korean garage restaurant... and the service was subpar. Basically a quick stop for food and drinks kind of restaurant, but not much more.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Customer experience:3/5
Food: 4/5
Soju: 4/5

The service is ok, nothing spectacular. Pretty much straightforward:) you can press a button on the tables for the employees to come over. 

The food 4/5 . The garlic fries i ordered were bomb! The bacon sausage was bomb! We got strawberry soju! We havent had it in a while, so it was definitely yummy!
author: Jeanette L.

description:
MMMMM, Toyose!

Came here for the first time all the way back in October or so with my teammate. We got there a few minutes after it opened and were seated immediately. I had the notion that they were going to open the garage door and we can be seated in the garage area, like how they do so in Taiwan. Not the case, you open the door to the garage and you walk in and upon entering there are booths. Interesting....

We sat down, we ordered the kimchee fried rice, seafood pancake, and a bulgoki. All were very delicious. Teammate's favorite was the kimchee fried rice and the seafood pancake. The seafood pancake comes with a delicious sauce a little soy saucey and a little spicy.

Came here a second time, initially we wanted to be seated and eat, but the wait was way too long, so we opted for take out instead. Again we got the kimchee fried rice and the seafood pancake, we changed it up and got the chicken wings instead of the bulgoki. CHICKEN WANGS ARE DA BOMB. Go for it. :)
author: Mabel Y.

description:
I finally tried Toyose! I've attempted to come here before and each time was during a busy weekend night where the waitresses could never give an accurate wait time (maybe an hour, maybe less) so I never waited. I came with a big group on a Monday night and we took advantage of making a reservation. 

I had the beef kim chi fried rice and the spicy chicken wings. Keep in mind that the kim chi fried rice doesn't include spam but you can request to have it added. I found that the fried rice was good but could have used more kick. Also, it didn't have a lot of beef. The spicy chicken wings could have been spicier but I enjoyed its super crunchy batter. My favorite part of the meal was the soju. Each flavor was balanced well and some flavors included fresh fruit bits. I tried all of the flavors, and liked each in the following order: 

1) Strawberry
2) Peach
3) Aloe
4) Yogurt
5) Kiwi
6) Mango
7) Pineapple
8) Lemon
9) Cranberry

I would definitely return for the soju!
author: Maya S.

description: If i could give this place a 0 star based on the server alone, i would. But they're lucky that yelp does not allow that. I just finished eating here with my girlfriend and her father for father's day and oh my god I just had the worst experience out of all the restaurants I've ever been to. After we finished eating, we got the check and after paying, one of the waitress had the audacity to come back and ask if we were going to pay the tip when we weren't even ready to leave yet and especially when she wasn't even our server. Because of how rude she was, we decided not to tip at all. As we were leaving, the waitress had the balls to yell out in front of all the customers telling us to stop and say we didn't pay tip. She followed us all the way outside the restaurant and even argued with my girlfriend's dad...on father's day! I just straight up told her that it's not by law that customers have to tip and she had the nerve to tell us, and I quote, "do not ever come back again." She didn't have to tell us that because no way would we ever come back to such poor service. WORST FATHER'S DAY EVER! There are way better Korean restaurants out there with way better service. NOTE TO OWNER: is a tip really worth losing customers to? Please talk to your employees because it seems they don't understand the concept of good customer service.
author: Gabriel H.

description:
Great wings, boiling pot, pancake,and kimchi fried rice. All the hits. Probably what Roy choi wishes his restaurants were like!
Nothing fancy.
Love the call button for servers.
author: Hallie C.

description: Ok. This was me and my gf went to this place for the second time, but we decided will never come here again. The waitresses were really rude to customers. Here's what had happened. We got 4 people party today and about to enjoyed the Korean hotspot because two friends come from Boston to visit us. We originally sat at a corner place and they gave us menu to look. Then, we thought the corner table was too small for all 4 of us because we don't feel comfortable to squeeze in. Then, I politely asked one of the waitresses about changing to a table near the front door, and they said yes. Then, another waitress turned around and told me: 'bring your water and menu with you.' I think 'shouldn't the waitress bring us those water and menu' because I would paid tips at the end. Then, I asked the waitresses could you help me to get two waters? Then, the waitress said to me 'we served you, and you were been rude.' I felt that was hilarious because she was being rude to her customers at the moment! Then, my gf told her, ' yes, we could bring our waters, but we won't pay the service fee.' Then, THAT WAITRESS TOLD US: 'THERE THE EXIT, YOU CAN GO.' We were shocked, and I have been to numerous Korean restaurant in years but never had this kind of disrespectful service. I am now still felt the anger about the altitude regarding that service lady thrown to us. Such an awful experience!
author: YI Z.

description:
When we arrived around 8:30 on a Friday night the restaurant was completely full, and had about 4-5 large groups waiting. They told us 1 hour wait, so we went to the wine and coffee bar across the street for a bottle to drink before dinner.

The wait was a mere 30-40 minutes in the end. The restaurant is decorated in a fun, Korean style and felt pretty authentic (Says the white guy who's never been to Korea). It was mostly Korean and Asian diners, which usually is a good sign. The 4 of us shared stir fried kimchi and beef, rice, deep fried Korean chicken wings, and a huge buckwheat noodle platter. We were all pretty full, the food was hot and fresh, and the wait staff were friendly and fast despite them being so busy. 

It's a bit far out there but parking isn't an issue and you pay a lot less money than if you ate closer to the city center.
author: Jordan C.

description:
I'm not sure how else you can describe it besides it being a "hole in the wall". 

You can very, very easily walk/drive by if you weren't looking for it. On the outside, it literally looks like someone's garage. But don't let that fool you!

I was here with some friends and we got the beef kimchi fried rice (very good) and the chicken wings (also very good). I'll start off with the beef kimchi fried rice (refer to my photo if you'd like to see what it looks like). Not sure how you feel about strips of seaweed but it really added the extra "flair" to the dish. It was more than just "garnish", it tasted really good! The bits of kimchi broke up the monotony of just having spoons fulls of rice. It offered a bit of crunch in between bites. This dish is not spicy at all!

Secondly, the chicken wings: not the "best" korean fried chicken I've had but still very, very good. Just enough crispiness on the outside, and moistness on the inside. Very good appetizer to share with 2 or 3 persons per order.

Tip: the later it gets, the busier it gets!!!
author: Charles K.

description:
My Ratings:
Quantity: 4
Quality: 4
Price: 3
Location: 3
Parking: 3
Service: 4
Speed: 4

Overall:  A cool place to eat with lots of good food and drinks!

What's good?:  Fried chicken, Spam noodle soup
What's not?:  no ban chans for dinner

My Opinion/Story:
This place is always busy and if you have a big group, make sure you have a reservation. Always fun to come here with a big group to share the soup and other dishes. Prices can be on the higher end but worth it. Service is always quick when you push the call button.  Soju drinks are tasty.  Food comes quick and there's always enough for more.
author: Cherryl D.

description:
A group of friends and I decided to go here to catch up over dinner. I had never heard of this place but I was pretty stoked about getting Korean food for dinner since I don't have it too often. 

When we got there, I was surprised by what I saw. This restaurant was built within a house so it looks very house-like outside. The doors to go in is made from past garage doors. For this, I find the outer appearance odd. 

Apparently, I was in for more surprises. Despite looking odd on the outside, the inside was very impressive. Fashioned with wood decor, it looked really authentic and cozy as a restaurant. A bit cramped, but it still fits a lot of people. You would have never known that it used to be a garage! 

Service was pretty attentive but forgot one order and then got it wrong after we asked them about it. It wasn't a super big deal, but it was kind of annoying. To be fair, the place has a really loud atmosphere and they seem to be busy very often.

We ordered two orders of kimchi fried rice, an order of split eel, an order of spicy pork, and one order of kimchi pancake. Everything was really delicious! I like their kimchi fried rice and the spicy pork the most. Very flavorful and filling.

Overall a really cool place. I plan to come back here not just because of the food but also to try their soju.
author: Sofia R.

description:
YAAAAWWWWWSSSSSSSS! Toyose is definitely one of the best Korean joints in town.

My boyfriend and I came to Toyose on a Friday night and found the garage to be pretty packed. The wait was quoted at an hour, however, we were seated before that which was nice! We ordered the Spicy Chicken Wings, the Beef Kimchi Fried Rice, and the Japchae.

Spicy Chicken Wings - Holy heck these were delicious! Although the menu states that they were "spicy" the wings were definitely not that spicy! Sure, they weren't the best wings I've had, but they were extremely satisfying. I wish they had some sort of sauce to dip them in though!

Beef Kimchi Fried Rice - Hands down, their Beef Kimchi Fried Rice was definitely one of the best dishes at Toyose! It was savory and flavorful, yet had that nice bitter Kimchi taste to it. I highly recommend this dish!

Japchae - The dish was loaded with lots of veggies, which I liked, however I wish there were more noodles. Nonetheless, the japchae was a good "carb" for the meal and pairs great with the chicken wings!

I honestly don't remember how much we spent, but it was around $40. The cozy garage (literally a garage) friendly staff, and great food made for an awesome experience.
author: Joyce E.

description: Came here with my co-workers after we were done with out shift. It was after 11:00 PM, but it was still very busy. We ordered spicy chicken wings, beef stew, seafood pancake, cheese corn, and stir fired calamari with bulgogi. All the food taste very good, except the cheese corn. The cheese corn taste blank. The beef stew is a must try. The service is ok. Not very good but not very bad.
author: Viola C.

description:
This place use to be the "hole in the wall" until everyone and their Marina bro mainstreamed it. Yes soju is booze and it's d*mn better than PBR and Bud Light. For all the guys who cringe at breaking a nail when they drink their cosmos or sex on the beach, you have the yogurt flavored soju to choose from. The Korean food is passable if you're "non-korean" and is considered awesome. Real Korean food is many levels above the fast food found here.

Why complain and whine about the cold weather here? You're here to get drunk and fed, the weather is the last of your worries. The food has changed somewhat since the Marina Bros started hitting this place in mass. 

The next "hole in the wall" will require a society ritual and fluency in 3 foreign languages just to get in. Until next time...
author: Joseph N.

description:
We've been shadows visiting Toyose probably every other time we frequent the city ... love this little hole in the wall ... 

We come for the beer, the ambience, and of course the chicken gizzards. What other cozy place do you go to in the sunset? This was the first place I had soju and yogur. First place, we had hite and gotten sufficiently smashed. 

It's a place where you should call ahead and put your table reservation in and it's also the place you decide to go to late night.

pricey if you're the type not to spend a lot of money but can't help ordering the kimchee fried rice and whatever tasty appetizer they have there ...

always a go-to place to bring our out of town visitors :)
author: Misty M.

description:
Can you say "best kimchi fried rice ever"? Because that's exactly it! Love, love, the kimchi fried rice here. In my personal opinion, it's the best in the city. Their kimchi chigae and their chicken wings are pretty good too. 

Service here is decent, nothing special. Not horrible and not great, bust just right.

If you just wanna hang out with friends, have some beer, soju, and food (whether it's a snack or a meal), this is the place to go.

The only thing is that there's always a line...so plan wisely!
author: Erica L.

description:
This was where I first discovered that I started an amazing relationship with the love of my life right now. 

So I'll have to say this place has done her and I well, I like the mussel soup, it's spicy good! And the chicken wings are amazing crunchy with the kimchi fried rice! And our favorite is the strawberry soju! But we sometime mix it bartender style with kiwi soju. We come here very so often to enjoy a night to remember of our first night that started our love life together. Our first kiss...
author: D L.

description:
I came here on a Friday night for a friend's birthday dinner.  Luckily we were able to snag a reservation since we had more than 4 people.  The place was completely packed, with a huge waiting list.  Based on our observations, it looked like people were waiting an hour+ to sit down.  As many other reviewers mentioned, the restaurant is tiny and was built out in a home-garage.  One complain I would have was that our party of 6 was pretty cramped in a table meant for 4.

The food was awesome!  We ordered the following:
Fried Chicken Wings- Amazing!!!  Super flavorful and crispy.  The chicken was moist and not overly greasy.
Rice Cakes- Definitely not my favorite (not a huge fan of rice cakes/mochi, which definitely explains why).
Seafood Pancake- Very good!  A lot of squid and onions and came with a flavorful sauce.
Bulgogi- One of my favorite things.  It was super tender and also had a ton of flavor.
Spam and Ramen Stew- This was my first time having Korean Stew, and I definitely recommend it.  It wasn't too spicy and was very savory with tofu, spam, hotdogs, fishcakes, ramen noodles, and cabbage.  It reminded me of a creamier soondubu.
Kimchee Fried Rice- This was good, but not super memorable.
Aloe Soju- Super sweet and tastes just like those Aloe drinks you can buy at the Asian supermarket.  If you're not a huge fan of the taste of alcohol, I definitely recommend this!

While the food was delicious, I don't think I'd wait more than 15 minutes for this place, and will only return if I'm able to reserve a table.
author: Michelle M.

description: A friend highly recommended the restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. We ordered beef stew and pineapple soju. In addition, they offered us some pickles for free. Really delicious and authentic Korean food.
author: Nancy S.

description: Hands down best Korean Tapas in town. Open Late, everyday. Food is amazing (taste of authentic Korean drinking food), Service is great, and flavored Soju is dangerous. Be advised, making reservations is highly recommend due to high popularity, the wait can be ridiculous.
author: Steed A.

description: lines are too long. In my opinion the foods are overrated. The waitress are not friendly and not bothered to put things slowly.
author: Johan K.

description:
Tried this place last night. 

Coming in I was surprised their restaurant was in a garage. Anyways, I came in and it styled out pretty weird. Wasn't sure who to talk to nor where to list my name. The waitress immediately saw my boyfriend and I and she said about 10-15 min wait. So we sat down and waited. So lucky we came in just in time before a huge group of people walked through the door. 

While we got seated we were looking at the menu to make sure we were ready to order because we were so hungry. I wanted the seafood combo hot pot, but they don't serve it with noodles!? Whaaaaaat? Minus  1 star. I'm sorry, but being asian you really need to put some noodles with soup. Rice just doesn't cut it. 

My boyfriend ordered the kimchi fried rice and japchae. I would def come back for the Kimchi fried rice with egg on top. Also ordered the strawberry soju with the seafood combo with noodles -- which was so so. 

These place would be really good for a group of friends sitting around hot pot, sharing dishes, and drinking soju.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Top quality Korean cuisine!  Moved out to the Outer Sunset neighborhood a few months ago and have ordered Toyose for take-out more than 5 times.  The food is spectacular.  Everything we've tried so far has been delicious.  Our favorite is the kimchi seafood pancake.  

One note for Toyose staff: do us take-out folks a favor and package the sauce for your pancake outside of the pancake box.  Twice I've had it break open dump all over one corner of the pancake, soaking it.  No biggy, but it would be better packed outside.
author: Scott B.

description:
Fried chicken wings is too dry and its not tasty.  It was recommended by someone and i was so excited to try, but i was disappointed.

Kimchi fried rice was nothing special. Pop corn was plain. I can't remember what else we ordered.

Nothing impressive. 

Will not go back for sure.
author: Che K.

description:
Garage Korean restaurant? No way?!

I was pretty amazed when my friend brought me to this place. I couldn't believe it was inside a garage. Boy, they are saving money by using their own garage as a restaurant. As you enter Toyose, it's small with tables and seats on the left side. We were seated right away. 

We ordered kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, and seafood tofu soup. Supposedly, this place is one of the best Korean restaurants in SF. This may be the situation, but I've had better seafood pancake and seafood tofu soup from Sac (Sarang bang). The seafood pancake small, possibly enough for 2 people. The seafood tofu soup lacked taste and I expected it to be spicy. 

With the disappointment of the food, the service was horrible. Our server was very rude and far from polite. I was very turned off from the way she treated us and spoke to us like we didn't know anything. 

I'll probably try other dishes next time and give it another try.
author: Karla Marie D.

description:
Took a date here cause I couldn't stop recommending the food here. The wait time is usually about 20 minutes and as I signed up on their wait list, we took a seat near the front of the restaurant. After conversing for about an hour and getting lost in our conversation, we realized we were never notified that our table was ready. I then went to tell the waitress who insisted that she called our names 20 minutes ago. Hmm, I think we would've remembered that since we were glancing over at them every ten minutes or so.

So we were seated ten minutes after this incident and right next to a drunk group of patrons. Okay, this is probably one of the worst places for a first date. I don't recall my last experience being so horrid.

Well, we ordered the seafood pancake, kimchi fried rice and the calamari. Okay, the food is just decent. I've dated a Korean girl in the past who would cook dishes that tasted way better than this spot and fresher. Parking around here is okay since it's pretty far away from many other venues at night and they still had the buzzer that they have in every korean restaurant.

Overall, this place needs to address their mistakes and live up to it. We would have left had it not been a Friday night and the fact we'd probably end up waiting another half hour at any other venue that night.
author: Ced C.

description: Zero star if possible, extremely bad service, very rude!!!!! Non reasonable!!! Don't make sense about what they are talking about, "you guys don't have to eat here you can leave!!"  they cancel our reservation for   2min, don't make sense at all.
author: Emily Z.

description: Besides the Kimchi fried rice. Everything seemed to me just meh! I wasn't too impressed with the tofu pot and the so called deep fried spicy chicken. I have had better tasting and actually spicy chicken else where. It was not as good as it was hyped up to be. Don't get me wrong, foods are decent, just wasn't wowing.
author: Yao Z.

description:
Deserves four and a half stars not four, to distinguish it from the other soju joints. Their food is that much better.

The lines are horrendous, come super early at opening or super late, if you can't get them to reserve you a table!
author: Carun J.

description: Kimchi fried rice is the best here. I love the ambiance of the place, defiantly would be a fun date night spot. The stews are always fun and you get a lot of food, we shared between 4 people and it was more than enough.
author: Vika N.

description: The Kimchi Fried Rice was epic. The Chicken Wing was awesome. Everything I ordered was great!
author: Joshua Edwin R.

description:
I'm a sucker for korean food, this place was a little bit of a disappointment. A couple od things before I do the food breakdown. It is pretty easy to miss this ave if you are going for the first time. It looks like a garage door from the outside, I'm pretty sure they converted the garage into a restaurant. It's a bit narrow and tight inside, but its clean and cozy.

Service: 2.5 stars
The place was almost full when I was there on a tuesday night around 7 pm. There were only 2 ppl working (server and cashier), so the service was slow. Honestly, the service wasn't bad, they were just under staffed. We pretty much had to waive them down everytime we needed something (our table was the only one without the call button).

Food:

Kimchi pancake 3 stars: it was a pretty decent size, but I didn't think it was worth $11. Might as well pay a couple of dollars more and get the seafood pancake. It comes with this chili fish sauce, which I liked (prbly the Vietnamese in me). The kimchi was cut into really small pieces and you couldn't really taste it (please put more kimchi in it!). 

Spicy chicken wings 3.5 stars: good amount of wings for the price.  It's lightly breaded and had a nice crunch to it. I didn't think it was spicy at all and honestly, could've used more seasoning or a sauce to dip it in. I actually dipped it in the sauce that came with my kimchi pancake. I do like that it comes with the pickled radish!

Kimchi fried rice 3.5 stars: the portion was decent and I love my sunny side up egg on top. I liked it, but didn't love it. I think it needs more pepper paste and kimchi! 

Overall, I thought this place is a bit pricey, but the food is pretty decent. I do want to try their big hot pot thing, the table next to us got one and it looked good.
author: Thuy N.

description: Super love this Korean place. Tried it for the first time. Really like the ambience and seating in the restaurant.the army stew was the bomb! The soup was very tasty and there were a lot of ingredients in it. the Fried chicken, seafood pancakes and kimchi fried rice were all very legit too! Would definitely recommend this
author: Qianqi L.

description: Another solid Korean dinner here.  We are regulars and once again had the spicy pork, potstickers, jap chae, and cheesy corn.  All good as usual!
author: Steven B.

description:
Wasn't the greatest Korean food I've had but it was decent. 

Service was good, food was okay.. Had bulgogi and yogurt soju. 

The corn cheese was way overhyped in my opinion. 

Will be back to try other things!
author: Catherine Y.

description:
This place was really good... really cool setup.

Located in what looks to be someones decked out garage, this place offers some of the best Korean dishes! The crowd is quiet- a great place to take a small family... I wouldn't plan on throwing any dinner party or birthday celebration here since space is limited from what I seen. Located a few blocks away from the beach, that way you can walk off what you ate!

***Come hungry, the portions are HUGE- enough to share for 2-3 people easy!***

I'am a huge fan of this place! We ordered Bulgogi, Sea food Pancakes and some Udon soup- BOMB!... when I looked around to see some of the food others had ordered THAT LOOKED EVEN BETTER!!!! i got jelly, so now i HAVE to come back... SOON! :))
author: Corey G.

description:
Uhh... are we in the right place?

Me and the hubby were looking for a place to eat after an evening at Nightlife, but it was getting pretty late. Options were dwindling. Toyose popped up on my Yelp app and we had never heard of it.

As we were driving down the road to get there, there were less and less businesses. Where were we going?? We almost missed the place actually. I was about to make a U-turn after seeing the shady dive bar across the street. Good thing we stayed though!

The outside of the place looks like someone's house and garage. I was a little worried we were in the wrong place, but then you open the door and...

*POOF*... a full blown restaurant?? So. Totally. Amazing. 

You would never think a restaurant was behind those doors! 

After a 15 minute wait, we were seated and immediately dived into the menu. We went for their spicy fried chicken and beef kimchi fried rice. They seemed like the most popular choices. I sooooo wanted to order soju, but I had work the next day. *sad face*

The fried chicken was super crispy. Not too spicy. I loved the pickled daikon it came with. 

O... M... G... but the beef kimchi fried rice.... sooooooo deliiiicious!! I could eat the whole plate by myself. You can taste the flavor in every piece of rice. There weren't any clumps of rice that missed the seasoning. And the sunnyside up egg enhances everything. It tastes especially delicious with the runny egg yolk coating the rice. There could have been more beef though. 

I totally suggest this place if you're looking for a late night hangout. They're open until 2AM. Definitely get the kimchi fried rice. You won't be disappointed.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Definitely a hole in the wall place, and even easy to miss since it looks like someone's house. 

First time there, ordered the kimchee rice ($11), seafood pancake ($13) and yogurt soju ($11). Fair prices, and the food was pretty good!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Large-portion, quality, Korean food out of a garage? Me thinks YES!

Food was amazing, so much flavor! Kimchi fried rice with egg, cheese corn, codfish tofu soup, calamari, seafood pancake, & fried chicken wings - all good!

They take reservations for larger parties but make sure everyone gets there on time because they will give your table away if not. Place is pretty small & poppin' so the earlier, the better!

1 star less because they didn't have the traditional meal dishes, like kalbi or bibimbop. I would definitely go back though!
author: Alysha K.

description: Well if the last member of our party had gotten here on time, we would have been able to get a seat right when they opened, but alas they didn't so we ended up in the 2nd wave of seating, which wasn't to bad aside from the wafting smells of delicious foods making us salivate. By the time we sat down and had our menus we already knew what we wanted based on looking at everyone elses orders. For three people we ordered a total feast and almost conquered it all. The kimchee onion pancake, fried rice, and chicken were our favorites. This is definitely a place i'd like to try again.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Talk about inconspicuous!  If you are not familiar with this area, the 40th Avenue area in the Outer Sunset has nothing but houses.  It's very residential and very quiet.  So the first time a friend brought me here, I thought we were going to someone's house for dinner.  If it weren't for the awning with TOYOSE written on it, this place would just blend right along with all the other houses next to it.  

Why?  Because this restaurant is a convert from a resident's garage.  Yup!  However, I must say, they did a pretty good job with the conversion.  Soju?  Check.  Extensive menu of traditional Korean dishes?  Check.  Korean pop music?  Oh yeah, check.  All around, it's a decent Korean restaurant.

However, I must comment:  The bulgogi was fairly disappointing.  I've been here a few times, and it always tastes a little off (someone always orders it).  However, I am a fan of the kimchi fried rice and the spicy chicken wings.

They are opened until 2am everyday!  It's great for Korean food cravings in the middle of the night :)

One last thing:  You WILL exude a strong Korean food odor after leaving this institution.  Even just a 10 minute wait for my takeout left me smelling like Korean food for the rest of the night!
author: Cecilia S.

description: The spam stew is a must try item !!!!!!! We order it every time we come here! Waitress are nice and pretty!! ^^ I wish the wait could be shorter !! We will be back!!
author: Pauline W.

description:
Food is good, but it would be nice if the staff could be more accommodating. We called in to ask about the wait, which they said would be 30 minutes (at 1am). Given their response, our party of 3 decided to order take out. Upon our arrival 20 minutes later, we saw that there were several large tables available. We asked if we could sit down and eat and offered to tip and/or order more food and drinks, but the staff was adamant about not letting us stay. They said that it was their policy because the food was already in the containers (which we said we didn't mind just using). The waitress was very unapologetic and did not really have any reason for not letting us sit there. She was not rude but certainly not welcoming.

There are definitely restaurants with much better hospitality and friendlier staff.
author: Denton X.

description:
Cozy, hole-in-the-wall place for amazing Korean food. It literally looks like the owners just converted their garage into a restaurant, which is cooler than it sounds.

We had a reservation on a Tuesday night, otherwise I've heard there's usually a long wait.

Food came out pretty fast. In order of preference, though everything was good: 

- Kimchi pancake
- Japchae
- Kimchi fried rice
- Dukboki
- Chicken wings (probably would try something else in place of this next time)
author: An Y.

description:
Stopped in for a late night dinner with the boyfriend and was seated quickly. Not a lot of people eating in at 10:30/11 in a Sunday night. We quickly ordered hot sake, calamari and noodles, bibimguksu, ddokbokki, and beef kimchi fried rice. A lot of food, I know. The food came out in waves, and we were thrilled at the speed.

Calamari and Noodles - 4/5
Piping hot, tons of calamari. Noodles overcooked, but fair amount of spice and crisp veggies.

Bibimguksu - 4/5
Deconstructed on a big platter to be mixed together. Great selection of veggies and proteins, sweet and spicy. Noodles were perfect.

Ddokbokki - 2/5
Wasn't my favorite dish, a bit too sweet like ketchup. The ricecakes were soft and chewy, but the flavor was all wrong :(

Beef Kimchi Fried Rice - 5/5
DELICIOUS. Possibly even better than kimchi fried rice I've had in Koreatown in NY. Generous amount of marinated beef and kimchi cut up and mixed together. So. Good.

Service was a little slow, but we were also tucked in a hidden corner. A boisterous, large group came in and that was our cue to pack takeaways and head on out. Overall, great late night gem. Would definitely dine here again.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Between 3-3.5 stars, but definitely not 4 stars so rounding down. I came to Toyose a few months ago since I kept hearing about those awesome Korean restaurant in the Sunset. We came on a Tuesday night around 9pm, and there was surprisingly still a 10 minute wait at that time! They have some booths at the front of the restaurant, and then a larger area in the back with more tables. I wish we were sat in the front versus the back, since it got a bit steamy in there with so many people and so many tofu stews/casseroles/noodle soup dishes. You definitely walk out smelling not so fresh after dining here. In any case, we ordered:

-Kimchi and Beef Fried Rice w/Egg (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=98QanNLoRhYdO_sFr3AQgQ#98QanNLoRhYdO_sFr3AQgQ): Good, but nothing special. I liked the fried egg on top, but it was on the salty side.
-Spicy Chicken Wings ($12.95, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=98QanNLoRhYdO_sFr3AQgQ#AYxO8k7SJv8MGKmntq6F0Q): Ok, but I didn't think they were that spicy. These are the dry style wings, whereas I like more of a sauce. It also seemed like our wings were slightly overfried.
-Seafood Pancake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=98QanNLoRhYdO_sFr3AQgQ#M2n1dbaLgkSVriantptJPw): Pretty good, but not much different from your seafood pancake at any other Korean restaurant. However, they didn't skimp on the seafood at least.
-Cheese Corn (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/toyose-san-francisco?select=98QanNLoRhYdO_sFr3AQgQ#PtpC_ewNx9-92WDWmKwEMg): Just ok. I didn't think this could ever be a problem, but there was actually too much cheese on the corn! Although you get the nice strings of cheese when you took your spoon of cheese corn, the cheese was still on the hard side. 

Overall, I was pretty disappointed with my experience at Toyose. However, I do live only 10 minutes away from 30 Korean restaurants (in the South Bay), so I think I have a pretty high standard for Korean food. There weren't any dishes at Toyose that stood out for me, and with the difficulty in finding parking in this area, I don't think I'll be back. However, I do regret not trying one of those giant noodle bowls that every other table seemed to have, so will definitely have to give that a try if I come back. Service was decent, but not very attentive, which was expected.
author: Amy D.

description:
The fried chicken wing is very awesome !!! Kimchi fried rice is very good too~ but the environment is crowded and stuffy!
I think it's a little noise in there, but food is good!
author: Angela D.

description:
Came here for a snack.

Seafood pancake - yummy.

Corn cheese - disappointed. Had better somewhere else. 

Fried chicken - pretty good. But nothing too special.
author: A A.

description: Poor services !!!!! I never write a bad review in my life but I was so surprised about their customer service.The waitress are arrogant and rude!!! We asked for the water refills and waved at them so many times, but she slowly turned and walked away.I even saw them yelled at a couple when they just wanted to change the seat. The food wjust ok...I won't be back to this restaurant because they don't respect the customers!!!
author: Grace P.

description: This place is so good. Many different flavors of soju and many different dishes to choose from. When we got there, the wait staff said that it would take 40 mins to seat us. However, we then got seated in  about 7 minutes. We ordered the kimchi & seafood fried pancake, mango soju, kimchi friend rice, and the Korean bbq chicken. All of which were absolutely delicious. One thing I do want to try there is the cheese corn, but that'll have to wait til next time. Their soju is stronger than Tonight's Sojo Bar's. It's absolutely so good as the flavors blend so well. Would definitely come back if I was in the area.
author: Julie L.

description:
Krazy Korean food konkoctions.  Plus, all your clothing-- okay, your entire body, from head to toe-- will reeek Eau de Toyose after dining here.

Looong wait for a table-- WTH.  And this was on a Wednesday.  At least it seems to be doing great business at dinner hour.

You would never know this was an eating establishment.  It is a standard Sunset District house whose ground floor level-- which is usually a garage or an in-law type living area/apartment-- was turned into Toyose.

Seriously.  Like, someone's home kitchen downstairs was bibbidi bibimbop-idi boo'd into a funky Korean resto.

All I can think is, this place somehow must have successfully battled through a fascinating inspections process by the City of San Francisco.  I have total sympathy for the property owner, in that respect.

My friend and I weren't that hungry, so we just ordered a couple of appetisers:  something called "corn cheese", and an order of fries.

Well, the dark spicy thick-cut french fries were eaten all gone; the corn veg mixture, covered in a layer of mozzarella (or some kind of white cheese) and broiled... not so much.

A little bummed out though, as I didn't dare drink because I had a bit of a freeway drive right afterwards.

Guess I might be interested in returning to try soju shooters.  That may be the only way I can happily distract myself from the pungent atmosphere.

So, I have to go now.  My Toyose-permeated jeans and tops are desperately begging me to launder them.

;P
author: Jade T.

description: I've been here twice now. Last time I was here was for a friend's birthday. This time I'm coming back for my birthday. The food is good so why two stars? Because one of the waitress is straight up Beezy. The last time we were here. The waitress kept giving us looks every time we order more food. There were 10 of us. So we're gonna bound to order a lot of things. Last time I didn't want to write a review because I don't have that much nice things to say about the place except the food. This time... I have worst things to say about their attitude. Maybe it's the way they look. I don't know... Bottom line is. Good food. Bad service
author: Nga C.

description:
They turned an unsuspecting home in the sunset into a restaurant without any hints of the former remaining. Amazing! I've heard of the "garage" and i love korean food - so why not?
