The space is small but they certainly make use of what they have. They managed to create privacy amongst the tables and the dangling christmas lights plus the dark decor feels really cozy.

Korean food is a little harder to find in San Francisco than it is some other areas. I'm always trying to find new places! The beef bulgogi and calamari was good. It was enough to share between two people when eaten with rice. The flavors were right but i don't know if i'd remember to order this again. I also shared a seafood and veggie soy miso hot pot that was warming but soon tasted too concentrated at the bottom. I probably should have mixed it up a little more. It's like a giant bowl of miso soup!

I think they charge more than i would expect.. $35 plus for two.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Pros:
- kimchi fried rice (perfect amount of kimchi flavor and so smooth that it was almost creamy? idk but it was delicious)
- kiwi yogurt soju (ask for the fruit flavors they have that are fresh)
- seafood pancake was good (squid was a bit tough & chewy)
- kind of like a Korean bar/izakaya

Cons:
- not much seating
- long wait sometimes (and it's always cold in the Sunset)

Bottom line: the kimchi fried rice was really really good and I would def return for that and yogurt soju. It's a bit out of the way, but the food is good, and if you want a short post-dinner walk, you can get some Eggettes for dessert
author: Jiann M.

description:
I came here on a Sunday night with coworkers after a long work week. The six of us were sat at a table and we ordered a couple carafes of soju (pineapple and strawberry). We proceeded to order an assortment of dishes to share, including that pancake-like thing (which was delicious by the way). This was awhile ago, but that pancake dish was something that stuck in my mind. After we demolished the two carafes of soju, we decided to order a yogurt one at the suggestion of a friend. It was okay -- the pineapple was definitely a favorite among everyone.

This is a pretty cool spot to hangout, sip some drinks, and munch on some food. I think I'd return. Also, it would be smart to either carpool or have someway back home because I definitely limited the drinks so I would be okay driving back downtown.
author: Leana L.

description:
You walk up to a fancy garage door, brightly lit on dark 45th and Noriega.  Did you really bring me to a garage?  You open the small doors and step into a whole other world: a restaurant, a cozy Korean style shack that goes deeper throughout the house.  They have secret doorways which make you wonder whether there's a secret garden outside.  Not super hot, since it's a garage that serves hotpot, so pretty well ventilated in my opinion.

[Service]  food came out pretty fast, and waitresses were prompt to spills.  Must make reservations for larger parties and have entire party present in order to be seated.

[Food]  people are right.  the spicy fried chicken, seafood pancake, and kimchi fried rice are the most popular dishes, especially at our table, and I was amongst 8 locals

[Setting]  better for smaller parties, only 1 restroom for use, so check sparingly

[Soju]  we ordered all 9 flavored soju's, and from what I heard it's a lot like The Spot.  My favorite was the aloe!

All in all, fun time, good food, order a soju
author: Janet T.

description:
This is definitely the best Korean restaurant I've been too in SF by far. The food definitely doesn't compare to LA's Korea Town restaurants-- but definitely the best in SF (in my experience).

The interior design is totally awesome-- wooden rafters, wooden tables, painted ceilings, and straw blinds (to create private enclosures around tables). We got the kimchi fried rice, fried chicken, and seafood ramen. All of it was flavorful and so good. I especially loved the kimchi fried rice. It had a good consistency-- sticky with a lot of chili sauce-- and had a strong delicious kimchi taste.

You should definitely try to reserve a table or come when they first open because you could be waiting over an hour just to eat some of that kimchi fried rice. Also, you might want to keep your thick sweaters and jackets in the car because you will definitely walk out smelling strongly of Korean food.

This place is probably best with 4 or less people-- because they've only got a few big tables. It gets really crowded every single day... so if you didn't make a reservation for your group.. good luck.

I'd definitely come back-- and can't wait!
author: Julie H.

description:
3.5 Stars. 

I understand why places like the spot and tonight are popular places. They offer affordable food with soju. I was told that these types of places served "Chinese style korean food' meaning that its not fully authentic. Some say Korean food is normally pricey and its considered Chinese style because they cut corners to make it more affordable. My experience with korean food is not well developed in the sense that i've only been to 3 korean style restaurants. They all taste the same to me. I enjoy eating it, but not one of them sticks out like a sore thumb. 

One thing did stick out like a sore thumb tho... it was the restaurant itself. I was originally skeptical having dinner at what it look to be a some ones house, but when you walk in it looks like a well themed restaurant. That is what you do not see that often anymore. Themes. 80% of asian restaurants all look the same. Plain white walls and round tables. This place is a bit small tho, granting it is a garage. 

The service was a little slow granting it was a packed house and only 2 waitresses were working. The service was very typical fast food Chinese style service. Get your order, food comes, gives checks and get out. 

Overall, i'm satisfied but not impressed. I would come back with a friend just to see their reactions when we walk to the garage, but other than its ok/good commercialized korean food.
author: Ryan R.

description: came here for our friends birthday, made a reservation for 4 and they sat us by the restroom. Its rather dark in there and the lighting was weird. we ordered the kimchi fried rice, spicy rice cakes, bulgogi and japchae. the lady was rather rude, when we wanted to get her attention she just stuck her head out from behind the counter and she wasn't too friendly, over all it was okay.
author: Siling C.

description:
Really great Korean food in the Outer Sunset. It's in a residential neighborhood and you enter through a garage-like entrance.

Love the Kim Chi fried rice.
author: Anthony W.

description:
I've heard good this about the kimchi fried rice and that is what I came here for. 
I know we are supposed to order chicken wings but it just looks like too much for us. 
The fried rice is indeed pretty good with the egg on top. It is still a lot of food for two people.
author: W C.

description:
The food is pretty darn good here! The kimchee fried rice is one of the best I've tried, especially considering I don't even like kimchee. I love the tempura shrimp and the fact that they keep the shrimp head on and deep fry that whole sucker. It's great! The one dish I was not too happy about was the cheese fries - I was expecting cheesy goodness - but it was bland and I personally think they should use a different type of cheese and it will be much better - perhaps something more rich in flavor, a Gouda, Cheddar, Parmesan, shoot even nacho cheese!
The only other complaint I have is the obvious - the environment. It's a true definition of "hole in the wall" - too crowded and not quite comfortable. Otherwise, if that doesn't bother you - it's definitely worth the try.
author: Charlene R.

description:
2.5 STARS

This is a Korean drinking place with average to below average food. The seafood pajeon was good (not great) the first time, and undercooked and soggy the second. The bulgogi (with squid) was some of the worst I've had - again soggy, bland, and just off. Wings were good but bland and not nearly as good as good Korean wings. Kimchi jjigae was good. Kimchi fried rice was bland. People raved about it in reviews. It's easy to make great kimchi fried rice (with spam - the best) at home, and this was a half-hearted effort.

Service was pretty bad, which is typical for many Korean restaurants, but this was worse than usual.

Many better places in Santa Clara and Oakland.
author: Adam G.

description:
Seafood Stew: Never getting this again! From the looks, there are too many items  that most people won't eat in this dish (things that looked like brains to soft blue shell crab that was hard to eat).  This dish was like the kitchen sink of seafood stews! None of the seafood in this stew was fresh. The blue crab had a weird taste to it confirming the fact that the seafood in this pot was not fresh. The only thing I like the best in this stew was the soup itself.
http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/wlVigjFPBf1WZ5wdDeE8VQ/l.jpg

Rabokki: I swear when you order Rabokki, it is supposed to be spicier than Dokkbokki. This was not spicy at all. The rice cake was cooked to perfection. If I ever come back to this place, I will request this dish to be extra spicy. 
http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/xh52XDlMnoghLD8p2lm16Q/l.jpg

KimChi Fried Rice ($10.95): The portion of this dish is not worth the price. 4 people didn't even get a full bowl of the Kimchi fried rice. It is very moist and tastes really good. 
http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/HNg3ovgr8oquE3miX14-6g/l.jpg

Fried Chicken ($12.95): The chicken was really crispy and cooked perfectly inside. For just a regular fried chicken, it wasn't that impressive.
http://s3-media3.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/11wtanH2BRqsCj6eOtXYWQ/l.jpg

Overall, I don't think I will come back to Toyose. I did come here several years ago and remembering the food being AWESOME, but it seems like it has gone downhill since then. Service was good, I would avoid sitting close to the main entrance as it gets uncomfortable having to see people waiting next to your table while you are eating.
author: Erica T.

description:
If I could give 3.5 stars, I would. But the food really pulls this review to a 4 instead of a 3. 

I came here at around 9 pm on a Friday night, hoping that we had lost the crowd, and thank goodness we did. We were seated within 5 minutes. 

The first time I came the wait was so long that we couldn't wait and decided to leave. So I was so happy that I finally got to try toyose. 

Just a heads up, you have to gain the attention of the waitress to get your name on the list to be seated. She will not come to you. 

The service here is terrible. We were ignored & I had to ask for everything twice. Not great. But the food is so good!

I opted for the japchae (clear sweet potato noodles with vegetables) and the seafood pancake. Both are so tasty! The japchae is probably one of the best I've had. The seafood pancake, first I've had, was also amazing. It's really filling, so don't let the name fool you. I loved every bite. Portions are also quite generous and prices are pretty standard, about $12-16, for korean entrees at a nice restaurant. 

Despite the lack of good service, I would love to come back to try their spicy fried chicken! But believe me, I'll come during down time and be ready for bad service & great food!
author: Junel S.

description: So far it the best Korean food in SF as I know. I like the drink and Kimchi fried rice.
author: James C.

description:
Incredible.  Delicious.  I need to get a thesaurus to find enough superlatives for the quality of food provided at Toyose.  

I cannot recall all the dishes my group ordered but each dish outdid the previous.  My favorite were the glass noodles.  Never before have I shaken my head in disbelief when taking a bite - the texture and flavor were truly a unique experience.

I had just finished mentioning to my friends that I do not enjoy tofu - that is until I tried to tofu at Toyose.  Wow.

The service was impersonal but close to what I expected.  They were busy as hell and not exactly friendly but everything was delivered swiftly and accurately.  

Be prepared to wait for a table.

I will keep Toyose in my heart to offer to my best of friends that take pride in eating.
author: Anthony L.

description:
How can anyone find this place just by walking by? You can hardly tell that it's a restaurant since it looks like a garage of someone's house. If it wasn't for Yelp and word of mouth, I don't think anyone would know that it's a great place for food and delicious drinks. 

Most of the cost of our bill came from the drinks xD There are so many flavors of soju! I tried the mango, kiwi, yogurt, and strawberry. All of them tasted pretty delicious so they either mask the alcohol really well with lots of sugar, or there isn't much alcohol in there haha.

As for the food, I tried the Spicy Chicken Wings (not spicy at all), Kimchi Fried Rice, Kimchi & Seafood Pancake, and the Rice Cakes with Ramen and Egg. All of the food was good but I don't think it was anything special. Korean food is one of my favorite foods so it's pretty hard for me to not like it. 

If you're looking for somewhere to eat, drink, and have a good time with your friends, Toyose is great for all of that! :)
author: Sandra N.

description:
This place is amazing! Don't be intimidated by the people outside or inside, just ask to see if they can seat you. We had a group of 9 surprisingly and very randomly and we only got seated in 10 minutes because of some reservation interesting combinations. 

They have an official sign now btw. 

Best dishes:
Chicken Wings & Kimchi Fried Rice
Don't get the whole chicken though, too much food
author: Rohan D.

description:
I don't get the hype. The service was nice (got a guy waiter) and yeah like everyone said - the waiters and waitresses are super pretty. I've heard the pretty waitress here tend to snob people and give preferential treatment to certain customers but I didn't experience this.

Anyways, It's very overpriced for the food and portions.

Nothing special in terms of taste and presentation. The kimchi fried rice was something I could have made myself. The fried chicken was honest to god tasteless. I mean...KFC tasted better.

The decor was cool, but how can a Korean place not have bannchan?

This is more of a hipster/cool place to chill for well off San Franciscans. 

Don't go if you like a Korean restaurants that has home cooked, home style, warm meals with generous sides and smiles.
author: Nina B.

description:
Finally got a chance to eat here a few weeks ago.  You can get a table for two pretty easily in the early evening mid-week, and that's when we went.

Mostly seafood on the menu.  Ordered octopus noodles, seafood pancake, beef fried rice.  Nothing to complain about, although it was a bit on the spicy side for me.  The portion sizes are quite large, and you can probably feed 2 people with just a single dish. 

The real story here is the atmosphere.  It has that this-is-some-place-hidden-and-special vibe to it.  

I honestly like the food at Shin Toe Bul Yi better, but I'm sure I will be back here soon enough.
author: Gopal R.

description:
The service is bad. The waitress even don't look at you. No smile at all, they ignore you randomly. The food is not authentic, too much seasoner and aginomoto. The flavor is bad, it makes me want to vomit. The restaurant is small and noisy. I can hear  the neighbor desk customer's talking information very clearly. The food is very over price. Those who think it is good restaurant, please go to Korea and eat some local restaurant. 
I won't go here again because it is not worth to wait so long. The restaurant must be open at 6:00 PM, but they open 7minutes late. There are many people waiting outside, it is not professional and disrespect for customers. There are always cold in sunset area, I feel not worth for the customers who those stand outside and wait for a seat.
author: Zong H.

description: Not sure if I am a fan, but the food is good! I did not find the food to be expecially delishious, it was more of a food court style Korean food. The soju is good though! They have a huge list of flavored soju, so that was a hit with my friends. I dont think this place is good for big groups, unless you get their when they just open. This place is really small, luckily, I got there right when it opened, out group of 5 got seated with no problem. However, it was hard to walk out the place is so small.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Best kimchi fried rice! Best seafood pancake! Best fried chicken wing! Best Korean hot pot! Best soju!
author: Jin Y.

description:
This place is good for a late night snack with soju to chill with a group of friends. The wait is a bit tedious, but the food and drinks are pretty good. 

I love the kimchi fried rice, you can't go wrong with this dish. It's my go-to dish here. Another go-to dish is PANCAKE anything - seafood pancake, kimchi pancake -- they're all good! My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

CORN CHEESE: my favorite dish of all time! It's a real small dish, but so friggen good and I've tried it at other places, but this place makes it the best.
*but beware, it really is just baked corn & cheese.........but so good. T_T

Soju drinks are pretty good, goto flavors are Yogurt soju & Mango soju, you can't go wrong with those two flavors. Just try it if you want to get a little buzzed.
author: Mel T.

description:
After having this place bookmarked for forever, I finally came here to give it a try.. I really wish I didn't because my thoughts of how it would be surpassed the expectation of what it really was. 

I ordered the kimchi and seafood pancake.. Way too doughy and not crispy enough. There was a measly few pieces of shrimp and squid. 

I also ordered the kimchi fried rice. It was probably the best thing of the 3 items I ordered, but it could definitely use some more flavor of some sort. 

Lastly, we ordered the spicy chicken wings. Such a big disappointment! All I tasted was battered and no chicken meat.. It was also way over fried and almost burnt. No spice in it at all too. 

The location is what appears to be inside a garage. Service was slow and we were the first ones there.
author: Kelly T.

description: From outside this place is easy to miss, but once inside it has a nice decor that makes it stand out from any other place in the area. We have been here a few times and there is usually a bit of a wait. The kimchi pancake is delicious! They have a wide variety of dishes that all look very tempting. This place can get a bit crazy packed on Fridays and Saturdays so come early.
author: Gaby E.

description:
This place can get busy but I can see why. It's totally authentic Korean food at very reasonable prices.

The kimchi stews are done well -- I recommend the pork and tofu one. The fried chicken wings are amazing. The seafood pancake is probably one of the best I've ever had.
author: Victor W.

description:
WOW WOW WOW WOW!!!!!

All I can say is this is some serious stuff. Never would expect a place like this to serve such delicious food. Really this was soo good. This is my first time trying Korean food and I am really impressed.

I came in on a Tuesday with friends and this place was packed and had a line waiting to be seated. This really proved to me that it was something. We got the kimchi fried rice, spicy chicken wings, fish pancake, and soup. It was all so incredibly fresh and yummy. I couldn't get enough of it!

The little button on the wall was super quick to get the attention of a server. They were there in no time. Also very helpful and efficient with everything that was asked of them. I thought this was awesome that they had the ability to run around from table to table with so many people. 

I most definitely want to come back here and bring more friends. Such a great little place to eat a tasty dinner. Can't wait for more :)
author: Julia K.

description:
I was so excited to get back to amazing mixed soju and korean drinking foods, but what a disappointment. 

Strawberry and yogur soju were waaay too sweet with barely any soju in em, so we had to do 3/4 soju to 1/4 flavored soju shots. 

Service was horrible, not polite, and super slow. We arrived before they opened and were the second table seated. Yet service was super slow, and food delivery came out at an overly slow pace. 

Before when I'd come here, they'd always bring out "service" but this time we didn't even get kimchi. 

Food was meh. 

Now that there are more soju bars in town, I doubt I'll be back. 

2 stars instead of 1 because of the menu variety that is hard to find in the bay area.
author: MiYong E.

description: An atmosphere that as a Korean, can confirm to be truly "Korean." It's a nice place to grab a drink with genuine Korean dishes.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Hands down this place is one of the best koreans spots ive been to. They are famous with there soju, kim chee fried rice, and sea food pan cake! Thats pretty much my favorite items on the menu. Getting here kind of threw me off a little cause GPS took us to a house LOL but inside its a restaurant. The setting feels nice and interior decor makes you feel like your in Korea. 
The servers were very friendly and food is absolutely amazing!! A friend and I shared a bottle of strawberry soju and we got a good buzz off of it. Soju was so delicious! Id reccomend this place to anyone who would come to the city to find a good spot to eat at.
author: Cheryl Ann B.

description:
Sigh the dearth of good, CHEAP, late night Korean places in SF and the Bay is well SAD. SAD. SAD. Born and raised in SF as a KA, it really really makes me miss LA every time I come back home and I seriously hate LA as a SF die hard.

This is one of two that I really know of in the area. The other being Tonight. In either place, if you go when you should (late nights, weekends), good luck getting in without a long wait if you don't have a reservation. 

Even with all these problems, Toyose is still my spot. Also, make sure you have a Korean (like me), it really does help the attentiveness and service. That's just the stupid way Koreans roll, aite? Haha.

Good food, a tad pricey, your standard selection of the best Korean drinks (don't go flavored soju anywhere unless you have women / a woman in tow), and just a pretty good scene considering its location. A tad cramped and no understanding of the word privacy, but who's looking for that at 1 in the morning on a Saturday?

Check it out. It'll be a place you go back to I'm sure. 

Cheers.
author: Joseph L.

description: Local, open late, AMAZING food, reasonable prices, and fantastic atmosphere. The server was very helpful the first time i was there. Recommend to anyone in the neighborhood. Make sure to try the spicy wings.
author: Kirill P.

description: We got there before closing 50 minutes ago. As published, they close at 2AM literally. They said that the restaurant kitchen is already closed when I got there. This is really bad. They advertised that they close at 2AM. I drove 25 minutes to get to the restaurant. This is very unprofessional and rude. They obviously don't care about people's time.
author: Hoyeon L.

description:
Food was 3.5 stars. 

My boyfriend and I went there and waited for half an hour and it wasn't bad, we went late.  Yet a whole bunch of people then came in without reservations and we should have had pick of the table that we wanted.

One of the waitresses was so rude.  I like June, she was sweet.  

Good food, okay wait, get June for the service.  Other than that, go else where!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
It was awful. We ordered the spicy seafood stew. The seafood was mostly chewy octopus ugh! I had to spit it out the first bite. There was only four baby shrimp which were also chewy. The only things that was not chewy were the  vegetables  The broth was okay. I couldn't eat it :-(.  We also ordered the Calamari tempura which was also chewy. I couldn't chew it,it was so hard like it was boiled  too long ugh!. We also ordered the corn cheese which was yummy. I asked the waitress if the calamari was suppose to be this way. She said yes because they cut it fresh.
Anyway we are not coming back. I also have a bad upset stomach.
I don't understand why this place is rated 4 stars????
author: Evelyn C.

description: Food is delicious. But the service is not polite. Make sure write down some simple names which are they will not call it wrong and missed you and they will ascribe the mistake to you and not them.
author: Yating L.

description:
A really overrated and overpriced but still fantastic Korean dive. Calling this place a dive evokes the idea that it's cheap and a hidden gem off the beaten path. Well, that would be a lie on both accounts. The place gives off the aura that it's a dive because it's housed in someone's basement, in a really San Franciscan way, so kudos to them for that. But the space constraints really lend itself to many seating problems as the place can seem to only fit a dozen people at a time. 

So, after a 45 minute wait where they seem to seat people who just got into the restaurant before you, prepare to be looked down upon by the entire waitstaff for your entire meal and then get ready to pay a 15% gratuity for no reason for your party of 5. 

After all of the introductory pleasantries, order some of the most expensive but delicious wings a Cornish Game Hen has ever had to sacrifice its life for, get the great seafood pancake, and for the love of what's good don't order any of their soups. During which, drink some barely alcoholic fruit daiquiris. Then pay the bill, and on your drive back convince yourself that it was fantastic so you can impress your backwards friends about this really unique place that you uncovered in the foggy land of the Sunset.
author: Alan H.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to eat here one night after he came home from being on an airplane for 6 hours. It was well after midnight, he was starving for a really good meal, and we drove a longer distance into the city than usual just to eat at this place because they conveniently close at 2am.

The wait for our table was about 20-25 minutes. We ordered the kimchi soup and beef kimchi rice plate with a fried egg, and specifically asked our waitress if she can remove any onions cooked into the food. She did tell us the rice plate is prepared with green onions already, but she can have the cooks remove any additional green onions that would be dolloped on top. That was fine for us and we waited patiently for our food.

The kimchi soup was tasty, but once the rice plate came out the entire thing was cooked with white onions. My boyfriend was disappointed that he couldn't eat any of it. I could eat onions so I was able to have some, however there was so much onions cooked into the dish it was a little overbearing. It would have been more enjoyable had they not put so much, but the kimchi rice itself was good to me.

My boyfriend decided to order the eel and asked the waitress once again to remove all the onions. After waiting a little bit longer for a third plate, guess what happened? The entire dish was covered in white onions so he couldn't eat any of the eel either. The only thing he ate from this restaurant was soup.

I don't know what was going on, but clearly something was miscommunicated when we asked for no onions on our food. I give this place two stars because the interior was really cool and the food wasn't terrible, but overall personal experience wasn't that great.
author: Sabrina P.

description: The place is literally a hole in a wall. Outside it looks like a garage but once you enter the door the eatery is so cute as if you entered an underground Korean village.  It has great food! If you love wings you got to try them. It was nice but a Korean restaurant wouldn't be perfect for me unless they had my spicy tofu soup :(.
author: Kay D.

description:
This by far seems like the closest legit Korean place I've been to in SF. They have a great variety of Korean food, more than other places. The ambiance is nice and comfortable for young people. The host/server was really nice and gave us rice on the house since we thought our meal came with rice. 

Their food is pretty bomb; esp. the stews: budae jjigae (army stew) and the beef stew. Very flavorful and satisfying. They make it right.
author: Julie T.

description:
If you want to say you've had dinner in a garage, is this the destination spot for you!

(For most of us living in San Francisco, it's not too difficult to find a friend living in a converted basement or in-law studio, so the novelty of eating in a garage spot like Toyose isn't there.)

Anyhoo, after a relatively quick 15 minute wait, we were seated. Our server was fast, and our orders came in bam! bam! bam! Before we knew it, our check was placed on our table--and this is pretty much why I'm giving Toyose a lower rating.

Food is decent but nothing to write home about. Portions also felt small in comparison to local competitors.  My biggest gripe about Toyose is everything feels rushed. Like a McDonalds or a Disney roller coaster line, everything is focused on getting you in and out efficiently. Being a late night Korean restaurant, I was a bit dissapointed in this, since I'm used to the social aspect of places that serve soju (friends, conversation, etc.). Dropping the check off without asking if we wanted more food or drinks moves Toyose from a Korean-restaurant to a Destination-restaurant-to-show-out-of-town-friends.

Maybe we came early and caught the family crowd--you definitely can't catch up on this week's gossip and talk like sailors when you have stuffy-looking multi-gen'ers sitting next to you. It probably didn't help our experience being seated near the restroom, either. After the second person, I tried to avoid eye contact each time someone came out--you know, giving them that look of, "Oh, you're the guy who just spent 10 minutes dropping a double flusher...Nice to meet you. Now let me get back to my food while I try not to think about the remnants of your hot-hot deuce wafting towards me from the door."
author: Sam W.

description:
had a ton of food here, all of it was really great!

corn cheese is literally the most genius thing
author: Jackson B.

description:
Terrible experience here at Toyose.

I was REALLY excited to come here. In fact, I was planning a trip here for the past month. I lots of Yelp reviews and talked about it with some friends.

We planned to come here on a Saturday arriving at about 7:00PM (The place opens at 6:00PM). We called for a reservation at 6:00PM but they only take reservations for parties of 4 or more. It was just the 2 of us so we thought that we'd still get seated with only a minor wait, if that.

When we arrived there, I was damn excited since the exterior lived up to it's hole-in-the-wall atmosphere (the best kinds of places to eat in my opinion). When we entered the place, it did look like a fixed-up garage, kinda cool. I first saw people seated/eating and other tables with reservation signs on them.

Anyway, when you walk into a restaurant, you usually expect a podium and a host/hostess to seat you or at least put you on a list if there's a wait. And who wouldn't mind a short wait for a restaurant they've been anticipating--it's probably well worth it.

Instead of the typical event that I just described, when we walked in, there was NO podium and there was NO host/hostess. What happened was that we walked in and we were just confused because it wasn't a traditional restaurant entrance. We stood for about 30 seconds not knowing what to do. There wasn't even chairs or anything to sit on to wait. It's like you just have to leave if you don't have a damn reservation. Then as a waitress finished serving a table near us, she began walking away to the kitchen, turned around towards us, and in a REALLY rude manner/tone, she said, "Ummm, it's going to be an hour wait."

Now, in any other setting, this would be fine, and I would happily wait to pay money for their product/service. But what I actually heard from this b*tch was, "Ummm, just leave, you're not Korean, you should just get out of here because even if you wait 1 hour, I'm going to make you wait another 30 minutes so you can just leave." Seriously, that's what I think she was trying to say. F*cked up right? She didn't even fully turn around to tell us this. I felt belittled and as if we weren't even worth it to turn around fully and tell us something like, "I'm sorry, it's going to be a long wait since we're pretty booked tonight, please have a seat and I'll let you know when a table is ready." How about saying that? Is a customer only worth a 2-second line? Do we have to be of Korean descent? Seems that way.

After much planning to eat here and rave about it to friends, this happened so we left and went elsewhere, shocked. It makes me sad that she did this and it wasn't a good way to start the night. Too bad Toyose, too bad.
author: Marlon T.

description: This place is amazing! A really cozy and cool setting, a converted garage. Hands down the best wings in the bay area and the kimchi beef fried rice is the bomb! It can get a little crowded at times as there is limited seating but it is worth the wait. Soju is tasty and service is friendly.
author: Joe K.

description:
I been coming here for 5 years now. 

I think the place is pretty cool, and cozy place to eat and drink with friends. But sometimes the services can be slow due to many orders. 

And if you don't come here at the right time, you will have to wait, because its just so popular now. 

But it is worth checking it out if you have never been. Get the fried chicken, kim chee fried rice, the casseroles, mussel, and gizzard. And any of the flavored soju are pretty good and fun to drink with your friends.
author: S S.

description:
Chicken wings in a garage at 1am? That's not my dad's? Okay it doesn't have the La-Z-Boy that his does, but his wings aren't as good as this. Add private tables where they -- behold! -- close a shade in front of your table to create a sense of mischief, like as kids with a tent in the backyard with friends on a weekend. 

You can adventure throughout the entire menu, but pancakes, wings and kimchi fried rice at 1am feels as comforting as any morning breakfast and more flavorful than other bland American traditions. 

Tip: there's going to be a wait, even if it's 20 minutes take the initiative and ask for something to drink and sit at the front small bar, bench until seated, and yes waiting for the table with the shade of mischief is likely worth it.
author: Jon A.

description:
Atmosphere: 
The bottom of a house, small, a bit stuffy. Come early and expect to wait

Dishes: 
-Spicy chicken wings: yumm. Could be spicier but the flavor is there.
-Potstickers: so many!
-Corn with cheese: exactly what it sounds like, and better than you'd think.
-Kimchi fried rice - flavor on point. One of the better kimchi fried rices I've had.
-Kimchi soup - could be a lot spicier. Flavors are very subtle. Mom's Tofu House has better soup.

Drinks:
-Yogurt/Pineapple Soju - comes in a container you use to pour oil? I wish they had real pitchers, still good though.

tldr: would come back for the wings, kimchi fried rice, corn with cheese, and to try more.
author: Krizia M.

description:
Went here with a few friends and had some great spicy korean kimchee fried rice, spicy fried chicken and bulgogi (sausage/spam/veggies).  Food was great but noisy inside because people were drunk from the flavored Soju.  We tried every flavor I think and it was all good.

One tip: bring extra packages of ramen noodles for the bulgogi soup/noodle dish.haha  You end up with hella soup and they charge $2 for a pack of noodles.  We brought our own, I know, a little ghetto, but hey, we're in a recession.  It was funny seeing the look on the waitresses face when the noodles magically refilled themselves.hahaha

This review is from 2011.  I quit yelp reviewing for a few years.  Too busy eating...
author: Alex T.

description:
If I have an option to give no stars, I would. I don't think this shitty place deserve even 1 star. Horrible customer service!!! Never in my life have I been treated so rudely and disrespected as a customer! 

When we got to the restaurant 5:50pm, the server said we're not open yet. We were thinking can we at least sit since it's only 10 minutes away and the effin door is open. She repeated "we are not open yet!". Ok, we get it so we waited outside until 6pm. 

Originally we reserved for 10 people and when we sat down we said only 6. We ended having 7 people. The waitress rolled her eyes and with a bad attitude said first you reserved for 10 then 6, now 7! Ok our fault for not calling to update the reservation but when have you ever been to a restaurant where the waitress rolls her ugly eyes at you because your entire party didn't show up?!?
1) if you're prettier maybe I will just stare at your pretty face and ignore your eyes rolling rudely at us but have your checked the mirror lately!!! 2) you must not have had any customer service training in your entire life!!!!

We ended canceling our order and walked out! 

To sum it up- horrible customer service x100! Rude staff! Decent food only. People -if you are looking for Korean food, there are plenty of good spots even in the sunset. Please no need to pay for a restaurant with such terrible customer service.
author: Eileen P.

description:
A-ok! toyose has some amazing looking dishes on their menu, and you can't help but stare at everyone's table as you walk in. the plating is beautiful, and the restaurant is filled with spices, but maybe because it's so small!

the thing is...generally i can find a good amount of things to eat at a restaurant with no meat. it's very rare for me to not be able to order anything. however there is literally nothing on the menu that is vegetarian. nothing? nothing. not a single dish. except french fries (which really confuses me). oh! and potato croquettes. so fried taters. 

against my better judgment, and because i was really freaking hungry, i split the tempura udon, calamari and noodles, and potato croquettes. i requested that the kimchi fired rice have no beef, so i was able to try a little more. the rice was freaking awesome. put a fried egg on anything and i'm set. soup was good, a little difficult to eat. calamari and noodles were pretty good, definitely had a kick. the croquettes were also tasty, but i guess it is just like a big hash brown! i also tried soju for the first time...eh...not for me. tastes like mad dog 20/20. 

all in all, toyose produces good food and clearly has a large following. it also is quite close to my house, however i think i'll just be back if i really don't feel like going far to pick up food. there is really just nothing for me to eat, and it's pretty pricey.
author: Liz M.

description:
Mmmmm....Korean comfort food. I immediately craved more the day after the first time I tried them. I found myself browsing through the food pictures on Toyose's Yelp page, reminiscing about the deliciousness which transpired that night. 

Duk Boki- I've never had this dish  before, but I'm not a big fan.
Kimchi Fried Rice-Drool! 
Chicken Wings-perfectly seasoned, crunchy exterior, moist and soft inside.
Spam Casserole-definitely interesting. It reminded me of something I have put together after coming home from a night of heavy drinking--soup, ramen noodles, hotdog, pork and Spam mixed together. Oddly good!
Bulgogi-Flavorful. It was one of the last dishes brought to us, and I wished I had more stomach space for it.
Breaded Fried prawns-unremarkable but I liked the dipping sauce.
Kiwi, Mango and Strawberry Soju-they're supposed to be taken as shots. But it was so damn yummy, I ended up sipping to savor the yumminess.

We went on a Tuesday night so it wasn't busy. We waited less than 10 minutes for a table with a party of 6. The first round of food arrived 5 minutes upon ordering. The servers were pretty attentive.

I can't wait to come back there again...minus the Duk Boki and prawns plus Cheesy Corn, plus a bottle of Kiwi Soju all to myself! :-)
author: Carmela A.

description:
I usually LOVE this place, but maybe we misordered this time.  The chicken wings were over cooked.  The Bu De Jji Gae was okay this time.  The Duk Bok Gi with ramen was delicious however! I always have to order this.

As usual, there was a wait before being seated. Remember that they will take reservations for parties of 4 and more, but if you have 3 or less, then it is first come, first serve.

The little red button to call the server is the best part because you don't have to worry about wishfully hoping one will make eye contact with you just so you can get some water.  Service was fine.
author: Elisha Y.

description: Everything is delicious! A few faves: chicken wings, kimchi fried rice, deep fried calamari and of course, the soju! I also love the omelet, but that's not everybody's thing ( I am not sure that is very authentic Korean)
author: Irina S.

description:
Been here twice now.

The first time my big group of six ordered the seafood hotpot which was okay. We also ordered some bottles of soju. Overall the experience was not that good that night.

The second time around the experience was slightly better. Me and my cousin got the cheese corn, spam casserole, and the kimchi fried rice, The food was good, like before. The serving size was big. 

I would come here again.
author: John W.

description:
I have heard of this place and finally came here for dinner last night with a friend. The place has an interesting concept, its very small, cozy, semi dark, its called "the garage" its literally a garage. 
The food is so good, we had beef kimchi fried rice, clam soup, spicy noodle with fish cakes, and yogurt soju (its really good, not strong at all).
Customer service is awesome, very friendly and prompt.
If you like Korean food this is the place to go.
author: ML A.

description:
Foggy weather in SF + Korean food = pure happiness. And considering that SF is foggy pretty much 300/365 days, I would come here any given foggy day... or any day in general.

The atmosphere feels so home-y and comfortable! It is seriously a hidden jem in San Francisco... literally in a garage!

Probably the best Korean food I've had in the bay area! The kimchee pork soup really hits the spot! Each spoonful was flavorful and spicy!! I love it!  And the kimchee pancake was pretty good, too... I didn't really need the dipping sauce that came with it. But get the soup! I wasn't really hungry but somehow I managed to keep eating and eating.

Okay... and obviously the best part for me was the yogurt soju! AHhh sooo tasty! You can't barely taste the soju. We split a kiwi flavor, and surprisingly, it was not sour. After four shots, I was pretty buzzed already. Wish I could've tried all the flavors!

I've been wanting to come here since literally three months ago and finally glad my friend took me here. Now, I am DETERMINED to bring my own friends here on a random SF escapade in the future. Thank you, Toyose, for a fun and of course, sumptuous, experience!!! Saranghaeyo!!
author: Janet H.

description:
Okay, this place is so cool. 

Came here on a Tuesday night with some friends after shopping downtown and we only ended up waiting about 10 minutes for our party of 4. At first I was really sketched out that we were dining at what looked like the downstairs garage of a house but once we went inside I was surprised to find that it was a fully functional korean restaurant!

We ordered the Kimchi Fried Rice, Fried Chicken, Calamari with noodles and the seafood stew.

The Kimchi Fried Rice was pretty good. Just the right amount of spicy and the egg cooked just right. The Calamari with noodles was my personal favorite. I liked how well it was seasoned and the udon noodles were soft and cooked just right; not too chewy like most places. 

The Fried Chicken was decent and good, but unfortunately I've had better. It was pretty crunchy though. Lastly,  I was a bit disappointed with the seafood soup. It was a bit watered down and the ramen noodles that came with it looked like instant ramen noodles. 

Overall, a great place to go with friends for a late night meal. The portions are pretty big so keep that in mind when you order. (:
author: Gayle G.

description:
Pay close attention when you come because if it is your first time, you will probably miss the door like I did.  My first thought about this place?  I absolutely loved how cute, small, and rustic it was.  With the delicious food and drinks, I always leave happy. 

Make sure you reserve a table in advance!
author: Lynn L.

description:
You can look through the rest of the reviews here for what's good to order.  I think it's important to know that you will NEED to bring someone Korean with you to get the full experience.  If you've been here with and without one before, you'll know what I mean.

The food gets 5 stars.  The service is dependent on whether there's a Korean at your table.  The alcohol content in your drinks will also vary depending on the same factor.

It's pretty typical to expect this kind of treatment from a Korean restaurant, so it doesn't bother me too much, but it definitely keeps it from being a 5 star rating.

When I come here with Korean friends, the mood from the waitresses is upbeat, drinks are wickedly stronger, and being of age isn't questioned.  When I visited more recently with non-Koreans, serving staff attitude was apathetic, drinks were like juice, and we were aggressively carded (I don't mind being carded, but everyone should be treated the same).

The last gripe I have, is that for the portions, it's pretty expensive... but when is Korean food not?  I know this all sounds pretty negative, but it's not.  I'm just sure people have said enough positive things about this place and I definitely would always be down to come here for food and drinks.  Just straying a bit from my typical review style to let people know what's up.

DO realize that this place gets pretty busy at night and that you can call to make reservations.  Be prepared to wait, if you don't.  If you have no Korean (or girls) with you, don't get flavored soju, it's a rip, unless you like juice for $11.

Oh yeah, each bottle of flavored soju pours about 10 shots.
author: Christopher L.

description:
I love how this place looks.  Literally, if my friend hadn't had pulled me in, I would have thought it was a garage and missed the place completely.  Anything hidden is a definite yes!

Inside it's nice and cozy, a little dim and pleasantly decorated.  I got yogurt soju.  God, I LOVE yogurt soju.  I also had the beef kimchi fried rice--delicious (although i can't say I've ever had bad kimchi fried rice--except when I make it).  

We also got this beef kimchi on a bed of tofu. I can't remember the name of the dish.  I've never had it before, normally when I go to this type of restaurant I get the typical tofu soup.  It was very flavorful. The tofu came cold and unseasoned, but balanced the beef very well.

I would definitely come back...and drink more soju.  Looks like I'll also have to try that seafood pancake too!
author: Aly A.

description:
Getting a 2 because your food kinda makes up for the horrible service.....?

I don't know why my friends always try to drag me here, but every time I'm here, I get to experience the worst service ever.  First, if you're going with a big group, go early, or be ready for a minimum 1 hour wait.  Second, if you're coming here, be prepared to be ignored by the waitresses... multiple times.  I can't stand this place and their service and I would try to avoid this place. I had to ask for things multiple times and they never showed up, such as napkins or drinks, and even the bill took forever to come.  The waitresses are rude... and get annoyed when you ask them for anything... I understand it gets busy, but the attitude is just unnecessary.

Although the service is really bad, the food makes up for it... kinda?  But not really.  Every table gets served popcorn as a little appetizer, which is interesting, and goes good with the soju. I've tried their kimchi fried rice, which is served with a sunny side egg on top and nori.  Taste flavorful, but a little bit on the soggy side.  The chicken wings are really good though, very crispy and hot, made to serve when you order.  It also comes with daikon, which goes well with the crispy/saltiness of the chicken.  I think that was the best dish for sure.  The spicy pork was too chewy in my experience, and it was O-K.  The spicy rice cake is bland and I would not suggest in ordering it.  I have to say that the food here is better than other soju bars in SF, but there are better korean joints out there for sure.  

The SOJU.   Only place that I've gotten the kiwi soju and been excited to drink it all.  Has "real" kiwi seeds in it, sweet and mild alcohol.  They have other flavors too, such as yogurt and lychee that I have tried.  If you're tryna get turnt, best to order a few more bottles...  

But in the end, does the food compensate for the service?   NO.  I don't recommend you coming here if you have a low tolerance for irresponsive waitresses.
author: Josie L.

description:
Came here with 4 people and surprisingly didn't have to wait very long at 7 on a Monday night. It has a pretty cool vibe being in a converted garage. It was also a lot bigger than I thought it was gonna be.

FOOD: The food that we ordered was pretty solid for SF korean food. Spicy fried chicken was okay. Great crunch, but not too much flavor that went along with it. It just tasted lightly salty with just a touch of heat. Not exactly bursting with flavor. The budaejjigae (spam casserole stew or something?) was absolutely amazing. Big kimchi flavors in the soup with spiciness. It was slightly heavy, which was perfect to me. Standard soup ingredients like hot dogs, spam, and kimchi. There were small rice cakes in there which were perfect to me in the soup. We also ordered calamari and bulgogi which was okay. The calamari did not have a lot of flavor. The bulgogi was where all the flavor was at and it all sort of just fell to the bottom. It was not exactly easy to get some of that flavor onto the calamari. I ended up having to scrape the bottom to get the flavors that I wanted. Lastly, we ordered the kimchi fried rice. It was good, not great. This may have been because I did not choose to ask for gochujjang, which is generally what I like to add to my kimchi fried rice but that's just my preference. I think I also kept yearning for more egg in my bites of fried rice.
We also ordered watermelon soju, and strawberry soju. Let's be honest, most soju drinks are delicious. These are no exception.

Overall, great place with a pretty cool feel. I'd probably come here to drink sooner or later or just come back for that budaejjigae
author: Bryant C.

description:
Drinking and Korean food, in somebody's garage converted into a restaurant/bar? Sounds like a pretty interesting formula. After finally giving it a try though, it was kind of a letdown.

You'll see this place pretty easily with a bunch of people standing outside someone's house at the far end of the Sunset. We were told it would be about a 40 minute wait, which ended up being closer to an hour. Try to make a reservation if you can.

I can't say anything about drinking here since I didn't try any drinks, but my friend who told me about this place said that it's all he comes here for, since the food itself is nothing to rave about. I tried the kimchi fried rice, and the rice had a really weird wet texture to it, so it felt like clumpy wet rice. Kimchi flavor wasn't particularly strong either. The saving grace was the seafood pancake which was decent, but I'm not really fond of appetizers being the highlight of the meal. Another friend tried the udon which wasn't anything special.

Probably a fun place to go drinking, but not really worth the wait if all you're looking for is the food.
author: Allen C.

description:
I heard more than 6 people said the Korean food here is so fantastic. I decided to give a try, but unfortunately it disappointed me very much. 
The advantage of this restaurant is they have the calling service press buttom. Also their food material is fresh I believe. The Soju is not bad though, two star for all that. Good for food taken in the late night, snack, soju, friends, hang-out..Nice place to go at late night because they open till 2:00AM. 
Ok, back to the dishes. I ordered the kimchi fried rice, there is no surprise at all. I can make it myself, and, better than that. Our second dish is spicy cold noodle. There are no broth, only noodle and some cold vegetables in one plate but seperately in order. It is too salty. I cannot eat the second bite. The last dish is the beef stew, it is sweet and taste not bad. But they put too much sweet-spicy sauce and aginomoto. I went to Korea twice, the flavor is not like that. 
I hope they can use their fresh food material to make authentic Korean food to the customers who really wait in a line for a really long time. Otherwise it is not worth to eat and pay these over-price dishes.
author: Yunru C.

description:
yummmmmmmmmy

don't be discouraged by the outside it's not a card club/private club it's actually a great little gem make reservations and get ur butt here and eat and drink! 

great chicken wings!
soju OHH my! 

quite the experience!
felt like we were part of a little secret that won't be a secret for long and it's actually in my neighborhood double down on that bonus!

did I forget the cheese corn? yea try it. it's corn with cheese. issss good
author: Nena L.

description:
I normally love this place but was really disappointed this last time. I went with a friend and they told us it was going to be an hour wait. While we were waiting and people were leaving they started closing down tables for reservations which would have been fine if I hadn't called in advance for a reservation and they told me they don't accept reservations for only 2 people. But 45 min later a couple came in and were seated at a reserved table!

Secondly when people in the back started leaving after waiting 1.15 hours the waitress started seating people that came in after us. What's the point of putting your name down if your not going to follow the list. 

Thirdly when we ordered our food we didn't get any side dishes and when 2 of our orders didn't arrive after 30min and we asked for them our waitress responded with an "Oh you still wanted them"? Of course we did we wouldn't have ordered them if we didn't. 

I understand it gets busy but you are in the customer service industry. I'm not a rude person so I didn't make a scene but as a paying customer I do expect some curtacy.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Best kimchee fried rice! Try going early (when it first opens) to avoid the long wait for a table because it does get busy.  I'd also highly recommend their chicken wings, all favors of soju, & my personal favorite - cheese corn! Yum!
author: Sheryl R.

description:
I love Toyose!

My recommendations:
- Cheesy garlic fries
- Cheesy corn
- Strawberry soju

It's very efficient how there's a bell to press to alert the servers if we need anything. I've tried their Mango, Yogurt, Peach, and Strawberry soju flavors. The Strawberry soju is my favorite.

Toyose is a great place to go for late night snacks and soju!
author: Jenny T.

description: Staff could be nicer but kimchi pancake and kimchi fried rice is the way to do it. Very small space, used to be a garage.
author: Marianna L.

description: Kimchi Fried Rice & Kimchi soup is where its at! but i wish i ate it outside there is freezing so i can warm up faster :P I came here on a Tuesday night, the wait was probably 20 minute wait. not bad for a small little garage shop. Also their soju is amazing! kiwi highly recommend
author: Nancy W.

description:
Really good comfort food, but maybe not worth the long wait and horrible service. The waitress last night was rude, often downright hostile to patrons. It was only 7PM- they'd only been open for an hour! Any simple question was met with a scowl and a rude quip. Tables are tiny, could barely fit the cod stew, kimchi fried rice, and fried chicken wings we ordered.

The food was pretty good- it'll definitely satisfy a craving for Korean comfort food- but maybe just order out. Not worth the 30-45 min wait and being antagonized by the wait staff. 

High points: food is tasty, servings are fair as compared to the price.

Low points: the aforementioned horrible service, and the long wait
author: Kim T.

description:
I surprised my husband today bringing him here for our 27th wedding anniversary .
 We were both delighted upon entering what once was the garage in a Sunset row house.
We stepped into a bustling little gem of a restaurant .
The staff was friendly.  We arrived at 7 pm on a Sunday and had a 35 minute wait.
Once we ordered the food came right away. A nice touch is a call bell in the booths alerting the waitstaff when we needed something.
We had the beef kimchee fried rice it was superb. The fermented kimchee with rice, vegetables and delicious seaweed was a surprise with every bite. So tasty, so unusual for our western palates.
The seafood with vegetables in a spicy chili sauce was excellent. We got it with noodles the noodles were delicious but there was too Next time I would ask for half the noodles.
The beef and calamari  in a sweet soy sauce was fantastic. I don't usually like beef - this was very appealing, a little sweet and very flavorful.
I drank a Korean beer OB lager it went well with the spices food.
I can't wait to go back and bring a group of friends .
author: Mary S.

description: Best Korean restaurant in SF plain and simple.  Sometimes I'm just sitting at work and my brain would just tell me......EAT TOYOSEEE.  The seafood pancake and chicken wings are a must each time.  Get those two and then everything else is just extra.
author: Vince L.

description:
Amazing find... good Korean food served in a garage that's open from 6pm to 2am!  Yay for late-night eats with personality!

Well... we'd not tried Toyose yet and we'd never had a Korean Casserole before so tonight we went on a mission to do both.  Mission accomplished.  

The restaurant:  Toyose was a cool lil space.  And it's lil for sure... I'd recommend getting there before 7 if you want a table with no wait.  That being said, I love the rough look and the fact that it's open until 2am.  Late-night joints are the best! Also, they have those cool lil service buttons and privacy mats you can lower around your table... at least the ones in the front.

The casserole:  Not really my thing.  I'd rather have Kim Chi Ji Gae, which is so delicious to me.  I don't see the point of this casserole.  It was good I guess, but not delicious.  Also, the meats seemed to cook weird.  The octopus was still weirdly chewy and the beef got too cooked even after we turned off the heat (10 min like she said).  Too bad.. squid and octopus are top choices of mine!  

We probably should've stuck with our favorites.  Oh jing oh duk bok ki, galbi, bulgogi and bibimbap.  We'll definitely go back because we think this place is good despite our not being a casserole fan.  And in the meantime, I give a positive 4 stars for the late hours, cool space and nifty waitress buttons.  kekeke

BY THE WAY... to the owners... The next time you print new menu pages, would you please print the Korean names of each dish written in English too?  I don't read Korean characters but the English descriptions are tedious to read through.  I didn't realize you had some dishes.  If the menu said 'oh jing oh duk bok ki', I'd have known you had my favorite right away!

See ya there!.. soon.
author: Susan D.

description: The wait is can definitely be pretty long during dinner time, even late nights on week days. So try to make a reservation, and make sure every member of your party is present. I'm very bad with korean food names, but we got the big pot of food with ramen inside and it was very fulfilling. We also got their kimchi fried rice (although it was a bit small but still taste good). If you want more meat you can get the half friend chicken? It's pretty big. Street parking is easy to find.
author: Shirley W.

description:
havent been here for more than a year!!!
I came on a Sunday night and there was a line of people waiting. The waitress told me it would take at least 1hr for us to have a table. i was debating if i should wait or not and i decided to wait since it was freaking cold outside.
~20mins later we got a table! i guess she was saying 1hr so they could have less customers????? lol
anyways ordered a lot of food and i love beef kimchi fried rice eve though it was kinda sticky(wet).. deep fried chicken wings was alright. didnt like the corn cheese.
we ordered assorted seafood soup and when we almost finish then we realized it was calamari soup.. oh well it was good even though not what we ordered.
author: Janice N.

description: We called to make a reservation for 4 people here and the lady that was on the phone told us she would cancel if we were late. We arrived with 3 people because the 4th person fell ill and couldn't make it but we were on time. When we went in the girl said that the minimum for reserving a table was 4 and that she had to cancel our reservation. Never did she ever tell us about this policy when we called to make a reservation and it basically wasted our time because we were on time there. What was the point of making a reservation in the first place? She was very rude about the situation and sounded like she didn't want to serve us anyways so we left. Whats the point of having good food if the service and people here suck?
author: Michele M.

description: The seafood pancake &kimchi fried rice are my main staples whenever I go here. It's also a nice place to go with a group of friends and drinks their yummy soju :). I've tried a variety of their other dishes including the corn cheese, the big hot pot resembling beef stew, and bul gogi.  I only knocked off a star for the sometimes reallllyyyy long wait (but that's just because of how popular they are right?) and the overwhelming smell you get used to after a while. I definitely go to Toyose more than often just for the seafood pancake. Did I mention the seafood pancake? UGHHH mouthgasm.
author: Kaitlyn E.

description: Nice enough but fairly unremarkable given our expectations (based on reviews etc). The food is plentiful & good value but nothing really "jumped out" at us as a taste sensation. The squid (which we had in two dishes) was pretty badly over cooked & chewy which was a bit of a fail. Also, we were sat in the back of the restaurant & boy was it cold! After a ridiculously long wait, it's fair to say we expected more than what we got.
author: Fi M.

description:
Always a good time here! Tasty and inexpensive with yummy flavors of soju (aloe is the strongest, strawberry the sweetes, yogurt the yummiest in my opinion, pineapple was just ok, peach and mango were tangy). The spam stew is quite large and could comfortably feed 4-5 girls. Maybe 2-3 guys. Kimchi fried rice is also flavorful, a bit on the salty side but it goes perfect with the seafood pancake. Fried chicken wings were pretty yummy too... crispy and salty on the outside, oily on the inside hahaha but foreal though, party in my mouth.

FYI: the whole restaurant is like a downstairs of a Sunset home so it's small and cozy. You can barely see the door or have space to wait (unless you're freezing outside) so get there early.
author: Christal T.

description:
I grew up in NY / Bergen County, NJ eating a lot of delicious authentic Korean food, so I am very critical when it comes down to giving reviews about Korean restaurants.

I've tried many Korean restaurants all around the Bay Area; from Santa Clara, Oakland, to San Francisco, mostly unimpressed with the quality of Korean food. But with Toyose, it's a different story.

It's located in a nondescript building that gives off semblance of a garage, but the ambiance of the restaurant is very typical of a Korean bar - dark, slightly cramped, loud, lots of booze, and best of all good bar-style Korean food. When you go to Toyose, you have to come with the mindset to drink, eat, and be merry.

Korean Fried Chicken at Toyose is a MUST. You CANNOT skip on the fried chicken. Those of you that might be wondering what the deal is with KFC (not the Colonel Sander's kind), just Google it and you'll understand what I mean. I'm used to eating BonChon, KyoChon, or Boom Boom chicken in the east coast where the twice-fried chicken wings are glazed in spicy soy sauce. However, Toyose does things a bit differently. They fry the chicken wings twice so that the skin is crunchy, while keeping things juicy on the inside, but it's not glazed in any sauce, other than its spicy salt and pepper. It sounds simple, but it is quite possibly the best fried chicken you'll ever have.
author: JD K.

description:
Long wait, empty tables, tight isles, two servers. I admit they did a good job manning the front of the house for that many people but an extra server or two could help speed things up. A little cramped in the waiting area. For some space, I recommend going across the street to a pizza joint and ordering some drinks while waiting. The wait can be at least 30 - 60 minutes long. 

The spicy chicken was fine, it wasn't memorable and not spicy at all. I nibbled on two and took the rest home to the little puppy. No sauce to dip the wings in. Sad story. Nice broth in the tofu soup but I've had better. The pork plate he got was okay. He ended up getting a horrible case of food poisoning that night. It had to be the pork plate because I only had a bite while he nearly finished it all. The onset of his situation was immediate, long and frequent. Poor guy :(

We wont be coming back here. Still searching for that special Korean spot, suggestions welcomed :)
author: Thuy M.

description: Came here really excited & all. The food was pretty good etc. but when it came to paying i made the wrong calculations with a few friends and only gave $3 for tips. One of the girl workers stopped us & started giving so much attitude and asking why we only gave $3. First of all, I dont think your even suppose to demand tips from customers BUT this worker was practically demanding tips from us and recounting our money in front of everyone. It was embarassing to me and my friends and we dont think that we are going to come back soon. Such a disappointment.
author: Ashley W.

description: My friends and I had dinner here on a Sunday night. We arrive about 8 minutes before it opened and were the second ones in line. We were seated right away and placed our orders: japchae, spicy wings, and spicy pork. The japchae was good but I've had better. The taste was lacking its usual taste (from others I've tried) so I was a little disappointed. The spicy wings were good and meaty. My favorite was the spicy pork- really spicy and seasoned well. Pork was tender and delicious. Service was pretty good. You get a little doorbell by your table to call over the waitresses at any time. Space is small so get there early. The line was out the door when we exited.
author: Faye F.

description:
Don't know too much about Korean food, but the stuff we ordered was pretty tasty. The ambiance is a little loud and a little cramped. If it weren't for the tiny curtains that blocked our table from the other tables it might have been a little suffocating with all the noise and the low ceilings and dark walls. I can see why this place could be a hang out for the night owls with music and drinks, but definitely not a family place or any place you want to go to have a conversation. 

I'd order out from here but probably would vote against dining in again.
author: Ping N.

description:
Absolutely the worst tasting Korean food I have ever had. I have many Korean family members and I've been to quite a few Korean restaurants, this place is just a hang-out for the 20 year old's. The only saving grace may be the Mango Soju. We ordered 3 dishes; the seafood pancake, the spicy pork and the seafood tofu stew/soup. The pancake was limp and flavorless, the spicy pork was also limp and possibly raw as I became extremely ill 30 minutes after eating, and the stew was special. The spicy pork was the most flavorless, un-spicy pork I have ever had in any Korean restaurant. And like other yelpers stated, the service is non-existent. You have to ask for the banchan and if they bring it to you all you get is some potatoes, kimchee, beansprouts and fishcake. Four dishes of banchan. 

Don't bother coming here, the food made me sick and was barely edible.
author: Terri Y.

description:
Third time's the charm, right?

So last time, we've ordered the ramen noodle hot pot with hotdogs and spam (which caused a severe stomachache), so I took the initiative to get recommendations and perhaps I could finally see what the hype is all about. 


Sauteed Calamari and Beef Bulgogi - [http://s3-media3.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/C8B8NhJcDuq7D-MN6_binw/l.jpg] 
There was a decent amount of calamari in comparison to the beef but the dish was on point. Beef was sauteed nicely and the calamari incorporated a different texture to the dish. 

Spicy Chicken Wings - [http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/LFCoPpxSQxAX4IuSSy-0AQ/l.jpg]
Drunk and craving a snack attack? This is the perfect meal for you; excessively deep fried, tad bit burnt, and a minimum amount of actual chicken meat. And the spiciness were there too.. or maybe that was just more burnt chicken skin.

Kimchee & Beef fried rice with egg - [http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WPdzIfcvBqy-SM8yhevl4g/l.jpg]
The hype is true about the kimchee fried rice -- It is the bomb. Fried rice soaked with kimchee flavor and the egg on top is straight-up overkill. 


Overall, the food can be a hit or a miss. (Moreover a hit if your drunk!) Their banchan (those little side dishes that are complimentary with your meal) is VERY limited and disappointing. Keep in mind that comfort food at Toyose is pricy! The dishes will run you a good $8-12 each and when their flavored Cocktail Soju is in play.. well, this spot just turned from $$ to $$$!
author: Albert L.

description:
Not sure why this place is reviewed so high. It's okay, but definitely nothing special.

In terms of food, we ordered the chicken wings, seafood pancake, and eel. The eel was the only thing we really liked. The chicken wings were just basic fried wings - and were dry and burnt. The seafood pancake was fine but nothing to write home about.

The outside doesn't look like a restaurant and the inside is really noisy. We could hear every word of the table next to us. They need some sound absorption or something.

The service was fine, they don't come check on you, but they have a little button you can push if you need anything.
author: T.J. H.

description:
I'd give 4 stars just for the chicken wings. There's something about the batter that makes each bite absolutely delightful. I docked 1 star 'cause the wings are a little skinny, needs more meat. Sometimes, it feels like I'm just eating the fried batter. 

I've had the fried rice, and bulgogi which is sub-par. Meh. However, the seafood panpcake is solid!

I really like how they have the service buttons at each table. So you don't have to try and make eye contact or wave down a server or shout out, "Over here," in Korean like a hooligan.

Parking in this area can be hell. Just FYI.
author: Joon Y.

description: Ahhh toyose! I discovered this place on yelp a few yrs ago! I love their chicken and korean fried rice..hella good food,just be prepared to wait in line
author: Emily V.

description:
I am in LOVE with Toyose. Yes you will most likely wait an hour and a half to get a table here but there's a pub directly across the street that you can drink at until they have a table waiting for you which is awesome. 

Order everything, especially the wings, and keep the drinks flowing and I guarantee you won't forget this meal!
author: Caitlin B.

description:
On a Saturday night, minutes after they open there is already a queue forming. 
We went with high expectations after reading all the favorable reviews. 
We left disappointed with the lack of flavor of the dishes. 
The Kimchee fried rice was under flavored.
The prawn tempura was ok, nothing to write home about. Best to eat tail first and eat the entire thing, including the head... of course. 
The corn cheese, at least the menu was accurate. Corn under cheese on a cast iron sizzle plate. 
We didn't get any soju. Perhaps the reason this place is so highly rated. 
The service was exceptional! Never having to ask to get your water glass filled is a good thing. 
Minus for pricing.
author: Geordie E.

description:
Review for multiple visits in Spring 2012:

Come with a few friends and order the seafood casserole (similar to hot pot) along with yogurt soju. You'll be set for the night - great food and great drinks!

If you don't come early in the night, expect a long wait.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
This is a cute little restaurant in a garage.  I love their chicken wings and flavored soju.  Everything else is pretty much average and very spicy.
The service bell is a plus, cause it's just way more convenient than trying to wave for a server, especially if you're tucked in the corner.
author: Karen L.

description:
i like this place but i dont like the wait. tonight i came here with two friends around 9pm and the wait time was an hour long.........they should really consider expanding the garage, perhaps extending it to their garden or something. 

needless to say, we didn't wait and went somewhere else instead. but i still like this place and for those who want a good first-time experience, i suggest ordering:

the cheese fries
kimchi fried rice
seafood pancake
& ANY of their cocktail soju, so delish.

also, my friend noticed that the nail salon place next door was still open at 9pm..i wonder what's going on in there...
author: Andy H.

description:
What the hell. Seriously. What kind of Korean place doesn't have bimbimbap? What kind of Korean place doesn't have spare ribs? Korean place with no SIDE DISHES!? I was thoroughly confused. Whenever we asked for another round of drinks, the waitress would look annoyed . I'm sorry, did we inconvenience you with our money? 

Complementary Popcorn "side dish" tasted like stale popcorn. 
Tofu soup came in a bigger than normal clay pot but no egg :(
Calamari with "bimbimbap" was flavorless in my opinion 
Spicy pork was dry and onions on the bottom were basically raw 
Kim chi fried rice was forgettable. Not much flavor at all. 
Seafood pancake was the best dish. 
Yogurt and strawberry soju was tasty and on the stronger side but I'm used to places that give you the yogurt soju
 in the original soju plastic bottle. They put it in an olive oil pourer so I felt like we got less. 
They only charged us once for 5 cups of rice so that's a plus 
The table and chairs were super cramped. 

Overall, I have had better and would not come back
author: Elaine L.

description: Generous fried chicken portions. Kimchi fried rice paired well and all service was succinct and very polite.
author: Ryan K.

description: the food is so so. nodles are salty. kimichi is not fresh. and bad services. push customers to check out.. we won't go there again!
author: Becal L.

description: I live right around the corner and never knew about this until I was in college and was looking for soju. This place is very well concealed. It blends in and looks like any other garage. This is a small place and gets filled up quickly. Usually theres a 20-30 min wait even on weeknights so I recommend calling ahead and making reservations. The food is outstanding, service can be better but its a soju bar so don't come expecting 5 star service. Try their flavored soju, there's so many and they're all good.
author: Simon L.

description: This place is honestly a hit or miss sometimes. Each visit I've had here have been different experiences. It's most likely due to the staff working each time. The only thing I really order here is the Kimchi Friend rice because it never fails to not fill me up, and their soju (Awesome place for soju because their cheap and open late night!). Their friend chicken wings is alright and their way too over priced. The overall amazing looking environment makes up for the lack of service or food sometimes.
author: Pj A.

description: Made reservations for 7:30 pm.   Got seated promptly at 7:30 sharp!  We ordered the following dishes:   Seafood pancake,  japchae,  seafood hot pot,  beef and squid bulbogi,  fried chicken, and beef fried rice.  Food came out promptly.  Good food overall.  Service is also good.  There is a red "call" button which we pressed to get our bill.
author: E. C.

description:
This is the kind of place that makes me fall in love with SF again. A restaurant in a garage, serving awesome Korean bar food (cheap awesome food), with access to a bell that instantly gets me a waiter or waitress when I want one. 

Get the seafood pancake and cheesy corn.
author: Christina K.

description:
My good friend told me about this place. OMG....at first i was a little questionable about this place. "WHAT a restaurant in the garage?" LOL...When I think of korean food, I want bbq short ribs and kim-chi soup. This place didn't have the beef, but they had every things else. 

The front door looks like a garage door, but with a business hours sign in the front. The place it small and I dont think you should go with no more then 3 or 4 (small) people. You would be sitting next to eachother with your arms locked together while trying to eat your dinner.  

We waiting an hour for a table and on top of that it was a friday night. At first we wanted to leave and go somewhere else because we were so hungry. I am GLAD we did not leave and it was worth the wait...WOW! We ordered fried chicken, kimchi fried rice, seafood soup (cooked at the table), seafood pancake and can't forget about the drinks. The flavor Soju drinks were so good!!! Oh and their large beer looks like a big 40 bottle...haha...everything was great and we had a good time. The food also came out pretty quick too. WELL WORTH THE WAIT. I suggest everyone try this place. I would FOSHO go back again.
author: Tanya C.

description:
There's always a wait but it's worth it. The fam always satisfied with quick service and delicious Korean dishes. Our usual order is the chicken wings, seafood pancake is a must and so is the spicy pork. 

The servers are always courteous. Good for groups and kids alike except when it gets pretty late on a Saturday night. More for young group hangout so, try their soju drinks. It's a small space setting in a garage turned resto. Highly recommended.
author: Eva D.

description: This place is really in the middle of no where. Super tiny as well. The food was good though. I really liked their chicken. The rest I thought was kind of of whatevers, but they weren't my usual dishes I would order at a Korean place, so I can't really judge. Good for late night food. Lots of street parking as well. Service is just like any other asian place, gotta flag down whoever you see.
author: Lisa T.

description: Love this place! I am always here when I am in SF...this place opens late night until 2am.  This great spot for some yummy Korean food and soju.
