I recommend coming here with a group of 4 or less because it allows for ample elbow room. However there is a table for 8 in the back of the restaurant. Have fun!
author: Jayne A.

description:
The food was good not great.  I don't remember the name of the dish so I listed the description of the food instead.
The customer was ok not great.  The staff was not very friendly nor rude.  Just indifferent.  

1) fried mussels - really really bad.  The mussels was old, so they over-cooked and dumped a bunch of sauce over it.  It was hard and fishy tasting.  Skip this.

2) Fried potatoes - good not great.  The potatoes were pretty good if you eat don't don't eat the disgusting sauce they put on top

3) Fried pork -ok nothing special.  Also the same disgusting sauce was placed on top of it

4) silver noodle in soy & sesame sauce - good.  I would order this again.

5) Beef stew - winner!  this was the highlight of our meal.  Would definitely order again 

6) shrimp tempura - good.  On the fence whether I would order this again.
author: L C.

description:
Service: Ok
Price: Reasonable

Food:
- Chicken Wings: Really crispy and perfectly seasoned. They're dry, like fried chicken, so they're not one bit saucy.
- Spam Casserole: Comes out in a hot pot, i recommend sharing!
- Spicy Seafood Pancake: One of the best I've had!
- Cheese Corn: Can't go wrong with cheese and corn on a sizzling hot plate!
- Chicken Gizzards: PASS! It's sautéed and over cooked! SUPER hard and chewy. It's like chewing rubber, YUCKO!

Experience: This place is small. Looks like someone's garage. I waited 1.5 hours to eat here, NOT WORTH IT. I'd probably wait 30 min max, next time.

Tip: There's a bar across the street that serves cheap drinks!
author: Judy C.

description: I just gotta say they have really great kimchi fried rice but the service and attitude that these people who work here is definitely one of most rudest people. Especially I thought when they're service would definitely exceed their delicious food. The waiter gave soo much attitude for us just askin for more chopsticks and napkins. Wtf?! Really? Not coming after today. Beware of the service
author: Chris L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place and gave it every chance because I live so close...

I was so disappointed we ordered the Fried chicken, kimchi tofu soup, and potato croquette. The chicken was way over cooked and dried out like a piece of beef jerky. The tofu soup had more salt that any I had ever had before. The potato croquette was pretty good but maybe it was because the other dishes were so terrible. 

Another strange thing was that we wanted to have the kimchi fried rice but with pork or chicken instead of beef and they couldn't change it.  Lastly, we had a seat near the front door and it's akward when people who are waiting for a table sit about 3 feet away from you and you are right in their site line. The place gets crazy busy but I don't understand why. 

If you are in the area and want korean go to shin toe bul yi instead.
author: Greg T.

description:
This place is trouble!! Well at least for me it is because their soju hits you when you least expect it. You wouldn't EVER expect someone to convert a garage into a restaraunt, but I guess Asian's just come up with the most random things. I like this place, not the best Korean food in town but it's not bad. I never had to wait for a table but maybe that's because we came on a Wednesday night. Whatever the case, this place is FUN and super chill. I like their soju more than playground (only because I'm a light weight). 

BTW, if you ever hear someone say I want the "Korean" french fries, slap them, because it's just regular french fries. (Ex: Jeniva) :)
author: Nancy Y.

description:
Ive walked by this place err single day in elementary school, middle school, and now since i moved back to sf.

Ive always wanted to try it after hearing rave reviews but ive always avoided it...
Why?? Honestly cause i didnt know how to open the door!

So one late night while I was craving korean, my boyfriend and I decided on Toyose. It soon became one of our number 1 late night options. The kimchee fried rice has won us over! It sucks because it is one of the only late night places and their soju is definitely a crowd pleaser. So it is constantly loud.

I have this pet peeve, its pretty mean, but reasonable. I hate loud noises as Im eating, sleeping, or talking. Why? Well.. Im not very good at multitasking, If I listen to music, ill end up singing instead of eating, sleeping or talking. I dont mind a constant noise, but when there is a particular voice that sticks out, Ill look over and give them the STFU IM TRYNA EAT&TALK TO MY BELOVED BOYFRIEND KINDA LOOK. I mean some of these groups had like 2 bottles of soju and their buddies are rolling all over the floor. Its just soju people. My boyfriend and I drink like 3 bottles and were just tipsy ish. I do not have high tolerance. BUT THEN AGAIN, some of these guys in the group have the right to brag because its like those lyrics 'sober girls around me they be actin like they drunkkk' cause its sooo obvious=.= I am humilated for them because theyre not fooling anyone. 


The kimcheee fried rice&the casseroles are YUMMMMMMMY. Our total always comes around 30-40. The soju is about 11 and comes in 8+flavors. All of them are reallllllly grrrr-eat.
author: Wendy X.

description:
Ok this place is incredible. A friend and I went here when we were visiting San Francisco last week. We were staying near Ocean beach and the restaurant was walkable from our condo. The one complaint I have is that the reservation/wait list is a bit chaotic. We got put on the list and were told it would be about an hour. We weren't in a huge hurry so went across the street for a drink (there is a wine bar and pub). After an hour we came back and were told it would likely be ANOTHER hour. Because we were already committed we stuck it out. After about 45 minutes we got a table. Under normal circumstances we probably wouldn't have waited but in this case we were happy we did. 

We ordered kimchi fried rice, the chicken wings, and garlic cheesy fries. Far and away the kimchi fried rice was the best dish. Everything was perfectly cooked and seasoned. We loved it. The chicken wings were crispy and delicious and had a really interesting flavor profile. Those were devoured in about 5 minutes. the garlic cheese fries were ordered because we were still hungry but didn't want to order another full plate. They were pretty good-- nothing special though. 

The service here is very friendly and responsive (they have call buttons at every table). We wanted to order one of the stews or casseroles because everyone around us was ordering them and they looked/smelled incredible. They are better for larger groups though. Maybe we'll get one next time!
author: Carson S.

description:
Sure, it's a little expensive for casual boon-shik (snacks) Korean food but the food is good, ambience is lively, and plenty of drinks.  The fact that it looks like you're walking into a garage makes it that much cooler.

There is a long wait sometimes and many times people seem to just sit here and drink hour after hour after hour so good luck.  

Fried chicken was good, kim chee fried rice was good, seafood pancake was ok (but slightly undercooked), etc.
author: Dan P.

description:
Been here over 5 times, and even though the food is a-ok, i'll always come back for the soju...

Seafood Pancake is better than  Kimchee Pancake by far

#1 Yogurt Soju
#2 Aloe Soju
#3 Strawberry Soju
#4 Mango Soju
- best mixed soju around in my opinion - even better than Playground's

Non-Spicy Casserole is amazing, even better than the spicy casserole, and i'm usually a spicy fan.  Noodles have a good texture and it is very flavorful and rich in seafood.

Spicy Noodles + Squid is waaay too spicy, its 1/2 red pepper paste, 1/4 noodles, and 1/4 squid

Tofu Soup - standard, but a strong savory seafood flavor 

Meager side dishes and popcorn = dissapointing for a Korean joint

In summary, just come here for the soju and perhaps share a casserole with some friends - be prepared for a hefty bill though - the food itself can end up costing up to $20 per person minimum
author: Tina A.

description:
It;s good!! the entrance is hidden.. Oh man.. if I didn't go there with my SF friends, I dont think I could find the entrance hahaa..
I got there around 9PM on Saturday night and it was pretty crowded.. We waited for at least 30minutes. The servers are not "friendly", no smile, just walk pass us although we are alreAdy in front of her.
Their chicken wings and seafood pancake is pretty good. But the kimchi fried rice is just so-so.. I had a lot better kimchi fried rice when I was back in LA so I dont see why people raving so much about their kimchi fried rice.
We also ordered yogurt soju, It is pretty good although you didn't taste that much alcohol in them.
Overal, will I go there again? maybe, there are some dishes that I want to try.. Like their tokboki with ramen and caseroles. they looked awesome but we weren't that hungry at that time so we didn't order that.
author: Diana A.

description:
Interesting place to have a restaurant...in a garage. The owner probably lives upstairs for all we know.

The service was alright. Just in case they can't serve you when you need them to, they have a lil buzzer to signal "WERE READY TO ORDER" or whatever you need them to take care of.

Food wise, it is pretty good. Of course being an asian cuisine, they go heavy on MSG. Quite thirsty afterward from eating cause of the msg. My friends and I ordered kimchi fried rice and the beef calamari with veggies. Both were pretty good. Definitely come back when I have my pay check...not a cheap restaurant...
author: Jade L.

description:
Where to begin....
First of all, this place is literally a garage of a normal outer sunset house. The restaurant itself is packed. Very crowded and dim, and filled with intoxicated people. The prices are also unreasonable. 12 dollars for a plate of mediocre fried rice?! Really? Three dishes ended up to be about $40 something. Ahh.

Kimchi Fried Rice -
Don't waste your money. It isn't anything special. It's just regular fried rice, with a few pieces of kimchi here and there. The red coloring comes from Ranch 99 canned spicy sauce that isn't spicy. This dish IS good, just way to expensive. I can make the same thing, and make it taste better, under $5. Not worth $12.

Spicy Pork Over Tofu -
All it is, is regular tofu with kimchi on top and a few pieces of beef here and there. The dish was really warm, and the tofu tasted like stone. Really regret this dish. Not worth $12 either.

We also ordered another dish, but I forgot the name of it.. wasnt great though.

Bottom line: Toyose is really a hit or miss, you just don't know what to expect, ever.
author: Belle Z.

description:
In the past, I came here for dinner but lately I came here more often as a late night hang out lounge. I like how  there are small tables and larger tables that accommodates small and large groups. They also have blinds that separate the tables giving people their own privacy. This place doesn't play loud music that over powers conversations and its just over all a great place to eat, talk, and catch up with friends.

As said before that there's usually a long wait but I realize that when you come after the dinner hours the wait isn't as bad.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
If you like to eat korean food and drink, come here
a little too cramp for my taste
also known as "the garage"
it's literally someone's garage converted into a restaurant
the korean food is pretty decent, usualy meats, pancakes, assorted side dishes, spicy soups
assortment of soju drinks
the low ceilings doesnt appeal to me
if you get caught in a wait, you will be in line for at least 30-45mins

came here couple of times, both for dinner, one with coworkers
i remember the squid being really tough
the meat was lacking flavor

i think this place is more of a drinking establishment than anything else because on both occasions, someone is yacking in the bathroom
the elbow to elbow environment makes me feel like this place is borderline a fire hazard.

service gets kind of slow sometimes because there's usually only 1 or 2 waitresses taking care of everyone
author: Andi I.

description: I used to go to temescal Korean town a lot. I have got many better food (e.g kimchi fried rice and beef stew pot) for a cheaper price and better service. Seriously, the food isn't even that impressive.
author: Ye Y.

description:
AKA... The Garage. I actually didn't know the real name of this place until I looked it up on yelp. 

This place literally looks like a garage when you first go. I usually come here after a night out in the town with friends. 

If you go here for dinner, call in for reservations for sure. It's a tiny place and there's always a wait! Even after hours too it can get pretty busy. 

Parking: I've never had a hard time finding street parking. You should find something within a couple of blocks. 

Food:

It's pretty good especially when you are suuuuper hungry. My favorite dish there is Budae Jigae. It's definitely my guilty pleasure. It's enough for at least four people. I always ask for more noodles though, cuz it's never enough. For the most part, the food is something you will get at your average korean restaurant. It is loud and more for a younger crowd, so don't go there if you want a nice quiet meal. You should go in smaller groups (4 people) since seating is pretty limited. 

Service:

Service is okay. It's always really busy so I always feel neglected. The waiters don't really check up on you and you have to wave them down every now and then. Don't wait around for them to bring you your bill. You need to wave them down and ask for it. 

If you plan on going during rush hour, don't plan on hanging out after you finish eating. It was so busy that the waiters actually rushed us after we paid to leave so we couldn't really hang out after eating.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
When it comes to Korean food, my expectations are very high (since I'm Korean). This place met my expectations and portion wasn't too bad.
You cant blame the wait or slow service since it's  usually busy at night. Try their kimchi pancackes, they don't mess around with it. They mostly, if not always play k-pop/Korean song just to let you guys know.
author: Colin C.

description:
KimchI Fried Rice = Not to spicy. Egg cooked to perfection. A must have as a side.

Calamari & Beef Bulgogi w/ Vegetables = Perfect balance of flavors. I thought it was just going to be your typical beef and Veggies but had much more flavor than expected. 

Cheese & Corn = Nothing spectacular but goes well as a side. Tasted more cheese than corn with each bite; which was fine for me.

Soju = had the yogurt flavor and it was extremely good. Alcohol not too strong. Me and my wife shared a bottle barely finished it. We felt a good buzz; but we're not heavy drinkers.

Small tiny sides = They gave us a few small sides like kimchi, and some yellow pickled stuff that I cant name. Strong potent flavors that goes well with the meal. 

Place was noisy because its so small, but we we're the only ones speaking english; which I feel is a good thing. Our 2 month old was still able to sleep in his car seat through out our stay.
author: Anthony A.

description: I have been here twice now, and I must say that I love their kimchi fried rice! It was delicious, along with their chicken wings and seafood pancake.  The only downside to Toyose is having to wait to eat, since they are always crowded, but other than that, the food is worth it!
author: Rachel B.

description:
Incredible.  

Great service after a short wait.  Well worth the wait.  It was different than most other Korean places. (In a good way)

I can't wait to go back!
author: B B.

description: Decent food but overpriced. Been here twice and both times the hostess and servers were extremely rude. Unfortunate because the food was pretty decent. Decent kimchi fried rice, pancake, chicken wings, and yogurt soju. Would probably have gone more often if the service was better.
author: Jenna D.

description:
It is in someone's garage!! Cosy little place! 

MUST GET:
Kimchi Fried Rice- tasty, awesome!!! Love the egg on top! Lots of meat :D
Seafood Casserole- Awesome loads of ingredients! Great to warm up in winter!!! Just a note, skip the prawns with shell on and the crab legs.. They seem to be just for flavor and not for eating.. 

Forget about it:
Seafood pancake- Too soft for my liking..
Garlic and Cheese Fries- probably good for a bar snack.. garlic just in chunks, flavor not really integrated

Don't be scared off by the appearance. It's AWESOME!
author: Ka L.

description: I went here a couple times with my friends and I have to say it was a pretty good korean restaurant! The food is definitely on point. Funny thing is I brought my parents to Toyose for my dad's birthday and they ended up really liking the food. They even came back a couple times on their own because they thought it was delicious and different from the regular chinese and vietnamese food that they usually have on a daily basis. haha I'm glad it is near my house and it opens late! But too bad the place is a little small tho, the restaurant should maybe think about expanding or something!
author: Joanne C.

description:
For a while now, I never realized that this place actually had a name. I just called it "The Garage." Unless "toyose" means "garage?" I don't know!

Anyway, this place basically has inspired me to turn my garage into a Korean restaurant, complete with cocktail soju and DELICIOUS food! ;) 
I love the pancakes here (kimchee and seafood!!) and fried rice!! 
I recently tried the dukbokki, which was spicy, but well worth the numbing in my mouth.
The popcorn and fries are FANTASTIC too, but then again, that could just be the alcohol talking. OH MY GOODNESS, add the cheese and garlic to those fries though and it's pure heaven!!

The service is OK...most of the waiters/waitresses are pretty indifferent. I give them props for having to deal with a lot of loud drunk people.

Toyose can get crowded, especially on the weekends, so if you come during peak hours, expect to wait a bit.
author: Kei H.

description:
This is the first review I wrote where I wish there were half stars. Toyose is a 2.5. 

Sorry but Han Il Kwan beats this place out hand down when it comes to food. I came here after reading the great reviews on yelp and was extremely intrigued because it looks like a garage on the outside but I was disappointed my the portion size and the taste. Everything tasted average and could barely feed my family of six. We ordered six dishes and mango soju. We got the kimichi fried rice, beef bulgolgi, seafood pancakes, chicken wings, BBQ chicken, and spicy pork. The kimichi fried rice was good but it could only feed three. For the price, I expected a bigger size. I think this place is more of a late-night hot spot to hang out with friends, not really a family scene. 

What I recommend: Han II Kwan for food instead
author: Andrew W.

description: The hype is too real here. The food is better than most Korean restaurants in SF. I did enjoy the fish dish here.
author: Michelle S.

description:
The quality of the food was alright. However the service was somewhat slow. During Busy hours, expect a long wait.
Also, the price of the item does not seem to match the quantity of the food either. The fried calamari for $9 is not worth the amount they give.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I love this great find! The outside will deceive you as it does look like a house, but inside runs a full on restaurant. Heads up: It will be a tight fit, but their food is full of flavor and great taste. We had so many items on a random night, but you can never go wrong with kimchee fried rice. Their wait staff is very attentive. 
This will be San Francisco's great find for late dinner and great food. If you have a visitor and want to expose them to some SF culture, take them here for dinner!
author: Jeana A.

description:
i just realized now that i've been coming here for the past 2 years and have never written a review. i mean there's not much else i can add to the other positive reviews that have been written. 

we are regulars. we come here every so often for a completely guilty dinner. most times it's on a weeknight when there's no crowd because luckily we live close. i've never had to spend more than $25 when sharing a number of dishes with a group of people. however, i must say that if you come here to eat with just one other person, you would spend way more and wouldn't be able to try a variety of dishes. 

we typically order their spicy fried wings - not spicy at all. just comes out piping hot and crunchy. so crunchy, so good. beef kimchee fried rice, a ton of beer, sake, a big ramen casserole and their seafood pancake. i am always full and satisfied after leaving this place. i have no idea why i've read some complaints on here. it's a good place located far out in the sunset. away from any sort of crowd. it's nothing like ktown food in LA, but you know, they do a good job.
author: Thao T.

description:
I finally got to try out The Garage!  After hearing about this place so much from my bf when he used to come here for drunk food.  I think Korean food is okay, but I'm not a huge fan & I think it's typically the most expensive Asian cuisine & I also don't care for kimchi, but my friend she didn't either and told me this place is worth a try.  I was also reassured that this isn't your traditional Korean place.  

We ordered Beef Kimchi Fried Rice & the Spicy Chicken Wings.  And of course we got a bottle of Strawberry Soju!  I asked the waitress if they could make it medium spicy, and she responded to me, "They're not spicy at all, I promise."  I wasn't expecting that but thought it was cute of her to say.  She was right though they weren't spicy at all; they  but still tasty & perfectly crispy.  We also enjoyed the accompanying shredded cabbage due to the yummy dressing it was topped with which reminded me sort of a spicy Thousand Island dressing, but not rich like Thousand Island.  The soju was delicious and tasted like fresh strawberry juice with no taste of alcohol in taste is good, and bad for my fruity alchie loving tongue!  That soju is always a creeper!  It's also fairly cheap compared to other places I've been, it's $11 here vs. $15 at other places.  The Beef Kimchi Fried Rice came topped with an over easy egg.  It didn't taste like the usual kimchi, which I appreciate because I find that kimchi is usually too vinegary/hot for me.  Overall we enjoyed our dishes, the soju, the banchan and the complimentary popcorn.  The portions were a good size too.

Most of the time service was prompted by the service bell (which I felt bad for pressing a few times because I think it's sort of demeaning/annoying), but the waitresses provided efficient and pleasant service with a smile.  I'm glad the bf suggested Toyose for dinner last night.  It did not disappoint and I would definitely come back.    I do like Korean BBQ, which they don't have, but that may be a good thing since the first time I ever got drunk way back in the day at this one party had to do with a whole lotta booze & a whole lotta Korean BBQ beef, but no carbs, needless to say it was all bad, & I wouldn't want any repeat incidents to tarnish my thoughts of Toyose, so I'm just going to call no KBBQ on the menu a blessing in disguise!
author: Cat C.

description:
Came here for some grub on date night. They told us to come back in 45 mins...so we left got a drink, came back and happened to be seated right away which was awesome! My date and I went a little cray with the food and ordered some kim chee fried rice, kim chee soup, chicken wings, potato croquettes, and cheese corn. Definitely a bit too much food for two people. In addition to that we also had beer and soju. 

Kim chee fried rice and soup - really hit the spot. Flavors were good and the soup had just the perfect amount of kick to it.
Potato croquettes - amazing and didn't taste super heavy and had a nice crispy outside
Cheese corn - interesting dish. so simple and yet so satisfying at the same time
Chicken wings - this was the only disappointment. It was extremely dry and lacking in flavor. Personally I think the wings at the spot are much better.
Strawberry soju - it was actually much stronger than I expected. not overly sweet which i prefer.

The most recent time I came here was to pick up take-out which ended up proving to be a great alternative instead of having to wait for a table. 

I think its a bit overpriced, but the food hits the spot. I would come back. =)
author: Linda N.

description: I don't even remember the food because our waitress was so bitter. She didn't speak or make eye contact with us and when she lead us to our table we weren't even sure if we were supposed to follow her until she double backed just far enough for us to see her waving us over from behind the support beam. Literally not one word from her even when we ordered food or got the check.
author: Matthew J.

description:
Decided to celebrate my birthday here. I've been here before late night and had no problems at all in the past.

We had a party of 10 people, but 8 showed up. I made reservations ahead of time for 8:00pm, but didn't get a table until 8:32pm. That wasn't really the problem. We didn't mind waiting. 

We ordered about $280 worth of food and soju. The service was not bad, but they don't give a damn about you even when you ring the bell. 

We asked for a refill for ban-chan and the girl said "no, you need to order more food." My friends gave each other a look of "what the f?" we ordered so much food but your too shady to give more. Okay that fine.... cuz it was nothing special.

Later we ring the bell and ask for more popcorn. Waiter says " you need to order more soju." At this point we argued and said are you serious?  We ordered 6 bottles of soju already and you're telling us that we need to order more? 

I was so mad I wanted to flip the table. We only got 3 single bowl refills for the 8 of us. Those bowl are ridiculously small. 

When the bill came, we got charged for 9 bottles of soju instead of 6. Waiter was looking at the check playing the "she's right game w/ my table." But in the end she made the change. She thought we were too drunk to know anything. 

Save yourself the trouble, don't even think about coming here with a party of 6 or more. Actually, don't even come here at all. I regret for not going to Tonight Soju Lounge even though I was on the waitlist. The Spot is a better option than this place. 

I will never come back here again.
author: Jacky L.

description:
Would have never found this place if it wasn't for my friend that is from the area. Definitely looks like you're about to walk into someones garage. Coolest thing about this restaurant is definitely the little doorbell ringer that lets the waiter know if you need something.

To start off, if you're of age I would recommend getting soju, which comes in many different flavors. A really popular dish is the kimchi fried rice which delicious. My friends loved their crispy chicken wings which were prepared very well. My absolutely favorite dish was the calamari and bulgogi (beef) which was something I'd never had before but was just couldn't get enough of. The seafood pancake I probably wouldn't order again, but if you really like seafood it's something different to try.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Thought I wrote a review for this place already but here I go. The place is mainly for locals because it is a garage converted into a restaurant. The food serves OK Korean food and lightly alcohol-ed flavored soju. 

Never  like straight soju or Korean beer. Gets packed at night especially on the weekends.
author: M C.

description: Bad service! I just got yell at the server and I tired to talk to the manager, however, she just let that server yelled me again. What kinda of service is that? I will never go back to this restaurant again!
author: Olivia W.

description:
Mmmm....the infamous Korean garage spot.  The food probably isn't going to blow you away compared to other Korean restaurants in the city.  But it's still pretty damn tasty, and you could certainly do worse.  Yes, it is a shade on the high side, but you can't blame them.  This isn't your usual sort of restaurant since the majority of their business comes after the traditional dinner hours.  Rather, it's a place to eat AND drink (or more appropriately, it's a place to eat while you drink), so naturally it makes some sense to make some money on people's alcohol driven appetites.

The most popular of the dishes has got to be their Fried Chicken Wings.  All battered up, these crunchy little things are great.  They actually come out pretty good too, unlike some places where it's just a weird flavored batter around dried out pieces of meat.  The Seafood Pancake is also another personal favorite to share, although it's a little oily.  I really like the Kimchi fried rice too and it's pretty up there in terms of quality you can find in the city.  Definitely one of the better ones I've come across.  Oh, and don't forget to get some bottles of soju cocktials - preferably pineapple and strawberry.  Throw in the giant plastic bottle of OB or Hite, and you have yourself a good night.

The biggest knock is the fact that there are just so many damn people that come here!  So please, do me a favor...savor the five star review, but don't come here...the lines can't get any worse.  Until I convert my own garage that is.
author: Mike L.

description:
It's a garage! My urbanist sell is giddy with excitement seeing this urban conversion of a space made for cars to a space made for people. However, that is just my urban planning nerd side coming out. Settle down now, let my foodie part say something.

Came here on a Tuesday night to catch up with a friend and find a reason for her not to exercise. What a better alternative than to eat fried chicken wings!

The food here is good. Ordered a plate of chicken wings, a potato cake dish, and another plate of chicken wings. Yes, that is a lot of chicken, and it was heavenly. Super crunchy skin, bold seasonings, moist meats, beautiful cartilage (yes, I eat the cartilage - it's the best part!)

Had the soju here too. I forgot the name of it, but the description went something like "rose extract from a bulb plucked at the prime temperature, coated with the morning dew..." or something like that. When you read it, you'll know what I mean - and it's good here.

Prices are a bit higher than expected.
author: Jason S.

description:
I love this place. My sister took me here and I was in love with the place. Yes, it's in a garage, but once you get over the garage exterior, it's as if you've stepped inside another world. The interior was just so amazing. I'd have never thought I was inside a garage if I had been led inside blindfolded.

I love their kimchi fried rice. I was a little skeptical at first because my mom has always told me that fried rice isn't something that you'd order at a restaurant since fried rice is basically yesterday's rice fried with leftover ingredients. However, my friends and sister ordered it so I tried it. It was delicious! I loved it.

We also ordered the seafood pancake / pajeon. I love this too. Actually, I think I loved this more. I'm a huge fan of seafood and the pajeon reminds me of a Chiu Chow oyster omelet dish, which I love.

I actually haven't been here in a while, but today I found myself reminiscing about the restaurant. I want to go back as soon as possible.
author: Jennie T.

description: This place is one of my favorite korean restaurants in SF. However, this place is extremely small and the people come in herds. People will wait in line like all good SF restaurants. I've tried many things on the menu but my favorite is the seafood casserole with soju. Additionally, I like the seafood pancake. But like most korean restaurants this place serves good ban chan and good selection to choose from. If I hear from people out of town that want some Korean I definitely would suggest this place if the time permits it.
author: Jason L.

description:
Epic. Amazing. out of this world.

I am so happy my friend recommended, Toyose, aka "The Garage" to me.
 
It's absolutely phenomenal from the food to the drinks/soju and ambiance.

A great spot for an affordable, filling meal or just coming to stuff your face after a long night out. I only wish they were open even later.

I really like the yogurt soju and peach iced tea together. Their other sojus, especially the fruit flavored ones, are too sweet for me. They are loaded with syrup! 

Their kimchi fried rice, octopus and udon noodles, and cheesy corn are the best! So tasty.

I'll def be a regular at Toyose. I only wish it wasn't so out of the way..but it's worth it  =)
author: Veronica S.

description:
Open 6pm to 2am everyday...what more can you possibly need in life?
I have tried every flavor of Soju in here and would have to say that mango and lychee are the best.

Get drunk and eat the complimentary popcorn. this place rocks.  Visited 9 times now and I don't plan on quitting!
author: Christopher N.

description: Don't believe the hype. My friend told me that this is more a place for drinking than eating.. I can't really vouch for the drinking part but I can confirm the part about the crappy food.
author: Aaron V.

description: Literally a restaurant in a garage, and it works out! Great korean food, decent selection of fruity soju, which are all positives. I've been here a few times with family and friends and have no complaints. Just be okay with others being loud cause they're intoxicated! Almost sounds like starcraft commentary, /noracial if you know what I mean!
author: Sam K.

description:
aka: "The Garage" 

Do get:
The yogurt soju, the dry assorted appetizer with cuttle fish, and kimchi fried rice.  I'm not a big fan of the seafood pancake though it wasn't bad, maybe because it was bland. Fried chicken was a bit on the dry side with not much flavor.  

Press the button on the wall if you need something, each table has one.  I thought that was pretty clever  

One thing I didn't like is how they allow people to smoke inside :(
author: Anna W.

description: The restaurant is very isolated and is family owned by being in a garage but the food is amazing and everything tasted fantastic. The portions are medium and I think the prices are reasonable.
author: Darian L.

description:
It's almost impossible to find a good Korean restaurant in SF. Especially  after eating my way through Ktown in LA... 

Surprisingly, Toyose is one of my favorite Korean restaurants in SF (the other is Tofu House on Geary).

Highly recommend: 

1. Kimchee fried rice: flavorful, big portion, and the perfect balance of kimchee. 

2. Korean fried chicken: tender, crispy, good size, big portion. 

3. Seafood pancake: I like to order seafood pancake at every Korean restaurant that serves it. It's my favorite Korean food. Toyose serves one of the better ones in SF. Once again, a lot of seafood and big portion. 

Just overall a very solid restaurant. Wish it wasn't so far away from me...
author: Tina S.

description:
I've been told that the wait here on weekends is crazy, especially at night! I came here with two friends after we went to the Academy of Sciences for Nightlife, so it was about 9:30PM. Luckily for us, we didn't even have to wait to be seated--big plus! I'd never been here before and was quite surprised to see how far back the restaurant extended. The waitress sat us next to the backyard door, which was fine by me, though it was a tad cramped since there was a large party next to us. The only thing I was curious about is emergency exits in case there was a fire or something? Umm, yeah...

Anyway, we ordered the bulgogi , kimchi fried rice with beef, some kind of tofu soup (name's slipped my mind, sorry!), and a yogurt soju. The food was pretty nom, especially the bulgogi which had mushroom and pieces of seafood! The soju, really nom; trumps the Spot's (sorry!). The service was alright. I wish they had been more attentive, but what's really cool is they have buttons at the table that you press to call them over if you really need anything. I still like it when they come around and ask if you're doing okay though, but what can you expect when you're dining in what's meant to be a garage?
author: Audrey T.

description:
Don't really pay much attention to the old reviews about indoor smoking, because I think that's all a thing of the past...

This place is definitely soju heaven! I could definitely recommend the lemon soju personally that one was my favorite.

The service I thought was pretty good, and they weren't pushy at all about me and my friend taking 3-4 hours to finish drinking (granted we did order like 1 large Hite and 3 different flavors of soju). I definitely appreciated that. Maybe the only downside is I felt they could have given us a little more popcorn and snacks with our drinks (I mean we ended up dropping like $70 on food and drinks between two people!) but that's just a really minor complaint - I don't go to watering holes just to snack on peanuts and munchies lol...

I think I had my very first soju experience in college here many many years ago. I think I definitely have a soft spot for this place, and after rediscovering it last night - I'll definitely be back!
author: Doug R.

description:
I don't get the four stars...really...I don't. I mean,... It's my bad for eating Korean food in SF when it is clearly not an SF specialty, but I have high expectations for a place that actually has 4 stars!

 My ex employers took me here today and the three of us ordered the Beef KimChee Fried Rice, Spicy Cod Tofu Soup, and the Octopus Udon. First of all, there were only 4 banchan dishes: bean sprouts, kimchee, pickled daikon, and seaweed. LAME. No jap chae? WTH? I didn't even see it on the menu! Nor was LA Kalbi on the menu! YOU CALL THIS A KOREAN RESTAURANT!? BLASPHEMOUS. I only tried the daikon and it was so-so..a litle too vinegary. 

Moving on... I have had better KimChee Fried Rice. It was not entirely flavorless but wasn't very spicy or memorable. It was just okay. Udon was probably the best part even though the octopus was extra chewy. Soup base was similar in flavor to Miso. A-OK. Cod and Tofu Soup....DON'T EVEN BOTHER. There was cod (which tasted a bit old to me), tofu, and vegetables sure.. but the rest of it is just soup base with a fat load of chili dumped in. I can mostly taste the chili is all. If your'e thinking of that bubbly loaded tofu concoction found at traditional Korean restaurants, then boy have you found the wrong place to dine tonight. 

So in conclusion, best thing about Toyose is the random location inside a house..and the decor is not so bad. It is pretty cozy inside. The service is okay. Did I mention the wait was like 30-35 minutes for our food? We came as it was opening and there were already lots of people inside so I suppose we ordered at the same time. Overall I wouldn't say my experience was horrible, just below average. Perhaps we just ordered things that were not their specialty (but then you have to ask yourself, why even have things on your menu that you don't specialize in?). Okay. Done with rant. Move on.
author: Cindy D.

description:
Interesting entrance! If I didn't find out from someone else that this was a restaurant, I don't think I would've entered at all. 

One of the best Korean restaurants I've been to. Their seafood pancake is a must get, the sauteed rice cakes were super delicious also. Very very spicy for me, maybe not for other people, after eating that I was sweating like a pig haha. 

Overall, the place was pretty good, the service was not bad, food came out quick. The only thing I would have to say is that i think its a little bit too small and too cramped up. I like to have some distant between other people when I dine. Other than that, everything was amazing. I would recommend this place to anybody who likes Korean food, and will definitely come back again !
author: Andrew H.

description:
We lived in the Outer Sunset and then moved away before we visited Toyose.  Go figure.  Should have gone sooner!  If you haven't been, get in yer TOYOta on your TOYO tires and head out to TOYOse... pattern?  Toyose means garage.  A converted garage they say.  Who cares.  Toyose is a comfortable private hideaway den that seems to reach back forever in space and time.   Like a pub in a poor fishing village, very welcoming and unpretentious.  Gotta like that.

The food is uniformly excellent. We tried a octo stew with an udon-type noodle in a fairly mild version of one of korea's 863 chili sauces that really got everything off to a great start.... well, except for the cheesy chopsticks that seem to always break in the middle when you separate them, and the 3" plates that are supposed to politely receive the temptations served... come on... this is BIG USA!!! Bring on those BIG PLATES!  the little plates may have slowed us down but could not prevent us from eating too much of the savories like kimchee fried rice (A+ comfort food) or the house deepfried chicken (CRUNCH!) or the value special, the seafood pancake.  Seriously the octo stew and the seafood pancake could each feed four with a side of rice.  

Very friendly and hardworking staff... not sure why they have a "CALL" button located just above each table.  You know how much you want to push those, just because.  If I can resist, you can too.

Shoju cocktails for those who like shoju. I am wary of shoju from business drinking parties in Asia, and keep a very respectful distance.  I like to keep the delicious food I eat and I'm DD to boot.  

Worth the trip no matter how you make it.  Four block walk from the N Judah line stop at 45th Ave.  

"Summer's coming" ... dress accordingly.
author: Bob K.

description:
This is certainly a unique restaurant (converted garage on a commercial street in the outer Sunset) to check out but I probably won't come back for the following reasons:

1)  poor staff service:  keep in mind that this is a fairly tiny place so you would think that the staff would ask people who were obviously finished eating and were literally just playing on their smart phones to leave especially when there were many parties waiting but no.      

2)  preferential treatment:  for the most part, this place caters to mostly hipsters or young people.  I could have sworn that a small group of hipsters simply walked in and got a table before us and a number of other groups.  That's not cool and totally unacceptable in my book.

3)  expensive:  for what you get the food here is kind of expensive.

The saving grace to this place is the variety of soju drinks it has.  If it weren't for that, I would have gone with one star.

I tend to be fairly easy on my reviews so for me to ding a place says a lot about the poor experience.  If I ever (and I will) have an urge for some chicken wings I'll gladly give my money to San Tung instead.
author: V C.

description:
We ordered a table full of food for four of us and said "oh, this is way too much," and then destroyed it.  I think one lone chicken wing and a half a croquette was left.  I had a slew of Korean food virgins with me, and I think they may have been a bit nervous, but they got over that with the first bite.  
It's total comfort/ late night/hangover food (so get some kimchee fried rice to go if you know what's good for you).
The other patrons were a bit snotty, and the wait even after 10 pm was 20 minutes, but service was fast and efficient (love the call button at each table) and food came out quickly.
I will dream about some of that food.  In fact, I'm wanting some right now.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Love the atmosphere.  A garage turned hole-in-the-wall restaurant  Private booths with wooden blinds for privacy and a little bell at each table for fast service.   Place can get pretty packed.  

The first time I went there, for a party of two, we ordered a bottle of yogurt soju and the kimchee spam and hot dog soup.  Way too much food, but we took it home and made left overs the next day.  I thought, "I'm bringing my whole crew here, so they can try out korean food!"  

Bad idea.

Toyose is NOT good for large parties.  We had a party of 10, and we couldn't fit in the table, so we had to split the tables.  Not comfortable at all, nor was the staff very helpful.  They were just so annoyed with us.  But in all honesty, a server dealing with a party needs to suck it up and love us because of that auto-grat/easy money.  We weren't even difficult either.  I can also say this because I've been a restaurant server for 10 years of my life.  I've done and dealt with that crap.  

We ordered the chicken wings, sausage wrapped in bacon, seafood pancake, bi bim bap and that kim chee soup with spam and hot dogs along with kiwi and yogurt soju.  

So good.  Next time, I'll just come with a few girlfriends, not the whole crew.
author: Cat A.

description: This really seems more like late night bar hang out to me.  Nothing wrong with that.  Love that it's open late.  Maybe I'm biased since food always taste better when your drunk and I wasn't so much.  The chicken was okay...too fried.  Got the seafood pancake.  A little bit weird that there was tomato in it.  The kimchi fried rice was great, but it hardly ever is bad.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
My friends come here a lot.  A... LOT.  I see lots of check-ins here at Toyose on Facebook, and well, finally I had a chance to see what all the hype was.  First things first.  It's in a garage.  I couldn't really imagine it in my head when people said "it's built in a garage", but that's what it is.  They took the ground floor of a Sunset house and made it into a restaurant.  Really interesting start.  We called beforehand and got a table in about 10 minutes.   

I let my friends order food, and we ended up with some kimchi fried rice, chicken wings, a rice cake dish, a "casserole", and some soju.  The food wasn't exceptionally memorable, but it was good!  I don't think I'd ever come here to satisfy a Korean food craving, but it wasn't bad.  

This place is more of a really chill, hang out with friends kind of place.  The atmosphere is really laid back.  Good place to hang out late at night.  It's a good place to eat and catch up with some friends.  

I don't think I'd ever drag any friends to Toyose, but if someone invited me out to the place, I'd probably tag along.
author: Wayland L.

description:
So, we ended up going here at a friend's suggestion, having been told that the draw of this place was the value, food, and chill/dive-y atmosphere. Did it deliver? Totally. That said, I think it's hard to equate my 4 star review of this place with a 4 star review I'd provide for a place in LA (Koreatown). We need to take context, value, and quality all into consideration when we rate places, right? 

The place had pretty decent food (albeit everything was very mild, even when we asked for things to be spicy... but I suspect that was due to the fact that our small group was quite ethnically diverse), service was very courteous and understanding despite being strained & sluggish at times, and the decor... well, it's a garage-y place that's meant to be a drinking, eating, and conversation inducing establishment so it. just. makes. sense.

It's not Ktown-LA food. Nor is it even SJ Korean food. But I'd say that the quality and attitude of the place is better than 95% of the other Korean places in the city of SF.

Notable good deeds:
- Seafood Pajun (A-, solid and the seafood was fresh, not rubbery or skimpy)
- Kimchi fried rice (B, overpriced for the portion size, but everyone loved it. it's like Korean Mac and Cheese... comfort food)
- Tempura (B+, not korean but hey, who dislikes fried food?)
- Seafood Jungol (B, solid and it's the only non-spicy large format soup there was on the menu. very approachable for all non veterans of Korean food)

Donate your sixpence to the poor:
- Tong Dahk, "whole chicken" (C-, it was really really really dry. it may be better on other occasions, but it sure as heck wasn't good on this one.)
- Kimchi Tofu (C, not much meat in the dish... just not impressive - I had to order it. I missed eating this sort of stuff in LA)
- Cocktail sojus (B/C-, because while the table liked it, I kept telling them how little soju there was vs. the filler drinks. it's a matter of value... I don't think it's worth it to drink something that would lead me to a cavity sooner than get me drunk).

Why the 4 stars? Because even if the food wasn't top notch, nor was the service spectacular, the service staff of 2 was really pleasant and tried their best to take care of a packed house and served food that, although at times missed the mark, was made with fresh ingredients in a very relaxed environment.. so much so, that I would ALMOST be willing to drive out there on a weeknight after work. Yes, kids, this place is hella far from civilization. :)

Sidenote: Um, for those of you confused about the bell button to call staff: That's what we call: evolution. It's ALL over the place in KTown, JTown, and is now spreading to random downtown gastropubs. What's more is that it isn't even new: I've seen it in the US for over a decade and has been used throughout Korea/Japan for... well, longer. 

Then again, I suppose some people would rather wave their hands wildly to flag down a server. I, for one, prefer to press a button and go back to my conversation (ahem, food bowl/booze) with my friends until a waiter/waitress pops up. To each their own.
author: Jae O.

description:
Blech..... if this is Korean food at it's best, i'm saving money to go to North Korea to eat better! It's like someone went to the freezer and pulled out this meat and seafood and served it up. 

Fried chicken, BONE DRY and totally lacking in flavor. I got the whole chicken...er..the "emaciated" chicken. nuf said!
Spicy Pork... over cooked and dry...well except for the 4oz of grease. blech me.
Seafood pancake..overcooked again. rubbery shrimp and calamari in a bland fried dough. WTF... c'mon!


I've had korean in LA, NYC and SF now. In LA i loved the noodles, in NYC the ultra crisp tender fried chicken and amazing mandoo of all types... and I'm hopeful of finding someplace in the bay area as well... this aint it and thats too bad because i live down the street and I just spent $50 on stuff others call "food". I can't call it that though.
author: Nik D.

description:
OK the first thing to beware of about this restaurant is that they don't take reservations and the restaurant is a converted garage so it's really tiny. Be prepared to wait a bit unless you avoid peak hours. 

Melissa H., my lovely tour guide for SF, was the one who first brought me here :). I've been here about 4-5 times now!

Here are the dishes I recommend:

Kimchi Fried Rice
Seafood Pancake (haemul pajeon!!!)
Chicken Wings
Peach Yogurt Soju

This is a great meal for 3-4 people :). Toyose is a bit expensive and I can't remember the exact prices for the above dishes but I remember they are in the $12-13 range.

I highly recommend this cozy SF favorite!!
author: Eileen E.

description: Amazing food, decent prices, and great service! It can be hard to get a table so make a reservation!
author: Cat M.

description: Great flavors- but leaves something to be desired. Personally, the best part of having Korean food are the banchans! I think it's strange that they only give you popcorn- it reminds me of going to a BAR in Korea, not a restaurant. My boyfriend doesn't like Toyose as much as me, but this is mostly because we steer towards different Korean flavor profiles. While they offer my favorites, his VERY TRADITIONAL favorite is nowhere to be found- bibimbap, no kimbap either! So without the BANCHAN, or bibimbap on the menu... this is not a complete Korean restaurant. The popcorn shows that they'd rather be seen as a bar, not a restaurant. Also, get there right at six or you'll be waiting for forever in unpleasant and crowded waiting conditions.
author: Megan M.

description: It was my first time eating dinner at Toyose and I'm sure I will go there again and again. Toyose is actually a small garage restaurant and all the taste of the food are super awesome and fresh.There are different kinds of menu and the most popular are kimchi fried rice and fried chicken wings. Service is quite so so but food are good.We ordered seafood kimchi pancake, spicy pork,seafood stew and japchae. All the foods are quite enough for 4 people and really good. Seafood stew is good to order for people with group. All the prices are good to eat often.
author: Catherine J.

description:
I went here for a friend's birthday party, it was fairly cramped for our party of 11, but they accommodated us with reservation and everything.

The food was tasty - especially the kimchi pancake, we had several orders of those.
The plum wine and soju was also very good.  Good and fun atmosphere for friends gathering.
author: Jessica L.

description:
oh Toyose, how i crave you! 
No other korean place compares to you.

Get the Spam Cassarole and Fries w/ garlic and cheese.
You wont be disappointed!

The Spam Cassarole is like all my favorites in a bubbling pot of soupy goodness. There is spam, ramen, fishcake, hotdog, veggies.. i can keep going but i might have to go there tomorrow just because i'm thinking about it and craving it.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Tasty, spicy and good for going into labor. I came here and got take out on my due date. There was no way I was going to wait 45 min for a table, and I probably wouldn't have fit into one of their tiny spaces, anyway, at a full 9 months pregnant.  
The food was delicious and had some kick. 3 hours later, I went into labor, and a few hours after that, we had our sweet (and maybe spicy?) baby in our arms. Thanks, Toyose!
author: J R.

description:
So I've been here on and off with my friends since my last visit. Food here is sometimes a hit and miss. The chicken wings are sometimes over fried, which isn't too pleasant to eat since it's just really hard and it has a slight burnt taste to it. Sometimes they over cook the pancake too so that has a lingering burnt after taste as well. 

Also, their food here that is spicy... is really good. The other stuff that isn't spicy... isn't really that good. For example, one of the bugolgi wasn't spicy and because of that, it wasn't too flavorful. So I'm not sure if it's just that dish, or their dishes that don't have the spicy paste it just lacks in general.

In general, I'll still be coming back, but food really isn't that OMG since it's not consistent at all.
author: Johnson S.

description: Great soju! Food is great also, I recommend the spicy chicken, kiwi soju and cheese corn!
author: Chris N.

description:
The good: 
Huge casseroles (can easily feed 4 if this is the only thing you order)
Food comes very quickly
Super tasty Sojuice

The bad:
The place is TINY (maybe ~15 tables of 4, tops)
If you're in a table out "front", you'll probably be looking at *ss your whole meal since the waiting area only has room for about 8 people and there's usually about 2 doz people waiting

The ugly:
The wait is LONG - make reservations if you can (not sure how that whole deal goes but even with a reservation, we must have waited an additional 30 minutes)
Because of the long wait, they usher you in and out ASAP
author: Yeelo N.

description:
the Prince of Taiwan, in an effort to improve relations with the South Korean gub'ment, decided to visit this often heralded dive in the Outer Sunset area on a popping Friday night. first of all, the wait is as bad as everyone here laments. And I think the reason isn't the fault of the servers or the kitchen at all. The food here is banged out fast and hot, and the servers (cute Korean chicks BTW) are fast and efficient. the problem with the wait are all the damn people sitting around and leaving when the last chicken has been eaten and the last drop of delicious mango soju has been drunk. 

When we got in around 800PM, there was this large group of Taiwanese lesboz sitting eating and drinking, and probably decide in whose rug to munch on later that night. They are my own people, so the Prince of Taiwan can make fun. 

When we left around 9:30Pm, those chicks were still there! And it wasn't like they were eating or drinking or fisting, etc. they were just sitting there talking as if they were still in the Shilin night market in Taipei, Taiwan. Cmon ladies..i know your hair is cool because you all styled it like Justin Beiber, but that gives you all no right to hog up a damn table for over 2.5 hours! 

Crowd is pretty rowdy and loud, and full of young Asian folks, and curious white folk. There was this one dude dressed like Asian Justin Timberlake with his fedora, vest, and slim pants hitting on a bunch of ladies. And to the table next to us there was a huge crowd of drunk as well Vietnamese young ladies (some pretty hot, some just ok) celebrating either the holidays or someone's birthday. They spoke in viet/ engrish so loud i felt like I was getting a rosetta stone class. And when they started singing "HAPPY VURTHDAY DO YOOO.. HAPPY VURTHDAY DO YOOO" over and over again..I had enough, and got up to leave with my wife and friend. 

O h yeah..the food. ehhhh. honestly I was expecting food that lift my skirt up like Marilyn Monroe. Instead it was just good, decent food, but not worth the hour plus wait. Spicy chicken was not spicy nor was it flavored..just fried chicken without any herbs or spices. Seafood pancake was the highlight of the night. Good and tasty, with the sauce it was really nice. hot tofu soup with calimari was very spicy and hit the spot on a cold night. Mango soju was like drinking candy..excellent. 

I am glad i tried this place out. I think the servers all work very hard, and stay friendly despite probably hit on by both men and women. the kitchen bangs out the plates fast. but the wait is probably a bit much.
author: Jerry C.

description:
Despite being a little more on the expensive side (dishes ranging between $12-$17) and the place being a little snug, it's a unique restaurant that everyone should try at least once. It's litterally in a garage, which is pretty neat.

The yogurt and strawberry sojus were BOMB ($12 each for about 10 shots a bottle)! The only dishes that stand out to me are the kim chi fried rice and the split eel with house sauce. You HAVE to try that eel dish. The sauce and texture are amazing.

It's definitely no Korean BBQ spot, but it's some really good authentic cuisine. Plus, they're open really late and parking isn't bad at all.

The portions aren't that big, so expect to spend some money if you're looking to be full. Other than that, it's a good time. I wouldn't suggest having groups more than 5 to eat here unless you make reservations.
author: Anna Marie T.

description:
This place is such an amazing find!

My boyfriend suggested this place to eat after a long day. Definitely would've missed it if I didn't really pay attention. It's a cute hole-in-the-wall garage place. Looks exactly like a garage from the outside, but on the inside it's completely different.

When you walk in, there are little booths to the right. They  have a screen on the sides so you won't be bothered by the people who are waiting for a table. Definitely a plus. The booths are cozy and private. We ordered the house soju and a big bottle of beer. They gave us a small bowl of popcorn to munch on which was great because we were starving. We got an order of the spicy chicken wings (YUM!), an order of the calamari and noodles and then the codfish in their spicy tofu soup.

Service was fine, they have the call button and they respond fairly quickly.

I guess the only thing that bummed me is that they don't serve the small korean dishes like every other korean restaurant does. 

Fyi, there's only one bathroom so generally you have to stalk it out.
author: Angela K.

description: Came here with my buddies for dinner and one of the waitress was super non-friendly. She gave us attitude and threw spoons on table after we asked for them. More importantly, my buddies and I all had stomachache after we went home. Second visit? Same result. Same mean waitress (same person as last time) and another unpleasant visit to the restroom. I don't know what's wrong with that particular waitress and more importantly, the food. Good luck when you have a meal here.
author: Andy H.

description: Totally great place.  Just pull the garage door open and enter!  It's not fancy.  But they try to give you a "booth" feeling with a pull-down shade for your table.  Sweet.  We ordered the kimchi soup -- spicy and delicious.  We also had chicken wings and a kimchi rice dish.  That was more than enough for two people and I have a little take-home today I'm excited for.  The location is way out by the beach, but it's worth the drive.
author: Jenny F.

description:
Having been forced to eat Korean food for most of my adolescence, I really don't like visiting or eating at Korean establishments, but this place is a clear outlier.

I visited Toyose two times with two different group of friends, one non-korean and one korean, and on both accounts Toyose did not disappoint. 

If you're looking for a straight-up pojang macha-type establishment, it doesn't get any better than Toyose. Toyose has all the Korean drinking-table favorites: Pa-jeon, Al-tang, Haejang-guk, Budae jjigae, and etc.; they also had a wide array of soju cocktails available on menu which was popular on my first visit with my non-Korean friends; on my second visit with Korean friends, we were impressed with their near-complete selection of Korean beer and soju (they also have baekseju and bokubunja, and maesilju as well.)

So whether you're Korean or not, if you enjoy/appreciate Korean food and LOVE drinking (can't emphasize this part enough,) then Toyose is an awesome place to spend twenty dollars; the only thing about this place is that the whole restaurant is a converted garage, and you might have to wait a bit if you're in a party of five or more.
author: Scott S.

description:
Now because this is a "korean" place, the first thing my friend and I looked for in the menu was KOREAN BBQ! They don't have it!!!! What a disappointment.

From the outside (since it's in a garage) you'd think that the inside looks like the inside of a typical garage. Nope! It actually looks nice inside. They even have buzzers at each table for when you need the waiter's attention.

Food was okay. Nothing special. My friends say that this place is more popular for it's soju. My friend and I didn't get any soju since we recently just got back from a Vegas trip filled with binge drinking all day long! I needed to stay away from alcohol. I guess it's just another place to get drunk off soju and not care about how the food really tastes.

Quick tip: Bring extra clothes. You'll smell like food after.
author: Majileen C.

description:
kimchi fried rice and seafood pancake!! the flavored sojus were good!
i like the fries too!!
we also ordered this spicy pork with tofu thing, it was delicious as well!!
would go back again!
author: Ru C.

description:
Adorable Korean restaurant tucked in a little garage.

(+) Yogurt Soju ($15)
(+) Strawberry Soju ($15)
(+/-) Mango Soju ($15)
(+) Popcorn to munch on with soju ($0)
(+) Kimchi Pancake ($8.95, 10-11 pieces)
(+) Spicy Chicken Wings ($11.95, 10-11 pieces)
(+) Kimchi Friend Rice + Egg ($11.95)
(+) Sauteed Rice Cake & Fish Cake in Hot Chili Sauce ($8.95)
(+) Cold-buckwheat-noodle-salad-in-kinda-spicy-sauce-thing ($17.95) 
(-) Disposable chopsticks ($Unnecessary waste)

We got here when it opened at 6pm, so drinks and food came pretty quickly. But come here later than 8pm, you'll not only have to wait outside in the cold, Pacific Ocean winds before a table opens up, but you'll also definitely have to wait some time for each dish to arrive. Which is fine -- more time in between to enjoy the cocktail sojus!

I've always liked the classic Yogurt Soju, but this time, we tried the Strawberry Soju and the Mango Soju, and I gotta say Strawberry beats Mango: the mango tasted like syrup, kind of medicinal; and the strawberry was more natural. (Just a side note: there's these little seeds in the Strawberry Soju...and I just totally dig berry things with berry seeds. So real.) Anyways, the cocktail sojus are pretty awesome since they come in these fun-to-pour bottles, and they hold maybe 10-15 shots -- excellent for groups. 

I really like that it's family style and that each person gets a little dish -- it really allows you to enjoy each bite of food. Really good place to go with a group of people -- you get to eat more dishes that way =).

Kimchi Pancake was good a starter. Then came the Spicy Chicken Wings, which weren't  spicy at all, in my opinion. But douse them in the sauce that comes with the Sauteed Rice+Fish Cakes, and they will be spicy! It's also quite genius to rest the Rice Cakes on top of Ramen noodles -- they really help to catch more of the yummy spicy sauce. Also, soak some of that sauce up with the Kimchi Fried Rice for some extra spicy-ness! In the end, we ordered the buckwheat noodle salad thing. It was a nice finish since it was seriously a plate of different veggies -- very cooling to the palate -- with cold buckwheat noodles (looks like zhazhangmyun) and cold pork. I wish there could have been more noodles and less greens, but I guess it was a pretty good dish with everything mixed in together...esp with the light chili vinegar sauce. 

Very satisfying meal.

Total (including tip) = $123 / 9 buddies = about $14 per buddy
author: Julia L.

description:
1-star for the decent taste and price for food 
1- star for great place to hang out with friends at a late night 

Downside: 
The menu states that auto gratuity for 6+. But we have a party of 5 and gave us auto gratuity of 18%. 
I specially put a dollar less than the bill for that additional person out of nowhere, and the waitress had the nerve to came out and ask for the dollar, so I told her I will give you that one dollar because you look like a homeless asking for money. But I did not appreciate that you charged auto gratuity to a party of 5. 
Service?! Is there service?! At least I didn't feel like I got any service unless you guys consider bringing out food is the service I'm tipping for. 
All the waitresses were having a sh*t face, seems like their family just got into a car crash. 
If you have a party of 5, I will suggest you guys to ask one more friend to come, or else they will only give you a small table that will only fit 4 people comfortable. One of my friend had to sit by the edge of the table and next to the bathroom, everyone was like running into him.
author: Nikki S.

description: " Nice" serves! There are three available table inside the restaurant, but the waitress still ask us to wait one and half hour for the seat and the reason is" I want to see everybody here, then I can give you the seat"! Hey, my friend just into the restroom, how can she come out just for let you see we all here? Really " nice" smile Korean lady!
author: Vivi L.

description: Totally fun - Bourdain-ey kind of place. Loved the yogurt soju cocktail and the popcorn and the bulgogi/calamari. Wanted the cheese corn.
author: Andrew K.

description:
SUCH an ADORABLE cute garage-hole-in-the-wall Korean restaurant.  I Love the decor on the inside and the dim lighting.  

I'd say the service is a 3/5, but the food was a 4/5.  SEAFOOD PANCAKE!!!!!

I can't wait to come back for more! :)
author: Liz W.

description: Never make a reservation and try to come to this place. They have no concept of customer service an are angry. Bad business. Lie to the customers. Food does not make a restaurant. None of the party of 16 will come back. F this place and the employees
author: Neal S.

description:
I been to this place since 2005,been there many times, it's a small place build in the garage, they busy as hell during the weekends, always line up.
I had eat the seafood hot pot and the seafood pancake, taste good to me, but my favorite is the yoguart soju, LOVE IT.
Didn''t eat in there for long time , think should back there to eat soon, of cause I'm a fan of the yoguart soju :)
author: DontHurtMe T.

description: I love this place, I come often for the seafood pancake and the seafood stew. Whenever I have nothing to do on a late night, this place usually pops into my head for some quick Korean food. They have other great items also, like fried chicken, cheese fries, and udon that I also like a lot. I think the portions are fairly large as well. They also serve soju cocktails here which are all very good. Really great place for a group outing. The place is in a garage, how cool is that?!
author: Wells Y.

description:
Moving down to SF from Portland, I've definitely wanted to try the local hot spots here and I was excited to hear about a Korean hot pot restaurant that is in a garage.

You can tell this place is real popular, as we walked in and it was filled with people lined up in the entry way waiting for a table.

The seafood pancake was delicious. We also ordered the seafood hot pot, which ... unfortunately was a little average. The mussels were real chewy and it was just OK. The noodles and the soup base were real good though.

Service here was excellent as well. I have no complaints. 

I'll probably come back to try something else and see if the food is a little better next time.
author: Alex T.

description:
Toyose is a secret garage restaurant. The best place imo for soju in SF. It's average priced and strawberry is definitely the BEST i've had, then yogurt comes in a very close second. 

Their seafood pots are hugeeeee and delicious. Way too much food for two people tho, the BF thought he could conquer it... HA HA HA. 

my favorite is definitely the kimchi fried rice. =) and the soju of course.

Overall, don't come on a busy night  with a group larger than 4 because it's soooo small that a table for 6 is impossible.
author: jennifer f.

description:
One of the best Korean places in the city! Doesn't even look like a restaurant from the outside, such a great hole in the wall.

Always delicious, hot and spicy Korean food. There can sometimes be a wait around dinner time, but this place is open very late (2AM), so always good post 9PM.

Recommended
- Seafood Pancake (Kimchi version is fantastic)
- Croquette 
- Almost all of the soups/hot pots
- Clear sweet potato noodles!

Also, I've seen a lot of people enjoying drinking here and eating some of the late night/drink friendly menu items! Been meaning to do this for a while.

Awesome place, worth the trip out to the outer sunset! Parking is usually pretty easy.
author: Ninja R.

description:
What's there not to love about this place? The service is excellent thanks to the door bell at each table. 

Must order items: 
Kimchi fried rice
Spicy chicken wings 
Peach soju (if you are of age)

Minus a star because they skimp the beef on the Kimchi fried rice.

Be easy on the soju. It's easy to spend upwards of $150+ between 4 people.
author: BYRON D.

description:
Toyose is such a quirky little Korean hot spot literally hidden in the Outer Sunset district.  It's a garage-turned-restaurant with some of the best, affordable Korean food ever.

My favorite dishes include: 
* Kimchi Fried Rice w/ Egg
* Seafood Pancake (relatively light and pleasingly thin and crispy) 
* Potstickers (great crunch on the skin with a warm core of tender meat)
* Fried Chicken Wings

I also love, love, love their Strawberry-flavored soju.  Their sojus are made with fresh fruits and are sweet to my liking.

I came here again last night for a friend's birthday, ordered 3 entrees, 1 appetizer, 1 pitcher of beer, and only paid $15 (with tax and 18% gratuity).  Cheap much?  Yes.  Filling?  Yes.  Delicious?  Yes!
author: Judy C.

description:
I remember the first time I came here about five years ago.. a friend brought me here because he knew they didn't card and I wasn't 21 yet.  Boy did I get drunk off Korean beer.  Admittedly I was a tad worried that my friend was taking me into a garage (thinking it was a brothel or something), but I should've known!  The best eats are the ones that are least flashy.

This is a good place for some quality Korean food, decent portions, and medium-size parties.  Portions are family-style-friendly, so I would say order to share.  Of course the first time I came here I finished a Spam Fried Rice on my own, so depending on your appetite you may not want to take my word for it.  What's good here?  My faves are the sticky rice stick/ramen noodle thing, the cheese corn, and the fried rice.  The fried chicken is decent too, but I don't count it cuz it doesn't seem feel "Korean" enough.  Bottoms up!
author: Jae Z.

description: I love this place! The atmosphere is pretty and has a great vibe. Food is delicious, the best Korean food I've ever ate. We had seafood and kimchi pancake, kimchi friend rice and the pork. It was so damn good! Yogurt Soju is tasty, I drank half the bottle. It's enough for 5 people though, we just wanted to finish it. I'd go there again anytime!
author: Elaine L.

description:
Toyose is my can't fail rowdy Korean go-to spot in the City, especially when I'm feeling like tapering off a night at the bar (in a good way) by imbibing on some seriously yummy soju cocktails and satisfying Hog Dog Casserole!

Tucked away in a garage in a quiet residential neighboorhood near 45th and Noriega, this place is easy to miss - unless you know what to look for. It's almost like a Korean speakeasy - look for the angry chicken! :) Once inside, you'll know why there is always a loooooooooong wait - there is only enough room for about 20 to 30 people, tops. And if it is at full capacity, you'll be waiting upwards of 1 to 1.5 hours. However, don't be a n00b--make a reservation and you'll be seated almost instantly. If you do, make sure to be on time as they WILL give your table away with a quickness, especially if  you're late and its big party. 

Consistent favorites here are the casserole, dduk bok gi, and kimchee pancake. I will make a disclaimer and say that if you do get the casserole, get extra spicy. There is NO point to not get spicy at a Korean restaurant! The casseroles are HUGE and easily shared between 3-4 people, especially if they have small appetites. The drinks are good, though the soju cocktails really are pretty weak, at least for me. 

Toyose is definitely more for the rowdy, younger crowd so if you're looking for something quieter I would skip this place. It's not the BEST Korean I've had (and it is not the best in the City), but I always have a great time here so four stars for me on this one!
author: Linda C.

description:
I like the spicy rice cake with fish cake. bulgogi with calamari, cheesie corn , seafood  pancakes there. 

There fried rices are normal and not so good, unless you are hungry you probably think it's good . 

The worst thing I experience here is, I never can make a reservation, and the waiting time is taking like forever, they want us to wait (such a waste of time!!!3ever)
author: Hallie N.

description:
i will make this review pretty simple 
 
PROS:

 friend rice
Soju(all flavors)
prices are reasonable
button at table to call waitress

Cons:
-Tiny
-the waitress are kinda snobby( atleast thats the impression i got)
-If you sit next to the door good luck trying to have a conversation with the people you        came with

over this place is ok. the food is good and its comes out pretty quick. just expect to wait about 45min to be seated. my only recommendation i can give is to try and hold out for a table in the back.
author: Mike M.

description: The atmosphere + food reminds me of Korea in the winter time. This cozy little place serves a lot of food for a good price, so it's best to bring a group of friends along. They're open late which is awesome~* BUT, expect a line shooting out the door when you arrive. The 1st time here, we were in a group of 12; waited 1.5 hrs. The 2nd time with two people, waited an hour. Nom Nom Nom.
author: Annie N.

description:
As you may have noticed, nearly every reviewer has mentioned that this place is actually in a garage, nestled smack in the middle of an unassuming residential area.  All of which makes Toyose's meteoric rise to fame quite remarkable - in no small part thanks to Yelp.

Ambiance is, of course, the star of the show.  It's quite jarring to enter a shady looking garagefront into a fully converted restaurant indoors.  It's still got that slightly claustrophobic homegrown charm to it though, like you're playing house inside the box that your refrigerator came in (I *know* you all did that as a kid...).  There's plenty of graffiti scrawled on the walls by previous patrons, which imho adds to the neighborhood watering hole atmosphere.  Go ahead and add your own contribution, but make sure the waitresses aren't looking!

As for the food, it's standard but solid.  You can pretty much find all the usual suspects, and they are reasonably priced to boot.  It's an interesting place to take friends who haven't been there before, and it's open really late!
author: Allen C.

description: Love this place. Though the place is a little bit tight, but it's very interesting to have a dinner in a garage. I always order the kimchi fried rice and kimchi pancake. They are sooooo good!! Fried chicken and the stews are my favorite too! But usually u cannot finish a whole stew with only two ppl.
author: Kathleen K.

description:
I came here last night and has the WORST customer service. If only there was an option for 0 stars on Yelp.

It used to be if you arrived before 6, they would let say, "We aren't open yet, but you can have a seat first." Nope. Not anymore. I've been here several times before, and have never experienced something like this. We originally had a reservation for 10 at 6PM, and when 6 of the party arrived, they wanted to sit, but they waitress simply said they weren't open yet and wouldn't let them sit. Since they will not seat you until the whole party arrives, when it came time for 6PM, our party told the waitress it was 6 people instead of the original 10 to get seated first. And then add a seat for the 7th person on arrival. It was going to be the same number of tables and seating either way with the 7th seat at the end of the table. The the waitress ROLLS HER EYES at one of our party. Are you serious? What kind of customer service is this? And said that we needed to let them know in advanced and they needed to "prepare." Prepare? I'm sorry, but the last time I ever saw them do anything was pull the tables together when a big party arrives. But they don't do that until they seat the party.

Just because a restaurant is popular does not mean you can disrespect and be rude to your patrons and potential customers. Our group was so angry that we all just left. 

There are plenty of good Korean restaurants in the Sunset. Don't waste your money and subject yourself to this type of treatment. Go elsewhere.
author: Jay L.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and I always leave full, satisfied and a little tipsy.  I'm a big fan of their seafood pancake and kimchi friend rice.
