Their SOJU is also delicious and a creeper, so be careful! lol. The prices seem to have went up since the last time I've been, and their chicken wings were a little, different. Not as tasty as I remember.  Docking 2 stars for these reasons alone.

I know it can get busy and it literally is like it's in the garage of a Sunset house, so it is a small restaurant.  I do believe they take reservations, so make some if you plan on going with a big group.
author: Olga F.

description:
The kimchi fried rice was AMAZING!!!!  

I went on a Friday night, and it was quite packed- people were waiting an hour and a half to get a table.  Definitely get reservations if you can on busy nights.  I just ordered takeout, and my food came in 15 minutes.  It was delicious.

I definitely plan on going back again.
author: Laleh J.

description:
I Love the location, I Love the food, I Love the soju juice cocktail and I Love the service . However....I don't like the price to portion size ratio. 
When i pay close to 10 dollars for a plate of rice, even if that rice is amazing kimchee rice, I expect a BIGGER plate. There were five of us at the table and we ordered a lot of things and made each dish stretch. I know the city is not a cheap place to operate but loosen the purse strings and pile on some food! 
P.S To avoid crowds go on a weekday when they first open.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
This place is pretty delicious.  The seafood pancake and kimchi fried rice were incredible, bulgogi and spicy pork were good.
If you go with a girl, or you are a girl, or you like girlie drinks, we tried a few flavors of the soju's which were all nice and refreshing.  If you are feeling more manly they also serve 40's which is kind of funny/cool.  
Like a rookie, I was bitching about how I hadn't seen a waitress for 10 mins.  When I finally flagged her down she pointed out that there's a button to push to call her, otherwise they give you privacy.  So heads up...
author: David G.

description: A different kind of Korean food experience. Their food is good. However, seating is horrible. This place is using a house garage as a restaurant so the seating is very limited. Most of the time you'll have to wait for 20-30 mins to get a table. Their profile pic suppose to be a bell that you can ask for assistance from the waitress. However, they're so busy and not really pay attention to that. Last time we were seat right next to the entrance. They didn't answer the bell not even once. I'll have to wave my hand like I'm in a concert to get the super star's attention. Once in a while is good. Am I a fan, not really.
author: Jason L.

description:
It's good and the portion is huge! Recommend ordering the JokBal and the spicy meat over tofu (forgot the name).
Gave it a 4 b/c we were told we had to leave by a certain time if we wanted to be seated. They didn't rush us tho even when it was past that 'certain' time that they wanted us to finish by.
One thing I have to say - go early! Or else u'll have to wait at least an hour for a table.
author: Mindy H.

description:
Push the button.

Good music happens: www.youtube.com/watch?v=1wu5zejiSFw

Good food happens: As if being located in a garage wasn't cool enough each table features a button for ordering. Push it and your server will bring things like:

- Seafood hot pot. Add in vegetables and tofu and you have the best dish of the night. Plenty of everything in a subtle and clean broth.

- Calamari salad. Add noodles for a few bucks more. Full of spice (as promised) and the headlining seafood. Quickly became full enjoying.

- Seafood pancake. Planned on just one piece but had (at least) one more. Sesame oil glaze and assorted seafood was just too delicious for my willpower.

All for about $50 for the two of us. Wish we had spent a little bit more and tried the soju. Small space amplifies all conversations to make it a lively and festive scene.  

Service is non-existent unless you push the button. Then your order is taken, drinks filled and bill provided.

Recommend pushing both.
author: Jason B.

description:
Damn this place was good. 

We finally got to try this place after hearing about it for a year or so. We ordered the kimchi fried rice and seafood pancake based on yelp suggestions. We also got a bottle of soju. 

They were all so good. We finished the bottle of soju and were sufficiently tipsy by the end of the night. Maybe next time, we'll walk there from my place and get drunk with not too many consequences. 

MUST TRY AGAIN!
author: Nina Y.

description:
Good flavored booze and chicken wings... Didn't really know what I was ordering and ended up with yucky cold pork dish. 

Door bell at each table to summon waitress... Which was convenient and degrading just how I like it
author: kevin C.

description:
Not trying to be a downer here, but my wife and I came after reading great Yelp reviews, and we were not too impressed. Now, maybe this is just a reflection of what we ordered...? We got the chicken katsu after reading that it was GREAT. it was just ok. Not foodie material in my opinion. Flavor was kind of blah. I said to my wife that it was kind of like a medium fancy chicken nugget. Just left me with an "eh". Also got the shrimp tempura udon soup with soy broth. Salty, and alright. 

Nothing to write home about. Maybe it really does it for some people, but I don't think I'll be going back.
author: Toby B.

description:
Came here with 1 girl friend & got seated right away. Another girl friend came later on. Bomb beef kimchi fried rice!! Yummy yogurt soju. Wish they put more rice cakes in the casserole tho!

Love the ambience, very cozy. It IS in a garage, so it's pretty small..but still pretty awesome!

There's a button on the wall to call for a waitress. The service is pretty good, I guess. Lol

Oh and we kept asking for more broccoli. After the third plate, they said they're out. Lying asses, they just said they so we stop asking for it. And I think it was kimchi that I kept asking for more also. They said this is the last one on the house, they're gonna start charging after this. Their food is already expensive, so I think banchan should be unlimited. Maybe that's just me. 

Other than that, definitely would come back many many times :D
author: Joann W.

description:
This place brings me back to my high school days when my friends and I used to chill in each others garage, getting drunk and who knows what.  Yes people, this joint is literally inside a garage.  It was surprisingly packed for a Sunday night.

But I must say, their kimchi fried rice and fried chicken wings are off the chains!  All that greasy food is best washed down with shots of aloe vera and yogurt soju - my two favorite flavors!  

Conveniently, there's a button to push on the wall to request for the waitress' presence - I'm glad norcal is finally catching on.
author: Saweena K.

description: I love love love the #7 Spicy Pork with Tofu. Best dish ever! The regular Spicy Pork is yummy too. Wait time is usually over 1 hour but I like to go right when they open at 6pm.
author: Susan C.

description:
The place would be great if it was actually bigger. If you plan to come here, expect giant lines, but other than that, the food's pretty good. I would go with the popular plates since the other items tend to be pretty hit or miss. I wasn't too huge a fan of the mongolian beef, but the chicken wings are excellent. 

Also, if you're smart, you'll call ahead for pickup. They deep fry things really crispy so you won't have to worry about the wings getting soggy.
author: Jeff M.

description: Terrible food and service! Unless you like kimchee and pungent smells you should avoid this place. The server spilled a bowl and oily soy sauce on my leg and I was wearing lite colored pants. It went from my crotch to my knee. She said "sorry". No offer to dry clean or offer to discount meal. Unless you know Korean food, I would not recommend going there.
author: C L.

description: Toyose is to late-night dining in the Outer Sunset as Grubstake/Bob's is to the TL or Sparky's/Orphan Andy's in the Castro.  We had the chicken wings (hot in the sense of freshness, but not spiciness), seafood pancake (sauce is good), and kimchi fried rice (hoped the fried egg would be runny, but it wasn't). The food was okay, the hours are great, but there are places more convenient and equally tasty should I crave Korean.
author: Jenn C.

description:
This place is the best.  

Everything I've ordered has been great.  I love the spicy sea bass soup-- lots of flavors and spice.  The shellfish and green onion soup is good too.  It's a lighter tasty broth with clams in it.  The fried chicken, tempura, eel....yum yum  They also serve sake, beer and flavored soju.

I went to this place 3 times in a month.  They only open at night but they stay open until 2am every night.  -great place to hang out with friends or take a date.  It's really hard to get in on the weekends and usually always people in there with lots of laughing and energy.  One of the Sunset's best kept secrets, I'd say.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
The outside of this place confused me a little, but this is a pretty great Korean place! 

The fried chicken wings were my favorite because it is amazingly crunchy--I've been itching to go back just to have this again, but alas, I'm rarely in this part of the city.

Everything else was also pretty great--we had the kimchi fried rice, the seafood stew, and garlic fries--but the fried chicken wings are a must!

Service was pretty consistent throughout, so I would come back here again.
author: Sylvia S.

description:
Been here ever since college years a decade ago...=X
Always go there for some good Korean dishes and midnight snacks. I gained at least 20 lbs from Toyose. Their dishes are awesome, still is. You'll never find a night where you don't need to wait in-line.

The atmosphere here is great, don't expect fancy pansy candlelight dinner blaah blahh.. here' is a great place to go after work with coworkers or with friends and family.

I don't know what else to say other than their Yogurt Soju's are my favorite!
author: Steven M.

description:
such a cute place!
my friends asked "you want to go to garage tonight?" i literally thought it was a garage, with random junks hanging on the ceilings and car parts everywhere.  we got there, opened the "garage door" and woah...its like cinderella turning into a princess.  nice restaurant inside with booths and a ringer on the wall for service.  
shared hot pot with ramen, rice cake, kimchi, spam, hot dog, beef.  made of the cheapest stuff but costs $23!! it was yummy though..but its spam, hot dogs and ramen!
also shared gizzards, tofu with kimchi and beef, and fried chicken.  with fried chicken, of course you need soju!!! got 3 bottles of aloe and yogurt soju! yums.  came in a cute olive oil container and shot glasses.

service was fast with the bell on the wall.  food was good, atmosphere was nice with friends, drinks, and food!  i love the concept of "garage" and actually being in one.
author: Linda T.

description:
I would've never notice this restaurant walking by. It looks just like a family home from outside with the tiniest sign. Yet every time I visit, it's filled with customers. Now, when such a low-key, almost hidden restaurant is this popular, you know it must be good.

Although it's not the most authentic Korean place, the dishes are tasty and comes in great portions. I also love the the atmosphere and the setting- restaurant/lounge with dim lights and wooden furnitures. Definitely a great place to have dinner follow by a few soju cocktails!

The only reason keeping me from giving it a five star is because they don't have seafood tofu soup(my fav) and side dishes. Besides that, thumbs up for everything else.
author: Nawei C.

description:
I like this place=) the one thing that caught my attention was the fact that this restaurant is in a garage! the food is good, and its decently priced.. they do get super busy though, but they hold themselves together pretty well. 

even before the place opened, there were probably like 5 groups waiting outsied already.. place is pack! so come early!!
author: Jessica C.

description:
im real snobby when it comes to korean food.

i was excited to go try out Toyose because the reviews for this place were so solid, and there was such a "buzz" about their amazing food...

we had reservations for 4 people around 8pm...got there a few minutes late and we still had to wait for the tables to be cleared...that sucked because the smell inside that place was intoxicating...especially when youre starved!

finally sat down and checked out the menu...menu was very very very extensive...every type of korean comfort/drinking food that you could think of...

i thought the prices were a bit pricey for drinking food, but i figured that the quality of the food would be more than worth it...

we ordered the "boo dae jjigae" (i forget what it was called on their menu) but its basically a combination everything soup/stew that they keep warm on a propane burner on your table...walking in, i noticed that almost every table had one so it must have been a "must try" dish...also ordered the pork knuckle...spicy chicken gizzard...seafood pancake...and a couple different soju's

the portions were pretty good...which might have explained why things were so expensive...

the all around speed and service of the staff were a bit "meh"

the food itself was okay as well...

i suppose i shouldnt have had such high expectations going into Toyose...i mean...how much better can you make drinking food when youre drinking and buzzed...

mom makes it way better at home...

ANY place in koreatown makes it the same...

would definitely recommend it if youre in the area and need a korean food fix...but dont expect anything spectacular...
author: Kyu L.

description:
Get the strawberry soju. It's only $11 for what amounts to like..10 shots! So worth it.

We ordered a hearty meal of spam, tofu, cabbage, hot dogs, ramen, kimchee, and, well, broth. In that light the dish wasn't worth the money..I can make that too! It was good at the moment though. The chicken wings..MMM. So good. Definitely get them. They're sweet and savory, slightly sticky from the sugar in the marinade, and fried to perfection. Why a 3/5? Because they don't have japchae!! My fave. :( Also they don't give out appetizers beforehand. They really should.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Their hot pot and seafood pancake are awesome! Reasonable Prices!

Forgot the exactly name of the hot pot. It is a super size and good for 4 people. It has lots of meats, tofu, vegetable inside, the best part of this dish is their soup!!!! So good! (Price- approx. $26.00)
author: Rock C.

description:
I've seen this place almost my whole life since I have family living in the area. I always thought it was like a hair cut place or something like that. A restaurant never occurred to me. I also caught the bird picture out side. I think it's a chicken. 

Not good for groups. They do have a section for a group that can Maybe fit 18-19 people max if you're not large. But you'd have to arrive at 5:50-6pm, since they open at 6pm. 

This place is pretty expensive. Sadly. But the experience was nice. It is very nicely decorated. They have a button for the waitress. Which is nice. They also come by once in awhile to refill your water. 

You probably will not like this place if you cannot handle hot and spicy. Which is why I most likely won't come back. My little body just cannot handle the food. 

I came here with my SO. We ordered the spicy friend chicken wings (super deep fried and not spicy, at all - trust me on this AND totally not worth $14!), a beef dish that was not spicy, and we ordered a casserole. The casserole was super spicy. It came uncooked and they brought a portable stove to our table. Which was fine. As I was eating, felt beads of sweat forming on my forehead. My mouth was on fire. I have to say my favorite portion of the dish was the noodles. Which were like clear noodles. I didn't even eat a bowl of the casserole. So my SO ended up eating the whole dish himself. (Whoops! Ordered too much food!)
author: Jess W.

description:
WARNING:  VENT SESSION AHEAD 
I did not appreciate it when a couple of Korean dudes arrived after me and my GF and were seated before us. I also did not appreciate that they did not say anything to the waitress to let her know that we were there before them. We ended up getting a table right next to them, which sucked because I saw that they got the bigger table that should've been ours. I know I was rude by giving them the evil eye and saying out loud "that should've been our table" but I'm sure you'd do the same. For this, a Yelp star was deducted for a justifiable reason.

Okay, enough of the bitching and on to the review...

This is my type of joint: It's a small hole in the wall restaurant where the entrance is a garage door. The place is pretty small with about 10+ tables. We went there around 10pm and had to wait for like 5 minutes so I can imagine that during dinner time this place can get pretty packed.

The food definitely satisfied my hunger. 

The best thing here is the kim chi fried rice.  This may have been the best kim chi fried rice that I've had anywhere.  The rice was not overcooked and the sauce had the right amount of spice to it.  This simple dish was cooked to perfection.

The rice cake is good but I just considered it a filler since these little things have a bit of weight to them.

The seafood pancake is big so you can definitely share it between four people.  It did not have too much batter and contained a generous amount of seafood.

To wash all this good food down, we ordered a bottle of pineapple soju.  For those of you that hate the taste of alcohol, this is your drink!  I did not taste any alcohol at all and only tasted pineapple.

I really enjoyed this place (for the most part) and will definitely come back.  I really can't wait to have some more of that kimchi fried rice...*drool*
author: Suzi K.

description:
Their yogurt soju is really good. They have a lot of flavors...strawberry, aloe, kiwi, yogurt, etc.  I'm not much of a drinker, but I can easily drink their stuff. I think that's probably how people get messed up My friends and I come here all the time, and for some reason we always run into people here. It's the hot place to be.

Food is decent here as well. I've tried their rice, chicken wings, and fries. The fries here are good. I'm a fries fanatic so trust me on this.

Bad part about this place is that it only has 1 bathroom and it's unisex. One time this guy cut me and I had to wait 20 minutes to finish his business. :O Do that at your own home! I don't mind, but you cut me!
author: Dorris W.

description:
I'm hoping this was an off night for Toyose. It was my first visit, and it definitely did not entice me to come back anytime soon.

I have a pretty high standard of Korean food (being Korean), and the food was well below par. We ordered the dukbokki w/ramen (spicy rice cake) and kimchi jjigae (kimchi stew). The dukbokki was OK. Too sweet, not spicy enough. The kimchi jjigae was absolutely terrible. The reason for this was most likely because their kimchi (just as a side dish) tasted disgusting (even worse than the kimchi you get at chinese restaurants). I assume this is what they used to make the jjiggae.

I don't doubt that their "comfort food" such as the kimchi fried rice and seafood pancake are good. On the other hand, they really screwed up some classic Korean dishes.

Can't even get your kimchi right? C'mon now.
author: Brian L.

description:
*Review of Kimchee Fried Rice and Spicy Chicken Wings only*

Kimchee Fried Rice: 5/10
Doesn't taste much like Kimchee. It's pretty tasty... but not $10 tasty.

Spicy Chicken Wings: 3/10
Something you can make at home. Not spicy. Probably could have chosen spicier?, but they would still be just normal chicken wings you can make at home... except spicier. Also not worth $13. Or was it $14? That would make it worse.

I probably wouldn't come here again.
author: Timothy L.

description:
Very chill hangout place to drink some soju and eat Korean bar food.
The interior was very cozy even though the outside looks like a garage (unique concept).

Try the Kimchi Fried Rice! Very buttery and love the runny egg over it. 

The Pajun seafood pancake was good too with just the right amount of crispiness and seafood. The sauce for the pancake was what made it amazing. 

The spicy grilled pork served over tofu was good too but nothing I haven't had before. It doesn't come with rice so you need to order it on the side.

Service is on and off depending on who's working that night and how busy they are. But overall, pretty good place go eat at nighttime and to drink some soju with friends. 

 Prepare to wait half an hour on busy nights.
author: Lily S.

description:
I believe this restaurant is built in a garage. I'm not saying this as an insult, I literally mean that I think it's in a converted car garage. As such, it's tiny, with maybe 6 or 7 tables along an aisle. There'll be a wait and it's almost kind of awkward standing around close to people sitting down and eating, like you're putting pressure on them.

The food itself was slightly above average and "authentic" Korean as far as I am tell, but.....I dunno, I kind of feel like I've been to other Korean restaurants I've liked a lot better. WE had the warm spicy noodles and Korean pancakes. Both items tasted quite fresh and flavorful and the portions were right for the price, but nothing really memorable for me.

Overall, I think it's certainly worth a try as I don't find many good Korean restaurants in SF but this is one of the better ones.
author: John N.

description:
I certainly ordered the wrong items last time, because after going back i (almost) LOVE it here!  
I went with a group of 9 people around 12am and we were seated immediately.  We ordered a bunch of items...strawberry soju, yogurt soju, regular soju, kim chee pancake, chicken wings, and seafood pancake.  The item that makes me want to come back for more is...the STRAWBERRY SOJU.  Omg it was amazing.  They pureed strawberries, added a little ice, and some soju for one MAGNIFICENT drink!  The kimchee pancake and chicken wings also stood out.  Both were great dishes to munch on while sipping on some soju. 
Seriously, get your butt down here for a hang out with yo friends!
author: Kristen T.

description:
Is a garage with an awning, typically eliciting WTF responses from friends' first-times. 

Then you enter, and it's packed with a mixed crowd!

There is a buzzer for your servers and most booths you can put a privacy curtain down. 

My go-to's:

-Kim Chee Pancakes
-Kim chee Fried Rice
-Croquettes (best in SF IMHO)
-Fried Chicken Wings
-Soju

Kinda expensive :( But portions are pretty generous and food is delicious.
author: Solitaire M.

description: Best Korean joint in SF. if you can stomach the weight (try to go on a weekday) and cramped seating (which I think adds character), you'll defeinitely enjoy the BOMB.com karage and well-soured Kimchi Jigae. Enjoy!
author: James L.

description:
The only thing that would make me love Toyose more is if I was married to it and was sharing in the profits of this brilliant idea.

If I had the brains, I'd totally turn my garage into a popular local hangout.  After so and so bottles of soju, people get hungry, and you can gouge them on more food!

Service is always great, and if you make reservations, they definitely make you feel special.  So, I've never really experienced the waiting around while everyone sitting down is enjoying their food and drinks.

Kimchi fried rice.  Strawberry soju.  Chicken wings.  Yogurt soju.  Seafood pancake.  Pineapple soju.  Enticed yet?  Go!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Pretty easy to find. On Noriega and 45th. 

Kind of feels like going inside a black hole. It's dark and looks exactly like going into a bar. It will be broad daylight outside, but once you go inside you will probably not know what time it is anymore. 

Got there at 6:30 on a Thursaday night, so there wasn't much of a wait. When we left though, there were a constant stream of customers. 

Our table had:
Kimchi fried rice- I thought this was okay. It wasn't mind-blowingly awesome, but it wasn't bad either. I would say that this is your standard kimchi fried rice, except you have meat. I thought that this wasn't overly salty or oily, which is great. One serving is enough for one person, although I started feeling overly full 3/4 of the way in and had to rest before continuing. 

Pineapple soju- Tasted like pineapple juice. I'm not sure if they put soju in it. But! It was good! 

Seafood pancake- Loaded with seafood. Didn't seemed to be cooked all the way though. Otherwise pretty good. AND HUGE.

chicken wings- I didn't think these were at all special. The chicken itself was, I think, ok. I liked the delicately spicy crust, and I think the chicken was cooked properly. Insultingly, the ggakdugi was not very good, and I think that is supposed to be the best part about eating korean fried chicken. 

garlic cheese fries- These were good. Fries are seasoned fries! 

Steamed egg- I didn' t try this, but from my impression it was improperly salted (I don't remember if it was too salty or not salty enough). Pretty big portion, so I think it would be good as an additional side dish to share.

Standard popcorn is standard. I didn't really eat the popcorn, but if you order alcohol you get a basket of popcorn. Actually now I'm wondering... why do most Korean bars give you popcorn with your alcohol anyways?

Overall, I like this place, but judging from the food, I don't think it's a place where the shining point is the food. It's clearly the alcohol. My advice: come here expecting to drink, lower expectations on the food, and know everyone will have a good time because this place has a comfortable atmosphere.
author: Hayne P.

description: They have great food but I must say the service isn't so great... the first time here I walk in and none of the workers greated me nor asked how many were in my party I had to chase one down just to tell her I needed a table ... second time had to do the same . The seafood kimchi pancake is a must have for sure
author: Ashley S.

description: Agreed with everyone else - what a great lil' find.  After arriving at the airport late at night, this was the first stop on my return trip to the city a few months ago.  The restaurant is small and has a funky cool sense of privacy and space.  Soju shots and laughter at almost every table.  If you wanted an inexpensive taste of local culture and Korean food, Toyose's a good bet and casual to the core.
author: Allison C.

description:
"Narnia" is what my friend has called this place.  On the outside, it is very unassuming, it blends in with the residential street it is located on, if you're not looking at the numbers, you may miss it.  The place seems to be set up in the garage of the typical SF townhouse.  

Once you enter, you're transformed to a Korean bar food scene.
Their fried chicken wings, the crispiest and juiciest wings I remember, and the pickled turnips that come with it is a great accompaniment.  

Their casseroles are my favorite, it is definitely not the casserole you think that bake in the oven.  The casserole is a huge hot pot (the waitress have to bring out its own stove top) with different ingredients thrown it, it is hearty and should be shared between 2-4 people.  My favorite is the spam and ramen noodles.

Their seafood pancakes and duboki are also worth mentioning, but the start of this restaurant is their flavored soju.  All their food is set up to complement their soju.  All of their flavors are yummy, I prefer their yogurt with any fruit flavoring.  

Service is so-so, there usually only have 2 waitress for the entire restaurant, so they're usually pretty busy, they do have a doorbell call button for the waitress.  The restaurant is always bumping the most updated Kpop, so if you're a fan of korean music this will be a fun environment for you.  

It is a great drinking/snacking place, similar concept to The Spot.  Even if you're not a drinker, come here and enjoy yummy korean street food.
author: Tabitha C.

description:
So where we eating tonight? Considering it's almost 1AM on a Tuesday night/ Wednesday morning. At a garage? What garage? Friend and I arrived, thinks *wow, we really are at someone's house. We're gonna eat at the garage? As we went inside. There were tons of empty seats. Wow, how'd this garage fit all these seats?

I love, love, love how the dishes tasted. Forgot what this beef sizzling plate was called, but wow the meat was tender and soft, full of flavor. 

Service was quick and I liked the fact that when you need service, you can just press the service bell that's against the wall. Pretty nifty if I don't say so myself. 

So if you're feeling hungry and craving some meat and authentic, warm food with an excellent taste randomly on a week night. I would most definitely come here!
author: Christine F.

description: Don't ever try to go here with a big group! The waitresses are completely rude. We showed up 15 min before our party and the told us to wait outside, ok so we did. 5 min until our reservation we had walked in and said were here, and that the last two people were parking their cars. So having 13 out of 15 people meant we could not be seated. We then all came back in at 9:03 and they told us that we would have to wait another 25 min because we missed our reservation and they had given our table away. Ok WOW we were there and the host or waitresses were so rude and hostile. I'm sorry but you definitely lost our business that night and many more to come.
author: Shelby H.

description:
This place is literally a hole in the wall, you would never imagine to go here to eat but once you try it you will not be disappointed. The garage look on the outside is really cool and when you walk in you're literally in awe because you expect nothing but it's really nicely decorated insdie. The lighting inside is pretty dim and there isn't too much seating. 

We came here around 7 and waited for about 15-20 minutes. I thought the seating was kind of weird, there were some tables near the front that had bamboo shades to separate the table from the waiting area but it didn't separate it very well and there wasn't a lot of space for people to wait so it was kind of awkward to sit there because you would have people really close to you and waiting for a seat while you were eating. There is a button you press if you want service and I thought that was pretty cool. 

We ordered the chicken wings, the kimchi fried rice, and the kimchi soup. Everything was so delicious, I want more right now just thinking about it. The kimchi fried rice was full of flavor with an egg on top, the kimchi soup was perfect and the chicken wings were crispy and flavored very well. 

My only complaint is that everything was pretty expensive for the amount of food that was given to us but definitely come here and give it a try.
author: Audrey C.

description:
Terrible service. We waited over an hour at this restaurant in their tiny crowded lobby only to be passed up by a party of 3 (we were a party of 4) who just walked in. This restaurant looks like it is in a garage someone converted and was a fire hazard. This place has rude waitresses and seems to be overrated. 

Expect to be ignored and disappointed if you come here.
author: Heather M.

description:
Really good soju.. all the different favor... man.. felt like I was in soju heaven.
I tried nearly all kind.. peach, mango, strawberry, pineapple, aloe.. feel like i'm fogetting.. but this place gets majorly packed starting at 11. so make your reservation. 

My friends call this place a garage, due to its cozy tiny room space. But i totally love this place..

And you get to ring a special bell to get service.
author: Monika T.

description: The Korean actually is not that good. The waitress is very rude. The fried wings taste like a sh*t, and I got nothing to talk about it, Really! We paid $100 for our dinner, but we got nothing! The food are nothing special. Because of the waitress, I paid a little bit tips. She ask me"You just give me this?" OMG, How much I suppose to paid for this service ? Bad, too bad...I won't come here anymore.
author: Jerry Y.

description:
I only come here for the budeh jjigae (spam casserole or whatever they've named it in English). It's filled with spam, hot dog, pork, kimchi, dduk (rice cakes), cabbage, and tofu, all happily bathing in a spicy soy bean base soup. 

The seafood pancake, fried chicken, and kimchi fried rice are delicious. I'd say they are above average compared to most of the Korean restaurants in the city. But the budeh jjigae just hits the spot on those all-too-familiar 50 degree summer days in San Francisco. I usually share it with another person, but it can be comfortably eaten by 3 people.
author: Moraia W.

description: Good for college kids and late nights. Soju is sweet and too easy to drink. Kimchee rice is good and I'm a popcorn fiend so the complimentary popcorn is delicious! This place is like a garage converted into a restaurant but its worth going to at least once and anytime you're looking for a good korean place open late night
author: Cecilia B.

description:
I've had this unfinished review sitting in my account for about a year and a half now, and I am not touching the score.

If you think you're about to enter someone's garage, you're at the right place.  Toyose is a small, unassuming little restaurant with big taste.  My favorite dish there is definitely the Beef Kimchi Fried Rice.  I enjoyed it with their Bulgogi as well as the Sauteed Rice and fishcake (with Ramen).  

The atmosphere is great, and I love that they're open til 2am.  I'll definitely be stopping by more often!
author: Andrew T.

description:
Toyose is a trek from where I live in order to get Korean food but it's fun to make a trip once in a while. Came here for dinner about 2 weeks ago with some of my co-workers and had a wonderful time! I love that it's literally a garage converted into a restaurant and that they have service buttons at every table for us to push as we please. =P Remember to make reservations for weekends since it gets SUPER packed. Their food coupled with the fruity soju cocktails makes for an amazing meal.

Started off with some complimentary popcorn even though we were hoping for shrimp chips. Our waitress was always really friendly every time she came to our table and prompt with our orders...extra plus for our food coming out in record time as well. I still can't believe how much food the 4 of us plowed through!

fried chicken - Nicely crispy with a hint of spiciness and was piping hot. Mix of wings and drumsticks...can't ask for more from this dish which was gone in a flash. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=bcTmHMCOUkFx_HzbcrYGsA)

kimchee fried rice - Looooved the abundant kimchee, the sunny-side up egg on top, and the pieces of seaweed/pork mixed in. The rice was cooked perfectly and wasn't too spicy. One of my favorite entrees for sure! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=XsEDW0OblZrvbVfJo_i4mQ)

seafood pancake - *drooools* I always order this dish at Korean places and this one was awesome! It wasn't too doughy, contained both octopus and squid, plus green onions and red bell peppers. Delicious with the dipping sauce of course. Only con was that the pancake stuck onto the wax paper. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=rKvuu1kihDnzjmIA4uD3Cw)

soft tofu soup - This came out to be a bigger portion than I thought and was bubbling hot. For some reason the soup had a slightly sour taste and the tofu wasn't the silky soft one I'm used to. Not something I would order again. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=W14vvBtWUl_tbpxBJUHScw)

potstickers - Here started round two of our dinner! Pretty much like pork gyoza you would find at Japanese restaurants. Still tasty and satisfying though. Be careful when you bite into them since the liquid inside may burn your tongue. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=glr59NrqaiCdCAZLOOmckA)

bulgogi - A different version of bulgogi since it was mixed with pieces of squid, mushrooms, carrots, cabbage, and onions. It was also in a sweeter and more watery marinade than what is usually offered at Korean restaurants. The additional ingredients were nice and the beef was still very tasty. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=4dfn21Nia8_L-Tv7kd2EnA)

shrimp and egg fried rice - I was stuffed at this point but gave it a try anyways. This time the egg was scrambled into the rice and had pieces of shrimp. Nothing too special about it but will fill you up! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AQjSsLrOheQ1snPWtYwv3w?select=2dAZqZziNSiLgwk96559dg)

Thumbs up to the strawberry and peach soju cocktails too! They got us tipsy and we loved the fruity flavors. The could creep up on you so please drink responsibly. 4 girls, 7 dishes, 2 soju cocktails came out to $35 a person! Not bad at all and those dishes probably could have fed one or two more people if we weren't so darn hungry. Basically, it's a great place for groups to enjoy yummy food and drinks but be sure to make reservations just in case.
author: Karen Y.

description:
Delicious:
Kimchi fried rice
Fried chicken wings
Seafood pancake
Spam/Seafood Casserole
Flavored Soju

Not Delicious:
Long wait (~30-40min) on weekends

Miscellaneous:
It's in a garage!
author: Christopher O.

description:
I'm sure that anyone who arrives at the place the first time is like, "wtf, why are we going in this garage?"  Yup my friends, its a Korean joint in a garage.  Just FYI, garages are the new boats. 

Add toyose as yet another fun place to get your drink on with some good food to boot.  Full disclosure: my preferred place is porno palace in Oakland, which I hold as the gold standard for similar places.  However, given that not everyone can or wants to go to Oakland (shame on them really), toyose is a great alternative holding it down for the city.

They have a good selection of various flavored sojus, and the yogurt-soju ratio is kept at a reasonable level.  Beers are your standard OB, Hite fare.  I will say though that the booths here are a little smaller and there's more areas with just regular tables.  Then again, its in a freaking garage so that's understandable.

The food selection here is much more robust than Toyose, with good amount of options.  The hamul pajun was okay, but a little thin for my liking.  The BBQ and boodaejjigae were both interesting but nothing to different.  I'd say this place's calling card is its kim chee fried rice, which is pretty delicious.  Too bad the portions are on the small.  Aside from the food, they give you a limited selection of banchan as well as popcorn.  

Overall, another solid Korean place but nothing that's going to blow your mind.
author: Chris D.

description:
This place is conveniently located walking distance from home, which makes it easy to crawl home after sharing a few bottles of soju and giant bottles of OB or Hite with friends. My friends and I dress accordingly when we know we'll be coming here because your clothes, hair and anything else you bring into the restaurant WILL smell for days. 

Soju favorites: yogurt, kiwi (even though some friends think it tastes like soap), peach (tastes like Trolli peachie-o's), strawberry, mango, pineapple, and aloe (tricky to pour since the aloe gets stuck in the cap). Feel like engaging in some risk taking activity? Mix them!      

The food is a little overpriced, but the spicy wings are worth it. 
The french fries (with or without garlic & cheese) are always served with the finest ketchup--Heinz, I can tell. Make it a special occasion and get the kimchi pancakes and/or fried rice, too.

They only take up to 2 credit cards per table, so tell your non-cash carrying friends to figure it out before they get there. 

I'm taking away a couple stars because there are ALWAYS people throwing up across the street, out front, in line for the bathroom, or right onto the dinner tables. There is only one bathroom, so you're better off letting your projectile vomit loose outside. Learn to hold your liquor, folks. 

Don't be a douche and abuse the service button.
author: Melanie P.

description:
This place is cool.  It is a garage turned into a restaurant but the food is "A-OK".  Love their hot pot spicy soup broth with ramen noodles.  Their chicken wings are good too.  Other items to order are their kimchee pancake and kimchee fried rice.  This place gets packed so be prepared for a little wait time.  Their service is a bit slow sometimes but better if you are Korean speaking Korean to them.

BEWARE:  You may get wasted / hammered / DRUNK!  after their many differ flavors of soju but I prefer the none sweet one n a bottle.
author: Patrick C.

description:
After my first time at Toyose, I instantly became a soju person.  Soju and korean beer. yum. Why would someone put themselves through taking shots when you can have delicious soju instead? Pfft soju is lighter? Gives you a reason to drink more! 

Like many said before me, Toyose is a Korean restaurant...inside a garage! It's pretty cute. This place is cozy and has about 7-9 tables. Imo, Thursday nights are the best nights to go. The place is not empty, nor is it full like on the weekends (yay, you get to skip out on the hour+ wait!). 

I've never ordered food here, just their beer and their many bottles of soju. Strawberry, pineapple, mango, and peach soju are my favorites. Kiwi wasn't bad. I personally didn't like the aloe nor the yogurt soju. 

Becareful, soju creeps up on you. One minute you're sober and out of nowhere your're drunk beyond belief (or really really buzzed).

Oh yeah, they give out free popcorn for us drunkies. Definitely a plus. :]
author: Tiffany H.

description: Best Kimchi fried rice around. I like the setting of the place. I would say its unique. I would like for the waiters and waitress to be more upbeat. I mean it's a tiny place. A bad little energy can cramp up the ambiance but imagine a good little energy?
author: Jackie B.

description: I tried their spicy chicken wings, spicy hot pot w/ ramen sausage and spam, seafood pancake, and kiwi soju. DELICIOUS!!!! The wait is ridiculous so if you decide to eat here, make reservations!
author: Tiff C.

description:
Dear Toyose, 

thank you for always serving delicious food, every single time I come. 

Set menu I always order:

Seafood & kimchi pancake 
Kimchi Fried rice
chewy noodles with double the ramen 
cheesy corn
garlic and cheese fries
giblets

Some Soju 

Try it, you'll love it.
author: arlene r.

description:
Since The Spot closes at midnight on Wednesdays, Toyose was our alternate. :(

We ordered the following:

FOOD:
*Spicy Chicken Wings: It was just ok. It was crisp, somewhat moist, and had a garlicky ginger flavor to it.  I was expecting wings more like "The Spot" and "Bon Chon" in NYC with the glaze, so it was a little disappointing.
*Beef Potstickers: It was just ok, the potsticker was more like gyoza. I prefer my potstickers to be pan fried vs. deep fried. 
*Fries: YUM! It was crisp outside, soft inside, and well-seasoned with some type of paprika seasoning?
*Kimchee Fried Rice w/ Beef and Egg : YUM! If you like spicy foods, this is something you should order. I couldn't find any beef in it though. Make sure to puncture the egg and let all the yolk goodness over the rice. MmMmMmm! However, this is probably not the best thing to order at 1 AM in the morning while drinking soju. I guess you can imagine what happened later that AM. :X

DRINKS:
*Strawberry Soju: Tasted like a fresh strawberry smoothie with a hint of soju. So bad, b/c that stuff creeps up on you (in a good way). 
*Lemon Soju: Tasted like fresh squeezed lemonade just as the waitress had mentioned. Not as creamy as the strawberry and peach soju though. 
*Peach Soju: My FAVORITE out of all 3 we tried. It literally tasted like Peaches & Cream---YUMMY!!!!!

SERVICE: Just as with any asian restarant, fast and efficient. Don't expect any small talk. 

AMBIANCE: Altough Toyose is in a garage, when you walk, it's totally different. It looks/feels like a regular restaurant. I didn't really care for the K-pop music though. 

All in all, if I had to choose between Toyose and The Spot: hands-down The Spot would be my pick....wings, soju, vibe, and music is FAR BETTER!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I was expecting a long wait going by the reviews and the fact the it was a Friday evening. But man, an hour and 20 minutes was kinda ridiculous. Adding insult to injury was that a party of 4 who had only waited for 10 minutes was seated in front of our very eyes *wail*. My iPhone battery gave out, leaving me to stare longingly at people drunkenly (due to soju) but very obviously enjoying their food. So the wait is painful and the food doesn't quite make up for it because come on, ANYTHING tastes good when you're ravenous. Even water is like sweet nectar from the gods. 

We ordered kimchee pancake and bu dae ji gae which is a traditional food eaten by Koreans during the second world war. It's a huge stew thing filled with sausages and spam, tofu, onions and bake beans. And to top it off, a block of instant noodles that cooks in front of you. Sounds good? Yeah. I'm kinda salivating just remembering it. So I liked it but I'm not sure if I can wait that long in the future unless I bring some popcorn to snack on. Which just defeats the purpose of eating a meal right?
author: Sarah L.

description:
Best Kimchi fried rice evveeer.  Just thinking about it makes my stomach growl with longing.  Now that I got that out of the way, here's the low-down.  My friend and I came here on a Saturday night knowing that the Yelp reviews all said the wait was at least an hour long.  And we hate, hate, hate waiting.  Luckily, I planned it all out and had a late lunch so by the time we finally got seated at 9:30 I was good to go.  

So talk about weird places to have restaurants.  This restaurant is literally in the garage of a Sunset home.  When you get inside, there are no windows, just a long narrow space with group tables that have privacy curtains in the front and regular restaurant tables in the back.  The front of the restaurant is hot as hell, but the back (where they have the air conditioning machine thing) had me cold as a popsicle.  It is a little loud in here - none of that fancy sound bouncing stuff they have in the nice restaurants and people do get loud after 4 bottles of their soju that tastes like juice.  (I pretty much drank a majority of the bottle by myself - you'd never know that this stuff has alcohol in it until you get up and you notice you're a little tipsy.)    Ambiance and comfort is not really what you should expect when you go to a place like this anyway.

After some extensive Yelp research, we decided we were going to eat like pregnant ladies because we wanted to try everything and had something on the magnitude of 5 dishes between 2 tiny Asian girls.  I guess that's what happens when you eat with your eyes.  We ordered the kimchi fried rice,  seafood pancake,  fried chicken, cheesy corn, and the pork hot pot dish and topped it off with some aloe vera soju.  My favorites were the kimchi fried rice (obviously), the seafood pancake, and the hot pot dish.  The fried chicken was eh, ok, nothing special there.  The cheesy corn dish was just weird.  It was like hard/bland mozzarella cheese over corn.  Not my favorite.  The aloe vera soju is Awesome with a capital a.  

Stop reading this review and just go already!
author: Jean A.

description:
WOW! All I can Say is it is one of the best Korean Restaurants I have been to in San Francisco Bay Area!!!!! They have one of the best Kimchi Korean Pancake, Kimchi Fried Rice, Their HUGE Spicy Hotpot was amazing, as well as their Deep Fried tempura!!!!

I CRAVE this place all the time, only bad thing is it is kind of small and it only opens at night so you will have to wait always in a long line to eat inside. I am very surprised they turned this garage looking house into a restaurant, but the atmosphere and ambiance is very nice and cozy.
author: Sophia W.

description:
Delicious korean food in a garage! Flavored Soju (Yogurt, Pineapple, and Strawberry- all tasteful!).  Order Kim Chi Fried Rice, Spicy Rice Cake with Fish Cake and Potstickers, Potstickers, fried chicken, and last but not least, Casserole with sausage, spam, pork and tofu. 

Background: I visited SF and my local friends took me here...turned out to be the best dinner in SF! Get some dessert a couple blocks away. Good dinner spot, but no bars around. 

Note: Arrive early (especially in a group), it can get crowded! If you're visiting, make sure your friends have a car!
author: Will T.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place! Toyose, saranghaeyo!
Been here 3 times and have always enjoyed the food. It's funny and strange how the place is located inside a garage - it could get crampy at times and the line always gets really long during dinner time. 
Here's my list of the recommended food on the menu (1 being the highest):
1. kimchi fried rice: it reminds me of the kimchi fried rice my ex used to make me - they were the best!
2. budae jigae: delish! It's good that it's not too spicy and they're not stingy at all with the sausages (no pun intended haha).
3. fried chicken wings: so crispy and flavorful, though it's a bit on the salty side
4. tteok bokki: pretty standard
I wanted to try the sauteed squid with noodles but we knew we weren't going to be able to finish it. Their pickled radish is also good and another huge plus to Toyose - their waitress that night was hot.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Off the beaten path. 
Typed in Late Night on Yelp & Toyose was the first place I got.

Toyose or the Garage - From the outside, all you see is a garage, a door & a sign in between.. At this point, it's hard to know what to expect but once you open the door, it's like walking into a korean movie. Def. a late night / comfort food kind of place. They have a pretty big menu with lots of different choices. A variety of korean beers & flavored Sojus.

I had their Spicy Chicken Wings, recommended by my friends mother, & i must say, it was some bad-ass KFC (Korean Fried chicken)! Perfectly crisp but not greasy & really flavorful. There's no sauce on it. The flavoring is in the batter instead & it comes with pickled radish, which is the perfect condiment to help cut through the richness.

Being here felt like having a night with friends at home with some bomb homemade food. One of the best late night experiences, hands down.
author: Aggie I.

description:
I sooo love their BIG dish with noodles, carrots and other stuff. Omgg it's to die for, and I never knew what it was since my cousins are the ones that order it. It's a great place if you want to eat and chill and drink soju, mmmm. 

Usually they are packed here at night on weekends, which is a bummer. The place is really small so be prepared to wait if you need to!

They only have 1 bathroom, so please don't get too drunk =X
author: Sandy T.

description:
This place is my Favorite korean place in SF! Its truly unique ( CONVERTED garage ) and I was little unsure about foods here because I got very spoiled by amazing Korean community in WA and I thought there aren't many korean restaurants in bay area but I was totally wrong!! 

their hot pots go perfect with their flavored soju and Its embarrasing to say but thier Kimchi Fried rice is sooo much better than any of KFR i tried lol ( it's def simple food that most of korean people know how to make) but their KFR is def best of all. lol 
and they have really good spicy cold noodles ( jaeng ban gook soo ) and my bf and I absolutely loved it!!!!!!
author: Juhwi K.

description: Food is ok.  Ambiance is....well, it's a small narrow garage like a modern day dungeon.  I am used to cheap eats, but cannot stand this place.  If you are claustrophobic, stay away.
author: Jo L.

description:
kimchi....fried...rice...... the BEST!

open late, but be ready to wait for a table. Have seen the wait time go up to 2.5 hours...
author: Larisa V.

description:
***Food's good, very tasty. We ordered the beef bulgolgi, calamari and shrimp fried rice and strawberry soju. I wasnt a fan of it. It reminded me of cough syrup.
* for the service. Buzzed twiced to ask where the calamari was. It finally came out when we finished our meal. How long does it take to fry calamari? We finished our food and the calamari came out really late... calamari was't that good. What a waste of $$$. I should of ordered something else.
Waiting for another 15min just to get the check. Its funny how long we had to wait given that they werent really busy.
author: Lo S.

description:
Dizzyingly busy on most Friday and Saturday nights. When you walk into Toyose, one of the waitresses will usually tell you "1 hr" like it's no big deal. 

Well, needless to say, I always wait because I love coming here for late night dinners. Yogurt soju, seafood pancakes, and kimchi fried rice are great here. I still need to try some soup-based meals, because everything I've had here is definitely not good for my health. I can't help it, I'm a sucker for spicy late-night eats.

I'll continue to come here because let's face it, the food is amazing and the servers are efficient. I like its location as well, the converted garage is surprisingly cozy.
author: Patricia Q.

description: A hole in the wall restaurant. This place is very cutely decorated and the food tastes great as well. I definitely recommend the seafood pancake, chicken wings and kimchi fried rice! Make sure to go early if you can. I went with a party of eight 20 minutes before opening and there was already a line forming.
author: Connie S.

description: This is like a speakeasy for Korean food. Service is ok, though they do get crowded and you may feel a bit rushed. The food is a little heavy. Order a big beer and settle in.
author: Patrick S.

description: Fun atmosphere, good soju (try the watermelon) ...  The steamed sea bass was delicious!  One thing missing was the array of kimchi that you get with a meal at a traditional Korean restaurant.  Overall, the 'hip' atmosphere and cool location brings the Yelp rating up to four stars.  Not sure the food by itself rates that high.
author: James M.

description: Love their Fried Chicken , Strawberry SOJU and Seafood Pancake!! Will definitely come back and try their pig shank/feet and Mango SOJU!  Do not be intimidated by the closed garage door because the restaurant is behind it.  Service is fast and the food is GREAT!
author: Claudine V.

description: What a strange little place. I came here to try the wings. Was hoping it was korean style fried chicken wings like the popular BonChon chain. It wasn't. They were still pretty good. Little pricey at $13 for 10 wings. But what's funny is they kind of tasted like another chain's wings. I couldn't quite place it while I was eating them. But then it hit me. Their wings taste like Outback Steakhouse's wings! Kinda of the same seasoning.
author: Augusto M.

description:
I preface this with the fact that my Korean food knowledge is limited, but I loved LOVED this place! 

2 star: Ambiance. The awesome review by Rebecca K. below is on point in my opinion. The garage door doors were pretty awesome. Additionally, I loved the bamboo blinds that give some privacy to each booth and the call button for when you need help (although we tested them and don't think they work). Cannot beat this. Also, apparently the thing to do is bring a deck of cards to play over dinner which I will definitely be doing next time. 

2 star: Food. We followed along with the fellow yelp reviews and got the Kimchi fried rice and Kimchi pancakes. Both were excellent, especially the pancakes. I adore them and wish they did delivery just so I could get them nightly. We also ordered a noodle dish (my roommates would kill me for not remembering hte name since they make it for me at home) which came plated with tons of vegetables to be mixed in. 

1 star: Drink. Fresh fruit soju, nothing like it. Although I will say, I think it was a little more fresh fruit than soju but I didn't really mind since it helped balance all the spicy from the food. 

Somehow we got extremely lucky and got a table right away. The person that came in right behind us was told they had to wait 45 minutes so we were beyond thankful. Go Go! You won't regret it.
author: Raina B.

description: This is a cute neighborhood place with unique twists on Korean food.  I definitely liked it, and would go back..  Especially for the yogurt soju..  Yum!
author: Edgar C.

description:
This place gets my Korean stamp of approval. It definitely reminds me of the bars that are common throughout Korea, so if you're looking for that authentic Korean bar feel, Toyose is your place.

Everyone recommends the kimchi fried rice, which is good, but I also like their "ramen dduk pokki," roughly translated, spicy rice cakes with ramen. Both are pretty good for sharing with some cocktail soju or just regular soju. Don't know what soju to get? Start off with the Chamisul Fresh. Served cold, it's smooth and goes great with the spicy Korean dishes.

The sojus that they carry are around 15-20% in alcohol content. Chamisul Fresh is just under 20%, which is pretty strong for your typical bottle of soju. As a rule of thumb, a 375ml (the ones that they serve are 375ml) soju bottle pours between 6 and 8 shots, depending on how heavy your hand is. If you do the math, that means a single bottle is about 3-4 shots of vodka, rum, or tequila. This is a pretty good deal, considering a bottle of soju at Toyose is currently $11, which gets you maybe 2 shots of vodka at any other bar. Because soju is at 20% alcohol content, it's notorious for "sneaking up" on drinkers. Have fun, but drink responsibly!
author: Gun-Ik P.

description:
Quaint little Korean eatery that is easy to miss. Only open for dinner, we went in at 6:45 and still had a 20 minute wait. Not bad, considering those arriving after us had to wait much longer. 

The kimchee chigae was okay, but the kimchee could have been fermented a but longer. The kimchee bulgogi bokum bap wasn't bad, but could have been spicier. And the kimchee jun (pancake) was a bit doughy. Overall, we would give them a B+. not exactly as mom would have made it, but close.
author: Squeaks L.

description: My husband and I sometimes enjoy walking to restaurants in Noriega and the other day we stumbled into Toyose. It is cute and well decorated. The restaurant is in a garage and makes you feel like you are going into a hidden location. The food is great, we really enjoyed the regular pancakes and bulgogi. The service is good and prices reasonable.
author: Johanna W.

description:
Turn a garage into a restaurant?  Fantastic!
Add soju to fresh strawberry puree?  Marvelous!
Super crispy korean fried chicken?  Sensational!
Large portions?  Incredible!
Doorbell service for your table? Wonderful!
Call ahead and put your name on the list before you show up?  Brilliant!
author: Yeeman N.

description: legit place for korean food. Even the decor was very korean - i felt like i was in korea. Their fried chicken was probably the best thing. Their dukboki was not that great. However their boodae jigae worthwhile! Would def go back, but just so darn far!
author: Sun P.

description:
The 'Garage' ! Countless drunken nights stumbling in and out of here is what most people would say happens when you come here but I must say the korean bar food is as close as you can get to authenticity in San Francisco compared to Oakland or LA. 

There are only a few items on the menu that I always get and those are,  not in particular order, kimchee fried rice, chicken gizzards, spam ramen hot dog casserole(which is actually more of a stew, go figure) and Soju. You can't go wrong with any of those items but remember, this place is small so expect to wait a bit on fridays/saturdays.

Food Highlight: Soju and Spam Casserole
author: Rich L.

description:
The fact that this restaurant was in a garage tripped me out.  But once you step inside you forget the idea that it is.  But may I add that it's pretty cramped in there.   Soo since  this place is pretty poppin during dinner hours the wait times may vary.  We were lucky and only waited for about half an hour.  

Dishes that were recommended by my BFF:

Kimchee fried rice with beef
Seafood pancake 
Soju-strawberry flavor

I was craving beef bulgogi and let me tell you... that was awesome!  Especially with the kimchee fried rice!  Everything was very well seasoned, so good that every bite was so delicious! 

I have to return and try all their soju flavors! mmm
author: Marilou A.

description:
I've been here twice, and both times I had to wait around 30 minutes to get seated (with a group of 6+).

This is the first place I've ever tried kimchi fried rice, and I haven't found another place that has a  tastes as good. It's the first time I've had  casserole, and I really liked it. It's soup and ramen noodles. We ordered one for 8 people to share and still had leftovers.

Seafood pancake is pretty good as well. One of the better ones that I've had.

Fried chicken is not that good. I would avoid ordering it even though I heard it was made better now than before.

I'm not sure what "good" soju tastes like, but I really like the yogurt soju here. It doesn't taste strong, so it feels like you can drink a few orders and you'll still be fine. Plus, it reminds me of the childhood favorite drink, Yakult (:
author: Adorable T.

description: Food is OK. I been here many times before. But it kind of changed. Its always been female waitress here, but this is the first time I seen a guy waiter. And he sucks big time. Why???? I don't even want to get to the part where we didn't get to have a table when we are only missing one person for a table of 3 and There are many empty tables when I got there. 45 m wait??? Wtf???
author: Albert W.

description:
More like 2.5 stars.

Aesthetics: From the outside, you can't even tell its a restaurant. It's a garage from the outside but definitely renovated on the inside. About ten tables or so, white Christmas lights adorn the walls alongside Korean beer posters and faux plants. Cool kick it spot for a late night bite.

Food: Meh. Expensive and definitely not worth the overpriced price tag. 

Had the following:

*Kim Chee Fried Rice with Fried Egg: The best dish of the night. Flavorful, seasoned well, and the fried egg yolk's richness on top of the rice pairs well with the slightly acidic and spicy notes of the rice. Portion size is quite small for the price.

*Spicy Fried Wings: Should be called "overcooked, rock hard, non-spicy fried wings." These were a joke. Fried to complete Sahara Desert dryness, they lacked flavor, and the spice must've been lost in the 24 hour fry time they gave these wings. The best part of this dish were the side condiment of pickled radish. How sad.

*Sauteed Fish and Rice Cakes with Potstickers in Spicy Sauce: Texturally quite off-putting. Fish cakes were non-existent, rice cakes were gummy and undercooked, and the potstickers were dry and overcooked. Tomato based sauce was mediocre at best.

*Bulgogi with Calamari: Effin' disappointing. The calamari were overcooked and literally rubber band status. The bulgogi had potential, but inconsistent cuts and lack of sauce gave this dish two thumbs down... way down.

Service: A joke. Non-existent. With a restaurant that small, theres no excuse for her inattentive nature. Took forever to ask for water, more napkins, and menus. She was real quick to check on the finished bill though. Sorry hun, its a confirmed negative on that tip you were expecting. So here's a tip for you: actually wait on and serve your guests instead of texting on your phone where everyone can see you NOT WORKING. SMH.

Overpriced. Horrible service. Food was sad, with the exception of the Kim Chee Fried Rice with Fried Egg. 

See you...never.
author: Peter G.

description:
-Pretty much a bar with some really good Korean snack type food
-BOMB ASS Kimchi Fried Rice-yums :)
-Don't order the Strawberry Soju cause it's really not that great -_-
-Cute interior (Outside sort of like a regular house)
author: Tina T.

description:
I remember when I use to walk home from school, I like what's this chicken head super random restaurant and wondered if they were ever open... 

Friends tried bring me here, but on two occasions the wait was over an hour. The first time we tried waiting but it seemed like people kept getting seated and everytime we asked how much longer they would extend the wait time so we left, so the second time we didn't bother trying to wait. 

So finally I got to eat there. We called like 9:30ish for reservation for 11:00 and they said they could make it for 11:35. 
Got there and got seated with 10 minutes or so. Ordered the kimchi fried rice, the chicken, the noodles with fish cake and rice rolls, and had the flavored soju, yogurt, pineapple, strawberry and peach. 

The chicken was on the dry side, I've had better chicken. The kimchi fried rice was pretty good but the rabbokki (the casserole with ramen, rice cake and fishcake) were sooooo goood. I've tried other places with rabbokki and this is my favorite place to get it.

I like how they gave us some popcorn before our food. too

My favorite flavor of the soju was yogurt, the pineapple was stronger out of the four and I liked how the strawberry had the lil strawberry seeds and strawberry bits. 

Service was ok, but they have those buttons you press if you need something. I would definitely make reservations before coming here.
author: Katie M.

description:
Soju. That's pretty much the review in one word. If you're not here for that, don't bother. If you are, great (order the Kiwi flavor by the way, you're welcome). Food is only ok, good but not worth the wait which is horrendous often during peak times and it's extremely uncomfortable to be waiting for a table as there's hardly any room and if you're going with a big group assign a friend as a sacrificial lamb and offer to buy this person drinks cause the seats to wait are literally in the face of the front tables who are eating. Place is not that big though. Luckily these tables have bamboo shades that drop down so these people can eat without the pressure of eating while having others staring at you. 

Kimchee fried rice is excellent, it's the only thing that sticks out for me. Everything else is standard stuff besides the Soju. I'm digging the buttons for the waiters attention which helps to keep that soju flow going throughout the night ;)
author: Peter W.

description:
Oh Toyose, how I miss your kimchi beef fried rice! :( 
Damn this distance!
author: Amber N.

description:
This place is good if you want to have delicious soju cocktails with crazy friends, pay for overpriced Korean food, and have young Asian eyecandy.

I've been here before and was disappointed. The food just didn't have any pizzazz to it. My friend loves this place and wanted to celebrate his birthday here. This was another opportunity to try other dishes so I could truly determine whether I like this place or not. 

Party o' six on a Saturday night. Waited for about 15 minutes without a reservation. The place is hella small, all bedazzled with lights and shiz, straight up garage. Perhaps why a lot of people like this place is the home feel and comfortable environment. Any more comfortable and you'll start taking your shoes off. 

I didn't have high hopes for the food and as expected, was mediocre. The seafood casserole and ramen/spam thing was meh. Definitely not worth the 20+ dolla dollas. The spicy chicken wings don't have sauce or anything. I think they just coat it with spice flour. It was ok but on the dry side. The kimchi fried rice is the winner. The portion is a bit small for sharing but the taste is perfect and flavorful.

Cocktail soju time! We ordered: Yogurt, Peach, 2 Aloe, Kiwi, Mango. All were good. I really recommend the kiwi and aloe ones. Super refreshing! Maybe this is why Toyose gets such good reviews. Everyone's too drunk off the alcohol to realize how bland and overpriced the food is. Imjussayin.
author: KD M.

description:
Korean hole in the wall i'd say? YES

You can never go wrong with any of their food. All affordable, delicious, and their service is usually pretty great

My favorite: kimchi fried rice, oh especially when you're playing some drinking game with some soju and beer. try that combo, you wont regret it!
author: Kenny L.

description:
OH MY GOSH. I'm so glad I have friends that know of secret spots to discover. I never would have imagined this place to ever be anything other than a garage. So my friends and I had been eating all day literally; Hooters to watch NCAA, Genki Crepes for dessert, Quickly for dessert's dessert, and Toyose after bowling at 130am. When we came, I was skeptical because it was in a deserted area and from the outside looked like when you walk in it would be a secret Korean mafia's hideout but when you walk in the decor is beautiful. The booths have drop down bamboo curtains and the atmosphere inside is just very warm and inviting.

We ordered kim chi fried rice, mild duk boki with ramen, seafood pancake, fried chicken, and croquette. We also drank strawberry soju. Amazing amazing amazing. I literally wanted to keep ordering food and try everything on the menu. They have a doorbell to call the waitress if you need something and our waitress was super friendly and adorable. 

I'm definitely going back here; with friends and even to take someone special enough to go on a date with haha. It's a little hidden gem for late night food and laid back/chill drinking when you're not ready to go home yet.
author: Caroline A.

description:
Lemme see, how to describe Toyose?  Well, it's in a garage.  Seriously.  They converted the garage of a Sunset home into a restaurant.  So as you can imagine, it's not THAT big and it will get crowded.  And it's not your typical Korean restaurant that serves bulgogi and kalbi.  I think someone else summed it up perfectly:  Korean bar food.  Came here pretty early on a Saturday night for dinner, but it filled up fast.  Ok, onto the food...

This is where things get sketchy.  The kimchi fried rice and the seafood pancakes I enjoyed.  They weren't super spectacular or anything, but they weren't bad.  The fried chicken, however, was too fried.  It was on the crunchy side which you can imagine was also pretty dry.  (I think we meant to order the wings but got the fried chicken instead.)  And the pork shank...uhh.....I don't like it at Chinese banquets too much and followed suit here.  Mental note:  never again.  But what made this an enjoyable experience, what was the saving grace of the meal, actually, was the soju.  I never had soju before, but I am now an instant fan.  If you don't know (like me), it's kind of like Korean vodka.  But here, they flavor it up.  They have like maybe 10 different flavors of the stuff.  Not wanting to take too many risks, we asked the waitress what her favorites were and she recommended Yogurt, Strawberry, and Aloe.  After some debate, we went with the Yogurt and guess what...home girl knows her stuff!  That sh!t was yum-f@ckin-good!!  F'reals, I want to go back just to try the other flavors.  I know, I'm only giving Toyose 3 stars but I'm making it a point to go back.  A couple bottles of soju, some fried rice and wings...biggity-bam!  Smiles all around.  Look for a later update...
author: Joe M.

description:
First, the food. It was good. I had the pot of soup with fish cakes and veggies. The broth was sweet and flavorful though the fishcakes weren't very good, it was a bit doughy for my taste. 
I wish there were vegetarian options..or at least one vegetarian dish, that would have been nice! It was so crowded! One wouldn't think so, since they are located in the middle of nowhere and they're a garage restaurant.  I think it's so cute! But the space was very tight! 
The service was relatively decent for such a busy night.  It seemed like there were only two cute waitresses for everybody there!! They didn't give us the pickled sides and we had to ask for it but it's okay, it was super busy and we were a big group. 
Overall, I had a good experience and would love to come back again to try other things..namely the alcohol.
author: Tu L.

description: Never order to go from here! I just bought spicy chicken wings and shrimp tempura, both were OVER COOKED! I am very disappointed because eating here, food were great but ordering for the first time was REALLY REALLY BAD! Plus, the sides that comes with the chicken like a slaw salad is not included in my order. The food I got was not very appetizing at all, dry and over cooked. Other than the food, the servers are very snobby, they do not really check on you unless you need something from them. I paid almost $50 just for three orders and had a BAD EXPERIENCE ORDERING TO GO. I would have returned it but was very hungry and just settled for what I have. Toyose you have failed me!
author: NieChelle C.

description:
I've never had flavoured soju before so we hit up this place because I was curious. 

Décor: We didn't have reservations or anything and for 2 people, we still waited about 40 minutes. The place is tiny, which explains why the wait is so long but we didn't mind much because their waiting area of the bench was actually quite comfortable while we just chatted. (FYI, while we were at our table, people still waited for a good 40 minutes.)

Service: Use the bell! Haha, they never really checked up on us but was prompt when we called!

Food: We only had their fried chicken as drunk munchies- it was fine, nothing that special nor fantastic. I LOVED their soju though. We had 3 between the 2 of us- yogurt, mango and peach. Peach was our favorite, followed by yogurt and then mango.

Overall: Recommended for their soju; can't say anything about the food.
author: Jessica L.

description:
So I'm gonna lay this one out for you in layman's terms, because I think that is the only way I would understand it too.
This place is in a garage...its neat.
If you get here right when they open, they are very accommodating for parties of 10 drunk folk...that was nice.
They have yogurt and strawberry flavored soju....it is delicious.

Then we got a lot of Korean Food.  Seriously, I don't know what we ate.  Calamari and Beef stuff?  Some soup?  Chicken Wings?  Rice Cakes?  Pancake?  The trick is to go with people who know what they are doing, and let them do the ordering.  They will do you right.  We even got a guy who apparently lives on pizza to eat spicy Korean food.  And he loved it!  So 5 stars to any place that can change someones life long eating habits.  I just met the guy but i got a little teary eyed when i saw the life changes he was going through.

I really need to venture out to the Sunset more and eat yummy food.  Its seriously another world out there.  Who knows what lay in other garages?  Discos?  BBQ restaurants?  Meth labs??  If more places like Toyose opened their garages to the public....we could find out.
author: Lauren F.

description: Kiwi soju and kimchi fried rice. Mmmm hmmmm.
author: Lily Z.

description: Renovated garage, so creative. I felt like I was at an underground super cool restaurant, and I was. I had a delicious sizzling beef and scallop dish and kimchee fried rice. Can't wait to go back!!!!!
author: Roxanne L.

description:
I don't care, I'm still real
No matter how many records I sell
After the show or after the Grammies
I like to go cool out with the family
Sippin', reminiscing on days when I had a mustache.
http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/m4Z5fiLw0PY62RAsgYQaMw/l


When you get together with old folks, you inevitably
talk about the good old days. U-Men, Menudo(Hi Omar!),
Z Cavaricci, Member's Only, acid washed jeans,
single-side-pony-tails, jelly-shoes, Vans, Converse,
fat laces, etc.

So apparently this used to be THE Korean hang out
spot. Now it's rife with Japos, Viets, and Chinese
too.  But the service rocks! The food is delicious! The soju is intoxicating!

They even let us play Gunther!
http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=7284751201680710911
(Not Work Safe)

I guess they thought it was K-pop...I don't think they listened too well to the lyrics. 

Oh, you touch my tralala.
la la la..
mmm, my ding ding dong,
oh you touch my tralala,
mmm, my ding ding dong.
la la la...
author: Kevo M.

description:
The boyfriend and I decided to give this place another try. I still don't get the charm of this place being in a little garage because it makes me feel so claustrophobic! The group next to our table obviously don't wear deodorant because I just had constant whiffs of body odor blowing towards be every single time someone walked by. Barf.

We ordered the Kimchi Pancake, Kimchi fried rice and Sauteed Calamari and Beef Bulgogi.

Meh, everything was alright. The kimchi pancake had a good dipping sauce, the kimchi fried rice was not better than The Spot and it was a much smaller portion. And the Sauteed Calamari and Beef bulgogi cannot beat the place on Balboa St. So overall, I probably wouldn't come back for a while.
author: Vikki K.

description:
Review a la Binky B.

got Midnight munchies?
Want Korean Fried Chicken?
run to Toyose.

Check out some of Binky's other reviews:
http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=-ASVMBruwZHaE5sIfobKzA
author: Dan B.

description:
Never thought that I would eat out in a garage!When I first heard about this place, I laughed because how could anyone open a restaurant in a garage and have success... well I was wrong for laughing and I'm sorry. I was excited to come eat Korean food AGAIN with my friends and try this place out. 

I heard/read this place was super busy and expected a wait, especially since it was a Friday night around 830. This place was super packed and the waitress, after acknowledging our existence instead of ignoring us for 5 whole minutes, finally let me put down my name and number so she can call us and let us know when our table is ready, supposedly 1hr long. We only waited at most 25 minutes and was seated!!

Looked through the menu and looked at what people were eating and a lot of them were eating the fried chicken so I knew i was going to order that. 

So we ordered:
Fried chicken wings ($12.95)- Really juicy and the fried perfectly. There were plenty of chicken in the order so I ate THREE whole pieces! So good, so fat.
Pork and vegetables in spicy chili sauce ($13.95)- My favorite one, Spicy but not overly spicy, PERFECT. Lots of pork to go around 10x. Sauteed with onions and mushrooms, yum.
calamari and bulgogi ($13.95)- Least favorite. It was just flavorless.
Potato Croquette ($9.95)Fried potato. Two of my favorite things put together = goodness. 

Service was OK.. There was only one waitress that I saw working, the on ignoring us in the beginning. The place was so busy and she was running around like a crazy person. I felt super bad for her but at least she gets plenty of tips!

I can't wait to come back here and try everything else on the menu!
OPEN TIL 2 IN THE MORNING!
author: Juliane N.

description:
Let's bump it up a bit.
The garage did not let me down this time as I chowed down here with a couple of my coworkers on a Monday night.
