So my buddy decided to bring me here for my bday a couple of weeks back. He asked me what I felt like, and I told him to surprise me. Man what a surprise! Who knew...an awesome find of a gem, located in a garage?!? Whaaa?? That's right, a garage! It's dark and kinda mysterious in there....but the food is great!

We ordered the spicy fried chicken wings, cheese and corn, some tofu stew, a dish with spicy squid with veggies, kimchi fried rice, and yogurt soju. All were pretty awesome!...especially the chicken wings! They did the wings right....nice and crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside. The slaw with dressing on the side of the wings was nice to munch on with the wings too!(...or was I just buzz munching?) The tofu stew I noticed had a thicker base soup then others I've had at other Korean restaurants...which tasted nice.

Next time I gotta try the seafood pancake(s=). Also, the casseroles I gotta try to. But for sure...an order (or two) of the wings and more yogurt soju. 

Paolo says: Wings and Soju!! Awesome stuff! Go run tell dat!!
author: Paolo V.

description:
Good comfort food.  Nothing amazing but consistently tasty, good service, not too expensive and best of all -open late. 
The decor is very ramshackle and random but that's part of the charm of a restaurant in a garage in the sunset.  Kimchi rice: eat half now and take the rest home for a great breakfast tomorrow.
author: Puffy P.

description:
I walked in here skeptical and left a fan. I'm always a little hesitant when it comes to Korean food. I don't eat red meat and I'm very picky with my seafood. The menu at Toyose wasn't very vegetarian friendly, but we found our way around that.

We were a group of 10 crammed into the corner of "the garage" but the service was great and the food was too. They were able to accomodate my request of no beef in the kimchi fried rice. The flavored soju's were so good!! I thought I didn't like soju, but I loved it here.

The food: kimchi fried rice (without beef) was scrumptious. I'd order it spicy next time for an extra kick. The "spicy" chicken wings were not that. They were almost flavorless and expensive for such tiny wings!! The seafood pancake was good, as were the garlic cheese fries! The mango and strawberry soju were perfection. They tasted like fresh fruit nectar with a little kick. 

Althought "The Garage" is a voyage to get to from Oakland (unless there is no traffic) I'd come back for kimchi fried rice and soju.
author: Joshua C.

description:
The restaurant is basically a house turned into a dining area and kitchen. I wonder what they turned the second floor into...

Make sure you get here early if you want some seating. I came with a friend who mentioned the crowds come in three phases. You have the families that come in early right around opening time @ 6pm. Then you get the people looking for a late dinner around 8-9pm. Lastly you got the midnight crowd that will stay here until closing.

The waitresses were very accommodating after you pressed the buzzer...make use of it when you need to. I can't say the food was extremely special, but it was a nice place to eat and chat.
author: Donald S.

description:
I love to get my food on. 

I love to get my drink on. 

Toyose? Lets me do both of these in their cozy little restaurant tucked away in a literal garage in the Outer Sunset (where there is ample parking, I might add!)

When my ex boyfriend and I broke up, I came here with my girlfriends the night after for some serious comfort food (and alcohol, of course). Earlier that year when we became official, I also came here to celebrate with some good friends. We had a horrible fight one night . . . and I fled here to Toyose, in tears, where my friends met me up.

While I was deathly afraid of this, coming here doesn't ring up painful remnants of our relationship-that-is-no-longer like I thought it would. Instead, I think about sitting in a warm cozy booth with my bests while the blustery San Francisco weather meddles on outside and I start to crave the crunchy batter-fried chicken wings, the huge tasty seafood pancake, the perfectly cooked savory kimchi fried rice (with an egg on top - yum!), and the huge pot that they bring to your table with their simmering kimchi and spicy tofu casserole soup (that contains cut up hotdogs, spam, blocks of ramen noodles, tender fatty pork, and rice cakes - it's a winning combo, trust).

I also think about even later nights here where Tim B (SUP WITH IT) and I got so drunk off soju that we started tossing their free popcorn into each others mouths (actually, this may have been before we started drinking . . . don't judge). I think about clinking bottles of OB and Hite beer to celebrate the moment and the many sweet glasses of tasty soju that they have to offer (yogurt, peach, and strawberry are my favorites).

One star off because Toyose, like most Korean places, tends to be on the more expensive side. Definitely more ideal for groups of 3-4 or more.

But, as for the rest - here's to delicious casual Korean food, tasty drinks, and good friends. 

Here's to the always reliable. :)
author: Betty W.

description:
Tried this place on St. Patty's Day, and given it's rep I was expecting a lot more. The 30-min wait for 2 people, I could handle. The service...not so much. Despite ringing that bell at the table and glancing back every 2 minutes (does that bell even work?), we got very little attention.

The yogurt soju was pretty tasty (kind of like Yakult), so I'd probably get that again, as well as the beef pot stickers. And the Kimchi and Beef Fried Rice was out of this world...BUT the fried chicken we got was pretty dry, and crazy expensive! I was honestly shocked by the bill.

I'd definitely come back again for a late night snack, because I can feel the fried rice cravings coming on...but I don't think the meal was worth the price tag. I'd give it another chance and see if I'd be as satisfied by the less expensive stuff on their  menu.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Even though I've had a Korean girlfriend for nearly half a decade, we never drank enough to get to experience Korean drinking food. We're also from LA.

First of all, CHEESE AND CORN. According to my GF, just about every Korean drinking joint has corn and cheese. As soon as my party had it I wanted to flip over the table in anger and yell at her "WHY DIDN'T YOU TELL THE REST OF US??? WHY DID YOU KEEP IT A SECRET???" ala Homer Simpson in episode 8F17 "Dog of Death." Corn & Cheese. A match made in Korean heaven, and I can't wait to try other restaurant's versions of it.

We also had the Spicy Chicken Wings. I would say they were as good or really close to the quality of other Korean fried chicken I've had. Defintiely worth the $8.

Their French Fries surprised me. For about $7, you get a big ass plate of perfectly seasons fries that are almost as thick as steak fries, drowning in melting mozzarella (i think it was mozzarella) and garlic. My party wolfed these down in no-time. 

My favorite item that night was the golbaengi muchim. It's a salad that uses sea snails that taste much like squid. Goddamn, this salad was amazing. It's one of those dishes that I'm not sure how I've lived without for so many years, especially having been raised in Koreatown, LA.

Beer is a little overpriced, but worth it if you're with the right crowd. PLEASE GET THE YOGURT SOJU DRINK. This stuff tastes like candy. It's liquid crack.

Price wasn't too bad. 4 people, 4 dishes, 1 pitcher of Hite and 1 bottle of the yogurt soju drink came out to a little over $70 before tip. This was a total win.
author: Brian S.

description:
I get it. Enough has been said about it being a garage. But I mean, c'mon: IT'S A GARAGE. Isn't that freakin...

...awesome?

Speaking of awesome, the food falls into that category as well. Though I didn't come hungry, it was hard to resist the kimchi pancake and the beef and calamari bulgogi. And with the push-button ordering action going on, you kinda want to order more food just for the pleasure of pressing that button. (Or was it just me???)

Equally delightful: the soju. (Pick a flavor, any flavor!)
author: Valerie C.

description: I really hate to give a poor review but the meal I had was totally subpar. I ordered the shrimp fried rice the japche and the sea bass.  Honestly the fried rice tasted like they used fresh ingredients but whoever prepared it probably didn't taste what they put out. It was very bland. The japche in my opinion was pretty dry and tasteless. I've honestly tasted better at a shopping mall.  And the sea bass is what compelled me to actually write a review. it was really overcooked and the sauce tasted is like chili spice and water. no saltiness no sweetness no balance of flavor no essence of any type of sesame oil or anything that resembled good flavor.  I really don't want to bash on this place because I have had good food here before but for the price you pay to eat at this restaurant I would expect a lot better food than what I was served tonight. I'm just really disappointed in tonight's dishE's.
author: Jon-Marc D.

description:
Personally, I prefer this place over brothers.  
My coworker kept raving about this place that was a converted garage, unfortunately I didn't try this place for a while because of parking.  I live outside of SF, so parking is a huge factor of places I go to eat (and being from Socal).  

Food: Food was ok, I think I was spoiled by socal korean food...so it wasn't bad, but wasn't great (i liked it way better than brother's...which in my opinion sucks).

Parking: Street parking, one of the biggest things I hate about SF.

Service: It was ok, a bit on the slower side.

Definitely deserved multiple tries from me...if I can ever get myself to come into the city on weekends.
author: Omar L.

description: I have been a resident of the area for almost 10 years, and am very happy with this restaurant.  The food is good and unique.  I encourage everyone to give it a try!
author: Daniel K.

description:
I have to admit, I was pretty out of it when we pulled up to this garage late at night.  I was pretty confused as we walked up to the nondescript entrance.  Once inside, it was still packed, even late on a Thurs night.  We were lucky to find parking right out front, and we only had to wait maybe 5-10 min for a table.

We opted for sake rather than soju, and the girl who could barely speak English made sure to check everyone's IDs.

We got a small bowl of popcorn and 3 small banchan.  We ordered the kimchee fried rice, which was beautifully red, well seasoned, and topped with a perfectly fried sunny side up egg, but it was pretty greasy.  The ramen had a good bite to it, and it totally warmed me up.  The seafood pancake was also pretty big, but it was pricey... the dipping sauce was what made the dish.

I honestly don't remember all that much besides sitting on a bench at a crowded table with good friends, enjoying strong flavored food late at night.  

I don't think it would feel right to come here during the day or with family, but for a late night craving, it hits the spot.
author: Marilyn H.

description:
Friend suggested this place - one of the places she hasn't been to in a long while. It was my first time.... we walked up to the place and I was like "heyyy where you going??" Low n behold the low-key front door looking like a garage.... never saw that coming!! 

Inside looked awesome, but with a very low ceiling. Bar-like setting n chill.... I didn't know what to order and forgot to hop on to yelp for pictures, so i ended up ordering the kimchi beef on rice and my friend ordered some rice cake seafood-tomoato-like dish... don't order that! LOL... its bland and nothing interesting.... I think I get more of a kick out of a Chef-Boyardee can of spaghetti-O's!!! 

Price is moderate: 2 dishes and water for $28ish with tax n tip included... good setting on the inside, but I'll have to try something else next time i go.... maybe the bolgogee... if they go wrong with that, oh they wont hear the last from me!!
author: Mike V.

description: chill spot that's open til about 2am. yes, it looks like a garage, but don't let that appearance outside fool you. love the fact that they have the little door bell at each table too. my order... chicken wangs and kimchee friend rice. soju here is pretty damn good too! one thing though... they're ALWAYS packed!
author: Ann T.

description:
First of all, I love the Kimchi Fried Rice.
Second of all, I love the seafood Pancake.
Third of all, I love the hotpot with sausage, spam and 'friends'.
That's all I ordered and I loved them all, definitely my fave Korean resto so far. 
This place does not look welcoming. The entrance looks like just another garage~ Oh, andthe service is good TOO :D nice.
author: Marlis T.

description: Really delicious food and very fast! Went on a Tuesday night and only had a 10 minute wait :)
author: Lauren B.

description:
My ex-boyfriend took me to this spot in the Sunset about a year and then some ago and I swear it's been a weekly MUST, and food tourist attraction ever since. Anytime someone from out of town comes in - Toyose. Anytime we wanna celebrate something, anything - Toyose. Anytime we wanna treat ourselves - Toyose. Pretty much anytime the sun rises in the East and sets in the West - TOYOSE.

You could call this spot a hole in the wall, except for the fact that it's actually a restaurant in the garage. Whenever I tell people that, they think I'm playin. And then when they realize I'm for real, they expect a car to be next to the dinner table and grandma to be doing laundry by the chef. Don't worry, neither is true. It looks more like one of those Asian spots gangster ass Korean extortionist go to after hours, considering their open 6pm - 2am.

A meal can get expensive if you eat the way me and my friends do, but it's definitely worth it. A variety of flavored Soju (Think Korean sake) is also available with Strawberry being my favorite. As far as courses, so far I've tried: Fried Chicken, Bulgogi Kimchi Tofu and most recently, the pot stickers.

But the "usual" for me would be a plate (To myself I don't share bitch!) of Kimchi Beef Fried Rice and the House Mussels. If you like rice, and you like spicy, and aren't freaked out by eating something that still lives inside it's house - this is THE ONE.

And if that buffet of greasy goodness wasn't enough to get you to go, did I mention each table has their own doorbell you can ring to call over the waitress?
author: Tor E.

description:
Best korean spot in the city hands down. Playground's got nothing on this joint. The food here is good especially when you consider I'm here at 12am in the morning when all the good cooks already have gone home. The soju is definitely good but never gets me buzzed. It's always a fun experience though. I like how this place is like a garage. It lowers all your friends expectations until they actually try it out. I never have any complaints...besides the service. They are always lacking in service but that isn't what yelp reviews should be about. I'm actually reviewing this place based on its food.


Try: Rice cakes, pancakes, yogurt soju hell yeah!

Ambience: Strange decor sorta reminds me of Hawaii. Noisy place but fun!

Food: Always consistent and tasty.

Yay or nay?: YAY!

Note: Wait times can be long on Friday & Saturday nights.
author: Jonathon C.

description:
I love how this place is a converted garage, but as soon as you walk in, you've entered a very cool/hip looking dinner cave...It's like magic!

The Korean food here is as authentic as I've had in the Bay Area.  It really reminds me of the food I ate while I lived in Korea.  They didn't hold back on the spices like most places do.

Stars for their cocktails, I loved their Soju & fruit juice mixes, fantastic!!  

If you don't want a full meal, their small plates are excellent.  The chicken wings are especially good and the kimchee fried rice is my favorite!!

If you come after 7, be prepared to wait in a line.  That's when coming in at 6 and eating early like an old person pays off.  The place gets swamped with 20 somethings quickly and the crowd doesn't let up until 2am, when they close.
author: Dave W.

description:
1) They accept reservations
2) Boo dae jji gah - best I ever had.  They could be a little more generous with the rice cakes though.  I felt like it didn't have enough.
3) It's a garage
4) Strawberry soju - had strawberry soju mini ice bits. Not ideal on a cold night but I can imagine how cool it would be on a warm summer night near Ocean Beach.
5) I came here, I believe, about 6 or 7 years ago with a friend and tried the dduk bokki (spicy rice cake dish).  - It was alright.  I may have to give this another chance to re-review
6) Con - not located near downtown, so if you wanna hop over to another joint, you gotta drive across town.  
7) Service was just alright.  
8) One bathroom
9) Fried Chicken - really good.  Only got to eat 1 drumstick cause the rest of my friends ate it all.  Damn pigs! haha j/k *wink wink* More my bad for getting there late.  Anyway....

TRY IT. IT'S WHAT'S FOR DINNER. (if you let it be.. or it could be late night snack).
author: Hanna Y.

description:
I came here with some friends the other night for dinner after a night out.

I have to say this is a cool place.  A Korean joint, in a garage.  Cool indeed.

Decor is nice and cute with call buttons at the tables.  Open up late, so bonus points.  This place is small, so depending on when you come you might need to wait for a table.  We came at 11 PM so we had no problems getting a table.

I must have had one too many to drink because I ordered a dish I normally NEVER would order.  Yet it intrigued me, so I did - Sausage and vegetables sauteed in tomato sauce.  Translation?  Hot dogs (and not the good "We Answer to a Higher Calling" brand), veggies, apples (?) smothered in ketchup.  Bizarre.  I've never had apple in ketchup and doubt I will again.  My friend's udon however was tasty according to her and so was the bulgogi my other friend ordered (I tried it, it was indeed yummy).  I *might* come here again but will never again be adventurous, not here anyways.  I'll stick with something more conventional.
author: Jen K.

description:
This restaurant is inside a garage and when you step right in it looks like a cozy small restaurant.  Most of the seatings have its only little booth and can let the curtains down for a little more privacy.  They also have this cool doorbell thing at each table to ring for the waitress to come.

The food there is actually pretty good.  My favs are the potato croquet, kimchi fried rice and the omelet. Things that isn't worth getting is the fruit platter.

The soju is very good too!  My favs are yogurt and strawberry flavor.

This is a great dinner and after dinner hang out place. But gotta warn ya, this place isn't cheap.
author: Jannifer H.

description:
The Garage! Awww damn homey!

I love the garage.  I love it. I love it. I love it.  

Why do I love it you ask?  

Because it is the only restaurant in San Francisco where i feel like I'm eating at my friend's garage.  I also love the green onion and vegetable pancakes, the kim chee fried rice and the different soon dubu.  I love it because when I'm hungry late night, Toyose is my secret hang out (not so secret no more since, well, now you know).

TIP:  The later, the more packed it gets.  Try to get there earlier or call ahead to see the wait time.
author: Roland L.

description:
we were rating this restaurant while eating!  we all agreed that giving 4 stars was fair enough!

Mango soju-around 11 bucks!  a really big bottle!  my friend and i were really light drinker, so her bf almost finished everything!  however, it tasted pretty good!  very sweet 

the fried rice- love the fried rice!  i like it a lot because it's spicy and delicious!

the tofu soup-ughhhh the tofu was only a few pieces!  and it's sweet! 

rice cake- yummm!  like it! and it's sweet!  does it suppose taste like that?

overall, very spicy!  if you like sweet and spicy food you will like it very much!  have fun`

P.S.  max for your group- 4 people
author: Brandy C.

description: Crazy long wait but worth it. This place is quite small but I didn't mind the crowded setting after my meal. Soju was good and kimchi noodle was excellent as well. It came in a giant pot that could feed a part of 4-5. Another favorite of mine were their chicken wings. Definitely snag those two dishes if you ever come here.
author: Annie S.

description: Went there with a friend on a Saturday; it was pretty stuffy and drink selection is small. They serve standard Korean drinking snacks, which is great. But then I can't think of one single thing that I am particularly impressed about
author: Victor K.

description:
My favorite Korean food in sf!  Came here for my birthday after making reservations 2 weeks in advance, and was pleasantly surprised to find that, in spite of being a relatively small restaurant, Toyose was able to seat all 17 of us timely, without splitting the group up into multiple tables.

Among the many items we ordered were the Budae Jjigae, Kimchi Fried Rice, Fried Chicken Wings, Seafood Pancake, Kimchi Tofu and Cheese Corn.  The Budae Jjigae is my favorite item on the menu, and something that many Korean restaurants don't serve.  The meat provided with the stew is plentiful, and although it's around $24 for that dish, one order is enough to feed 3-4 people.

We also tried many different flavors of the Soju: Strawberry, Mango, Kiwi, Pineapple, Yogurt, Aloe.  Of these, our favorites were Strawberry and Kiwi.

Definitely one of my go-to spots, and a great place for groups (if you have reservations).  They don't take reservations for smaller parties, and if you happen to be in a small party on a night when they are also accommodating a bigger group or two, be prepared to wait for 30-90 minutes to be seated.
author: Diana C.

description:
seafood pancake is good, great with the sauce.  beef kimchi rice is a-okay.  

clean bathroom.  narrow walkways.
author: Di Yin L.

description: Only in SF you can find a Korean restaurant in a house garage. Located in sunset district in SF. The portions are big, the price is not bad but the place is small and so big groups are going to get hard to come in here.  Service is a little slow. The soup is a little too salty, i guess its tasty because it has so much salt. Worth to try to get the experience of eating in a restaurant garage restaurant.
author: Joiera C.

description: Shared family style with four people. YUMMY KIMCHEE FRIED RICE! It was my first time eating ramen with the rice sticks. Heh. The crisping chicken wings were really crispy. The seafoodpancake was yum. I would definitely go back there again!
author: Alice S.

description:
I enjoyed drinking and eating their alcohol absorbing Korean bar delicacies.  My favorite food to order was the budeh jigae.  Accompanied with a bottle of Soju i was one happy camper.  

The interior has a rustic/outdoor market feel to it.  I like these types of places,..
author: David L.

description:
Great late night hangout drink eat place.  Real homestyle korean cooking, so don't expect the Korean BBQ.

Recommendations:  Chicken Wings, Deep Fried Seaweed roll, and the Kimchi Fried Rice. They go great with the soju.
author: Roadrunner G.

description:
Didn't have any alcohol here, just went for the food.
Ordered a hotpot and a bulgogi dish, they were average, nothing spectacular.  I went before the nighttime rush, so there was no wait and the service was quick
author: Tony T.

description:
I'm keeping this short and sweet. The food coma is getting to me. 

I've been here once since my friend knows the owners quite well. It is a Korean cuisine restaurant and is almost like a hole in the wall type joint. It fills up fast at night too. Tonight would be my second time and it was for a group of 17 people. I think we dominated the restaurant too.

Located between 45th and 46th ave. It's easy to miss this place because during the day it looks like another house. At night, it stands out with its strings of mono colored Christmas lights. 

Toyose is the place to go for a variation of alcoholic drinks. Forget the soda, order up a peach soju cocktail or some plum wine. Food wise, Toyose has everything from a Kimchi fried rice to dukkbokki to spicy chicken wings. The spicy chicken wings were served hot and when you bite into them, it came with a loud crunch! 

If you are into some exotic food, try the chicken gizzards which come with a sweet non spicy chili sauce. It is more sweet than spicy but adds a really refreshing taste to it. 

Overall, if I could come here again I so totally would. The food and service are great too. The only difference would be the buzzer on the wall next to the table. It is there for a reason. The waitresses leave you alone until you ring the buzzer. This is how you get your meal and eat it undisturbed. hehe

I recommend this as a Dinner or Late night eatery only. 

If you needa place to go to for a late night snack, come here! Toyose closes at 2am!
author: Jason C. J.

description: This place feels like a korean speakeasy in the best way possible. What looks like someone's house from the street is probably the best kept secret in outer sunset. Highly recommend the tofu kimchee. It feels like an izakaya and it's open ridiculously late. Go!
author: Andrew R.

description: Not bad at all!!  I think this place was pretty good for my being tipsy already.  The soju drinks aren't too bad, but I would recommend the calamari and the pancakes.  I didn't really like the rice cakes.  I grew up eating these so I'm pretty picky when it comes to ddokbokki.  The service was just ok.  Not compared to the typical Korean service I used to getting growing up.  This place isn't bad if the Spot Lounge is closed, but other wise I would just go to the Spot Lounge.  Better service, food, and soju drinks taste better too.
author: John H.

description:
Been here too many times to keep count of. and every time i come here they never let me down. Its a garage turned into a restaurant. its hella legit looking and cute in here. when your ready to order you could press the red bell .

Kimchi Fried Rice - Have to try it

Spicy Chicken Wings - we always get at least 2 orders of them. its not really spicy but still hella good

Casseroles - tried 2 different kinds one is the spam and ramen in spicy broth. have leftover soup but no more noodles? get so steam rice and eat it with the soup its really good. The other casserole is the fishcake with i think is soy sauce broth its also pretty good

Number 3 - don't remember the name but its calamari with vegtables and noodles in a chili sauce - it might to too spicy for some but i couldnt stop eating it.

PotStickers -  i would order it again but i love eating potstickers its kinda average to some 

Soju - My favorite flavors are mango and aloe but all of them are really good

I cant wait to go back
author: Lisa D.

description: I usually come here all the time, one of my favorite restaurants in SF but tonight just ticked me off. We had a table for 7 and the waitress would not let us get seated until my whole party got there. My friends were late and we were starving! So we asked the waitress if we can be seated and she kept asking us where is the rest of our party...... It's only two freakin people, what is the big deal?!?!? Then later our friends decided to not show up and once we got our bill she charged us gratuity!!!! What the f*#%!!!!! We told her that there was only 5 of us and her excuse was "Well you guys told me 7 people".. That just blew me off...... She ended up taking of the gratuity and we STILL tipped her 15%.. I come her all the time and this was my first time seeing this lady work there. Thumbs down on my waitress, on top of that she took so long on bringing out my soju, when soju is usually the first thing that gets brought out.
author: Josephine H.

description:
"The Garage" 

Toyose is a Korean restaurant/drinking spot in the Richmond district that is a conversion of a garage.  Once you step inside, you don't feel like you're in garage,  it a charming space, with little semi private booths. I always have a great time when I come here, except it's way out in the Avenues, which is quite a drive. 

It's hard to find decent Korean food in the city. This type of cuisine, is what Koreans call, "Anju" . Americans have cheese sticks and jalapeno poppers, Koreans have crispy fried chicken and an assortment of spicy spicy dishes. 

So for all you Non-Koreans here's the low down: 
2- 4 Bottles of Baek Soju: 
Spicy Duk Bok ee Ramen 
and some good old fashion drunk Korean, "I love you, Man" bonding.

Go Karaoke after ward in J-town and earn your honorary Korean badge.  

Kum Bae! Chan! *^^*
author: Sandy C.

description:
This place is located in what you expect to be the inside of a garage, but turns out to be a cute and very modernly decorated restaurant dimly lit with great food!

I shared the shrimp and vegetable fried rice and the seafood pancake with a friend and both dishes were delicious.  The fried rice was just the right amount of saltiness and the seafood pancake perfectly balanced a crispy crust with a soft and fluffy interior filled with a nice variety of seafood.

The service was also very friendly and patient and I would definitely go back again.

Street parking was also easy on a week day and the area was not crowded with traffic at all.
author: Stella T.

description:
3.5 stars
This place is a bit pricey for what they give you. The food came out pretty quickly. The food wasn't disappointing nor was the strawberry soju. I'd probably come back to try some of the other dishes and the other flavor soju.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Last night I arrived at this place.  My first impression was that it was really cool and cozy! The interior is actually a garage, and I love how they decorated the whole restaurant.  My friends and I (we had 8 people) were waiting for the big table.  I guess they only had one, because we had been waiting for over 40 minutes.  At first we were getting frustrated and hungry...but then we just got the 4 seat table and squeezed in 4 more seats.  It was a bit squished, but when we were eating all of our problems were forgotten.  All i could think about was how yummy the food was.  

This was my first time eating Korean food and I really like it.  

We had the Kimchee soup Hot Pot, Bulgoki, Spicy Chicken wings, Kimchee Fried Rice, the Pork stuff(umm they're round and flat? XD), eel.. 

Everything was pretty good. Although its a bit pricey, i'd definetly come back here!! at night =D It closes at 2 AM!!
author: Emi K.

description: Came here with a friend to satisfy a kimchi fried rice craving I'd had for a while. Craving fully satisfied here! Kimchi fried rice was great, and we got a kimchi pancake as well which was crispy and flavorful, if a bit greasy. We shared all the dishes and got chicken wings as well, which I thought were just okay. Overall, food is solid for what it is, but like a lot of similar Korean bar food places it's a little overpriced. Oh, and expect a LONG wait!
author: Kelly D.

description:
Oh man, this place is so good!

The biggest reason this place is a must is the bell that you will have right next to you on the wall. Magic bell that will make your waiter appear immediately when you push it 

Love love love their:
Cassaroles
Seafood with noodles
Chicken wings with (oh so delicious) side of pickled radishes - btw you should order them with whatever else you are going to order

On a friday or saturday night expect to wait for as long as an hour. They only take reservations for parties of 4 or more.

Toyose is an absolute must!!!
author: Mila Y.

description:
Hands down 5 star for the amazing yogurt soju drinks. 

Kimchee fried rice is delicious and spam casserole (Budae-Jjigae) is uber spicy. Who knew that spam casserole is an actual korean food - not california made faux korean dish. 

The waitress has sour faces but who cares about the service when the food and drink can catalyze the fun time with your buddies.
author: Fred F.

description: I don't find this place a good place to eat Korean food. Maybe I don't know what Korean food really tastes like. Maybe I was drunk to taste their food. Anyway, it is a great cozy place to hang out with your soju buddies. The serving area is too crowded and people are usually too loud. I don't think I want to come back here again.
author: Celene S.

description:
Toyose has got to be one of my favorite Korean drinking places in the bay area. The funny thing is though, that for the longest time, I didn't know that this place was called Toyose! Whenever my friends and I wanted to come here, we just referred to it as "The Garage".  No joke, it literally is someones converted garage.

Nevertheless, it's a great place to come have some Korean food and knock back a couple of shots of soju.  

Since garages aren't that big, it's usually pretty crowded here.. like ALL the time. I highly recommend making reservations beforehand, especially during the weekends, or you'll end up waiting for HOURS for a table. I had to learn that the hard way.

Some of the dishes I like here:

Kim chi fried rice- This is a MUST order.  Toyose makes the best Kim chi fried rice! It always comes out piping hot and full of flavor.

Sauteed gizzards-  This might be an acquired taste for some people, but I love gizzards and they prepare it well here.  It's a good dish to go with beer:)

Seafood pancakes-  Delicious when you dip it in the sauce that it comes with! But yes, eat it quick or it gets stuck to the wax paper that it comes on..

As for the soju, I would recommend both the lemon and yogurt flavors.  I am the LAST person who would ever use the word " yum" to describe alcohol since I'm not a big drinker. But I can honestly say that their soju here is pretty "yum".

The service here is decent. They do have the buttons on the table that you can buzz to get the servers attention when you want to order or to get the bill.  However, as with many Korean bars/restaurants...it can get a bit pricey.  I was here with a group of 7 the other night, and food & drink  evened out to about 50 bucks a person.  When you're having a good time, you don't realize how quickly those bottles of soju disappear!
author: Anna C.

description:
I hadn't been back to Toyose in years, and got dragged there a week ago. It ain't what it used to be.

I am still mourning the demise of the fried chicken wings. They used to be so tasty. Now they're bland and completely unseasoned. 

No more trekking to the deep Sunset for me :)
author: Mary M.

description:
If you're looking for a chill-ass good time come here! Kim chee fried rice, chicken wings, and soju are the perfect combination! You get passed the fact that it's in a garage and small, but the flavor makes up for everything. The ambiance is homey and the food is tasty. Only thing is, is the price can get a little steep when your drunk and keep orderig $11 soju bottles and extra fried rice! Whatever the price, toyose is a must!!!

Ps. The doorbells are sooo inventive!!
author: Rachel M.

description: So me and a group of friends decided to come here and we waited for our table. We made a reservation before time but because not everyone was on time , we couldn't be seated . But anyways , as we went inside , you expect the place to be quite small but to my surprise it was kinda roomy . But we had a group of 8 people and we were all kinda squished but we didn't mind . We ordered the kimchi seafood stew , it was on point . Everything was really good but the only things I have to complain in that dish was that it wasn't really filling . We didn't get any rice and the octopus was practically inedible , it was like chewing on an old piece of gum . It was extremely rubbery . Since we weren't full , we decided to order up a couple of plates of kimchi rice . The kimchi rice was the best I've ever eaten . I would probably even say that it's the best kimchi fried rice in San Francisco ! I really enjoyed my experience at Toyose , definitely coming back
author: Dorothy W.

description:
Downside: The wait. 

Reservation for 8 pm. 
Seated at 8:49 pm.

It's a tiny place but it's quite charming given that it's located in someone's basement. It's interesting and the decorations make you feel like you're in a different country. The place is tiny and they need to pump up the A/C. 

The staff is pretty friendly although not 100% there all the time, meaning they are working hard so they are really spaced out. 

Us: What kind of dipping sauce is this?

Waiter: Umm... I'm not sure. 

Us: Is it the same one you used for the salad? It tastes like Miso.

Waiter: Yes it is, but i'm not sure.

Us: ???

Waiter: Do you like it?

Us: Yeah it's good. 

Waiter: Okay. 

But overall the food was good. Atmosphere was good. 

While we were eating there was this one rowdy group of 10 behind us and when they left the place was just THAT much better. 
I think everyone else in the restaurant felt the same way. 

The great thing is that this place is open till 2 am. Even though i most likely will never intend on going there since it's quite out of the way. 
If i lived in the neighborhood tho, that'd be a different story. 

Bottom Line: Good food, good atmosphere, relatively good price.
author: Michael L.

description:
Food: 4/5
service: 5/5
atmosphere/decor: 5/5
price: $14-16
Would definitely come here again.

Toyose is a small hole in the wall korean restaurant in the sunset district. Its a really tiny place that opens for dinner till the wee hours in the morning. If you come right when they open at 6pm, there is no line at all. The later you come, the longer the line is. Even at 10pm, there is at least an hour wait. The waitstaff is really nice but has limited english. Which isn't a big deal though, unless you want to ask really descriptive questions about the dishes. But I'm familiar with Korean food.
     
 I came here with a party of six people and all our dishes were all pretty good solid korean dishes. Not the best, but would keep me comming. I had the bbq chicken which was marinated well and tasted great. The tempera platter is just regular, but a little too oily. My friend tried the chicken gibblets (very tough, chewy organs) which is not that great when eaten alone. A whole plate of gibblets, eventhough seasoned well, is waaay too much. A dish I recommend is the one with calamari. You can also order kimchi fried rice which is great because its not too spicy. All the portions were large and fills you up. Lastly, the flavored soju here is great. Its super light though, so don't think of getting drunk off it.
author: Cecile S.

description: The French fire,and house special are so good,peach and kiwi soju is my fav.....
author: Kim H.

description:
Perhaps I have high standards, or maybe the rest of SF's is very low, but at 4 stars in a "foodie" city this place better be prettying effing good. Oh ho ho, that's where we're wrong. If you're looking for traditional Korean food, go somewhere else. 

My main beef (or should I say bulgogi) with this place is its rude SNSD-wannabe staff. We were told 40 minutes on a Saturday night for our group of 6. The place is tiny, so we chose to stand outside for the first 15 minutes. We quickly moved inside as it was freezing out and ordered a large bottle of Hite to share. My party was apparently standing in the way of one of the waitresses as we got our beer and she snapped at us to move away. Well I'm sorry dear, it's not our fault this place is so gd tiny, the waiting area is already packed, and it's freaking cold outside. Two glasses of beer later, we are still not seated and I'm reaching boiling point after seeing people who came in after us get seated before us. Had I not been in a group, I honestly would have just walked out. We weren't seated for an hour and thirty minutes - which isn't really a reflection of our group size since two other groups of 6 got seated before us.

And a little rant while I'm on it. This has nothing to do with the actual restaurant, but clearly chivalry is dead. It would be nice to see guys offer up a seat in the waiting area to one of the 4+ women standing... yeah, ok that's too much to ask from ghetto asians in their snapback hats. lalala

When we were finally seated, we actually got served pretty fast. Our Korean friend ordered for us- strawberry soju, jjigae with doobu and spam, and kimchi fried rice. This is not a traditional Korean bbq place. For one, our "banchan" was a small bowl of popcorn. WTF. No kimchi? Livid and starving me wanted something of substance. You call this a Korean restaurant?! Other wtfs that followed: No galbi, mandu, or bibimbap on the menu. 

The food was ok, nothing amazing, and actually lacking spice. The best thing we ordered was the soju. Price was cheap considering it was 3 entrees and a soju split 6 ways. Came out to about 12 dollars a person with tip included (a tip I wouldn't have included). By the way, once they seat you, you use the buttons on the wall to call the waitresses to your table as they do in Asia. 

Bottom line: Food is so-so, drinks are good, and don't expect traditional Korean food or good service.
author: Miffy Y.

description: I heard many good comments about this restaurant which was inside of a garage hummm interesting so i decided to give it a try.  I like their interior cozy setting we ordered seafood pancake, kimchi fired rice & ...... forgot it's been a while lol anyway overall i think their food is pretty good job would recommend to others!
author: Charlie H.

description: Get their dukpoki (the hell, im not korean, dont know how to spell it right!) and ADD SEAWEED ROLL!!!
author: Joanathan L.

description: Your restaurants hours are posted as 6-2 am though clearly that's wrong since we're here at 12:42am and you're closed. If you're going to be on yelp and have your hours posted then correct hours so we don't have to waste our time.
author: Vincent W.

description:
My favorite things to order here are definitely the assorted meat casserole and the kimchi fried rice. Their casserole tastes a lot better than The Spot Lounge, too. 

The place is pretty cool and interesting, considering that it's a garage. I would recommend going here with some friends for some late night food and drinks. I love going here! 

I didn't give 5 stars because I find that some of the dishes are a bit overpriced considering how small the portions are.
author: Joy Q.

description:
4.5 stars

This hole in the wall, or as locals call it, "the garage" (literally) is probably one of my favorite korean joints in the city for comfort korean food.  Whether it's a night of casual eats or soju drinking, one thing is a must.......

THE CASSEROLE, or as people call it, "the army soup!"  

The rest of the food and drinks are yummy and reasonably priced, but the casserole is a definite must for me at every visit....yum yum yum!
author: Carmen Y.

description:
I was craving for korean food so my friend suggested that we should go here for dinner. It was my first time hearing about the place, and my friend told me that it was in a garage, which kinda through me off guard. In my head I was picturing a dinky restaurant that's probably not very appealing that's in a dirty garage.

To my surprise, when we went inside, the place actually had quite a few tables and seats and it was super clean! We got seated immediately, so no wait for us.

My friends been here a few times so I told him to do all the ordering. We got some seafood pancake, kimchee fried rice with egg on top, and a bulgogi dish. 

Seafood pancake- DEEEELICIOUS! especially when you dip it in the peppered soy sauce that they have. It had a variety of seafood, bell peppers, and onions, and it was really good!

Kimchee fried rice- had a sunnyside egg and strips of seaweed on top. The fried rice was yummy! It looked semi-spicy at first, but it wasn't at all! 

Bulgogi dish with veggies- didn't have too much veggies, all i saw was mushrooms and bunch of onion. I think this dish couldve had a lil more flavor to it. 

Service was friendly and quick! Overall, my experience at Toyose was enjoyable and delicious! I would definitely recommend coming to this place!
author: Bonnie S.

description:
Biggest tip I can offer: RESERVE or deal with the consequences! The wait was one hour around 7-8 PM. Suckers.

I was here earlier with my sisters + boo and I love the dirty Korean food here. The chicken wings are the yummiest thing I've had in a long while. It's fried and finger-lickin' good! We also had beef fried rice and it was alright. I've been here before and their beef fried rice was hella bomb. Oh well, maybe it's an off day here. We also had some seafood hotpot of some sort. Yum. They even peeled some shrimp skin off for us. We're lazy people.

Oh, get the seafood pancake. Eat it hot or else it gets stuck on the wax paper.

And it's not a Korean dinner without SOJU! We had two orders of lemon, a peach, and yogurt. I don't like yogurt personally but for those who have a sweet tooth, order yogurt! I prefer lemon soju since I wanted a lemonade-y taste and damn. It hit the spot.

This is definitely THE place to bring friends to drink and egg people on to drink. 

I'm coming back for more soju!
author: Karry D.

description: Not a great place to go as a group. Soju is delicious. Cramped and interesting place to go. Their food was not all that amazing, but I'd come back for the soju (=
author: Thanh N.

description:
No this place ain't cheap, despite it being a garage all the way in outter Sunset.  And there was a short wait even though we made a reservation ahead and all got there on time.  

But we didn't care to let that get in the way because we had so much fun!  The fruity soju definitely made my night.  And the kimchee fried rice was so yummy.  It is a great place to hang loose with friends and drink and eat and drink and eat.  

And the fried chicken cushioned my stomach well--- my perfect buzz lasted and lasted.  Toyose was awesome.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
Love Love LOVE this place! 
Every time I have guests in town this is the place I bring them.  The kimchee pancakes are to die for and the hotwings are freakin HOT!!!!!! And don't even get me started on the drinks. I can go on and on about this place Oh and they're open late too!!!!!! Just trust me EAT HERE NOW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: foo d.

description:
Cute place with good Korean food.
I think I arrived at Toyose with my expectations way too high. The rice noodle stirfry, although delicious, tasted a lot different from stand food in Korea. I think it lacked oomph. The seafood pancake was stuck to the cooking paper it was served on.
Aside from that, I enjoyed dinner at Toyose (: I'm not a picky eater, and after getting over my initial disappointment, I saw that we were being served good food. I like the garage-converted-restaurant, and the environment is a lot like what you see in Korea, with the little curtains and buzzers. We went a little early, so we weren't in the mood to drink, but next time we'll definitely be trying the fruit sojus!
author: Carolyn K.

description:
If you like spicy Korean food with varieties rather than just Korean BBQ meat and tofu soup, this place is for you. People who come here are usually the younger generations because they open until very late on the weekends and also have great drinks.  They also have great service and food.

 I love their Casserole which is a korean style hot pot and the soup base is very delicious!  Had their mussel and a corn and cheese dish and they were both really good.  However ordered their fried chicken wing before and it was very bland and didn't think there was anything special with it.  I have tried their Pineapple, Mango and Peach Soju and Mango is the best!

This place might have a long wait on the weekends and they only take reservation for party of 4 or more.  Parking can be really challenging as well however I am still a fan.
author: Kuankii N.

description:
This is by far my favorite KOREAN Restaurant. Fried food galore! Yummy in my tummy. This place is literally in a garbage and is dark and small. The food is AMAZING! The best KIM CHEE fried rice I have ever had. The rice is so flavorful and I am a fan of sunny side eggs on top of rice. Delish. 

Must get items:

- Spicy chicken wings 
- Fries with cheese. (They are seasoned fries)
- Potato Croquettes
- Beef Potstickers 
 
Pass on:

- Seafood Pancake
- Calamari

Also, make sure you ask for the spicy mayo! So good and tasty with wings and fries.

I love how they are generous with their banchans. Love kim chee, those little fishy, bean sprouts and pickled radishes.

Make sure you call in for reservations bc this place gets packed!

Service here is great! I love the doorbell thingy = genius idea. Best server there is Lanni. Such a sweet girl and always know what I want to order :)
author: Rose L.

description: Best Korean Bar Food Eva! Just take it from another Korean who lived in Korea :)
author: Carmen S.

description: was great. Just don't forget to hit the bell when you want service.
author: Alicia S.

description: This place is opened late at night until roughly 2am! Very nice place to go to if you are craving korean food at this hour! This place is actually just a spacious garage turned into a small restaurant, the food here is rather delicious , they have a big menu and also serve soju. The 2 main dishes I really enjoyed eating was the kimchi fried rice and the pajeon. Spicy and very delicious. I also tried udon soup , fried chicken wings, french fries, and some sizzling beefs plates, all I can say is the food full of taste and really authentic. They also have Aloe soju here which I rarely see at other korean restaurants, the atmosphere is great , they play kpop music here and always have a good time eating here. Overall 4/5 stars. Toyose!
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
I can always appreciate greasy, good food for decent, reasonable priceas and that's what Toyose offers. When i had gone to Toyose I was greeted with a cute, Asian hostess, who could barely speak english yet who was so friendly. She sat us and poured my friend and I glass of water. 

The scene was cramped and filled with young people, I assume students SFSU, UCSF, and any students within the proximity of Toyose. We ordered the obligatory chicken wings and I admit it was tasty, the price for dinner were even better. So it's no wonder there were college students dwelling in the vicinity.
author: C M.

description:
Me loves Soju. Me loves fruity drinks. Me loves Toyose. 

I love the soju here. My favorite is mango and aloe soju. Those two are a must order when I visit this place, which has been getting more and more often nowadays. 

The place is unassuming, it's a converted garage with minimal ventilation and probably not the most structurally sound place for a restaurant. I mean it's supposed to be a place to store cars, not living and breathing people getting intoxicated with delicious soju and eating kimchee fried rice!

I love the kimchee fried rice here, especially the soft yolk that goes with it. I have had better seafood pancake somewhere else, but I won't take offense because my love for yummy soju is more than my love for seafood pancake. The soups are also good! 

This is a great place to catch up with friends and to enjoy delicious soju. They also have those gigantic beer for those of you who might feel emasculated by drinking fruity colorful cute shots of soju. 

Come early on the weekend. The server is very accommodating for large group if they have tables available. Order several varieties of soju (again, mango and aloe are recommended, but everything is good), seafood pancake to munch on, some soups, and of course, long live kimchee fried rice!
author: tee w.

description:
Didnt get to eat since the wait was a hour and half!!

Food looked delicious!! And I got super jealous looking at the all the food everyone was stuffing their faces with. 

I will be back stuff my face..just hoping the wait wont be soooo long.
author: Nessreen H.

description: This place is amazing!! Its cozy and cute place. I luv their cocktail sojus. Theyre fresh, tasty, and colorful:) best korean restaurant!
author: Jun I.

description:
Toyose is not a restaurant.  We didn't realize this.  Well, it is and it isn't.  See, they serve food, but so do most bars...and this place is basically a bar with snack food.

Instead, we ordered full meals and were disappointed.  The prices/quality were not in order.

What we did notice were all the other people ordering Soju, getting a bowl of popcorn with it and then ordering fried foods.  It's a small place but warmly decorated.  I will go back for the bar food experience, just eat dinner elsewhere!
author: Sir Paul L.

description:
every time i go back home i NEED to go to this place. one of the best korean restaurants i have been too! definitely a hole (garage) in a wall! their dishes are created to perfection! no joke! from their chicken wings (when i use to eat meat) to their yogurt soju! line gets a little long sometimes however it's definitely worth the wait. 

few favorite dishes:
- chicken wings
- bu dae ji gae (AMAZE BALLS)
- seafood pancake
- kimchi fried rice
author: Annalyn A.

description:
Looky here! My husband finally found a Korean place he actually likes! What can I say, he's a picky man and usually don't care for Korean. I on the other hand love Korean food but needless to say, my opportunity is slim due to my hubby. Ok, onto the review.

We're both big fans of the buckwheat cold noodle. It's a bit on the spicy side but we love hot 'n spicy. Don't feel guilty at all eating cause it has an array of julienne veggies (carrots, cucumbers, red bell peppers, lettuce), apples/pears, slices of hard boiled eggs. Huge portion for $17 (it can feed 3 people).

The spicy grilled pork served over tofu was very good too. It doesn't come with rice so you need to order it on the side.

Didn't like to steamed house mussels. The dressing tasted a little like Thousand Island.

I like the fact that it's cozy and a former garage although a little dark but made up by the fact that they had lights all around. The service was great and the staff was friendly!  They get busy even at 6pm. Wow. We'll be back!!
author: Sassy G.

description: This really does look like it's in a garage. Came here with some girlfriends one night and we all loved it. Chicken was good, seafood pancake was good, GIANT bottle of hite was awesome. Can't remember everything we had, but we left happy campers.
author: Caroline D.

description:
This place is half a block from where I live. It's great! 

My friends call this place the 'garage'. I mean, it's quite literally in a garage and you practically have to open a garage door to get in. But, to be honest, once you're inside you're swept away into a Korean lounge-type atmosphere, where the waitresses really move quickly and the food quality is impressive. I really enjoyed their spicy bbq wings and the seafood pancake is great too! They also have an excellent selection of flavoured soju options. =)

Great that this place is open late and has good service.
author: Jj H.

description:
Have I said that there wasn't good Korean food in San Francisco? This is me eating my words (and good Korean food).

The Fiance and I were meeting up with some Korean friends and we were jonesing for some Korean food. Yelp led us to Toyose and even though the Fiance warned me that he'd read that it looks like someone's garage, I was surprised to find that it really does. 

Actually, the entrance is located right next to a garage door. When I walked in, I immediately felt at home. Toyose's is a small restaurant but the atmosphere is exactly what a good Korean wants - fun with dark brown decor and mood lighting!

When you're drinking your soju/soju cocktail, you don't want ugly white lights glaring down at you while you're surrounded by white walls. No, you want to be sitting in a cozy section with wood and brick walls (the latter have names carved into them from former patrons and the former have the ubiquitous Hyori/soju posters). 

On to the food. The four of us ordered:

- Soh gogi kimchi bokeum bap (kimchi fried rice with beef): This was a solid dish. It's pretty easy to make, even at home, so it's difficult to mess up. It comes with a fried egg on top. 

- Rabbokki (ddukboki with ramyun, i.e., spicy rice cakes with ramen): I haven't had good rabbokki since...well, for a long time. Ddukboki is hard to make "right" and of course every family has a different recipe (my mom's is the best. Seriously.). This dish was appropriately spicy, the rice cakes were cooked well (it sucks when they're over- or under-cooked) and they included a nice helping of ramen. 

- Jun gol (hot pot): Toyose calls this section the Casserole section but I would disagree slightly, given that you would never cook jun gol in the oven. It's a stew with raw meat, vegetables and soup that cooks quickly over a gas flame. I don't remember the name of the one we ordered but it's the one with baby octopus and beef. Delicious! 

- Yogurt soju: You can't have a Korean reunion with Korean friends and not have some sort of soju. The cocktails come out in olive oil bottles which isn't a bad idea since the spout makes pouring into shot glasses really easy. One order is about 8-10 shots, depending on how much you pour. 

All in all, I had a fantastic time and I can't wait to go back again. Who knew that such a gem lay nestled in the Outer Sunset?? 

Toyose is open until 2 a.m. (another wonder!) and they WILL card you. Don't think that just because this is a Korean joint, they play loosey-goosey with the ID's! 

Have no fear about trying the restaurant if you're not Korean. The waitresses speak English quite well, the menu is written in both Korean and English and they don't only serve things like baby octopus stew.
author: Christine P.

description:
Only by luck and at the most random times would you find this place for the first time, but after you find it you'll wonder how you never saw it before.

Toyose is a Korean restaurant located along the edge of of the Outer Sunset on Noriega. I found out about this restaurant with my Korean food loving friends one late night. The funny thing is I've lived in the Sunset all my life and I NEVER heard about this restaurant till that night.

At first glance you wouldn't believe it's a restaurant, Toyose literally looks like your typical Sunset house but inside surprises you. Tables setup along the walls complete with a call button if you ever need to flag a waiter/waitress. In terms of food, their menu is slightly different however their kimchi dishes are excellent.

You'll only be able to get dinner here as the restaurant opens at 6PM. HOWEVER they are open late so they're PERFECT for those late night food cravings or when you don't want to call it a night after getting out of the clubs/bars. Only problem I've had was extremely limited seating and at times difficult to walk around due to the small dining areas. But if you can get around that, I would recommend you try out Toyose.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Toyose is literally a door in the wall.  We drove from 19th to 46th, back to 32nd, then back to 46th, squinting to find it, driving at a crawl's pace.  It was when Kder finally yelled, "what the...they have a sign now" did the Toyose experience begin.  I nearly walked by the building, wondering if I had to ring a bell to this "garage".  However, when some patrons left, opening a door in the wall that I didn't notice, it brought back memories of the bar in Japantown where you are led through a kitchen.  Wondering if I was being tricked and walking into a death trap, I was happily greeted by Korean accents happily eating seafood pancakes.  Toyose is a very small establishment and is set up in a make-shift garage.  It is tiny yet teaming with laughter, men missing the acetaldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme, and patrons flattening themselves against the wall so that the waitresses can pass.  We ordered the

kim chee fried rice: 5/5  I don't even like kim chee but I have to give bless ups when bless ups are due.  This kim chee fried rice, while I am sure was super cheap to make, was fucken most savory and was the best dish of the night.  Over easy eggs on top of anything makes it 1000x better.  Luckily, it wasn't that spicy because I am a puss when it comes to spiciness.  

fried chicken wings: 3.5/5  I don't know how Toyose pumped out these dishes so fast.  Everything came out after 5 minutes.  The fried chicken was good, much better than anything KFC can offer, but after a couple wings, got too salty.  After a couple wings, I had to ask for a bowl of rice to balance the saltiness.  I was debating on whether I should get a whole chicken so that I can have different pieces of the chicken, however, due to the amount of food we got, opted for handfood.

bulgogi: 4/5  We ordered the bulgogi without the calamari and were happily accommodated.  The bulgogi wasn't grilled however; it was sauteed.  As a result, there was less of a char taste however, it was still good.  I liked how the bulgogi wasn't too sweet and there was a strong taste of garlic and the vegetable juices.  

cheese corn: 2/5.  KDer often talks fondly of Toyose cheese corn, however, was disappointed in last night's batch.  It was good, however, Bob Sang in Fremont was better.  The cheese was not creamy and the cheese quickly hardened up.  It was like the topping of a pizza once it gets cold.  This dish really put me over the edge as the hardened cheese was so filling.  

Toyose is one of the Korean restaurants I've been too in San Francisco.  It's very warm and cozy unless you sit next to the AC and back door where I was inconveniently seated.  Minor gripe however.  The waitresses were the silent friendly type, always accommodating, never speaking.
author: Brian V.

description:
FINALLY came here for dinner the other night!

This place gets packed very easily and good thing my friend and I came here at the RIGHT time because we were able to get seats. The place is quite small, but surprisingly it sat a lot of people. 

Our meal consisted of the Seafood Pancake, the Spicy Fried Chicken, and of course the famous Kimchi Fried Rice. 

IT WAS SOOOO GOOOD. I only wished they have more banchans, but I guess it's a "bar" atmosphere so not really their specialty. We were going to get soju, but we had passed until the next time because we had ordered three entrees.

The Seafood Pancake is pretty good, and the Spicy Chicken wings were delicious too. But the breading on the chicken was SUPER crispy and took me like two bites just to reach the chicken. And lastly, the Kimchi Fried Rice was AMAAAZING, one of the best I've had. I kinda wish they had tofu soup or some kind of kimchi stew, but they had different variations of it, which was okay, but too much for one person.

Anyways, go try this place out! Good atmosphere and good food.

OH! I almost forget, they have a little blinds that cover the front of the table if you don't like to be bothered from other people waiting to get a seat. I thought that was pretty clever yet funny at the same time. 

happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description:
I love this place! When I first move to the city everyone I met says I should go here with a few of my friends.

Yes the food is expensive, but I love their Kimchi Fried Rice! YUM :) I had the pancake and that was good too. I didn't really like their ddeokbokki, but my roommate loved it.

Besides the food and flavored Soju, I really like the environment. Yes it's extremely small because it's built inside a long SF garage (hence the nickname), but I love the feel to the place. There are the small booths where you can pull down the curtains and it's like a party inside of one (alcohol recommended). 

This definitely one of my favorite place to go with to chill with a few friends in SF.
author: Tina T.

description:
Inferno inside the mouth type of good!

I've been here a few times, once my female friend introduced/treated me and my gf to this place. The other time I went with a few buddies. They were both ok visits prices quite up there in range. The other night was what finally made me realize this place is the "SHIZZAT!" In a good way of course.

It was getting late, my girl was already hungry with a splash of moody "I want to rip my bf's head off if I don't eat in 5 minutes." I had sweaty palms, trying to dodge the few random side hits from the passenger without swerving the car off the road. Thank god I remembered this place.

We walked in eager to cure our stomach grumblers. I ordered the stir fried spicy baby octupus udon dish. My girl got the spicy chicken wings. Both were phenominal!. With the ice cold Hite beer to wash it down, I couldn't think of anything better. 

You know something's delicious when your tongue is burning, sweat's starting to accumulate on your forehead and back of the neck but your still shoveling it in your mouth. 

In conclusion, besides the high prices, this place has some spicy delights and is open in the late hours. A must try!
author: Tip S.

description: The tables are cleaner and the lights are brighter and there's no watermelon soju.  But they have many other flavors that are just as yummy.  We liquored up 8 people for $145.  I didn't touch the food the others ate but they look much better than Tonight's.
author: Byron L.

description:
stilll a fan! 

the seafood pancake is a definite must compared to other places. its actually filled with seafood stuff. 

the rice cake with fish cake and added ramen was good, but i think the sauce was too thick for our liking.

the chicken wings were good, nothing special. 

mango soju and strawberry soju, yum, don't taste any alcohol, but i think the bottle looks smaller? haha

moderate priced food in the outer sunset, cozy lil place, great for nights when you're bored since they open till 2am everyday! easy parking too
author: Christine M.

description:
I generally try to reserve my 5-star ratings for places I think are unique enough that it would be hard to replicate the experience elsewhere in the city. Toyose definitely fits into this category. The best way I can describe this place is 'Korean izakaya' - go here to drink beer/soju and snack on food items that go awesomely with drinking. 

Waaaay out in Outer Sunset (almost to the beach) and basically housed in a converted garage, this place is an odd find in the middle of a mostly-residential neighborhood. When we entered, both of us got this distinct feeling that we're no longer in SF. Not having been to Korea, I can only say that the place reminds much more of places in Hong Kong or Tokyo or even NYC. Also, I think we were possibly the oldest people in the place since it seems to be a hangout spot for local college kids. 

The place itself is tiny with quirky decor and only one waitress, so we prepared ourselves for the long haul. Once we managed to get our order in though, the food came very quickly. We ordered spicy fried chicken wings, seafood pajun, and kimchee+beef fried rice - all delicious and of course, went perfectly with our little bottle of soju. We saw other tables order the 'cocktail sojus' with various flavors as well as large boiling cauldrons of delicious meats and vegetables with ramen noodles - we'll definitely try that next time. 

The best part? They're open every single night until 2am! Where else in the Sunset can you find that??
author: Angi C.

description:
A great place for a low-key drinking and snacking with friends. 

Great korean snacks, especially the chicken wings and ddeokbokki, at a fairly reasonable price. The soju cocktails are also a big hit, my favorites being strawberry and kiwi. Can be a bit louder at peak times, but generally a place to feel at ease after a long day.

The service can be spotty at times, especially if you're at a table without a call button, but generally food comes out fast.
author: James P.

description:
I thought it was Christmas when I entered Toyose.  The inside of the restaurant is small and dark.

I needed my fix of Korean food.  My hands were shaking..
I picked up my order of addicting kimchee fried rice at the counter.

As I walked towards the front door with the food in my hand I saw a blonde girl light up like a Christmas tree.  I guess the alcohol was going straight to her head. Ha!! another lightweight..

Toyose is kind of like that.  The food is so good that it lights up your taste buds and goes straight to your stomach.  After your meal, you kind of forget that this place is so small..
author: Walter C.

description:
I always referred to this place as "the winking duck" turns out it's a chicken. It also looks like a garage and it is "THE garage." 

Great little Korean place, the inside is cute with wooden booths and walls and each table is equip with a call button that you can use to get a waitress whenever you need anything.

Order: Kimchi fried rice, cheese corn, fried chicken, yogurt soju. 

This place gets packed fast, they only take reservations for 4+ people, if you have a smaller party if you get there by 7 to ensure a table.
author: Nicole L.

description:
came here for dinner again after... don't even remember how long... 

ordered fried chicken wings, kimchee fried rice, seafood pancake and mango soju. i loved the chicken wings and the kimchee fried rice! the chicken wings were flavorful and crispy! the kimchee fried rice isn't dry (like other places i've had) and the kimchee flavor is there! amazing huh?!? haha... the pancake was ok. i think it's because i like my pancakes thinner than the ones here. the soju was ok... i m not a big alcohol fan so it's ehhh... 

i'd definitely come back for the kimchee fried rice and the chicken wings tho!!!
author: Kapo T.

description:
i rarely give 5 stars. and i never give 5 stars to korean places... but this place got me.

just something about the aura.. it brings nostalgia of being in korea...

but let me tell you about this magical place.

i say magical because from the streets you can't even tell its a restaurant. it just looks like any old house with a garage... but as you get closer you see that the garage are actually DOORS! and then all of a sudden you're in korea right as you walk in.

its dark but the mood is good. people are there drinking, eating some good street korean food and having a good time.

i went there for my friend's birthday, and maybe its because she had her baby with her, but we got really good service hahaha. the server couldnt get enough of my friend's baby. she kept tickling and touching my friend's baby. now if it was some other server we would have been like WTF RUDE DONT TOUCH MY BABY but she was nice and friendly and supppper helpful so it was okay :)

we ordered the kimchi fried rice JUST because people were raving about it on yelp, kimchi pancake, boodaejjigae and ddeokbokki

kimchi fried rice:
good stuff! the egg on top was a nice surprise and a good idea! ive actually never had kimchi fried rice with an egg and its actually really good together! so i will be making mine that way now.. and yeah there was just something about it.. so good..

kimchi pancake (kimchi pajeon):
OOOHH YUMMM it was sooooooo good. i usually hate pajeon or boochinggae because its got too many veggies for me, but the kimchi pajeon only had kimchi and maybe onion? not sure, but it was crunchy and delicious. and they give you a dipping sauce that makes it all the more better

ddeokbokki/tteokbokki/spicy rice cakes:
okay well we ordered rabokki (which is the dish with ramen noodles) and omgggg i dont know why but it was good! maybe it was the people i was with or the atmosphere of the place but everything that night was delicious. it wasnt too spicy, and very flavorful and my sister and i fought over the fishcakes (hehe) its sooo good!

boodaejjigae:
i've never in my life had this before but i had heard of it. its apparently a new creation that koreans made up with american ingredients. anyways by the time this came out, my girls and i were really full but we all decided to have one bowl of it. SPICY and the spam was REALLY good. they also put the same pork they use for dwagibulgogi (pork bulgogi) and my sister and friends fought over that too (lol) it was good, but i could have done without the sausages.. they tasted kinda funky. but the SPAM, RAMEN NOODLES, PORK, RICE CAKES were the best part of the stew. the soup was yummy too

unfortunately, since my sister and i had to run a marathon the next morning (THE NIKE WOMEN'S MARATHON OH YEAH WE FINISHED IT TOO BY THE WAY) we steered clear of the alcohol.. and obviously the mother in our group didnt drink since shes still breast feeding her baby and our other friend also drove so she couldnt drink either so none of us tried the alcohol, but we all do want to come back specifically to try the alcohol. but the food was wonderful and they get 5 stars JUST for that.
author: Rebecca K.

description: 5 words...Kimchi Fried Rice Fuck Yeah!
author: Marc E.

description:
words cannot explain how much i love toyose (the garage)

kimchi tofu, kimchi pancake. i could even eat their cheese corn on a bed of dog crap. on a bad day.

the service is spot on, the girls are nice and attentive, their beer/soju is inexpensive and its an overall good time and EASILY my favorite korean joint in the city (oakland has "pornos" on telegraph, which is similar, but not as awesome).
 
great for big groups or a one-on-one. 

keep being, well, awesome!
author: Ryan L.

description:
This is where I go for some good time just drinking and hanging out with friends because they are open until 2am! Truly a hole in the wall, since it is in a garage in the middle of sunset. I've tried all the flavors of the soju and the two that prevents my shot glass from getting dry is mango and Yogurt soju.. also love the HITE beer ,by the PISHER, as it is mispelled on the menu. =D 

As for food, the price is a bit high for the taste but nonetheless, it is still good compared to another korean/bar place like THE SPOT. 

1. kimchi fried rice - default dish I get here, tastes really good on some days, lacks a bit of consistency of the taste but it still has all the flavors I love.
2. calamari & beef bulgogi- mMm mMm, sooo goood, especially the sauce. Beef is really tender and juicy... calamari very chewy but not too chewy to the point where the tentacles will get stuck between your teeth. 
3. seafood casserole - For a wallet-robbing $26 and some change, you get glass noodles boiled with calimari, clams, octopus, veggies, tofu, and a really delicious spicy broth. This is my favorite! 
4. garlic fries- this is not your typical ballpark/theme park garlic fries... this is literally fries topped with freshly chopped garlic on melted cheese. kinda weird, yet surprising delicious.

If you go during weekends at night, you better make reservations. Also if you are expecting the traditional small dishes at a korean restaurant...bad news--you're not getting any. However, in exchange, they do give you a small dish of popcorn. BLEH

So in summary.. food (OKAY), price (kinda HIGH), drinks (GOOD), Service (GOOD), Atmosphere (EXCELLENT). If you like to gossip, catchup, get tipsy, talk smack till 2am with k-pop music in the background, this is the place to be!!! ^_^
author: Mishi W.

description:
Recommended by a bunch of Koreans, this restaurant is AWESOME. Note this is NOT Korean BBQ, more like home cooking! And it really is in a garage. 

Spam Kimchi Soup with Noodles! - I'm not sure exactly what it's called but it is DERRICIOUS!! They bring it out in a big metal bowl on top of a propane fire. It's got a mix of vegetables including mushrooms, onions, cabbage? Note: don't mix the ramen in until the end or it'll get soggy.

Fried Cheese and Corn - You might not want to get this unless you have a large party. It's plenty tasty and rich but if you leave it for too long it gets gross.

Ramen and Rice rolls? - Yummy but can be a bit starchy as the rice rolls are very dense. But the sauce is excellent and there are plenty of vegetables to go with it.

This is more of a home-cooking / drinking place open til 2am (longer if you're korean :P) Make reservations or you'll be hanging out at the bar across the street (also good).
author: Brandon O.

description:
Heard from my colleague the other day about this very interesting restaurant and decided to to try this weekend. I have passed this place many times before, but never noticed this place. It does look like it is in the garage but actually the place is narrow and long to the back of the house.  We had seafood saute , kimchee and beef fried rice (good!) and also potato croquettes. seafood saute tasted a little sweet first but after a while it burns your tongue !!  It had squid, shrimp, clams, and a lot of vegetables. Croquettes were crisp and very good.My 16 year-old loved them! The best of the three dishes was fried rice. The spiciness is just right and tasty with a soft cooked fried egg on top.
Price is very reasonable for the portion and I can see myself going back there again and again.
author: Kana Y.

description: After hanging out at the beach I was (with some luck) able to get a table on a Thursday night at this inconspicuous, but active spot. I devoured the seafood pancake and polished off the leftovers a couple hours later. Prompt service, great food.
author: Luis C.

description: I came back last night with a gf and totally ordered stuff I would normally not.  Mussels were awesome, kimchee pancake was so much better than the seafood one.  I'm not a fan of chewy seafood.  The #1, spicy seafood and veggies was also very good but again the octopus was too chewy for me.  Kimchee over tofu with spicy pork was AMAZING!  I could have eaten the whole dish myself.  We also shared the yogurt soju.  I'm curious about the kiwi sofu, next time!
author: Rosalind S.

description: While nice there's a place in the cuts open 'till 2a.m. for something besides a slice, I was definitely let down with the quality of grub at Toyose. I dined here a couple months ago with a few other folks, so we ordered 4 or 5 dishes to share. I had heard good things about the chicken wings, and although not worth a drive across town they were the best thing on the table. I still found them under seasoned, although crispy and fried perfectly. We also ordered an octopus dish which was borderline painfully chewy, ugh. Overall I felt like our meal at Toyose was made by people who knew how to follow directions but didn't know how to cook. There was a serious lacking of care and it was evident in the sub-par selection of dishes.
author: Anthony R.

description:
A's sister had told us about this place and I was in the mood for some kimchi fried rice, so we headed over to check-check-check it out.  I know how it's called the "garage," but it is literally a garage.  It was kind of weird, but a great utilization of space.  I think it's pretty awesome. 

It was pretty empty when we got there and we got seated way, way, way in the back.  We weren't aware of the whole doorbell system, so didn't know what the little brown thing on the wall was.  Me, being so nosy, was pushing at it and accidentally pushed the button.  The waitress was there lickety split.  Luckily we were all ready to order.

We got the kimchi fried rice, kimchi pancake, and the spicy chicken wings.  The fried rice was good.  It didn't taste too much like kimchi, but it was good.  The pancake dish came with a lot.
