KIM-CHEE fried rice, orgasmic good, nothing compares to it! SERVICE is a bit slow but it's understandable, there is usually one waitress/hostess. BUT if you need immediate attention you can ring the handy-dandy buzzer on the wall adjacent to the table and you can be sure that they will be there about... 3-4 minutes afterwards.

You just need to try this place, hands down the best korean food i've had thus far. and don't for get to say hi to the glowing asians that seem to be glued to all the tables!
author: Alex C.

description:
I had low expectations for this place when I kept hearing from people that it was in someone's "garage", even though everyone kept raving about this place. I was expecting it to be a mom-and-pop type of place and quality, which can be good still, but I meant also in the ambient-sense. But boy was I wrong! As soon as you walk in entirely different from what you would think. It's a ornate nicely decorated korean restaurant on the inside, so forget the part that it's in someone's "garage". 

This place is very tiny though, so I wouldn't recommend it for big groups even though they have tables for 6 or 8 people. It just gets a little clausterphobic at that point. But it's super cute on the inside! Service was pretty good, they have those buttons you can push to call for service when you need it. And for the most part they come right away, but you have to be understanding when it's packed. 

They give you a complimentary bowl of popcorn for each table, which is a little odd. Then they give you the standard complimentary korean appetizers of kimichi and pickled cucumbers and other vegetables. Yummy! 

The Kimchi fried rice is DELICIOUS! Yumm! So flavorful and it has chopped up bits of kimchi mixed into it with a big fried egg on top.  I wasn't too fond of the egg yolk being left runny, but everyone likes it differently I suppose. You should definitely give the Kimchi Fried Rice a try though! 

One of my friends got the "casserole", not a typical casserole that you would expect like something baked. Their "casserole" is a giant hot pot, cooking spam, hot dog, noodles (ramen) and vegetables. It's a little spicy, but good flavor broth. I would definitely get this next time, and you can share it between several people, it's that big! 

The beef & calamari bulgogi was pretty tasty, but it doesn't come with rice, so you have to request it. 

The soju was yummy, but why would you get the yogurt flavored one when they have so many other enticing choices?? We got the peach flavored one and that was really good! The yogurt one is bland compared to the peach one. 

Next time I am coming back for the casserole item, the kimchi friend rice and the chicken wings! We saw a waitress bring out a an order of the chicken wings, and it was a heaping plate of wings. yummmm!! can't wait!
author: Grace L.

description:
I swear after going to Toyose, I'm a changed woman. I love Korean food, the KIMCHI fried rice was awesome. I also have been craving their pancake dish. This is an awesome place to go, just make sure you have reservations and bring a jacket. it's in a garage, what was i thinking not bringing my parka!!! besides being slightly cold, it was the best Korean food I've had and it might be my new foodie obsession.

Again, it's worth the travel to get to outter richmond with a reservation!!! if you don't have one, it might be a 2 hr wait!!!!
author: Olivia W.

description:
A decent attempt at bringing authentic Korean bar drinking/dining to SF.  Not that I know what authentic Korean bar drinking/dining is, but since Euge told me so, I am saying so.

The decor makes it feel like I'm in Korea, especially with the low-ceilings.  Not that I know what it feels like to be in Korea, but Euge, low-ceilings...hello.  I put two and two together and decided: "this is what it must feel like to be in Korea."

The service is slow but good.  Poor lady who has to take orders from drunk little kids.

I don't know how reasonable or unreasonable the price is because I'm usually too drunk to notice.  I did front a $180 bill one time but that was between a group of good friends who drink a lot.  Okay, it was just Euge and Omar.  Damn alcoholics.
author: Hodie K.

description: Just ordered two main dishes (a typical fried chicken and spicy grilled pork) as a take out, and they are the worst ever. Chicken meats were very hard and not chewable at all. The spicy pork, the spices are not the right and not the usual Korean taste either. Wasted $30 for two dishes that are not eatable. The restaurant should be ashamed of itself. I came here once before two months ago and it was just ok and the waitresses were hard to be found. We thought we would try again today as our favorite local Korean restaurant is closed today. The price isn't on the cheaper side either. Side dishes are so limited for a typical Korean restaurant normally would provide to customers. I just don't understand how others are raving about this place.
author: W L.

description: Kimchi fried rice was the bomb. There mango soju was surprisingly very good will have to try another flavor next visit.
author: Tina O.

description:
Don't be fooled by the garage door, the food here is GEWD!

I'm a big fan of Korean, so I've been wanting to taste this place for a while. Let me say that I was not disappointed!
Caution: The food here is SPICY, so be careful for those who has weak stomaches. I came here with my boyfriend, and unfortunately his stomach was not as strong as mine. So I'm guessing his review won't be as great as mine.

I ordered the Casserole, the seafood pancake, and 2 Sojus. The Casserole was really big. I guess it wasn;t intended for a two- person meal. The broth was really rich and spicy to my liking. 
Might I say that the seafood pancake was THE BEST  seafood pancake i've tasted in San Francisco. It was crispy on the outside, savory and rich with seafood and vegetable. It was just perfect.
The Soju was also the best tasting Soju I've tasted so far. They were sweet and fruity (We ordered the strwaberry and the pineapple). We thought we were going to be served a regular sized glass of soju. It turned out each order was a whole mini vase (i don't really know how else to explain the size), with little shot glasses. I came out feeling extra cheerful.
author: Libby K.

description:
This place is cool because it's in a garage. But don't worry, once you step in, it actually looks more like a restaurant. It's really small and cozy, but I have yet to see what the back of the restaurant looks like. That section is usually reserved for larger parties. 

A few of my favorite dishes are the kimchi fried rice, and potato croquettes.  I've also tried the duk bok ki, chicken wings and probably some other stuff. Their kimchi fried rice is the best I've ever had! As far as soju goes, I stick with yogurt and strawberry. I loooooove their strawberry soju because they use real strawberries (you can see the seeds in the bottle as you pour!) and you can really taste the true essence of the fruit. Sorta reminds me of that strawberry drink you get at taquerias.

Service on the other hand...is a hit or miss. The last time I was here, it was a hit. Previous times were mostly misses. They have this buzzer on the wall that you can press so that the waitress will come to your table. Depending on the waitress, you might have to press the buzzer a few times.

Overall, the food and soju is pretty good, ambiance is nice and cozy, but the service can be sub par. Oh yeah, this place doesn't give you Korean side dishes. From what I remember, they give you a bowl of shrimp chips.
author: Maryann T.

description:
Shopping at Noriega Produce across the street, I always thought this unassuming place was a night club/dive bar just judging from the late hours posted on the door.  It's a bona fide restaurant that rivals some of the best home cooked Korean meals that I have eaten in private homes.  Wow!  I can't wait to bring Korean friends here.  The strawberry soju rocks.  The parking is way easy.

We came 10 minutes after opening on a Sat. night.  By the time we left at 7, the place was PACKED.  Come early.
author: K W.

description:
Toyose...where have you been all my life?!

It started as a whisper. A friend mentioned it first saying they had eaten at a great Korean place in a garage...but couldn't remember where it was. Then I was in LA one trip, in Korea town enjoying a great meal at a restaurant that had no a word of English anywhere (I'm not even Korean)....truly authentic Korean bar food! Was lamenting that the Bay Area didn't have a similar place. The whisper got louder. The LA friend said yes there is. It's way out there in the residential neighborhood. Hidden in a garage...address please?...um...it's across from the cleaners...huh?!

After much searching with the tidbits of information from the whispers I finally found the place and we made time to go there this weekend. Awesome!

There were 5 of us. We were starving. Came at a great time and got the last available table. 

We ordered pork dumplings. All made noises about how there were too many! Only expected 6 or so, there were more than a dozen. We genuinely though we had ordered too much food! 60 seconds later we were fighting over the sauce and ALL the dumplings were gone!

The kim chee pancake and spicy grilled pork came soon after. Equally delicious and both very quickly decimated. We then tackled the cold soba platter - soba noodles with a large variety of shredded fruits and vegetables that you mix in yourself. lovely combo! Finishing off with the seafood hot pot. So big, so yummy, cooked fast too! We were getting really full by now...but the smell...it was too good to resist!

We left full with promises to come back again soon. Not so good if you have only 2 in your group since the portions are huge. With tax and tip we spent about $20 a head without alcohol. Wonderful change from the BBQ houses.
author: Purple Lotus x.

description: ahhhhhhhhhh..........the Garage. Sad to say, I wasn't "in the know" about this place for quite a while, but now that I am, I can't seem to stay away from this place! The have some of the BEST FRESH SOJU ever. I love me some soju.....mmmmmmmm. Last time the waitress brought us our shotglasses and I said to my friends," OHHH, this time we didn't get the ones w/ Lee Hyori" and she overheard and exchanged them w/o my asking!!! That was cool! BUt anyways, there is usually an hour wait if you arrive when it's crowded and most times it's not good for big groups if you want to sit together and didn't call in a reservation. So, lesson here people, call ahead to reserve a table. The staff is cool and the food and drinks are great....so hurry up and try this place already.
author: Sara C.

description: I love their soju at Toyose! My co-workers and came here after work on a Monday for a drink and dinner.  We ordered quite a few items on their menu and 3 flavors of soju.  I was sort of buzzed by the time all the food arrived and couldn't remember all of them. However, I do remember ordering kimchi fried rice, fried chicken wings, and this pork shoulder thing. We also had the yogurt, peach and mango soju.  I thought I loved the peach one most but once I tasted the mango it became my favorite. The place is literally in a garage and not very spacious. Overall, this place is a very cool place to hang out for a small bite and a drink (or more).
author: Anh W.

description: Worst service ever. Thanks for spilling that ice cold water on me AND had no intention for apologies.. To me, service and food is JUST as important.
author: Rosina G.

description:
There's a chance you'll miss this place if you're just casually passing by. I know I did numerous times. It's a two door garage house in the freakin Sunset!!!

What are you supposed to make of a restaurant in a garage? Words cannot describe the weirdness as you enter the first time. I wasn't sure if I would be walking in on some random ass family or not. But upon entering, if you're lucky enough to get a seat, it's a great place to chill, eat and drink. I can't say I remember much of the food, which I blame on the soju, but I dont remember it being shitty
author: Dennis L.

description:
I must say that this place is very cute, unique and interesting. I was first brought here by my friend when we decided to drink a lil one nite and do some catching up since high school. 

Turns out I ate rice cake for the first time and tried my first yogurt soju. sooo yummy... we also tried strawberry but it was a little one its sweet side.

What I enjoy most about this place is that its sectioned out in front so it feels like u have ur own private area and space but the werid thing is you can hella ease drop on other ppls conversations especially if you know they were drinking.

Also, I came here for my second time with my bf and he absotely loved it. we ordered the kimichi fried rice and rice cake. which he also grew to love. 
Best part of this place is that its open till 2 am. and usually they don't check ids. also a buzzer is at the table for you to call ur waiter
author: Sally Y.

description:
I was very surprised to find so many reviews for this place, not that it is ever dead when I go there but I feel like it is one of those places not many people know about. I am usually one of if not that only white boy in the place when I go, unless I bring other crackers with me :) 

The food is good, the service is decent, what sets it apart is that it is a hidden gem in the city. Once you walk in the garage you are taken away to another country and better yet Korea! OH OH and they have HITE in a large plastic bottle and late night food in the sunset.

All of my friends who lived by there have recently moved, 3 different groups all within a month of each other so if you ever want to go out there I am totally down, just hit me up.
author: Bobby B.

description:
I would say Toyose is the best Korean garage restaurant out there because I don't know of another one. But seriously the food they serve here is better then most Korean restaurants in SF. No Korean BBQ here, you don't get a stove or grill to cook on, although they do have a few BBQ dishes. It's more like traditional home style cooking. A bit on the pricey side, But the food makes up for that. 

I personally think a nice cold beer goes best with hot spicy Korean food. But if you like soju then go for it. Some things to get are their fried chicken, seafood pancake, spicy red tofu soup, spicy noodles, BBQ beef and pork. Everything is spicy here so if cannot take spicy food, stay clear or bring a gallon of milk. But mixing dairy and spicy food has bad news written all over it the next day. I'll stop here.
author: HUNG L.

description:
I really wished that i lived blocks away like the others on this post. This place is awesome after 11 because the law seems to get thrown out the window at this hr. AND OMG the KiM Chi Fried RICE. OMG OMG OMG!!!!!!!!!!! Totally cool to hang out here. Try to keep it in a minimal tab though it tends to rack with alcohol. A hole in the wall! Find it and love it!

Second Act:
Unfortunately Toyose does suffer from one very distinctive flaw. The resturant is as good as the owners mood. Take this in as a fact. If she's in a bad mood. You wont even be seated. O dear, can anyone tell me her favorite flowers and candy?
author: Harry L.

description:
PRO:
- Though this restaurant is in a garage, it sure doesnt feel like it when you walk in. It is on the smaller side, but you have to make due with the space. Pretty impressive for what they've done
- SOJU. Their sojus are amazing, esp yogurt. Very creamy texture--goes down like nothing. Comes out icy cold.
- Chicken wings are a must have, but they have a lot of other deep fried goodness.
- I'm not sure if it comes with the beer, but there's always a complimentary dish of shrimp chips (yum!). Big thumbs up.
- There's a button at each booth to call for service.
- Blinds you can roll down for more privacy with your company in the booths

CONS:
- LONGEST WAIT OF MY LIFE. Seriously, if you go around 1030p, the wait can be up to 2 hrs. I dont even know how i was able to sit through that type of wait TWICE.
- the wait.
- the wait.
- the wait.
- the lack of waiting space. Well, you can go outside, but if its cold, which it usually is, then you're forced to be in the awkward space watching ppl eat and cheers their beer/soju.

TIPS:
- You have to drive pretty slowly down the street and keep an eye out for the place because its a pretty dark street and light is minimal. 
- I dont remember having to park more than a block away either, but be sure to get there before 1030p or be ready for a long wait, unless you get lucky or call in before.

Despite the wait, I still like the place. Their sojus makes it worth it.
author: Rena Y.

description:
I'm going here tonight. This place is AWESOME! This place is always a good time, not too many restaurants like it at all. It's in a garage like atmosphere with hella tiki-like surroundings. Makes you feel from out of town, and nowhere in Sf. Great Soju and Korean food! Thanks Gourment G for helping me remember this place.

Yummy in my tummy!

It is extremely hard to find this place, it's a hidden Korean gem! No signs outside but you have to find it. North side middle of the block...

updates: if you hate people or tolerate people smoking while eating, then this place is not for you. This place can get extremely loud with large parties there. 

Quick note- So beware! Food can take awhile, but if that happens, tell them you want to cancel and they will speed it up.
author: Stanley K.

description:
Serving food in unconventional ways has become all the rage--from food trucks to food carts, Food 2.0 is all about mobile. Toyose puts all that to shame--you are served food that is cooked by a man walking around with a microwave plugged into a random public socket. It's seriously, all about the food.

Okay, just kidding. 

However, there is fun to be made at the fact that Toyose exists in a converted garage deep in the residential zone of the Outer Sunset. The ambience matches the mood of an anju/izakaya style restaurant. At 2am in the morning, you feel like an insider as you push through a minimally marked door and enter a rambunctious house of soju shots and fobby giggles. Outside on the facade of the building, there are no lights betraying the liveliness of the party inside.

Ambience aside, the food holds its own against some of the better late night Korean joints I've had. 

Bad news first--the Korean Fried Chicken is an absolutely letdown. This pales in comparison to Bon Chan and even Kentucky(FC) at it's best. While the skin was crispy and light, the insides were clearly overcooked and the wings were small and dry. The seasoning was reasonable, though it could have had a more Korean bent with more heat and whatever else these star Korean chefs put into their awesome FC (fried chicken). 

Good news--the Kimchee Fried Rice and the Kimchee Tofu Pork were excellent. Both showcased the kimchee well.

4 stars for the overall environment. 
3 stars for the food.
author: Andrew H.

description: I grew up in this restaurant when it was run by my parents and I'm happy to that all of my Dad's old recipes have not changed. Chicken Garage is still what it was ten years ago: a place that serves good korean food. I must say the Katsu and the kimchi fried rice are the necessities to grab here when you're with friends grabbing a beer. Might still look like a hole in the wall type restaurant from the outside but the food and decor inside makes up for it all the way.
author: Nick C.

description:
Imagine my surprise when asked to dine in a garage!  No way!  What about those grease stains or the big question of will there be hubcaps on the walls?  

Being the first to arrive when they opened at 6pm gave me a bit of apprehension-no windows and a sliding door to the place!  But my misgivings gave way as soon as I entered the place.  Really nice decor and no signs of being in a garage.  Service was friendly and helpful.  The seafood pancake was delish and enjoyed the chicken wings-although they could have been spicier.  A little bit on the pricier side and panchan was only a small bowl of pickled daikon.   Left the place in a strawberry soju haze-very nice feeling!
author: Al L.

description: Delicious food, surprisingly clean bathroom, and yummy soju. Go on a weekday and have a reservation- our party of 5 didn't have to wait at all!
author: Janelle V.

description: Aside from the high presentation marks, Toyose was just OK. I went with some friends that swear they know their Korean food. The authenticity of Toyose won their hearts... but not mine. I wasn't a fan of the whole fried chicken. This dry chopped-up discombobulation should have been called whole fried cardboard. The kimchi pancake was quite good. It was the only thing that stood out. Our main dish was the seafood casserole. Mediocre at best. You know something's off when each dead sea critter floating in the soup starts tasting the same or becomes masked by the spiciness of the broth. You know something's off when you don't even know what part of the fish (or is it not fish?) is being served because it's so mutilated. I understand the attraction of cooking your own food at a restaurant (sort of), but waiting that long to even get the cooking started? Maybe it was the lack of soju on a Sunday night. But that shouldn't matter. Because we all know everything tastes and looks better with alcohol. Bottom line is the food needs to stand alone.
author: Michael Paul C.

description: Loved the fried chicken, sea food hot pot and the kim chee pancakes. Great late night find in the quiet outer sunset!
author: Eric M.

description:
don't let the outside fool you their food is pretty damn good. Although it might be really crammed inside, take notice that it IS a garage. And for spicy food eaters, you would love this place. For non-spicy eaters but would want the Korean experience; eat the spicy food and then take shots of soju that will ease the sweats. 

I came here for one of my girlfriends' 21st birthdays,even though i doubt they check id here we ordered the peach soju which wasnt disappointing but i think i still prefer strawberry. 

Another note; don't dress up for this place or else youll be out of the norm.
author: Tracy A.

description:
I have never been to Korea, but I like to imagine that upon entering this garage I am whisked away to a tiny little village restaurant off the beaten path... The little buzzer at the tables are a nice edition...

KIMCHEE FRIED RICE! enough said.

Vanessa took me here for the first time in 2007... No explanation in the world could prepare me for this restaurant hidden in the heart of one of Sunset's neighborhood block... Not the most advertised restaurant from a street-view, but I guess they don't need it since Customer service and good quality Korean food takes precedence...

Favorite things here include: Kimchee Fried Rice and the Seafood Pancake... I have yet to try more traditional meals here... as well as the STRAWBERRY SOJU!
author: Chrysantha C.

description:
333 other reviews...I'm not gonna elaborate, as you can see from others this place rocks.

The converted garage feel actually makes for a semi intimate/friendly place to hang out for some good food and drink.  The Soju here is bomb...and I've gone through 6 - 10 bottles with friends here easily.   Prices are reasonable for food, however if you order a lot of soju like we do, it's crazy expensive. 

Sorry to the guy that left a 1 star review, I'm white and I've never had a problem with service here.  The waitresses are very friendly, and I've never had to wait more than 20 minutes or so.
author: Evan R.

description:
Haven't been here in a while, had dinner here this past Friday.
In my opinion, one does not go to Toyose to eat.  One goes to Toyose to drink.
However,
they do have pretty good food here.
The whole "garage converted into restaurant" thing is inherently cool.
It's one of the things I really enjoy about the place.
This spot would be a whole lot better if the staff gave a little more attentive service.
I mean, at least clear off the finished beer bottles, Sansachun bottles, and empty plates...
author: Barry A.

description:
ok so i think im biased a lil cause i live like 4 blocks from this place so i can get drunk and just walk home haha
first off, korean drinking places in SF is NOT the same shit as they are in LA or SD, LA/SD is at least a billion light years ahead when it comes to korean drinking places, but its nice to see this little gem in the middle of outer sunset, very very random and they do their food right, my mom was not impressed with their BOODAEJJEGAE and wings but i think its b/c she got jealous when i said i liked it haha, their kimchee fried rice was good too

and the flavored soju is pretty standard, but its on point, good enough to get me drunk, ure alright in my book!

3.5 stars
author: Michael K.

description: Good find.  Reasonable prices.  Hole in the wall.  Went on a Wednesday night around 7:30pm and the place was like 45% full.  Fried chicken wings may have been the best I've ever had in my life.  Seafood soup unfortunately was more like octopus soup, that kind of was dissapointing because I was expecting more of a variety like more shrimp, squid, fish, mussels, clams, etc...  Service was great, but I also like to be left alone for the most part.  Clean bathrooms.  WIll definitely be back for another serving of the chicken wings, soju, some kim chee fried rice, and some bulgogi.
author: Danny H.

description:
Vrrrrrrrroooooommmm!  
"Ah crap! Did we miss it?"
"Dude I heard it was a garage. Look for a garage!"
"We're at the beach already, turn around." 
Vrrrrrrooooooommmm!
"Is that it, right there?"
"I dunno. Maybe?"
"Naw that can't be it." 
"Hey we're already closer to Sunset Blvd. turn around." 
Vrrrrrrooooooooommm!
"THERE IT IS. SEE THE BIRD!!"
"OK, keep your pants on. I got it."
"RIGHT THERE! THE GARAGE!
"I got it. Hmm parking,parking...ah right here."
"DUDE IT'S A GARAGE! IT REALLY IS. COOL!"
"Not in my ear!"

Easy to miss this place. It's located in the outer OUTER Sunset, Noriega and 40something. K-style booth seating. Chicken wing app was interesting; a type Bulgogi dish; soup; and a Pajeon (green onion pancake) were all good. Couple of OB's and you're sitting pretty. With good friends and good convo, you can't beat a night at Toyose. Another plus, they're open late!!

3 duckets for atmosphere and the novelty garage. Minus 1 ducket for being way the hell out there! Minus another ducket for my having eaten the piece of squid that made me pay!!
author: Johnny C.

description:
i love the atmostphere here the music is amazing! love their mashups!!!

i ordered like mixed rice or something but i didnt like it ,i usualy just get the flavored soju here , and like some sides i love their onion rings thats all i can say!!   ,
flavored soju 11-12 and so many flavored i try em all ! :D
author: eric l.

description:
went on a date here earlier this year.. what a surprise :D 

it's located in this garage. SO AWESOMELY COOL! ehhehehe tight space. was like an  L shape. i had the chicken wings. very yum! some yogurt soju - a must! anddddddddd the hot pot tofu soup. so muchhh food. and also spicy kimchi fried rice = spicy lovers dream.

:D i will be back to show my friends! girls were cute, hence my date staring away at them. hahaha
author: Jenna L.

description:
To be fair, we only have the spicy chicken wings + yogurt soju...but the chicken was too dry and not super tasty. the yogurt soju was ok. 
but yes, it was quite pricey for ok chicken. 
but great, gritty late-nite bar ambience
i would go back to try other dishes since it seems fairly popular...
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
This restaurant offers a nice ambiance considering it's in a garage (As with most of the reviews is quite possibly what sets it apart from other Korean Restaurants). It's quite easy to find parking and the wait isn't too bad. My favorite dish is the kim chi fried rice and the spicy caserole. I don't want to make any generalizations about the food, so I'll just say that it definitely hits the spot whenever I'm craving for some Korean food.

I recommend this place.
author: Jason N.

description:
I guess I don't eat at Korean restaurants too often, this wasn't what I expect at a typical Korean place. Everything comes out pre-cooked and I didn't see any BiBimBap.
I liked the KimChee pancakes, that was something I hadn't tried before - I already admit that I don't eat Korean food often, right?
My mom thought the atmosphere was cute but as others have described, I think gritty is the perfect word. The waitresses, although nice were not very attentive. But the food was decent and it's in my new 'hood.
author: JaM W.

description: Honestly, besides the soju here everything else is pretty so so and the service here is pretty bad. Most of the time, when i come to this restaurant, i always see these two waitresses who always dress very " Korean style". They always have this conceited look on their face, with their head held high and stuff, i am not even exaggerating  and they would never smile to greet me or any of my friends. They either rudely take us to our seats or takes forever to get a hold of them and ask how long the wait is. Most of the time, when there wait is around an hour and i see those "bitchy" attitudes on their faces, while desperately trying to wave at them and get them to come over and they would see you but just ignore you for a good 10 minutes before coming over. I would just turn my back and leave this restaurant. This place gets a lot of youngsters, so i guess younger customers never really care that much about service, that explains why they have their 4 star rating and the soju is good here.. But, meh i had better service and food, so they are not getting a high rating from me.
author: Swifty L.

description:
I'll admit ... Michael N did have to eat Jack in the Box aftewards ... but we did spend some of that money on alcohol.

They key to this place is: don't order the $30 "garbage stew" totally not worth it ... you can make that at home ... it definitely kicked up the bill a lot.
author: Alex C.

description: I've been coming here for the past 15 years for drinks and late night snacks.  My first reaction was that we were eating in a garage. You get used to the environment after awhile.  Now-a-days I'll just pop in for a quick late night snack: Spicy Chicken Wings, spicy rice cake etc.  There's not too many Korean drinking places left in the City.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Unfortunately, a big disappointment.  Service was awful, but the chicken wings were great.  They were definitely the best Korean fried chicken I've ever had.

Won't be going back, though.  :*(
author: C L.

description:
The best korean restaurant in SF (in my opinion).

Everything we ordered was absolutely yummy! 
Tofu soup YUM!
Mandoo YUM!
Steamed egg YUM!

Oh, & the interesting thing about the restaurant is that it's located in a garage.
author: Ryoko Y.

description:
I came here with a few friends to celebrate a birthday two Sundays ago. Even though it was a Sunday, we still had to make reservations because space is limited for big parties. Popularly nicknamed "the garage," Toyose is not your typical Korean restaurant with BBQ and meat. However, they still provide a large variety in food selection. We ordered:

Rice cakes in chili paste: The rice cakes were a little on the hard side for me. Probably won't order this dish again.
Spam Casserole: This dish consists of spam, hot dogs, rice cakes, kimchee and two packages of ramen all boiled together in a hot pot stove. Hmmm Mmmm!
Beef Potstickers: This had to be my favorite dish of them all!!! The flavors were fantastic. 
Seafood Pancake: One of the best seafood pancakes I've ever had and the portions were large.
Fried Chicken: We only ordered this after the waitress mistakenly placed it on our table and we all thought it looked delicious. However, we were wrong and it looked better than it tasted. 

Though the food is good, the best thing about Toyose has to be the SOJU! For $11 a bottle, they have many flavors ranging from yogurt to pineapple. I'm definitely coming here again!
author: Julia K.

description: I'll just let it out, I hate girl drinks but the soju wasn't bad at all. I ate there with a friend and we went through 3 of them... pineapple, strawberry, and yogurt. Ok, glad I got that out of the way. We order the popular stuff like the kimchee fried rice and the chicken wings. They were good although, I wish the wings were a bit more spicy. We also had an order of the bulgogi. Usually, when I order it, the taste is pretty strong or a better way of putting, it's heavily marinated. This one was mild, which I guess suits my palate better. Try to get there when they first open(at 6pm) because even on a weekend, I promise you it will be packed by like 7. Suprisingly, I parking was easy. Oh, make sure you press the 'button' where your table is located to get their attention.
author: Conrad C.

description: I tried to make a reservation for 2 on the phone on Friday night, and they tell me that they only accept reservations for 4+.  And they said for 2 just show up and we'll get a seat.  So we go through the trouble of driving all the way there on my first date, and walk in and they tell us that the wait is 1 hour and 15 min.  I was so mad.  Why couldn't these punk asses tell us that over the phone instead of making us waste so much of our time driving there?  So we just left and looked for another restaurant.  They have some major discriminatory practices here.  One day they will diss the wrong person, get sued, and it's all over.
author: Snoopy D.

description: Great Korean comfort foods, good prices, nice servers, delicious  favorites. Makes me feel like I'm back in Asia. Our favorite date night location, and a great place to take friends.  Pineapple soju is yummy.
author: Heather S.

description:
Like the stars say - 4 stars = Yay, I am a fan. We went here on Saturday night at about 9pm. We pull up and yes, it is seriously a garage. Well, garage turned restaurant now. If you drove by, you'd never know this decently decorated restaurant existed. We walk in and its packed. There's only like 4 booths plus a few more tables in the back, but nonetheless its packed. We ask how long the wait is and find out 30 minutes from one waitress and one hour from another waitress. We talk to them again asking why the wait is so long (even though all the tables were full, it shouldn't be that long) and they report that there are reservations supposed to be coming in. Well after talking it out with them longer, they agree to give us a booth where the party is almost finished. Sweet deal, we only waited about 10 min. I guess you could say they accommodated us, but we had to talk our way into it. From that rocky start, I was kinda feeling eehh, but it smelled so good in there and I was starving so here we went.

So we're seated and given popcorn as an appetizer. Yes, popcorn. And it was pretty darn good (or maybe we were all just that hungry). We ordered the kimchi fried rice, casserole with the seafood, and the bulgogi/calamari combination plate. The bulgogi and calamari hit the spot. It came out sizzling and had an amazing combination of flavors. The casserole was alright. It was a really large pot of spicy soup with mushrooms, other veggies, pork, seafood, and anything else they threw in there. It was good at first, but I think the broth lost its appeal after the third or fourth serving. My favorite was the kimchi fried rice. I expected spicier, but I'm glad that it wasn't. Overall, I was pleased with the food.

My bf and I also shared a peach soju. No complaints there. It's soju, what else do I say?

Service was fine. The waitresses were pretty busy with all the tables, but they do have a convenient little bell that you can ring to get their attention. They're pretty good about responding to that. 

Price-wise.. it's okay. Their bottle of soju is a good deal, but I felt like we spent more than we should have. I think next time I won't get the casserole. Instead I want to try the spicy chicken wings that everyone else raves about or one of their pancakes. So obviously, I will be coming back.
author: Danielle G.

description: An enjoyable place to spend an evening. Decent food.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
I do love this place as an after happy hour joint to keep the buzz going and feed the belly.  After hearing about this place from friends, the idea of going to a garage to drink soju was beyond me.  But after coming here, it's one of my favorite watering holes, although the wait can be horrible at times.  I'd recommend the yogurt soju, but I tend to stay away from the strawberry one because of the little seeds in it.  Also, you've gotta try the potstickers and the fried chicken!  They both go great with your drinks.
Warning: If you don't like the smell of smoke, you may not like this place.
author: Allan H.

description:
Gambei!  Soju fusion time. Need a place to hang out for drinks and quick snack?  Now if we can just get that start up rock band going in here, this place can be condsidered the local club.  Tucked away near the beach on Noriega, this house converted their garage and Toyose was born.
Most come for late nite drinks -- the flavored Sojus, snacks, and more soju.  If yuo can cuont the shots youev had, yu haven't ahd enough, so tyr an0ter bottel! Cheers!
author: Eric Y.

description:
Love going to Soju places and this is one of my favorites.  Just because it seems more laid back than most of them.  The food is pretty good and if you got Soju and some Korean beer to wash it down.  Well, all you need is a few friends to share the experience with.  And voila, the drinks will lead to some good conversation and some good times.....


Be careful though, if you are not careful, you will miss the place cause it indeed is a converted garage and is a little hard to spot if you are not looking for it.  Can you say Korean Speakeasy.....
author: Mark W.

description:
This place is tiny and very inconspicuous from the street reminding me of many establishments in NY.  The food was yummy, but the portions were a little small for my liking.  

Koreans definitely know how to make good chicken!  The fried chicken wings are sooo crispy!  The beef kimchi fried rice and seafood pancake were also yummy.  The bugolgi was oober tender and flavorful.  Since the place is small...be prepared to wait!
author: Maria D.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Some spicy dry udon dish
2.) Some other spicy doughy noodle thing
3.) Rice with them tiny pickled dishes
Overall, good. Gets kinda spicy tho :P

SERVICE:
She was nice, a little language barrier, got the nifty Korean service button on the table -__-

ATMOSPHERE:
I love how this little Korean hideaway is so inconspicuous from the outside. Now I know why everyone just calls it "the garage" :P Inside looks like a Korean bar
author: Angela L.

description:
Toyose is also known as the Garage.  Go there for yourself, and/or see pictures and you'll know why.  Someone transformed their garage, or someone else's garage, into a cute little Korean restaraunt.  

This is my favorite place in San Francisco to get strawberry flavored soju.  Compared to the other places where it's more watery, I like how Toyose blend real strawberries (or maybe the frozen ones) into the cocktail.

I really like their kimchi stew.  It's a fairly big bowl with huge chunks of tofu and meat. My friend also ordered the seafood pancake which was pretty thick and a good size.  It had a lot of calamari, shrimp, and vegetables in it.  The seafood pancake was good, but a little too mushy for me.  I prefer the thinner and crispier kimchi pancake.  

Toyose is a nice place for a smaller group of friends to come together to drink and eat with a more intimate setting.
author: Katherine C.

description: Late night food!  The beef kimchi fried rice and seafood pancake is so good!  Call ahead and make a reservation.  We were there on a Saturday night and there was a 2 hour wait.  If you are looking for quiet dining experience, this is not the place to go.
author: Ren A.

description:
I really like this place.  It's very "Korean."  Love that it's an old garage. 

So, who doesn't like flavored soju?  They have delicious flavors, I love the lemon.  The chicken wings are hella good.  Reminds me of the fried chicken in Korea (good thing).  Also, we shared some type of soup (sorry I can't remember the name) that had mussels in it.  Super tasty.  

I will be back one day, hopefully soon.
author: Sarah F.

description: I used to come here a lot for the kimchi fried rice, bulgogi and soju. Was one of my favorite spots to go to for korean food but the last few times I've been was disappointing. The food wasn't as good as before. Maybe it's just me, but I'll keep going back for their soju.
author: Lucy T.

description:
I've been here once before but I think I finally got the appeal about this place last night.  It is literally in a someone's garage and has a dark but incredibly homey feeling.  The walls are plastered with Lee Hyori Soju ads with Korean music thumbing in the background.  As it gets later into the night, more people fill this joint, making you feel like you are getting closer to the people in your party. The food is good and you are amongst good people.  What is there not to like.   

If you like spicy, this is the place for you.  Everything we ordered was literally RED and all of us had a glistening glow on our faces from sweating.  We ordered 5 dishes - I would highly recommend the chicken yummies...lol...I mean the chicken wings, kimchee fried rice, and the kimchee pancakes (#46).  The wings are crispy on the outside but juicy on the inside, the kimchee fried rice with bits of fried egg, beef, and veggies, and seaweed was moist, spicy, flavorful...JUST try it.  And make sure you grab the end pieces of the kimchee pancakes as those are the crispiest. :)  The fruit soju drinks are good...especially the peach. 

We also had the rice cake with ramen dish (#11) and the spam/hot dog/kimchee ramen casserole but I thought they were ok.  I'm not a big fan of rice cake and felt the flavors were a bit off.

Anyways, it is a great place for a group of friends to unwind after a 'freaken drive me crazy' work week.  We got there at 6:30 and grabbed a table for 6...right before it got PACKED.
author: Rose J.

description:
go GO GO GO 

everything was delish (read: fried) and we got:
-beef potstickers (YES)
-spicy wings (not as spicy as I would have liked, but YES)
-prawn fried rice (yum with some interesting sweetness... YES)
-chicken cutlet (YES)

yes, we did not step outside of the box too much, but it was my first foray into this garage restaurant, so cut me some slack.

also, it's teeny tiny so if you have a large group, call ahead for reservations.

p.s.
there is a waitress call button... and xmas lights (YES and YES)
author: Josie A.

description: Awesome Korean restaurant in the Sunset. The kimchi fried rice is awesome and the soups are huge and filled with lots of great stuff. Ask them about portions because some dishes are really big and others are smaller. Nice atmosphere - definitely different from the typical Korean restaurant.
author: Tom T.

description:
No way we're ever coming back here again!

First of all, the place looked so shady and there were so many people packed in such a small space. It was really stuffy in there. Plus, the place made us nervous the whole time we were there because it literally looks like a FIRE HAZARD... 
There were only 2 small doors, I'm not clear if the back door is locked. There were some windows but they were all obstructed by posters and whatnot... There was no ventilation because the windows weren't opened.. Seems like they don't care if we suffocate..

We give the food 2 stars.
The reason we went there was because we craved for kimchi fried rice... But they couldn't even satisfy our cravings. The dish was bland and almost tasteless. There was so little kimchi or beef in it.
Tappoki and spicy pork+tofu+kimchi was okay.

Overpriced for the quality and quantity.

Naturally, we left with our clothes smelling horrible, just like the restaurant.
author: Roland R.

description:
what a hidden gem. literally.

raves over the kimchi fried rice are legit. it's delicious. scrumptious. havent tried anything else on the menu, nor do i care to as im completely satisfied with this hearty dish.

$11 mango soju - icing on the cake.

parking isnt too bad. front seating is a little more intimate, back room can get rowdy, but this is to be expected of cheap delish soju + 2am close time.
author: Rica R.

description:
made my way back here with the roommate for weekend late night noms. had the seafood casserole (like a steamboat/hotpot), and it was chock-full of goodies!! loved the many types of seafood and vegetables that they stuffed in there, it was like a treasure trove, for serious! mussels, clams, fish, fish eggs, prawns, crab claws, calamari rings, enoki mushrooms, carrots, and various veggies. you also get a hunk of noodles to cook in the bubbling pot. excellent for when the night is cold and blustery. just remember to take out the fish pieces before they overcook and get all unattractively tough and rubbery!

my roommate and i being legit chubbies, ordered along with the bigass casserole, a plate of kimchi fried rice with beef and egg. almost $11 for what i think is a modest serving of fried rice, hmmm not too sexy, HOWEVER, they sprinkle some crazy good magic crack dust nonsense on that thing, and we ended up ordering a second plate of kimchi fried rice, after demolishing the casserole and first place of rice between just the two of us.

got damn, we's food troopers.

on another visit, had more chicken wings - still tasting super yummy and so necessary at 1.15am - and tried out their kimchi pancake. very addictive, i must say! even without the accompanying dipping soy sauce with chopped chillies, the pancake was extremely moreish. gone fast.

and of course, we rounded up supper with...a plate of kimchi fried rice.

GOT DAMN, WE'S FOOD TROOPERS.
author: Eliza D.

description: Why didn't I realize upon entering the restaurant I was actually going into a converted garage? Why didn't I think about the picture of the chicken in the front? It was only after eating at this fine establishment, I realized I went into a "Chicken Garage" restaurant and didn't order any chicken??? How silly of me??!?!?! We ordered the sea bass soup and beef Bulgogi. Both were delicious and came out quite quickly. I give this place a solid 3.5 stars, but I have to admit it's one very long trip for someone coming from SOMA.
author: Lisa R.

description: Toyose is my new fave Korean spot. Converted from a garage in the Outer Sunset, the restaurant blends in with the block of single-family units and is a hidden gem. Once inside, the restaurant is cozy and intimate. Their peach soju cocktail is my favorite drink in the city (disclaimer: I like girly drinks). I also like the bulgolgi here which is sauteed with veggies and mushrooms but overpriced.
author: Diana B.

description:
normally, this place would be 5 Stars... but the last time i went here wasn't so great.  But of course, i will go here again.

I LOVE their bul go gi ... the best!  it's not dry... SOOOOO juicy (but the last time i was here, it was not so great)

also love their Kimchi & Spam Casserole.

Strawberry soju is yummy too.
author: Joanne H.

description:
Sports a consistent kitchen that serves up great korean dishes that pair perfectly with their tasty soju cocktails- you must try the yogurt and strawberry flavors. =)  Delectable banchan, spicy chicken wings, pajoon, kim chee or taroko doobu.  

June, Ream, and Young are incredible waitresses that will tend to your needs b4 the bell is needed (except for weekends after 11pm) open till 2am.  Soshite 1030p no ato de tabako suwate daijoubu.
author: omar b.

description:
This place is so freakin cool! it's a korean restaurant in the garage of a house in the sunset! I've been here a dozen times to eat and drink b/c they don't close til really late. You wouldn't think that the ambiguous yellow duck on the outside is an invitation to eat, drink, and be merry. The  inside decor is really interesting...kinda boatish and they have these buttons on the wall at your table so you can call your waitress for something. The service here is always great and the food too. Dishes that I always get are:

FRIED CHICKEN: the wings are fried right when you order them and it's a light crispy batter with tender juicy meat on the inside ...not too thick and greasy.

SEAFOOD GREEN ONION PANCAKE: I just love this dish. it's huge and filling. It comes with a hodgepodge of seafood including shrimp and squid.

KIMCHI FRIED RICE: This dish is always a safe bet...it's just fried rice with kimchi and it's spicy juices w/ a fried egg on top.

DUK BOKKI: this is on of my favorites. Make sure you get this with ramen. the noodles just sop up the spicy sauce and it's just gooood. this dish has rice cakes, fish cakes, green onions, cabbage, carrots, and onions. 

The soju here is excellent too. it's the perfect soju to fruit juice.. not too sweet and syrupy like at other korean places. My favorite is the peach soju. This place is small and gets crowded on friday and saturday nights, so call ahead and make a reservation...yes...the restaurant-in-the-garage takes reservations :)
author: Ivy L.

description: Good korean pancakes, fantastic ambiance. The only thing that keeps it from getting 5 stars is that it's very crowded. Oh yea and when I got home my mom asked me if I had bbq. Yes the BBQ smell won't leave you afterwards. Don't wear anything too nice. I'll come back here to drink soju next time I'm in the city.
author: Gary Y.

description:
Affectionately referred to as the "Chicken Garage", this is yet another Sunset hangout for the young'uns. Decent Korean food combined with Soju makes for a good time with the friends (You can pack 6 or 7 to a table), and there is ample parking, to boot. The Korean pancakes and the Kimchee fried rice are awesome, albeit a tad overpriced.

If you're looking for it, you can't miss it. It's a garage. There's a picture of a chicken outside. Did I mention it's a garage?
author: Karl K.

description:
I finally was able to try this place tonight, since I read everyone else's reviews..Of all the places I have tried Korean food in the Bay Area, this place tops the list. Love that it's an old garage. 

All their dishes on their menu are very delicious. I tried the seafood pancake, chicken wings, spicy rice cake, and the hot pot with spam, tofu, & ramen were all good choices. They serve the best pancake i tried..it's so crispy.

I also tried the strawberry, yogurt and pineapple soju all in one night. I think the strawberry & yogurt soju are the best. I definitely got buzzed tonight after a stressful day of work.

What else is cool is you literally have to ring a bell at your table to call for a waitress to serve you. The service doesn't automatically come to you:)

They also recommend reservations because the place can get packed. You will not get a table if you just walk in. I tried it before.
author: Jenny K.

description:
This place is cool. 

First of all, it looks like a garage from the outside. There is a sign and some tube lights, but you aren't sure what to make of it from first glance. 

Inside, low ceilings, private booths with screens to pull down for privacy, and tables with buzzers for you to call your server. 

They serve delicious Korean food like the kim chi fried rice (with a friend egg on top), which is the best fried rice that I've ever had. The fried chicken is great too, and when you order a casserole, or stew, they serve it to you on a burner that they bring to your table. 

And did I mention the Soju? Soju in 5 or 6 fruit flavors like Strawberry, PIneapple, Peach, Lemon, and maybe Lychee. The strawberry is the most popular and it's like drinking sweet nectar The sweetness compliments the spicy food really well. 

Also, it's open till 2 am. I can't wait to go back.
author: Netty L.

description:
I just come here for the food these days.  It's good and the price is decent.  I'm in love with the casseroles and the rice cake dish (dukbokgyi).  This place is more of a korean bar type place, so you don't get panchan (side dishes).  We always end up ordering too much when we come here because everything looks good.  

On Friday and Saturday nights this place can get packed with people there to drink.  I've come here and gotten turned away because the wait was....well there was no wait because they were packed until closing.  When that happens I resort to TheSpot.
author: Tokki M.

description:
Tonight I went to Toyose after hearing about it from a few friends, who have never ever tried it, but also just heard about it --the restaurant in a garage -- no way!! only in San Francisco I guess, where everyone turns their garage into something to make some extra money.

It really is a garage, but when you walk in, you'll see plenty of tables to sit in. The hostess station, which I guess isn't really one, is in the middle of the room off to the side... so I guess you just walk in and take a table.  We actually had reservations for 6:30pm, and they told us to not be late... but when we walked in, it was empty!  We were the first people in the joint.  Around 7pm, more people trickled in, and by 7:30pm, the place was packed.  

The menu isn't full of your traditional korean dishes that you find at Brothers or My Tofu House.  It had different combos, like Calamari and Bulgolgi, Casseroles (more like hot pots), and variety of appetizers.  We got the Sausage, spam, pork, fish cake casserole in spicy broth.  This had a nice spicy flavor to it, along with some sweetness.  It was REALLLLY good.  A lot of other tables ended up getting it too.  It's definitely big enough to share between 4-5 people.  We also got the kimchi pancake, which I have never seen anywhere.  It was pretty good!  They also have a menu page labeled "Hot Pots" but it's really similar to the casseroles, but just smaller.  The casseroles are about $22.95, depending on what kind you get, and the hot pots are about $13.95-15.95 (I think).  They didn't give us the popcorn tho, or any of the side dishes to munch on while they were making out food.  That was kind of disappointing.  They brought out 4 small side dishes to share between 6 people... SERIOUSLY?! c'man!  Kind of ridiculous... you know we're going to order more in like 2 seconds.

Overall, the food was fantastic!  The restaurant really looked like a restaurant =P  The bill between 6 people for 1 appetizer, and 3 entrees was about $58 = $13.35 / person.  Can't beat that!

Parking can be difficult tho, it's right in the middle of a residential area =P
author: Diane L.

description:
Solid Korean. Fried chicken was delicious, mandoo/dukboki combi was good too. I would definitely come back.

Chief complaints: the spot was way out west, and it was also pretty cold inside - I always underestimate San Franciscan winters. Bring friends and get crunk. Just make sure you have a D.D., you damn Cali folk.
author: Joseph L.

description:
Yes, you're eating in someone's "garage."  But it's not really a garage, it's palace of tastiness.  The fish cake soup is superb and their kim chee fried rice is classic.  We've had KCFR at a lot of Korean restaurants and this one ranks in the top three.

It's located in Outer Sunset, so be prepared to drive out there if you're from the real "city."  It's hidden inside the deep grid of matchbox houses, so if you feel like you're driving through a half-sketchy neighborhood, you're in the right place.  The truth is, it's not that sketchy and it's not that drab-- it's the weather that drives the mood.  Come here on a hot summer day and you'll think you're in East L.A. (Okay, not a good comparison).

Anyways, this is not your Korean BBQ place.  We're Chinese so for the non-Koreans, this is not the kind of restaurant you go to and eat bulgogi with dol sot bi bab.  They have beef but it's not the kind that comes out on a searing platter.  We'd get more technical, but this all sounds better in layman's terms.  They also don't have the small dishes of seaweed, tofu, pickled cucumber, and other random snacks.  This place is all about single orders, so be mentally prepared.

Also, it's not smoky and humming like Korean BBQ places.  They blast Kpop music, so be prepared for some S.E.S-flavored (we like old school beats) melodies.  The decor is also nice.  The low ceilings and compartments make the place feel intimate, as if your ah-jim-mah was cooking you some hearty meal.

Overall, great place to stop by if you're around the area.  It's open until 2 a.m., so it's perfect for the Sunset clubbers (that's a joke).  Beware of the serious Asian crowd... if you're non-Asian, you WILL stand out. 

We couldn't give this place four stars simply because of service.  It's a bit pricey ($10-15 plates), so one would compare this to My Tofu House or a value-priced Brothers and say it's sub-par.

That's our perspective. We're aware that we generalized all Korean food, which is very ignorant, but it's easier for review purposes.  We like reading reviews where people compare Hong Kong bistro cuisine with Panda Express.  Seriously.  It's entertaining.  Yeah, it's the same. =)
author: Kel S.

description:
I completely got the atmosphere here...and also the Japanese influence. Now, did I get the hype? Meh!
Strawberry shoju was divine but I could tell that my pancreas was struggling and insulting me for jugging all that sugar. We may have had the wrong dishes but all the seafood was way overcooked (read "gummy" ) and the "pizza lookin' thing" (thanks Nobu K.), a sort of okonomiyaki, was dripping in rancid-tasting oil.
Big downer...not even the kimchi was very good. 
Alas...this reminded me of la "Taverna del Vento" a place where we used to go when 15-16, eat terrible food (I mean good, but nutritionally questionable), jug beers and laugh hard.
At least Toyose had a more intimate feel...how can you beat eating in a garage?
author: Dario B.

description: This place was pretty good. The exterior is kind of surprising for a lot of people since it's pretty much a house, but I liked the interior a lot.  My friends and I came here tonight (a Thursday) around 9 and were seated quickly. I hear the weekends are difficult but if you can, just come on a Thursday night! Just lively enough, but not crowded so you'd have to wait. We ordered kimchee fried rice, chicken wings, and 3 bottles of soju (strawberry, pineapple, and yogurt). Everyone really liked the kimchee fried rice, the wings were alright (crispy exterior, but not particularly juicy) and the soju was pretty good. We all liked the strawberry the best. You could tell that there were real strawberries involved in the making of this soju because there were seeds at the bottom of the bottle. The pineapple kind of just tasted like slightly watered down pineapple juice. The yogurt soju was pretty strong tasting as the yogurt flavor didn't mask the soju taste as well as the other flavors. Overall good experience. Decent food, good soju drinks, lively/cozy environment and prompt service.
author: Sannie L.

description:
Kimchi Beef fried rice w/ egg- Yummy!
Spicy chicken wings (8 of 10 were chicken drums, not wings) were not spicy at all!

It is located in a home's garage, not a place anyone would expect to find a restaurant. I've lived in the neighborhood for 10 years but never realized there's such a restaurant on Noriega.

Too bad they don't make the flavored soju in a smaller size. Two of us could not finish the whole jar.

They have a service bell at each table, the server gets to your table within 5 seconds of you ringing the bell. Cool uh?

A little bit pricey: pancake, rice and wings, for two people = $40
author: Pauline H.

description:
not too shabby.  

1.  the food was on par with sf korean food - so just ok.
2.  price-wise, little pricier than other sf korean joints.
3.  service - was ok as well, but slightly sub-par relative to a nicer korean restaurant.
4. ambiance - it feels more like a korean drinking place so perfect for that ... except it's really dark and stuff.  

overall, if you don't live in the area i'm not sure that it's worth driving out to.  if you live there ... or want something open until 2am ... then this is a reasonable spot to get your fix.

enjoy!
author: Good U.

description:
I am not a fan of spicy food but man this place was good.
Its crazy that its in a garage.  But the food is super good.
Prices are low too.  I will def eat here again.
author: Justin I.

description:
I just went here last night with some of my high school friends and what a spot it is.. couldnt believe it when my friends said it's a house in which they converted the garage to a restaurant. so it's definitely a small place.

had three friends who've been there before so they went ahead and ordered beer and 2 sojus.. strawberry [seemed to be everyone's fav] and a cool pinapple. place is a bit pricy--i shared the spicy chicken wings which was 12.95 and another friend ordered the kimchee with egg which was 11.95. not to mention soju is 11. food is quite good tho but definitely not worth its price.

at the end of the night.. we had a good buzz and a good tab... $117 for 8 of us.
author: JJ C.

description: The wait here is kinda long, but the wait is sooooo worth it!! There kimchi fried rice is hella bomb!! The garlic fried chicken is crunchy and juicy. There garlic cheese fries is yummy!!
author: Vanessa B.

description:
This place is nuts.  Literally, someone gutted their garage and built a pretty funky bar in it.  Pretty wild, I gotta say.  

Good late night food...kim chi fried rice, some tofu dish, a fish cake soup and some korean pancakes were sampled.  

Also tried an extensive sampling of the flavored soju beverages.  Yogurt is still king.  Nothing beats yogurt.  
Great place for a crowd if you reserve a table.  You can be loud, boisterous and no one will give a rats ass.
author: Mike C.

description: My friends and I frequent "The Garage".  The door bell in your booth is such a kick to have.  Service is always pretty good.  We've tried a few things on the menu but we never get tired of the kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, chicken wings and the soju.
author: she q.

description:
We needed a place to eat that was open late, so we decided to try Toyose since we were craving Korean food!

We got here around 10pm and on a foggy night, it is a littlle bit creepy in this neighborhood. But once you walk in its surprising to see how well transformed this restaurant is. 

Prices are a little bit steep, we ordered the Spicy Fried Chicken wings and the Beef Casserole Soup. They both came out to be $43! 

The casserole is BIG, but it doesn't have enough noodles. If you like cabbage then this is for you. But otherwise at $26 a bowl it could use some more noodles. It  could feed about 4 people if you are not too hungry. 

I would come back again! For a Thursday night it was pretty busy. However, since the restaurant is a little small, large parties will be a little bit annoying to sit next to. Especially after they've been drinking all that Soju! :)
author: Jo L.

description: Two words: corn cheese.  Best I've had anywhere.  Fried rice and flavored soju are also both good, as are the korean pancakes.  Not much more to say.  It's in a garage!  (My friends and I call this place "the garage."
author: Ken L.

description: This little Korean restaurant is awsome! The seafood pancake is great
author: Kin M.

description: Food is bomb. Cool late night weekday date spot.
author: Sarah L.

description: I really don't get the hype over this place. I've been here three times and there is always a ton of people. If you are coming with a group (like more than 4), definitely call for a reservation. They only have 1 table that can fit more than 8 people. The food was okay, but nothing amazing. My favorite was the kimchi fried rice and the fried chicken wings. The portions were kinda small and they don't give you much banchan. I feel that the menu is kinda expensive too. We spent more than $25+ per person and we weren't completely full when we left. Their yogurt soju was pretty tasty tho. I liked it. The restaurant itself feels really cramped. The seats were really tight and there were a lot of people. Very hard to walk around everyone to get to the restroom.
author: Annie L.

description:
I went there for dinner, but i think i shoulda gone 2 hours later and 2x more drunker in order to give em a 5 star.  But i'll admit, i can see why people enjoy this place for the homestyle korean food and the soju.  my o my the soju.  

we had the yogurt and strawberry.  strawberry was a lil too sweet and on the girly side, well to be honest they all were.  but the yogurt one is always my favorite and its been hard to find something like this in the city after i tried it in NY.  but definitely the soju is well worth it

The food we got was the kimchi fried rice, the fried chicken wings, the seafood pancake, and the tofu stew.  all really tasty and something different from the usual korean bbq type food.  i can't say it was great but good.  and just the vibe and the soju made it a 4 star place.  

but again, having it open till 2am, i'm sure i woulda loved it if i was more drunk and came in till closing just kickin it wit some friends.
author: Vincent K.

description:
I have only been here twice, but every visit I make is always packed with people (mainly Korean, some Chinese).  It's hard to spot this place as it looks pretty much like a house.  They have food but more importantly, drinks.  I haven't had much of the food to be honest, but others say it's pretty good (the potstickers and kimchi fried rice).  Drinks are decent and pretty reasonable, but don't expect the flavored soju to do much.  It has like, no alcohol in it.

And they're open pretty late, so if you live in outer Sunset, want to chill for a while, without really going out, this place will do the job.
author: Yosie G.

description:
Yogurt shoju is like candy.
Tofu soup is filled with stuff.
Mandoo is the best in the city so far.
Egg custard is always divine.
Service...start ringing them bells!
Parking has never been a problem in that neighborhood.
No popcorn for me please...
They give you popcorn to "start".

I actually do crave this place.
author: Elisa O.

description:
Yum...Toyose is another place in SF that I must try again...and again and again.  It seems like a great spot to go to when you have late night cravings or somewhere to ummm...sober up with some good food.  

My friends and I came here to get our grub on after leaving that stinkin' place, Holy Cow.  We got greedy and ordered two dishes and a soup: the beef & calamari, spicy pork and kimchi, and the seafood & tofu soup.  All very delicious.  The soup was a little on the salty side after it cooled down though, but it was no biggie.  We ended up packing up a lot of the food leftover and had it for a tasty breakfast the next day.

I love the interior of the place.  It feels very home-y and intimate.  I didn't make use of the restroom, but my friend wanted me to mention that "their restroom is incredibly well-kept for a place that harbors drunks late night."

We had no problems with the service here.  The bell was very useful to get the waitress's attention.  I forget the total of our bill, but it was definitely worth the price for the good food.

Next time, I'm trying the soju!
author: Zee W.

description: It's an interesting hot spot hidden in a garage. The minute you enter this joint, you feel as if you've stepped below street level, and into some misadventure right out of "The Goonies" or "Big Trouble in Little China".  Pirates could be opening the door based on the dark wood interior, and the semi-seafaring theme.  I can only imagine that parking during the day would be crazy, so i can see why this might be a good spot to try at night.
author: Bonene G.

description:
I was craving for Korean food and I've passed by this place for the last few months during my volunteer work in the school nearby -- so me and my Bear decided to try it out.

THey opened at 6 and we got there like at 6.15 so it was pretty empty then. We ordered 3 dishes and we finsihed everything! :D 
We ordered chicken giblets (sth like gizzards?) and it's on a sizzling plate.. it's a little too oily and burnt; and become flavorless after we tried the other spicier dishes. We also ordered sth like a Korean Salad (forgot the name), with apples, cabbage and shellfish and bunch of other veggie.. it's VERY spicy but i really like it. I have never tried anything like that in other Korean restaurant. THe third dish we ordered is a hot pot (tofu soup with fish) -- it's not as spicy as the salad dish and the soup taste really good with rice.

The only complaint is the lack of variety of the side dishes... they should have a larger variety like other korean restaurant.. 
But over all it's a very good, garage restaurant (I think the owner and family lives upstairs).
author: Doris H.

description: come here for the kim chi fried rice. it's THAT good.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I love this place...from my first strawberry soju - I knew we were def a match made in heaven.  I've only been here twice, but I plan on coming back again and again...

First off - it's in a garage!  You would think that the food would not be as good as it is - but it'll surprise you!  My friends and I ordered the casserole - kind of like a hotpot style with kimchi and ramen noodle thrown on top...wish they gave us more noodles tho...their pancakes were delicious - crispy and oily...we also had the kimchi fried rice - good but not out of this world...their fried chicken is def something you should order...yes to the yogurt soju...

service was ok - only one girl running around serving everyone...I understand the neglect - don't make it right but I can empathize...I don't see the point of the buzzer - I don't think they even hear it...

But for me, the soju will have me coming back.  It creates an atmosphere where friends can just kick back and be loud and obnoxious as they want...I hope they pass zoning laws!
author: Julie H.

description: I've been here a few times now and Toyose  is very consistent with the quality of their food. My favorites so far are: Kimchi pancake, Beef & Squid bulgogi, Kimchi fried rice, Japchae, Spicy Chicken Wings, and the dried fish platter that is best served with a round of beer as a companion snack. When you come here expect to wait for your food but know that it's definitely worth your time!
author: Christina S.

description:
The first time I came to this place was sometime in high school. I didn't even know about it but was invited by a friend who told me we are having Korean! Upon arrival it felt sketchy since it was in a residential neighborhood and really in a GARAGE! perhaps this is why I became very intrigued and grown a fascination that I have returned a number of times.

Every time I come here I get the spicy chicken wings, kimchi fried rice, seafood pancake, and calamari. If greasy isn't for you please skip all the following and don't even try. You are getting Korean! 

Do try the soju as it is quite tasty or a glass of OB to clean your palette for the next amazing dish. 

The service is fast and there are only 2 girls running this place and it is quite small. (why are all the good eats always at small places?) This place does get packed so be sure to arrive early or arrive very late.
author: Myron J.

description:
"Yea you should try this really great Korean resturant its delicious!, but its hard to find, because its like a garage resturant. "

My first impression, was "Great"! another hole in the wall place that serves up Korean food.  You would think that since the place was in some converted garage the price for the food would be decent.  But its actually quite pricey as well.  

I was addicted to this place for  quite a while, despite the pricey dishes and the long waits.  I think most Korean places charge a lot of $$ for their meals.....so its no surprise.

You never go wrong with peach, pineapple and strawberry soju.  Beer goes great with the food here too!,

We usually order seafood pancake, bulgolgi and rice cake...MmMmm my fav but hopefully the next time we come back we'll try other dishes

Let me tell you the other kind of mixed soju that comes in teapots......its friggin strong. 

I would give this a 5 but because of the wait, sometimes wait service sucks depending on the waitress.  ALso they never called me back when I put my name on the waitlist.....
author: Shirley H.

description:
The food here is not that bad.  Tofu soup is standard.  The fried chicken is what me and the guys come for.  So good you can keep eating and eating and washing it down with strawberry soju.  The downside though it feels you don't get good service if you're Korean.  Excuse me that my friends and I are Chinese/Caucasian/Etc...

The food is good but not good enough for someone to treat you like a second class citizen.
author: Michael P.

description:
i had a late dinner with a friend and ordered some favorites - the seafood pancake, the whole fried chicken, and the kimchee beef fried rice. we chased the meal down with a 1600ml OB korean beer. it took us two hours to wolf down most the meal but this place was jammed packed the whole time. friendly helpful service throughout aided by a wireless call button (a great idea in this crazy busy environment). 
a slight negative on the whole fried chicken. it was overdone and a little dry. its taste and texture is a lot like ja jee gai (a Cantonese style fried chicken) served with a small dish of spiced salt.
i may be better off with the fried chicken wings next time.
the seafood pancake was great. a simple savory pan fried doughy cake with squid shrimp and egg.
kim chee beef fried rice is always a winner served with a sunnyside up egg. it's not too spice and is a nice flavorful starch.
and any place with a beer bottle that is 1600 ml has got its menu set up for success!
author: Jeff W.

description: I love this place.  It feels like I'm eating in my friends garage.  I think all the homes in the Sunset are the same actually.  I brought my Korean friend here from Korea and she thought that I lived upstairs.  Also, I love pushing that bell, even if the waiter is standing right next to me.
author: Doug F.

description: We love coming here! Their kimchee fried rice is amazing! The spam sausage casserole is super good! Ooh and the chicken wings and potato croquette! Make sure if you have a large party to call for reservations, wait can be long to be seated if you don't call ahead. It's definitely a hole in the wall but awesome ambiance.
author: Yennie N.

description:
It's an overpriced garage. I'm sure the drinks are great, but if you want to eat and don't want to get drunk, go somewhere else. The food's absolutely not worth its money, but hte place looks okay. 
Keep in mind: IT"S A GARAGE. (without the band)
author: Roger W.

description:
I love this place a lot lot lot !!!! (wanna go now la)

They open late from 6 p.m. until 2 a.m...which is like a heaven for me as a night owl. Basically, everything is yummy~My friends and I always order new items for fun, and the result always be so good! Nothing is bad in this small Korean Bar. 
Parking is easy, but when you go around 9 to 12(Especially, during weekend or Fri), there are a lot of people. You may wait for a while because they don't have many tables.

Must try their liquor~Soju~~~~  !!!!!!!
author: YT T.

description: The wait for food is too long even we get there right when they open.  Spend more than an hour in the resturant, and I would say 90% of the time we were waiting for our dishes to come out.
author: Choi A.

description:
Soju? what the hell is that? then i tried it.... yuuummmmm...

the food was good, and the waitress/hostess/bus girl was very nice and attentive. i especially love the little buzzer at each table to get her attention, very handy..

4 bottles of soju later, we left very happy.
author: Manny M.

description: I like the design of the place. The food is alright. YAY! to yogurt soju! :]
author: May H.

description:
We came to the location looking for Korean healthy friend chicken akin to Bon Chon Chicken. Unfortunately, we did not find what we were craving (we drove 3 hrs from Lodi thinking about KFC). 

But that doesn't mean that this place isn't good/great. 

Personally, the best part of this restaurant, was the experience of finding it and entering it. My companions commented that it felt like being in Japan (strange for Korean joint). 

You enter in what looks like a garage door, the inside of which looks like an old ship, with old wood everywhere and (of course) the necessary posters. 

Very cozy and comfy place for a cold evening in the Sunset. 

Loved their seafood pancake. Filled with big chunks of seafood, not like some places that give you more dough than meat. 

The fried chicken was a lot smaller than I expected and wasn't crisp and juicy like Bon Chon Chicken. 

Their soups seemed really good. Almost every table had a kim chi soup. 

Would love to go back and try more.
author: Justine L.

description:
BF:  I thought you said there was a Korean restaurant out here?
ME:  It's right there. You just passed it!!  
BF:  Where?!
ME:  Right there!! The one with the lights.
BF:  WHERE???
ME:  RIGHT THERE!!!!!!!!
BF:  Nah!!  That's someone's house with the Christmas light.
ME:  Trust me.  I've been there before.  
BF:  Are you for reals?!  That's someone's garage!
ME:  Look, there's a sign.  It's a real restaurant inside.
BF:  Are you sure you want to eat here?
ME:  Fine, you don't know what you're missing.  It's really cute inside.  You won't even notice that you're in someone's garage.  They have these bamboo blinds that you can pull down at each table for privacy. It's something you've never experienced before.  It's pretty neat!
BF:  Nah it's cool, let's go to richmond .
author: hello k.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco.  the food is great I have been there a couple times and every thing I tried was delicious. The Kimchee pancakes and fried rice was amazing, and the soups were so good.  I recomend going with a group of people, or with people who are big eaters, it's a lot of food.  I just turned 21 so I am HELLA excited to go to get some Soju and eat delicious food. Hopefully this week, maybe see you there! It is worth it.
author: James S.

description:
Where do you start with a restaurant in a garage? Well, after my experience at Toyose, I've learned to never judge a garage by it's door. Aside from the novelty of eating in a converted-garage restaurant, the food was tasty, the staff friendly (albeit a tad on the slow side) and the soju refreshing.

The appetizers were definitely the highlight. The kimchi (sp?) pancake and fried chicken wings standout in my memory. You've got to have your game together for me to pick apart chicken bones and these were amazing - super crispy, salty and spicy. The kimchi pancake was warm, doughy and salty. 

The main dishes were good but I could have had another pancake. We shared the baby octopus spicy noodle dish and fish hot pot. Both were flavorful and good.
