But we were not allowed to stand inside the restaurant [my friend complained about this, since she knew that the last time she went there, her party of 10 was able to]. We were out in the shivering cold [because the beach/ocean was down a couple of blocks], for about a good hour! We all took turns to go inside to see if anyone was finished eating, and when it was my turn, the lady just gave me a hard, annoying look. I voted to leave because it was getting late and I was starving. And we did just that.

PS. The place never called us back for our table. I guess that meant people didn't leave this place all night. NOT.
author: Sandy L.

description:
this place will always have a place in my heart since it's the first korean bar i got introduced to by my sunbae's  :)

it's small, usually always crowded, full of Koreans..smoking
i'm not that fond of the smell of cigarettes and crowds of koreans ahaha even though i'm korean myself :d so i haven't been here for a while but recently i got taken here..for a first date anyways the service was slow but the girl serving us was a sweetheart and she was doing a pretty good job  for the fact that she was working alone. Other then that the food was good just as i remember and you can never go wrong with flavored soju.
author: esther k.

description: Where have you been all my life?  This place is probably one of the best Korean places I've eaten in SF.  We arrived at 6pm and left at 1030pm.  Yes its that good.  Eat and drink until you die is my second motto.  The kitchen is in the garage and you eat in the living room, hallway, family room, etc...  The kimchi rice, chicken wings, assorted seafood with noddles, and seafood pancake are all good.  Too bad its located out in the boondocks.
author: Fatty A.

description: awesome korean restaurant located towards the end of noriega st, i'd definitely recommend the casserole, their fried chicken wings, kimchi pancakes, kimchi fried rice and their cheesy garlic fries !! this place is great for groups and especially if you got a thirst for soju. the only reason that this place doesn't get 5 stars is because there always a long wait when me and my friends go there. other than that... this place is like what i said in the very beginning of this review. IT"S AWESOME !!
author: Jeff C.

description: This is the craziest Korean bar/restaurant way, way out in the Outer Sunset. Not sure how my friends heard about it, maybe K-town kids told them as a joke? Anywho, from the outside, it doesn't look like much, but you'll definitely be surprised walking thru the front door. The big draw here is the flavored soju, or at least it's the reason I keep going back. If you've never had soju, this might be the right place to start. White peach soju is my current favorite, but I still haven't finished the list. Need to somehow get my butt back thataways. The food is typical of Korean drinking holes (so I've been told by native ex-Seoulites) - hot, filling, "good for hangovers," etc.  OH!! And don't forget to use the buttons in the walls if you want to call your waitress over.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
two stars...why?

food sucks and is hella expensive..a regular noodle with hardly anything in it is like $14...everything taste like they've drowned it in soy sauce for days...

only good thing about this place is alot of kids go there for soju...yogurt soju is so good and they never card..meaning ma 21 n younger friends go there n drink all night...

another thing is "restaurant" is in someone's garage..like FO REAL..someone's GARAGE...its so damn small...n is it even legal? o wells...if you come here...only drink yogurt soju n leave when ur done..don't order any food b/c u will only waste ur money n be dissapointed
author: Tammy F.

description: Sometimes you need to go really far to get what you want.  Toyose is really far away from everything. You have to want Korean food so badly that you will be content to eat it in a garage all the way in the OUTER sunset.  Yes, only come here if you need to drink, eat budae chigae and pound some soju as if you are in Korea.
author: Sarah C.

description: Talk about unique...This restaurant is inside a garage! ya, it's weird but somehow they managed to make it feel cozy inside.  Best time to go is during the week cus i hear weekends get very crowded.  The food is good and its open till 2am in case you get those late night cravings.  The only bad thing is that some dishes are slightly pricey for what you get.
author: anette d.

description:
so, i was down with the uniqueness of eating in a converted garage.... but i wasn't down with the HORRIFIC service we received. 
true, we were a large party (but had made reservations in advance, so they were prepared) - but we had to ask THREE times for water. TWICE for utensils. we never got any popcorn (not that i care, since i hate popcorn, but still, on principle). part of our order was forgotten (i dunno how that happens, since she wrote it all down). granted, there was only one server, but if she's running the whole joint, i think that's the restaurant's choice. 

ok, so what? we aren't korean. but geez. come on, we're in sf, not ktown la, so i KNOW they get a lot of chinese people in there for business. but i digress. 

let's talk about the food. slim pickings. and totally untraditional, as in do not expect an banchan (WHAT, no kimchi?!?!??!)
our party only ordered the ddukbokgi ($8.95, ramen/egg/etc +$2), kimchi kogi bokeumbap/fried rice ($10.95), and chicken wings. and the food is not TERRIBLE, but it's nothing to race over to try. and.... for that price, i'm expecting a bit more dduk and rice. i can say that the ddukbokgi is not very spicy, as i didn't spontaneously start to cry halfway thru my dinner. 
i've had better. much better. probably will not be coming back to dine here.
author: Aletheia W.

description:
i will admit i came here b/c i had heard there was a korean joint in a "garage".

and for that aspect it gets a 5, since it literally is in a garage.  but once you walk inside, the similarities to the outside are gone, it's a normal restaurant inside and you'd never know what it originally was.

the food, some was pretty good, some was pretty sub par (compared to what else you can get in SF only - it's not fair to compare to other further locations like LA - i mean come on, i might as well then compared that to korea right?).  the bulgogi was pretty ehhhh, the seafood pajon was pretty good.  the kimchi pajon was awesome and i would order again.  the om rice (fried rice/egg) i would never get again, the spicy pork was quite good.  sure the soju was good, but then again we only had the bottles, so that's standard fare anywhere.  the bottles of hite are huge, which is awesome.  

but we found that it wasn't necessarily cheaper than other korean drinking joints where you can also eat.  so for me it's a little far to drive compared to other places, though i'm sure just for the kimchi pajon i will be back.  you gotta change it up every once in a while.
author: Jason J.

description: I love the many types of soju there like the yogurt or strawberry is the way to go.  I was disappointed with the portions though the Kimchi fried rice I could eat two of those orders myself because it was so good.  Also the chicken gizzards were chewy which is good with soju.
author: Stevezee C.

description: Came here for a Guy Love night before Jay left for Fresno for 6 weeks.  We had been talking about coming here for months, wanting to check out "the garage" restaurant.  Man we were not disappointed.  This place really is straight up a garage, but they cleaned it up real nice and it reminds me of the restaurant/bars I used to go to in K-Town.  Really good seafood pancake and ramen with dduk.  Oh and they have this spicy pork and tofu dish that's pretty bomb.  We didn't get any soju that night but I can assure you that we will go again and it will be glorious.
author: William S.

description: I order the bulgogi with calamari and boyy was it good. There was mushroom, veggies and the marinate sauce was sooo good. Great dish! We also had Aloe Soju, very delicious. Although it might be a squeeze at times,( its a garage what do you expect) it set off a good vibe. Great place to eat with friends. ohh, and yes the fried chicken was goooooooooooood. Must try or you'll regret it. (I'm a big chicken wing fan!)
author: Lind G.

description:
i have such fond memories of this place from high school and college. i had soju shots for the first time at this very place. 

i keep forgetting this place is called toyose b/c i always refered to it as yo's. hahahahha

although it seems kinda hidden, and all garage looking, it could be easy to miss late at night.

i love coming here after concerts. stuffing my face with hot food.

you don't have to speak korean to get good service here.... it might help to look korean tho. HAAAAAAW..... i would spend a couple hours here, friends will come in and out, they aren't pushy about clearing tables after you're done so that you can leave, you can be as loud and obnoxious as you want. 

i feel like i kinda out grown this place but seriously... i love this place.
author: Irene C.

description:
the garage!

order the bokumbop (kimchi fried rice!)
author: Carli F.

description: Make DAMN sure you call in 20mins before your reservation to make sure they didn't give your goddaaam table away!!!  2 stars for the soju
author: Henry M.

description: very good food. I love their kimchi fried rice, and spicy chicken wings, and korean pancake... their food goes really good with beer, soju, and so on. I have tried their pomogranate wine, it was pretty good too. It gets pretty packed even on weeknights, so be aware to wait for at least 15 mins, or make sure to be there on time if you make a reservation, otherwise the seat is gonna be passed onto someone else. (that's what happened to us last night when my friend and I went.)
author: chihiro i.

description: Kimchi Fried Rice is B0o0oomB! Get that.. some yogurt and strawberry soju. Between just me and my friend, we had 3 orders of soju. 1-10 we were like 6.4 drunk. So not really, but kind of. And we had like 23979729198471 refills of complimentary popcorn..
author: Eda L.

description: When I heard this place was in a garage, I expected to see bikes and old skis hanging from the rafters. It was actually a real legit restaurant! The soju cocktails are so good - they use fresh strawberries! I recommend the chicken wings and the seafood pancake. YUM! The strawberry, peach, and yogurt soju cocktails are the best. They don't mind it if you sit there for a long time -  we were there for over 2 hours! Just try not to be too rowdy, they may refuse to serve you anymore alcohol. Yummy shrimp chips to snack on. My only complaint - they don't have those little side dishes you normally get at korean restaurants (kim chee, bean sprouts, etc.). All in all, I would totally go back!
author: Joanne T.

description:
My friend and I ordered Carousel , spicy rice cake with fish cake and kimchi fried rice (i ordered this for to go)... The carousel was delicious. it has sausage, spam, cabbage, beef, tofu and noodle).  The spicy rice cake, i only like fish cake and the sauce. the rice cake, for me, i don't really like it...  Side dish, I like the dried fish, it was really good...
I will come back and try other dish....
author: Elisabeth T.

description: Possibly the best place to eat authentic Korean food. Reminds me so much of my how my mom (Korean) cooked at home, especially their seafood and green onion pancakes. Highly recommend the yogurt soju, also.
author: M C.

description: I've lived in the neighborhood for about twenty years. I finally decided to try this place. It has an unassuming exterior, almost screaming "Go away", as it might be for an inside crowd. It is in a garage and has a few private booths. The menu is different from  other Korean restaurants I have been to. Less grilled meats here and more focus on seafood. They give none of the customary free bowls of  marinated / pickled vegetables one gets at other Korean restaurants. We didn't get rice, but then we didn't ask for it. I could learn to live with the menu / food limitations as the nearest Korean restaurant is three or four miles away. We were seated and served reasonably quickly and what we had we liked. I'll be back.
author: Sleepy T.

description: This place is so cute! its literally a regular sunset SF house that is built into a restaurant in the garage! it`s reallly small but definitely fun with friends to eat together! i loved the kim-chi fried rice but the dish is not worth the cost. its too expensive for a small amount of fried rice which can cost less than 5 bucks in chinatown. we also ordered the seafood pancake which is yummmy too but still pretty high on the price. lastly, we had a 'casserole' which is literally ramen in a bigass bowl of soup with other meat and veggies. the soju is yummy too. we ordered the strawberry, guava and aloe which was done half way through our meal. :) overalll, 4 stars just cause it is pretty expensive for little amounts of food!
author: Stella C.

description: We call this place the Korean garage and after reading some of the reviews on yelp it sounds like great minds think alike. For being a restaurant deep in the Outer Sunset this place gets pretty packed on weekend evenings. The restaurant is definitely a Korean drinking place and they serve a bunch of different flavored sojus and beers. The food is also surprisingly good. They don't have the traditional Korean BBQ items on the menu, but they have a lot of dishes that pair well with the alcohol they assume you're drinking. Our favorites are the fried chicken, seafood pancake and this tofu dish with spicy pork and kimchee. The decor is a little strange (it has a beach theme), but how can you resist a restaurant that looks like a garage on the outside and also has the quintessential doorbells at each table to call your watier/waitress?
author: A and K W.

description:
The atmosphere of this place is cool but besides that, this place is seriously overrated. 

First, they have blaring Korean pop-rock music that, after a while, becomes painfully repetitive. Second, the service was terrible. I had to wait 40 minutes for my dish (which was just a bowl of soup) and I was the second customer to enter the place at 6pm on a Sunday evening.  When I ordered the soup, I asked if it included Kim Chi and they said it did. But after 40 minutes, the soup was given to me with no Kim Chi. This is the first time I've EVER had Korean food with no Kim Chi served. I finally got 4 small bowls of Kim Chi. This is half what I get at any other Korean restaurant. And, anywhere else, the Kim Chi bowls are served right away, so they can be enjoyed while waiting for the meal to be prepared. The food itself was just OK. I had sea bass soup and the sea bass was clearly not fresh. Parts of it were so bad that I could not even eat them. And, there were also cheap prawns thrown into it that were clearly fresh from the freezer and a factory farm before that. Prices were very high, the whole meal (a bowl of soup and some cheap mass produced Lotte brand soju) was $40!
author: Eater S.

description:
Is this place even legal?  Have they passed all the zoning regulations and the building codes inspections?  I hope so, because this place was good and would hate to see it disappear. 

Regardless.... holy smokes, this place is hardcore.  It looks like everyone eating here and all the servers are straight from the motherland.  It's not so much a restaurant as it is a watering hole that sells food,  and it's like the Korean version of a wild-west cowboy saloon... I think if any non-Asian were to step in, all the Korean chatter would come to an instant end and everyone would look up from their tables.  Not that this place is racist in any way, but it's seems pretty hardcore for even the most philic of the Asiaphiles.

In case I needed to break it out for an emergency, I went through all the Korean vocab that I knew in my head a few times to refresh myself (roughly equivalent to a 6 year old's... probably closer to a 6 year old that failed first grade).  We stepped in and ordered spicy chicken wings and this kim-chi soup that had hot dogs in it.  Delicious.  Authentically spicy and delicious.

The booth had this buzzer to summon the waitress, but that is a bit bourgeois for me, so we just called her using internationally known hand signals, and the service was good.

Overall, very very good.
author: Stan L.

description: True hole in the wall secret for San Franciscans. Must haves are the sojo and spicy chicken wings. Opens late till 2AM, late night snacks and chilling a must. All other Korean food is good and the best is PARKING is abundant.
author: Phillip K.

description: I brought my non-asian friends here, they loved the atmosphere, the food, but they were creeped out when the after hours crowd came in.  I don't recommend you bring kids here at all.  I love the cook she is a sweet heart.  Korean home cooking at the finest!
author: kevin h.

description: good korean food and cant beat cocktail soju lol
author: Linda A.

description: Isn't kimchi assortment a distinct characteristic of a Korean meal?  Why did I have to ask for this toward the end of the meal? Boo.  The order: Seafood Pancake (undercooked), Potstickers (they are good...but they are deep fried, not pan fried), Fishcake Soup with udon (eat this quickly before the noodles get soggy), Bulgogi (I didn't eat this...I think I'm really going vegetarian soon....), Strawberry Soju (it didnt not have much seeds in it, which is what I like about strawberry soju...)  Overall, I wouldn't eat here again unless it was 2am and I was drunk.  Sorry.
author: Jenny K.

description: Cozy cute intimate place. Good for small groups, young and hip people. The grilled mussels with special house sauce lived up to the hype. We, in fact, order another one we liked it so much. The fried chicken was whatever. Crispy but dry. Can't compete with chicken from KyoChon or CoCoBang. We also spicy soup w/ sea bass (meh woon tang). I've had better, but it was good. We had two bottles of mango soju and that went down easy. Overall, it was a good experience due to the space decor and servers. If you want authentic Korean food (that Koreans would flock to) this is not the place, but this places makes for a good time for young people.
author: Sun K.

description: Interesting environment. I felt like I was in hiding. I went there one night right after work (around 630) with co-workers. We tried to order several chicken dishes and they kept saying they didn't have it. Everything we pointed to they didn't have! It's freaking 630 on a random weekday, the place wasn't even packed! We ended up ordering 3 dishes of what they actually had and we didn't even like it. What else could we do? Seemed like they didn't have anything. Plus it was expensive! We only had 3 dishes and ice water and it cost us over $50. Not coming back. Food wasn't that great.
author: Al T.

description: sorry, this is no LA.  just try Gaam in LA Ktown and you can appreciate the difference.  it's nice that toyose is open till 2 (reason for all the high ratings), but not filled with any koreans ironically.  they serve cheese corn, fried chicken, yogurt soju.  typical bar food items that u come to expect, tasted merely ok, prices high.  garage entrance, now that's unique
author: Rob C.

description:
Kim Chee Friend Rice? Check 
Chicken Giblets? Check 
Those Korean Pancakes? Check 
Korean Casseroles? Check 
Soju? Check 
Small fun place to hang out and chill all night? Check 

This place has it all. Great food, little doorbells to call the ladies over for more drinks, dry popcorn, good food, and good times. Best of all, its pretty hidden. It's disguised as a garage! There's also plenty of parking around here, and thats a huge plus. I've never had to look around for it. 

Warning, this place does get a little packed at night on weekends, be prepared to wait as groups tend to stick around and talk. 

Waaaay better than The Spot!
author: Josh M.

description: Finally tried out this place during a friend's birthday party.  We ordered pretty much the standard of what everyone else ordered: bulgogi, kimchi fried rice, spicy chicken wings, seafood pancake. We also ordered peach, yogurt, and mango soju.  Overall I only think their food was ok, it wasn't as good as everyone hyped it up to be.  The flavored soju tasted more alcoholy than the juice. I still think the yogurt soju tasted better at Playground. If you want to come here, be prepared to wait for the service.
author: Juliana L.

description: This is definitely a place to come for drinks!... its reminiscent of small izakaya style eating, Its a glorified bar, but their main stable is their soju... Many of the dishes are reasonably priced, compared to some other restaurants in the city.  Their kimchi fried rice is really good! And beware, if you don't like spicy food.. this really isn't the place to go.  They do have seafood udon noodle soups, which are decent, but the majority of the menu is filled with spicy food!
author: Mel H.

description:
Awesome authentic Korean food.  Reminded me of the meals I had in rural Korea.  We had the whole fired chicken.  Moist, not oily, eat it with the radish kimchee (koko bang style).  The kimchee and tofu with pork belly was good maybe slightly heavy on the sesame oil. Spicy cod soup came later in the meal piping hot, not too spicy.  Combo of fish, red pepper, fermented miso paste and zucchini is actually quite complimentary.

Location is easy to find off the 35th ave highway.  It is a converted garage which also brought me back to some of the makeshift eateries in Korea.  It was a bit drafty and kitchy but you dont come here for the decor.  We got there right after it opened so we sat right away.  It gets PACKED so arrive early.  Service was good.  The aisles are tight and the 2 waitresses are zipping around serving boiling hot soups so expect to wait a little once the place heats up.  Prices are not cheap but not too high either.  The banchan was not as plentiful as in other places (perhaps keeping the prices reigned in) and the cabage kimchee was not as good as my wifes.  

We'll be back for the pork foot and soju.  Just get there early, don't mind the decor,  and be ready for good authentic Korean food at a reasonable price.
author: Dennis W.

description: Toyose is held in the garage of a house, pretty unique. The kimchi fried rice here is delicious! add an extra egg if you love eggs ;) They have a huge variety of Tofu Boiling Hot Pot. great place to drink and hang out. However, not recommended for any party more than 8 because space is very limited. It might be possible, but expect a longer wait. They have a button at each table whenever you need the waitress so dont worry about having to raise your hand, or run around looking for one. Try this place out, i believe you'll be satisfied with the food here. :)
author: Nancy N.

description:
an hour wait!

a plate of kimchi beef fried rice was 10 bucks... BUT free shrimp chips!the waitress didnt seem to give a hoot.... she just tossed us the bags of chips to get us out of her hair. i wouldnt blame her tho.... 12 am and the garage is still pretty filled! 

neways... i thot this place would have a homie feel since it is in a garage and all.. but nope... just a tiny little resturant. the most interesting thing about toyose.... you press a button to call the waitress over... hah and she didnt come!

you know what... even with all that not so goodness... im pretty sure imma end up back here again.. but i really dont mind... i like a resturant/bar with a little spunk!
author: Lynn T.

description: Takes forever to get seated. Just because its always packed and the place is fairly small. Other than that, the food is always great! SHRIMP CHIPS! Fried chicken and some HITE beer, and all you need to do to get the waitress is push the doorbell button by your table.
author: J B.

description:
this place is where you can drink soju & beer and order korean food to accompany all the drinking.  

the food here is actually suprisingly good.  Soju, chicken gizzard, and Sea Snails... or fruit platter if i'm feeling guilty.   

i come here because of the service though... waitresses are super cool.
author: Doug ..

description:
was is SF.  called out nelson since i was in the city.   wanted a place to drink and eat.  i just wanted to go to a place where we can drink on a sunday night.  decided on this place as i wanted some korean bar food.

it was 3 of us.  we ordered kimchee chicken soup, bulgolgi, spicey noodles, stirred fried chicken gizzard, and seafood korean pancake(okonomiyaki) and a pitcher of Hite.  total was $85 + 20 tip

its still delicious.  however, i get more for less in southbay though...  the pitcher of hite was $15.  they just gave you a 1-liter bottle.  i guess i thought it was kinda expensive since its probably only $5 at korean supermarket.  but, usually we go there for the soju.  had to drive back, so just beer this time.

all the food was great.  if you take out the beer it was only $70 for 5 dishes.  still pretty good deal in SF.  a great place to go eat some good food and drink.  

the waitress was nice to look at as well.  i think she got a boob job.
author: Peter L.

description:
this place rules!  if you can get past the southern hemisphere location (its really cold in the summer) and the fact that it's a garage, then you are in for a treat. 

first, you must get drunk here.  its against the law to not drink here.  get pitchers of hite, which is actually a 1.5 liter plastic bottle.  no worries.  get a bottle of soju with yogurt as well, and double fist all dinner.  mmm...

we got both the seafood & green onion and the kim chee pancakes.  both delicious.  who ever came up with savory pancakes?  genius.

the pork bulgogi (kulgogi?) was good, but nothing special.

kim chee fried rice w an egg on top was awesome, as expected.

the crown jewel of the night, though, was a 'soup' or something of kim chee, spam, sausage, green onion, tofu, and what the heck some ramen noodles just for good measure.  stir it all up and divy it in bowls and you are just plain happy.

lastly, this place had mostly asians, so you know its got some cred.  that, or only asian ppl are willing to travel out this far to the land of mist just to eat korean food.  whatever the case, pretty damn good.
author: Robert S.

description:
be sure not to miss this unassuming little hole in the wall while you're trying to find it.

here's a hint: ITS A GARAGE!

the food is amazing and for a reasonable price. maybe i'm just a snob, but good korean food is hard to come by in this city. (i am not impressed by any of the brothers). but toyose is ittttt!

kimchi fried rice, yes plz and i'll have another.
author: Diana R.

description: SHhhhhhhhhhhhhh.  Dont tell anyone else, there is already not enough room for us.    I like it cause I can walk home.    Oh yeah, and we OWN this place, right, right, yall know who im talkin ta.
author: Hen A.

description:
"Dude, this place is in a garage?" was my first reaction when I first heard about this place.  Though skeptical of whether or not this place is good, I went to go check it out.  Almost missed this place it if weren't for the Asians smoking outside and small chicken on a lit sign outside.  

Walking in, Toyose looks like a very well decorated place.  Since this place in a converted garage, there isn't a lot of space, but they maximize the seating and it's comfortable to be in the booths.  You get a screen for privacy, and you'll notice the faux brick that lines the wall.  In each booth is a doorbell on the wall. Pressing the doorbell calls your server to your table, like on an airplane.  This way you're not waving crazily with your arm to get someone's attention, and whacking someone.  I wish more places have it cause it just works really well.

Bit of advice, get a table toward the back rather than the front.  We got the first table by the front entrance and there's a serious cold draft coming in.  Plus the people waiting for a table face the booths and they like staring at you while you eat.  The screen they provide doesn't really help, and the staring kind of creeps me out.  Anyways, get a table in the back if possible where it's warm and cozy.  

What we ordered:

#17 Casserole - Spam, beef hot dogs, fish cake, rice cake, kim chi noodle (ramen) ***1/2
Pajun Seafood Pancake ****1/2
Fried Chicken Wings ****1/2

Out of ***** stars

Toyose starts you off with a small bowl of Calbee Shrimp flavored Chips, pickled white radish, but no kim chi. Now their casserole dish is big - too much for two people, probably big enough for 4 people with extra dishes.  We took a lot of it home.  Rice cakes were kind of grainy, but I liked the spicy soup.  Toyose's "noodle" is freeze-dried ramen that you can get at any Asian supermarket, but I like that kind of stuff so I was chowing down.  However, to go out and get instant ramen isn't why I go out, so I would rather have something I can't make at home, but it is what it is.  The Pajun Seafood Pancake was tasty, and my girlfriend really liked it.  Also great is their Fried Chicken Wings with a wedge of lemon, which seems to be the current fad in Korean restaurants.  I'm still a huge fan of San Tung Dry Fried Wings, but San Tung is in their own class.  A friend once said Toyose reminded him of Korean bar food, and I would agree with that.

I liked this place.  I would try a different casserole dish next time I go, but the rest, I would definitely get again.  I took the leftovers from the casserole dish and added mixture of chicken and beef broth to it to thin it out and added some more vegetables, which turned into multiple meals in a row.  The place gets crowded and for good reason.  Definitely a great to take friends and they're open late.  Go and get some.
author: Ed Y.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant in North bay.  I came from LA and miss the Korean town very badly.  (For those of you who have been to LA Korean town, you know what I'm talking about.  It's a "Korean Food Heaven" in the States)  Unfortunately, we don't have many options here in SF.  This is the best so far.
author: D C.

description:
Can get $$$ if it's just for 2 but, portions were generous: A (giant) seafood pancake was probably enough (for 2) to go with soju or sake for a late dinner/ snack.  Beef kim chee rice was surprisingly tame and tasty.  Both dishes did not leave us inspired for another visit to try others.

Service was nice pleasant.  Got there around 11:15, beat the late night rush and got our food quick.

This place is really for a group of 3+ to get drunk and loud with (and to split the bill with).

Definitely not recommended for a quiet get-2-know-U date.
author: Donut Cak e.

description: The food is alright, I wouldn't come again strictly for the long wait. I came at 7:30 and they said that our wait would be 30 minutes to 2 hours - that is the greatest time span I've ever received in terms of how long to wait. I'd say that you should not come here unless you have a small group. I had seven people and we waited for an hour and a half - there is literally nothing to do in the area but loiter. As you know from the other reviews, this restaurant is in a garage. The restaurant is extremely small, if you have parties larger than four, you'll have to sit on those small plastic chairs for kids that you can get in Chinatown. I ordered the spicy fried chicken, spicy sausage/spam casserole, seafood hot pot, spicy beef, and some spicy fishcake. The majority of the menu is spicy so beware. The fried chicken was nice, the casserole was pretty bland to me, I wouldn't pay $23 for hot dogs, spam, spicy tomato broth, and a block of ramen, would you?  Well, I did and I don't think it was worth it. The best part of the dinner was probably the waitresses, they were really efficient in getting everything. Upon arriving to the restaurant, I got out in 35 minutes, that right there is good service. The food overall was not bad, not superb either. This place makes me think that Yelp reviews on small, independent, restaurants creates a lot of hype which are highly misleading.
author: Ryan L.

description: Best fried chicken EVER!  I LOVE THIS PLACE!  This place has ruined me for any other fried chicken place.  :)
author: dream p.

description: I would of never found this place , this restaurant is inside a garage?!!?!! But once you get in, it's a little comfortable spot. Soju , beer, chicken wings, dumplings, casserole , kim chee fried rice, gizzard, and more chicken wings... none stop order of food and drink that will make you chill there for awhile.
author: Daniel W.

description: I've heard so much about this Korean restaurant in a garage that I had to try this out. Came here last night with a couple friends and got seated right away. It looks amazing in the inside! You would've never thought it was a garage. Service was fast and efficient. I thought the food was okay... I had the fried chicken, seafood & green onion pancake, and the spicy pork. Fried chicken tasted just like regular fried chicken. The pancake was just okay. I've definitely tasted better spicy pork. They also didn't give us little dishes of appetizers like other Korean restaurants do =( I think this restaurant is mainly for the plentiful flavors of soju than food. I'll probably come by Toyose again to try out more food though =)
author: Vivian L.

description: Almost everything on their menu is delicious.  My only complaint would be for their service but you can't blame them cuz they usually have only one waitress servicing all the tables.  Make sure you make a rsvp if you're going on the weekends.
author: Mike K.

description:
"Dude, this place is in a garage?" was my first reaction when I first heard about this place.  Though skeptical of whether or not this place is good, I went to go check it out.  Almost missed this place it if weren't for the Asians smoking outside and small chicken on a lit sign outside.  

Walking in, Toyose looks like a very well decorated place.  Since this place in a converted garage, there isn't a lot of space, but they maximize the seating and it's comfortable to be in the booths.  You get a screen for privacy, and you'll notice the faux brick that lines the wall.  In each booth is a doorbell on the wall. Pressing the doorbell calls your server to your table, like on an airplane.  This way you're not waving crazily with your arm to get someone's attention, and whacking someone.  I wish more places have it cause it just works really well.

Bit of advice, get a table toward the back rather than the front.  We got the first table by the front entrance and there's a serious cold draft coming in.  Plus the people waiting for a table face the booths and they like staring at you while you eat.  The screen they provide doesn't really help, and the staring kind of creeps me out.  Anyways, get a table in the back if possible where it's warm and cozy.  

What we ordered:

#17 Casserole - Spam, beef hot dogs, fish cake, rice cake, kim chi noodle (ramen) ***1/2
Pajun Seafood Pancake ****1/2
Fried Chicken Wings ****1/2

Out of ***** stars

Toyose starts you off with a small bowl of Calbee Shrimp flavored Chips, pickled white radish, but no kim chi. Now their casserole dish is big - too much for two people, probably big enough for 4 people with extra dishes.  We took a lot of it home.  Rice cakes were kind of grainy, but I liked the spicy soup.  Toyose's "noodle" is freeze-dried ramen that you can get at any Asian supermarket, but I like that kind of stuff so I was chowing down.  However, to go out and get instant ramen isn't why I go out, so I would rather have something I can't make at home, but it is what it is.  The Pajun Seafood Pancake was tasty, and my girlfriend really liked it.  Also great is their Fried Chicken Wings with a wedge of lemon, which seems to be the current fad in Korean restaurants.  I'm still a huge fan of San Tung Dry Fried Wings, but San Tung is in their own class.  A friend once said Toyose reminded him of Korean bar food, and I would agree with that.

I liked this place.  I would try a different casserole dish next time I go, but the rest, I would definitely get again.  I took the leftovers from the casserole dish and added mixture of chicken and beef broth to it to thin it out and added some more vegetables, which turned into multiple meals in a row.  The place gets crowded and for good reason.  Definitely a great to take friends and they're open late.  Go and get some.
author: Edmund Y.

description:
i went here with two friends on a recent visit to sf. one of my friends lives around the corner from this place and it looked like a cool little hole in the wall so we decided to check it out. 

i have become a recent korean-fried-chicken enthusiast so we ordered 12 wings, some bubbling cauldron of yummy veggies and tofu, some hite beer and a kind of liquor that i can't remember the name of. 

the food was all great -- and more than enough for the three of us. i loved that we could buzz for service instead of having someone check on us for no reason. 

when we left, we saw huge purple fireworks going off at the end of the street by the beach. it was the 4th of july and i was worried we were going to miss the fireworks, but we got our own personal show!
author: Molly T.

description: This is the place to go when you want an alternative menu to the typical korean bbq place AND, I really mean AND, you want to drink with your meal.  I decided to eat dinner here without drinking, and it just wasn't the same.  The tasty soju and beer with the spicy food go hand in hand. The ETOH dull your sense of time, not realizing its takes a long while for service here(there's only one person taking orders, serving, taking care of the bills, and bussing. hey mon!)  I think the ETOH also ease the pain of the pricey bill.  Oh well. The homestyle food is good here.  I'll just make sure I plan on getting buzzed next time...
author: Ezduzit S.

description: Been here a bunch of times and I gotta say this place is great! It's best to come here with a bunch of your friends and some sort of drinking game...then order a few bottles of soju (the yogurt flavor is THE BEST, the strawberry isn't bad either).  There is usually just one lady serving late light so service may not be super prompt but the good thing is that they never kick you out or rush you!  The food here is pretty good too and it's nice that they are opened til pretty late.  This is definitely a good spot if you have a bunch of friends and nowhere to go.
author: Ann H.

description: great soju! yummy food! love to hang out here with friends! :)
author: Connie W.

description: We ordered the bulgogi with calamari, kimche fried rice, chicken wings and calamari with vegetable boiling pot. The food was delicious. We asked for extra kimche but that never came and their banchan is pretty limited.
author: Talisa L.

description:
a converted gargage at the end of the world ... a hideout or clandestine meeting place, korean faire at very $$$ 

there is more to this place that maybe never revealed ... oh the food, okay maybe delicious, but i got to get past the facade to reveal the many layers of  ... this meeting place

puzzled
author: tim y.

description: This place is over rated. Food is decent but I give it two stars because of the immature atomosphere. These is basically a place for underaged high schoolers to hang out and drink because they don't card here. Second worse thing about this place is that they don't care if you smoke in the resturant. Any other Korean place is better than here. Shut this place down!
author: David W.

description: Located in the *outer* sunset in a converted garage, this restaurant scores some points for quirkiness, but the food is not amazing.  Plus, their menu was a little thin on some of my Korean faves.
author: Tim G.

description: I've dined here twice already. The first time was ok, the second time was very bad. I understand and have to give them credit for the Soju. It's one of the best you will ever have. The food is ok, you can get from anywhere. My second time dinning here, the customer service was extremely bad. The host/ female server, the one with the long hair was extremely rude and bad. The water didn't even come out until like 45 minutes after. They didn't even give us chopsticks and napkins and bowls after 15 minutes the food was brought out. They seated us at a very small table that is suppose to have 4 people-table, but there was 6 of us. I understand that the business if doing really well, but they have to look at the ways how they serve their customers. If the soju wasn't that good, I would have given them a 1 star rating due to their customer service skills. Btw, don't ever order the fishcake soup that is recommended by the waiters. It is the worse soup I have ever had. They just decorate it well, other than that it's just fish balls or artificial fish cake. I hope the owner really look into the way how the waiters are serving customers. They need to be more friendly.
author: Phat N.

description: Came here again many times since the last review . I really like their Yogurt Soju .. it's a lot better than the Peach . The potstickers are ok .. I don't really like how it's deep-fried though . I like non deep-fried potstickers more . The fish cakes & rice cakes was yucky .. it got really tiring . The fruit platter was nicely constructed and really big .. but a big big rip off too at like $17 I believe ?
author: Eileen L.

description: It's a garage, it's a korean restaurant, it serves flavored soju, and it's open late. While there is better korean food out there, for late night korean in the sunset, this is the place to go. Only problem is that since it's "the place to go" it gets pretty crowded and it's not a very big place. I was very unimpressed by their stew.
author: Tiff L.

description:
i wish that toyose was closer to me.  this is what i missed about LA, casual korean drinkin places (cafe); where you can just hang out with friends shooting back some soju.  ahhh, i miss LA & k-town......

i liked the food here.  note, though, that this is not a proper restaurant for meals, more like a bunshik (snacks) place or drinking place with good anju (tapas).  i wish this was closer to me (i'm repeating myself here....)
author: E S.

description: I was very unimpressed by this place. I went here on a recommendaiton from a crazy mexican chef I know. The food was lackluster. the environment was cool, and the sheer fact that we were dining in a garage was cool. It felt like we were  at some illegal restaurant, but the food was lacking. The service also lacked, was overpriced for what you get. I will not be back, nor recommend it, but it was an experience.
author: Burne D.

description: This is such a bizarre place. Not authentic by any means (last time I checked, Korean restaurants don't usually serve popcorn at the beginning of the meal). That said, the food is pretty authentic. The soju cocktails were pretty tasty, and so was the rest of the food. Definitely need to come back to explore some of the other options on the menu (we had the fried chicken and the pork kimchee tofu). Lots of others ordered the seafood or kimchee pancakes, both of which looked tasty.
author: Lemon S.

description: It's a tiny little place. Front door looks like a normal house. The wait was long because it's friday night and people were having fun and drinking. But the food and yogurt soju was so good that it's totally worth it. I will def. come back to try the seafood pancake and some other dishes.
author: Lance C.

description: Toyose is impossible to find, because it looks like a house from the outside.....well actually it is a house.  I was surprised that the inside was so nice, but  it is somewhat narrow and the occupancy is very limited.  The food is really delicious plus all you can eat shrimp chips!  I recommend their chicken wings and rice cake with ramen noodles.  Eat with caution because almost everything is spicy.  Call to make reservations because the wait can be very long.
author: Mike S.

description:
ah the garage...

people go there for the soju. theres a food menu but its not really dinner type food. the food is there for people to drink and chew on something at the same time. the dukbokgi is alright. ive had better.

the soju is great tho!
author: L M.

description:
This place almost made me wish I grew up in LA and not Santa Barbara, or even better, spoke more Korean with my parents, damn the 805's lack of Asian diversity!  
This place seemed very Korean exclusive, come here with at least one in your group.  I made reservations, showed up on time and still the waitress wouldn't make eye contact until I told her in a heavy accent (one friend calls it the beach bum accent) that I had a reservation...first came the shock, "what the hell just came out of this boy's mouth?"  then came the amusement, "aww, the gyopo is trying."  I think I got big points for trying, because she was pretty nice after that.
The food was good.  Fried chicken was well seasoned, kimchi fried rice was tasty, duk bok ki was a little on the small side, but good.  The winner of the night, I thought, was the pa chun.
Definitely worth checking out, just don't forget to bring your Korean friend.
author: Mike U.

description:
chicken wings, spicy seafood pancake, kim chee fried rice, spicy pork and tofu, yogurt soju, bokbunja. 

order these things and you will see why it is worth 5 stars.  i am hear at least once a week. sigh* open till 2am everyday thank god.
author: Charlie L.

description:
if you want restaurant quality food you should go somewhere else, since they serve korean bar food here - though as far as korean bar food goes it's really quite good.  

still, i don't understand why the wait could get up to 3 hours.

and why it's poppin' with a bunch of high school lookin' kids.
author: Andrew P.

description: I discovered this spot maybe 8 or 9 yrs ago. My friends and I have been going there ever since for the seafood casserole, yogurt soju and of course the slightly burnt fried chicken. While these stables are still there, I also find quite a bit of new items added to the menu. Anyway, maybe I m getting older, but the younger customers are just plain rude. That's why I don't go there anymore. I still love the staff, the food and the fact that it is a garage converted restaurant. Maybe I should hit the spot in the early evening before the clubbing crowd come.
author: Sandy N.

description:
I came here for the first time this weekend and it's as good as everyone says. Maybe it's the novelty of a restaurant tucked away in the foggy sunset neighborhood, but I really enjoyed Toyose. 
The chicken had a good spice and the soju was nice and cold. The other dishes we had, a casserole with spam and hot dogs, and kimchi fried rice were good too, but next time I might just come for snacks and drinks.
Because space is so limited, if you sit by the door, prepare for a draft from everyone lining up to eat!
author: Lauren K.

description: this is your standard korean food. i came here on a friday night with 5 other friends. we had a reservation for 6:30 and were seated upon arrival. we ordered giblets, bulgogi, korean pancakes (seafood), fried rice with an egg over it (can't remember the authentic name for this), and fried chicken. the orders came out really quickly (freshly cooked and piping hot!), but the food was so-so. everything was well( perhaps too well and too salty)-seasoned and greasy, pretty much what you expect from most korean fare. positives of the meal - we ate in a garage, there's a doorbell to indicate you're ready, and we didn't get kicked out for hogging two tables for a couple hours due to our catch-up, stimulating conversation. negatives - nothing to write home about, $13 per person (just the right amount for the amount of food ordered, perhaps even a bit cheaper than expected), the level of spice for indicated spicy dishes was very tame, and the night ended too early (not a dinger against the restaurant here).
author: Danny C.

description: I've been craving my moms kimchi fried rice and even after a trip to LA this place was surprisingly the closest! The service isn't spectacular...but that is expected from a Korean place...
author: Christina K.

description: I have always liked this place for drinks and food on Saturday nights.  Love their soju (esp. strawberry flavored soju) and their chicken wings and calamari!!  Service was okay and the waitress wasn't too attentive.  Me and my friends were late for 5 minutes and the waitress actually called and said I should have called her and let her know we would be late...arghhh.  Will still go there because of the soju and the food.
author: Josie K W.

description: I really dig the garage theme....its so gritty and grimey, like true hip-hop.  This place is great for later night gatherings or to hide from the cold outer sunset temp and fog.  The dishes are yummy but be wary of the prices for the amount of food you get.  Service is awesome too as the waitresses are so attentive.  I love the buttons to press when you need assistance....this place is special!
author: Mark B.

description:
now i know where to go late a night when im in the sunset and hungry. i really liked this place. 

it looks like a garage from the outside. i always forget the actual name, i always referred it as "the garage" and people know what im talkign about. 

it's not the biggest. so it does get crowed. but you can make reservations if you ave a bigger group. 

the food was really good. the sticky rice cakes / dukbokki are delicious! and there's a variety of flavored soju. we tried the pineapple, peach, and strawberry, yogurt. i liked the peach a lot! but i also heard the lemon [lemonade like] tasted really good.
author: Natalie B.

description:
When my friend recommended this place saying it was in a garage, I had pictured something weird like a table in someone's garage and a hot plate set up ready to make your food.  While on the outside it does resemble someone's house garage, the inside seriously throws you off.  If I wasn't told about the place, I never would've guessed it was a restaurant.

The food here was actually pretty good.  I didn't get a chance to try the soju cocktails since the friends I were with weren't of age yet, but I am tempted to try it next time.  The downside was that for us, it seemed like the waitresses were intentionally ignoring us.  After maybe 30 minutes of finishing eating, no one came to take our plates or bring us our check.  We even had to get up to ask for our check.  If it wasn't for those aspects of the service, I would have no problems giving them four stars.
author: Joel J.

description:
This place is truly a rare find.  A friend took me here once and it was challenging to find the place again the second time.  It is in the residential area within the Sunset district, away from the clusters of shops along Noriega.  The owner must've converted the garage of his house, put tables and chairs along this really narrow room, and install tiny bells on each table that you can press for service.

The food was awesome - you wouldn't find the usual bulgogi / galbi / soon tofu here.  My Korean friend told me that this is a korean 'bar', instead of a korean 'restaurant' (hence they serve different kinds of food O_O).  I always order the 'everything soup' (bu te ji ge), being a spicy stew filled with spam, sausage, pork, cabbage and egg noodles, served in metal pot (enough for 3 people).  Last time I went there we also ordered deep fried chicken wing - which is also great.  

This place opens super late... I think it closes at 2AM every day.  Definitely a good place for a late-night snack (and alcohol).  I would suggest coming in during weeknights... it gets super busy on Friday and Saturday nights and waiting in front of the restaurant (due to lack of space inside) is never fun.
author: Ange L.

description: Awesome Late night place in the outer sunset.  It actually looks like a garage at night.  We had some fried chicken as well at a hot soup with fish.  We also had Bek Se Ju to drink which is a Korean rice wine like Sake with herbs in it, real good.  I really need to go back here to try more stuff.  I wish it was closer though :)
author: Mitch A.

description: This is definitely a cool spot to go drink and have some good food with friends. The restaurant is made to look like a renovated garage. There is dimly lit walls with buzzers to call the servers to your table which is very unique from any other Korean restaurant. They do a pretty decent job at waiting on their customers on hand and foot. I love coming here to unwind after a long, strenuous project and have a good time with friends. I like there spicy fried chicken wings, tofu with pork and kimchi fried rice. Another thing that's great about Toyose is it is open until 2 am all week.
author: Miggy T.

description: This is what we nicknamed " chamsae" thanks to my korean friend keemchee...i was introduced to this hole in the wall..literally, but the food is really awesome though!! i dont really know the names of the dish but in brief description, the spicy chicken wings is A++++, that rice cake dish? A+++++++, onion and seafood cake? A++, & DUN DUN DUN....THE RED SOUP WITH SPAM TOFU FISH CAKES..AND RAMEN IS SOOOOO GOOD!! i havent been there in a while,but this is our regular spot.....a "little bird" told me this place is yummmyy!!! TOYOSE!! fyi that means little bird!! hehehe :)
author: Lynners C.

description:
fried chicken...
kimchee fried rice...
yogurt soju...
at 1am in your pjs...

enough said*
author: Scarlet S.

description: nice little spot for late dinner only catch is there is a long wait at times
author: mister f.

description:
I would have given this place  no stars at all but sadly this is not an option when rating restaurants on yelp. so my primary complaint stems from the fact that my girlfriend and I were refused service because according to the hostess our party was too small, and required at least 4 persons minimum. I did not feel this was fair considering a few couples were waiting for a table when we arrived. Just to verify this was the actual protocol for Toyose my girlfriend called them when we arrived home. and asked if they could accommodate a party of two? "Yes" we were told, they even said they could hurry us in if we got there soon. She then asked to speak to a manger. who ever had answered the pone claimed to be so, after relaying the story to them the person on the other end of the phone said I had lied to my girlfriend and that she had in fact offered us a place in line for seating. I am still not completely sure why they refused us service or to admit to their lies, but as soon as we walked in the door 
 the vibe was similar to (as the late comedian and prophet Bill Hicks put it)" walking into the middle of a Klan rally dressed in a Boy George outfit".
to put it lightly.
 It is just whimsical thinking to suppose the restaurants of San Francisco have done away with segregation.
author: john e.

description:
02.08.11 with 6 others. ordered chicken wings, fishcake casserole, onion pancakes, fried rice, seafood clay pot, calamari, and soju

1 star for the good food! 
1 star for the atmosphere, its a small place, but quiet enough to hear each other talk.
1 star for the service (there is a button at every table to call the waiter over)
1 star for the soju! so yummy! but very light on the alcohol. 
 
place looks like a house, enter through the garage door. 
small place, not good for large groups.
author: Jay R.

description: This place was definitely a HOLE IN THE WALL. I liked the homey decor inside with bamboo blinds separating each dining party. Been here twice and the food is totally awesome especially the seafood pancake and their boiling spicy tofu soups. However, the service is not as desirable. Most korean restaurants readily serve you their appetizers but it seems like our waitress totally forgot so remember to ask for those to kickstart your dinner :)
author: Topazskye L.

description:
This is a great korean restaurant.  It's just a great place to eat and drink with friends. 

We ordered 4 items here: the spicy casserole, kim chi bo keum bop, korean pancake thing (forget the name) and 2 sojus.  It was more than enough food and just felt like home cooking.  It should because the place felt like a home.  It was a home!  The garage was converted into a kitchen and the restaurant was a small passage-way basically that had about 8 tables of 4.  It's a really small place and I recommend making reservations.

About the food, everything was really good and the service is fast.  We started off with the kim chi fried rice which was really good.  It wasn't a lot of food split 4 ways but it was a good starter.  Next, the pancake and spicy casserole came out.  The casserole was basically a pot of spicy broth and a bunch of meat, tofu and vegetables.  Very homey.  I liked it a lot and would definitely go back.  To top it off, we ordered two bottles of soju, a yogurt and a strawberry flavored one.  The soju here is pretty good.

This is a great place to eat and drink with a small group of friends.  We celebrated a little bit last night and it was really fun.
author: Scott L.

description: For all you korean food lovers, this is the place to be. It's a nice small place in a garage serving korean food and soju and beer.  When I went to dinner with a friend, we waited for the waitress for quite awhile..had to ring the bell at the table twice before she came over. We ordered the baby octopus and vegetable in spicy sauce with noodles, fried chicken wings, and a large pineapple soju. Everything was yummy and spicy too! If you want to try soju but with less of the alcohol taste, you should definitely try the pineapple one. Overall, dinner was great and service was poor.
author: Rhonda H.

description: This is definately unlike any restaurant I've been to here in the city.  It's apparently a small neighborhood joint.  Everyone knows everyone that comes here.  The strange thing about this restaurnat is the interior and name of the restaurant.  The interior is of an old japanese fisherman's village.  The name "Toyose" is also Japanese.  I'm thinking that this restaurant was once a Japanese restaurant owned by a native Japanese  or the restaurant is owned by a Korean who grew up in Japan.  Aside from that, the food was quite tasty.  The only turn-off, cigarette smoke trailing into the non-smoking section.  I think I need to go to this place one more time to make a better judgement of it.
author: Mellie P.

description: food is not as good as Han il Kwan.  atmosphere is very good.  solid 3-star restaurant.
author: Wats C.

description:
Here's a black guys review. 

After hearing many positives about Toyose, I decided to order for pickup. I ordered the Kimchi fried rice with shrimp and their spicy chicken wings. Upon arrival, I was surprised to see how nice it was on the inside considering the front is just the typical garage door. However, it was packed! I mean there were people waiting outside to get seated. 

The waitress was friendly, and she is good looking too. With all that said, can you guess how much the order cost me? No, not $15. Nope! not $20. You guessed it...$28. Now, I don't mind paying up if I'm getting my money's worth. However, I didn't. Their Kimchi fried rice was just okay with a bitter aftertaste to it which i don't like. Their chicken wings was okay; it was crunchy and soft on the inside, but I've had better. 

Overall, this is a great place to take a date if you're the college type and in your 20's. Moreover, you won't be disappointed by the meal, but you won't be thrilled either. However, you must be prepared to spend some money. A dinner for two should run you close to $80 or more. 

Pros: 
Great atmosphere for a hole in the wall.
Friendly staff.
Young crowd.
Very intimate. Ideal for a first date.
Good menu and food is okay.
Opens late.
Bar right across the street!

Cons:
Overrated!!
Expensive for the college student on a budget.
It's small.
Not ideal for older folks.
Not ideal for take out.
author: Akinyemi O.

description: This place is so illegal. A Korean restaurant in a garage that allows a lot of underage drinking? Food there was pretty good but overpriced. Only place in the city that I know of that serves budaechigae (unfortunately no spam, but they have hot dogs!).
author: Rod M.

description:
I have eaten here twice now and it is consistently delicious and PACKED!!! From the street it didn't look busy (actually like a garage), but as soon as I opened the door...BAM...big ol' line! We put our name down and they said they would call us when our table was ready. We went to another restaurant to eat while we were waiting and they called us twice!!! We couldn't believe it! In addition, when we got back to Toyose, they accidentally sat another party at our table and they actually had the other party get up to let us sit there instead!!! This is service that you don't get ANYWHERE else!

Ok, now to the good stuff, the food is great! The kimchi fried rice is fantastic! The fried chicken wings are delicious! I love the cold buckwheat noodle soup! Accidentally, I ordered the cold noodles (not in soup) and a gargantuan plate of noodles along with assorted veggies, egg, meat, and apple came out topped with the red spicy sauce. The mix of everything together is oh so good and it is going to take me probably 3 days to finish off the leftovers! Add the yogurt soju, excellent dinner!!!

Overall, probably hands my favorite Korean restaurant in the city! Great service and excellent food!
author: Matt K.

description: inconspicuously tucked in a garage, this is a great place for drinking and eating Korean-style!  the food is authentic, goes beyond the typical korean menu to include lots of tasty Korean-style dishes to go along with your beer and soju, and everything is really flavorful.  it's an extensive menu, and the setting is great for groups.
author: lois j.

description: five stars for the yogurt and strawberry soju, three stars for the food. if you must get food, I recommend the split eel dish with rice on the side!
author: L W.

description:
i like this place alot because its out of no where. i didnt even know about it until a friend told me. i like to try new places so i decided to go. when i went inside yes its a bit small. but it has a really home feeling. it feels like i am in korea. but i am not. 

service is good. all the waitress's have great smiles except this one she always wear black and she has black tip finger nails. i got kindof mad one time cause she called my friend a basterd in korean, its what i get for watching korean movies. 

the food is pricey like all korean food. i dont know why? i think its just that theirs so many chinese food restaurants and the prices why pay more for kimchi and rice right? wrong great place. if you want to go drink. you can also smoke in there. but it only applies at night. for some odd reason. i recommend going early. or going a little later. because the place gets packed. maximum you can probably fit only 40 people in there. 

if you didnt realize most of the food in the place is mainly for drinking. like popcorn with beer or pretzels. my favorite is the tofu with kimchi and pork. real bomb with HITE or OB when the kimchi gets spicy drink some hite and it goes away. 

what my korean boy told me was toyose it means to drop in eat and leave. something like that. so keep that in mind.
author: Nicholas Y.

description: My friends and i went here on a monday night and believe me you would definitely want to make reservations before you come here. it's a really small restaurant with no more than 12 tables and very narrow walking space. i think you can say that this place can pass as a crack in the wall that serves good food. the kimchi fried rice is really awesome. the flavor of hot and spicy mix really well with alcohol. =) the soju is to die for. i think we ordered about 6 bottle of soju and one liter of beer. one botlle of soju can go for 10 shots. i would suggest the pineapple soju. you can taste more of the pineapple than the alcohol. there is a really cool feature that they have when you want to get the waitress. there is a button on the wall that you can press and will ring to get their attention.
author: Lynn P.

description:
to the owners: 

please put up a freakin' menu somewhere on the internet so i can pre-order food to stuff my fat-$#& face with!  sh*&@!  seriously, it's been forever.   thank you.
author: Darren H.

description: Good Korean bar food in a wacky atmosphere...it's the Korean bar at the end of the universe =)  If you know what Korean bar food is, then you'll like it better than if you think it's a Korean restaurant.  The fried chicken is good (at least it's the authentic style, even if not executed perfectly) and the soju works.  If you get liquored up you might forget and think you're in Seoul.  Had a couple of pleasant experiences with friends here, stumble outside into a sea of fog by the ocean...
author: Patrick Z.

description: This place is literally a garage! the food is just decent but i could see how this place would be a hit for drinking. I like how it is in true Korean style
author: Rosa K.

description: They have very oil kimchee fried rice.  Their seafood pancake is too doughy with too much flour.  I hate oily food.
author: Yelper Y.

description: My first time coming here and there food isn't bad.  Peach and yogurt soju were good too.  I also tried strawberry, but didn't like it as much as peach and yogurt.
author: YELP U.

description: kim chee fried rice and spicy chicken wings hit the spot at 12:30 midnight.  the place is small and the wait is long, but the food is really good.
author: My N.

description: Totally not traditional Korean cuisine.  The kimchee fried rice was okay, not as great as people have written about.  Wings were okay as well.  If you want something similar to Korean and are in the area, try it out, otherwise, I suggest you go to Hanuri BBQ or Brother's.
author: Cathy W.

description: a fan of their kimchi fried rice and spam and sausage casserole... soju is delicious... can get pretty crowded after 8pm and groups larger than 6 is kinda tough to accomodate....
author: Chan T.

description: A couple of friends and I felt those hunger pains at 11ish. What's open at that time? Korean of course! Enter Toyose. There was a 15 minute wait. Once sat two menu items were telling me to "pick me! pick me!" So, we chose Kim Chee fried rice and Kim Chee pancake. Those two dishes had me getting all ghetto selfish and claiming the last scoops for myself. As a Filipino, I'm used to leaving the last portion of any shared dish. To take it meant that you were selfish. I could have cared less for any culture etiquette of my upbringing. I want it all. The fried rice alone was swallowed (did I even chew?) so quick that we had to order a second batch. The pancake was so ono (a.k.a. hella good). The sauce for the pancake was done just right. Oh, and I heart Strawberry Soju. I'm definitely going back again. Too bad they aren't open till 4am cuz I would be flip flopping between this and Filipino food after a long night of whatever.
author: Heizel M.

description: i think the food is a bit expensive but isn't all korean food? when you walk in... its a little tiny garage. you'd think its literally in a garage... i'm like... can  I change my oil in this place as well? but clever utilization of space... the portions are a bit large.. my eyes were bigger than my stomach when we ordered. we had 3 plates of food for two people... way too much. order plate by plate if you can. had the seafood pancake, chap jae and the bulgogi ... great stuff.. just order wisely.
author: Darren C.

description: OK, if we're just talking about the food, I would only rate this restaurant a 3, compared to other great Korean restaurants in the City.  On the other hand, where else can you go to in the Sunset (or any neighborhood in San Francisco for that matter) with this kind of atmosphere, a great selection of soju, and decent food, that stays open until 2:00am 7 nights a week?  Based on the big picture, I'll have to give this restaurant a 5 because it is so unique.
author: Robert C.

description: Known as "The Garage" and I finally understand why! The wait is my only issue with this place. Other than that, the food and the services are great! My favorites are the chicken wings, Kim Chi fried rice, chicken gizzard, and the spicy squid noodles. Of course, you must try their different favors of Soju as well. Yogurt and strawberry are my recommendations!
author: Maggie L.

description:
to all you mad korean soju lovers, check this out! oh, and i insist you read my next review because its a place that just simply sucks ass...

***

it would've been 4.5 but i bumped it to 5 only because it gave me that comfort of feeling as if i was back in LA... 

HAHAHAHHAHAH... who would've thought? a drinking place in disguise of a freakin garage? i dont know if i should love this place or not.. for you LA folks, kinda has that dansungsa feel, but i'm telling ya, it's inside this darn garage ... hahhaha ... 

can't get any more korean than this... the decor and vibe is pretty much like a tiki bar ... felt right at home ... come one, come all, and let's all get drunk off our arse, having multiple shots of soju, shall we? i could probably see myself coming in here often when and only i need to get that korean drinkin fix, but sadly, i'm not a hardcore alki-holic. place gets hecka loud, like any old drinking place, and it's not only filled with koreans, it's pretty much whoever and wherever ... 

i can't help but to be shocked to see how some kimchi fried rice is almost $11. are you kidding? but yea, it was pretty good, but not $11 good ... can't be no more than $6 at most.. i bet i can make it better too ... just get in line, grab a number, and ill make you JEN'S KIMCHI FRIED RICE ... delivery charge is extra too... AND my KIMCHI is authentic as it can get, since my mommy made it ... 

the great part of this place is (can't help to be biased) there ain't no asian gangsters protectin their turf inside toyose, or am i just being blind???  and parking isn't that bad ... 

a true gem in sf, since this is the land of cantos ... no need to drive all the way to santa clara ... just hop in your car and drive over to the outer sunset..
author: Jennifer S.

description:
one of the best korean bar food places in SF.  the wings are amazing. so is the lahbuki and yogurt soju.

not sure what's up with the new name, so it will always be 'chamseh' in my mind. good times!
author: Terri L.

description: The service, food, and ambiance was awesome.   There's a button that you can press for prompt service.   Its in a garage but once you step in your in a whole new world.  I guess that's the appeal of this restaurant as well.   The soju is exceptional here(my favorite was the strawberry soju).   Perfect place to get with friends and a date to let loose and eat good food.
author: Mike J.

description: pretty good food.  i like their chicken wings. and just about anything else on the menu.  it looks like youre in the hull of a pirate ship. kinda strange but it works
author: Dan T.

description: This place was actually nicer than I expected - well, all I really expected was a sheet-rocked garage with a couple of tables. Finally came here with a friend who'd been many times before but he was no help when it came to ordering. Maybe cause he wasn't Korean, or maybe cause he was drunk all the times he's been here and couldn't remember the signature dishes.  Came here on a Thursday night around midnight- the crowd was young and drunk and apparently one girl yacked right next to our table.  I didn't see it, but we sure smelled it -blech.  We had the kimchee fried rice and a fish liver tofu stew (eh- I think I envisioned a richer ankimo type of liver) and a "picher" of OB. Considering this is a converted garage and the panchan offering is a bowl of popcorn, I didn't think it was all that great for $50.  I'll probably try it again with more friends (i love being with my friends, but I really love em when it means I can try more dishes!)
author: Amina B.

description: I came here with a good friend of mine and she forewarned me that it was in a garage. I didn't understand what she meant by it, but when we approached the restaurant I almost passed right by it. It looked like a garage...lol. When we entered the restaurant I was impressed by the transformation, it was cozy and had the quaint restaurant feel. The place wasn't packed, but there were 2 large parties when we entered. We were seated right away...it was great! As we looked through the menu I was surprised at all the different selections of food. I am the type though that looks at what everyone else has on their table, I noticed that there was a lot of hot pots which looked yummy. My friend had been there before, so I left her the honors of ordering. (I'm so glad I did) We ordered the Bulgogi, Kimchee Fried Rice and the Seafood Pancake. We also had the Yogurt Soju. EVERYTHING was sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo freakin good! I was just bouncing up and down and nodding my head the entire time while eating (that translates to...I AM LOVING THE FOOD) The service was fast and they were definitely on top of their game that night. It looked like only 2 people were working that night and with the large parties, they were still very attentive. I did notice that there was a doorbell looking thing near our seating area, which I thought was odd...but after reading the other review I guess you use it when you need help. WELL...we didn't have to use it at all. I had such a great time there and I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: I LOVE ME SOME G.

description: Great spot for flavored soju (yogurt!!), kimchi fried rice, and kimchi pancakes.  A quaint setting with "seaside" decor tucked away in the basement of a Sunset "residence".  Toyose houses a young crowd, most of whom will appreciate their 2am closing at one point or another.
author: Jon F.

description: i was really reluctant to come here, first off because it was cinco de mayo and i wanted to get some burritos... well majority ruled and i had to eat at "the garage" or so my friends called it... and voila! it is in a garage!!! hahaha i totally did not expect it... upon walking in, it was a whole new atmosphere the interior decor is nice and nothing garagey like.. the food was good.. but a little on the pricey side.. it came out to 20 dollars a person.. we had spam and hot dogs and ramen? i mean i could have made that at home myself!!
author: JUDY L.

description: great soju (especially strawberry), great creepy location factor (in someone's converted basement), great seafood pancake.  however, they lack the little appetizers most other korean restaurants serve and for some reason, it's incredibly hard to get rice served with your meal (every time we've been there the waitress brings it 10 min after all the other food has been dropped off at the table), and i'd love it if they served soon dubu.
author: Beth H.

description: ahh , ive been going here for soo long it deserves 5 stars, have to try: fried chicken wings, seafood pan cake, kimchi fried rice. prepare to run into people you know here
author: Wei W.

description: i went there with all of my korean friends and it was really great. 'Bokyung', the waitress was really nice to us. everything was really nice. only thing i dont like about the restaurant is the location. but still .. its great
author: Eunsoo J.

description: Kids, get the passports cause we're going to Korea.... well, it feels like it having to get out to the extreme Outer Sunset to get to Toyose... the converted garage that now just looks like a garage door with xmas lights up front and the parrot to welcome you in.  Once inside, you quickly notice that.... well, it's mainly Koreans comfortably burrowed into the table area... (those up to no-good will have their table 'shade' down).  But what a bit of Korean heaven this place is... anju...dried cuttlefish, 'rah-bok-kee', and yes, if you are curious, the wonderfully sliced and presented fruit plate. Crown Royale might not be the drink of choice, but choose a fruity-soju drink and watch as your friends declare... "This tastes like nothing" and then get ripped off their @$$e$.  Chase it down with the beer-flavored water they call Hite or OB Lager and you've got the makings of a good night.  Don't forget to get your passport stamped as you head back to the US!!
author: Dale K.

description: This place is truly...MEH.  Interesting to eat in a converted garage, but the service we received was horrible.  The waitress gave us like 3 menus for 11 people.  It took us another 10 minutes to try to get more menus, and she was extremely rude about it.  We had to ask a bunch of times for water, utensils, and for the check.  Every time we tried to get her attention, we were pretty much ignored.  People were saying how cool those doorbell buzzer things were...yeah I guess they were cool for decoration, but they don't get the server to come over to you, so what's the point?  Oh yeah, did I mention, they cramped 11 people around a tiny table in the middle of a walkway instead of giving us two tables where we could have fit 5 and 6 comfortably?  Whatever.  Anyway...food.  Edible, but not that great.  Did I also mention that after waiting a good 20 minutes to order, half of our food was forgotten?  I digress.  The fried chicken was ok, my pinky noodles (rice cakes) and ramen weren't even that spicy...it reminded me of eating spaghetti-o's with siracha added.  Plus, the eggs weren't poached eggs, they were hardboiled...and I paid an extra $3 for them!  Mediocre food, horrible service.  Only a cool spot if I was drunk and craving more soju and korean snacks at 1AM.
author: Cheryl L.

description: This is kind of a secret place for Korean.  Toyose (aka Chamsae) is a great example of Korean style bar.  They have great "Anju" side dishes when drinking and variety selections of Korean Soju.  It is a little funky because you have to go through the garage.  You will get the full effect of Korean bar culture.  Bottoms up!
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: Call ahead for a reservation, tried to go w/o one last week and there was a 2 hour wait @ midnight.   For 4 the perfect meal was the whole fried chicken (little dry, as bf pointed out, but other companion and i felt was decent/ good, but all together tasty) and the kimchee fried rice (soooo good, spicy served with a fried egg and nori on top..mmmmmm).  Between OB and Hite (the 2 Korean beers they serve) I'd go hite all the way next time.  OB is pretty watery, like miller light, hite has more flavor. The 'pitcher' is really a 1.5 liter plastic bottle that serves a party of four light drinkers well.  We, on the other hand had a party of 3 and had 2 ob pitchers and a 'bottle' (22oz.) of hite plus 2 bottle of soju,  and the chicken and kimchee rice coming to $85, which i think is pretty decent for beer, alcohol and dinner for 3.  Cheap bastards of the naan and curry variety need not apply.  Anything is expensive to people who won't pay more than $3 for curry.  Call ahead, request a booth, drop the bamboo shade, and bring your dominoes.
author: Emily X.

description: a restaurant made out of garage! that clever.. inside is nice.. service is slow since only one waitress.. younger waitress is nicer the older one is a bitch.. Must try their kim chi fried rice.. spicy n delicious.. Most people go there for soju ( fruited alcohol)... that place gets u fucked up.. my fren haRry L. yucked on himself.. then he pasSEd out
author: Lily T.

description: food is good here.  soju is good too.  good place to get wasted, that is if you can get seated on a fri/sat night
author: A L.

description: totally disappointed.    Everything is just overpriced.   think about it.   if you consider the ingredients that used for the dishes and labor fee for the quality of the foods that the restaurant serves, you'll notice that  price are totally unfair.    I don't really understand why many people come to the restaurant enven though there is still plenty of good korean restaurants in SF.
author: mike t.

description: fried chicken wings and soju.  those are 2 musts when you come here.  their drink selection is pretty good.  this tiny garage converted into a beach-like atmosphere is a perfect place to hang out with friends.
author: Big e.

description: This place is great.  First of all, it's in a garage, which I've never seen before (once you get inside, you would have no idea), and second, they have delicious blended-fruit soju.  I also like the food, but you can probably find better korean food elsewhere.  The ambiance is great because the tables are really well separated.  The only downside is the service is slow because they only have one waitress, but I keep coming back anyway, so still I give it 5 stars.
author: Mark F.

description: 1:30 in the morning in the Sunset and a craving to feast on some fried chicken pops up...where the hell do I go?!?!!?  KFC genetic modified poultry?  nooo they've closed a few hours ago!  let me search yelp!  Toyose pops up and it's only a few blocks away!  Reading reviews...oh look, the korean fried chicken is good.  Put in an order for korean fried chicken plus kimchi fried rice.  10 minutes later i'm picking up the food.  The cool thing is that Toyose is built where the garage should be, but total restaurant feel once you get in.  Individual booths.  Seems like a cool place to take your drinking buddy.  The bill was a little steep, $25 for chicken and korean fried rice, but when your fiending for food at this hour of night it's kinda worth it...supply and demand people!  The next time I visit will probably be with a drinking buddy just to hang out.  BTW the food was tasty...it hit the spot...and the pickled daikon was great!
author: LittleBird 8.
